Red Cross.lead_paragraph: A man who claimed two wives -- Kim and Lisa -- were missing and presumed dead after the Sept. 11 attack has pleaded guilty to stealing more than $70,000 in relief funds. The man, Mark Christopher, pleaded guilty this week to charges of theft by deception, identity theft and falsifying records. Mr. Christopher, who will be sentenced on Nov. 7, faces a maximum prison sentence of 20 years. According to the State Division of Criminal Justice, Mr. Christopher told the American Red Cross on Nov. 14, 2001, that his wife, Kim Christopher, was working in the World Trade Center during the attack. He documented his claim with a Maryland marriage license that had been issued to someone else, the State Division of Criminal Justice said. Using the pseudonym of Mark Palmerri, he also reported another wife, Lisa Palmerri, missing in applications between Sept. 11, 2001, and Jan. 9, 2002, to the Red Cross and the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Stacy Albin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Plea By Man With 2 'Wives'

Red Cross.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Plea By Man With 2 'Wives'

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: The American Red Cross has tentatively agreed to participate in the creation of a central database that would keep track of how donations raised in the aftermath of Sept. 11 are distributed to victims' families. The agreement, announced last night by Eliot L. Spitzer, the New York State attorney general, represents an important step in the effort to coordinate the distribution of more than $1 billion in charity. It also marks a major policy reversal for the Red Cross, the nation's largest disaster relief organization and the recipient of $505 million in donations since the attacks.

headline.main: Red Cross Agrees to Database

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: Aid workers in Kandahar, Afghanistan, have buried a man originally identified by the Taliban as an American, the International Committee of the Red Cross said today. Citing privacy concerns, Red Cross officials here would not identify the man or release his nationality, saying only that he was not an Afghan or an American.

headline.main: Taliban's Dead Man Wasn't From U.S.

Red Cross.mainheadline: Taliban's Dead Man Wasn't From U.S.

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: Despite a surge in blood donations after the World Trade Center attack, the New York Blood Center, a nonprofit collection and distribution agency, is making an emergency appeal for blood and platelet donors. Because of a misperception that donation centers had more blood than they needed, donations since November have been far lower than normal, according to the center. Center officials project that by next week there will be less than a one-day supply of O-negative blood, the type that can be used by any patient in case of an emergency. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Center Reports Blood Shortage

Red Cross.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Center Reports Blood Shortage

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: In an ambitious effort to address the emotional needs of disaster victims, two charities agreed to underwrite extended mental health treatment for people directly affected by last year's terrorist attacks. About 150,000 families meet the eligibility requirements set by the American Red Cross and the September 11th Fund, including relatives of people killed in the World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks, people injured in those attacks, rescue workers and displaced residents.

headline.main: August 18-24: NATIONAL; 9/11 MENTAL HEALTH AID

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: A Manhattan woman was charged yesterday with fraud, accused of filing false papers indicating that her father had been missing since the attack on the World Trade Center and receiving $75,000 from a relief fund established by the American Red Cross. The police said the woman, Rosalba Wild, 50, of 435 East 79th Street, was arrested at 8 a.m. and charged with grand larceny. The arrest followed dozens of others in recent months in which people have been charged with various schemes to defraud charities and government agencies working in Sept. 11 disaster relief. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Charged With 9/11 Fraud

Red Cross.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Charged With 9/11 Fraud

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday officially reopened the Marriott Financial Center hotel, which had been used as a Red Cross center for workers at ground zero since the Sept. 11 terror attack. The 504-room hotel at 85 West Street, a few blocks south of ground zero, suffered extensive water damage from fire hoses after the attack but has since been repaired. ''I want everyone to understand that New York is safe, it's clean and it's open for business,'' Mr. Bloomberg said. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hotel Reopens Near Ground Zero

Red Cross.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hotel Reopens Near Ground Zero

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: Fifth Avenue and Times Square were nearly silent; it was time for Scrooge and sleigh bells and the peace of long ago.

headline.seo: Christmas Morning Brings Rare Serenity to N.Y.C.
headline.main: With Christmas Morning, the Rare Serenity of Long Ago
headline.print_headline: With Christmas Morning, the Rare Serenity of Long Ago

Red Cross.mainheadline: With Christmas Morning, the Rare Serenity of Long Ago

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: For the second consecutive start and the third time in his last five, A. J. Burnett was nothing short of terrible as the Orioles pounded the Yankees in front of a crowd of 32,762 at Camden Yards.

headline.main: One Lost Day Follows Another
headline.print_headline: One Lost Day Follows Another

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: Just four days after 9/11, James P. Stuckey, then a vice president of Forest City Ratner Companies, met with executives of Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield at Forest City's headquarters in Brooklyn. Empire had been the fourth-largest tenant at the World Trade Center, and the shell-shocked executives were already thinking about new offices. Mr. Stuckey promised them a building in 18 months, even though, he said, ''they didn't have any floor plans, they didn't know who had sat next to who, or even where much of their staff was.''

headline.main: Born of 9/11, an Effort to Rebuild Shattered Haiti

Red Cross.mainheadline: Born of 9/11, an Effort to Rebuild Shattered Haiti

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: Two men face possible life sentences in a plan to detonate fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport and set off cascading explosions along a fuel pipeline.

headline.seo: Trial Is Set to Start in Plot to Bomb Kennedy Airport
headline.main: 3 Years Later, Trial to Start in J.F.K. Bomb Plot
headline.print_headline: 3 Years Later, Trial Is Set to Start in a Plot to Use Fuel Tanks to Bomb Kennedy Airport

Red Cross.mainheadline: 3 Years Later, Trial to Start in J.F.K. Bomb Plot

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: In New York’s latest religious battle, a group protested the Empire State Building’s rejection of a request for blue-and-white lighting in honor of Mother Teresa.

headline.seo: At Empire State, a Call to Arms for Mother Teresa
headline.main: In the Latest Religious Battle, a Call to Arms for Mother Teresa
headline.print_headline: In the Latest Religious Battle, a Call to Arms for Mother Teresa

Red Cross.mainheadline: In the Latest Religious Battle, a Call to Arms for Mother Teresa

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg opened an emergency operations center yesterday to replace the one in 7 World Trade Center that was destroyed on 9/11. Creating the center, at 165 Cadman Plaza East, involved a $50 million federally financed renovation of a building once used by the American Red Cross. The four-story, 65,000-square-foot building, which will serve as the headquarters of the Office of Emergency Management, has a center for representatives of 130 agencies who will gather during emergencies; a press briefing room; and conference rooms. The building was designed to be environmentally sensitive, with columns and floors reused from the old building, heat-reflecting roof tiles and water-saving bathroom fixtures. SEWELL CHAN

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Emergency Command Center Opened

Red Cross.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Emergency Command Center Opened

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: In New Orleans and the coastal flood plains of Mississippi, many people are complaining that the American Red Cross was missing in their worst hours of need and are worried that its billowing relief fund may bypass them entirely. The organization did not open shelters in flood-prone areas and was therefore unable to provide food and other necessities to people closest to the coast ravaged by Hurricane Katrina.

headline.main: As Its Coffers Swell, Red Cross Is Criticized On Gulf Coast Response

Red Cross.mainheadline: As Its Coffers Swell, Red Cross Is Criticized On Gulf Coast Response

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: An Iowa company that charged sharply higher gasoline prices at stations in Illinois after the terrorist attacks must give refunds to customers under a settlement reached with the Illinois attorney general, Jim Ryan. Mr. Ryan filed a lawsuit two weeks ago accusing the company, Casey's General Stores Inc., of charging customers as much as $5 a gallon. The company must also donate $25,000 to the American Red Cross and pay $5,000 to cover state legal expenses. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Gas Price Gouger To Pay Refunds

Red Cross.mainheadline: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Gas Price Gouger To Pay Refunds

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: A man who had already been accused of falsely claiming benefits for a fictitious wife who died in the World Trade Center attack was charged on Friday with making the same claim for a second invented spouse. Prosecutors say the man, Mark Christopher, 38, was not married but applied for more than $83,000 in survivors' aid from the Red Cross and the Federal Emergency Management Agency. He received about $72,000. Based on the indictment Friday, Mr. Christopher faces a maximum of 10 years in prison on charges of theft, identity theft and falsifying records. Mr. Christopher, of Sicklerville, N.J., was originally indicted in March after claiming that a wife, Lisa, died in the attack.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Ruse Charged In 9/11 Claim

Red Cross.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Ruse Charged In 9/11 Claim

Red Cross.lead_paragraph: A Missouri woman was indicted yesterday on federal charges that she concocted a story about having lost a younger brother in the World Trade Center disaster to collect more than $60,000 in financial aid from the American Red Cross and several other disaster-relief organizations. The 10-count indictment, announced by the United States attorney's office in Kansas City, Mo., charges that the woman, Cassaundrea Montgomery, 41, of St. Joseph, filed a false missing persons report with the New York Police Department regarding a 23-year-old brother, who the authorities say does not exist. She said that her brother, Jeffrey, had been in Lower Manhattan on Sept. 11 for a job interview with the financial services firm Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline.main: Woman Is Indicted In 9/11 Aid Fraud

Red Cross.mainheadline: Woman Is Indicted In 9/11 Aid Fraud

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The South Korean air carriers, Korean Air and Asiana Airlines, are to receive $191 million in loans under a special $1.5 billion budget. The plan also provides for rolling over about $300 million in bonds that were issued by Korean Air along with a request that Asiana's creditor banks, most of them owned by the government, extend nearly $200 million in new loans. In addition, the two airlines were exempted from paying about $11 million in taxes through 2002. The losses for the airlines as a result of declining business since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States were expected to total $400 million this year. Don Kirk (NYT)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airline Assistance

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airline Assistance

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Continental Airlines plans to raise about $151.7 million by selling common shares next week, giving the company more cash as it contends with a loss this quarter. The 6.74 million shares of Class B stock, expected to be issued Monday, will be priced at $22.50 each, the airline said. Continental, which has about 55.4 million Class B shares outstanding, plans to use the money for general corporate purposes. Stock in Continental, which is based in Houston, fell $2.40, to $21.70 a share.

headline.main: CONTINENTAL PLANS SHARE SALE TO RAISE MONEY

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: CONTINENTAL PLANS SHARE SALE TO RAISE MONEY

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: United Airlines will extend discounts for business travelers to March from December as it tries to win back customers after the Sept. 11 attacks. The company, the second-largest airline, is offering business travelers 50 percent off an unrestricted business fare, which requires a 21-day advance purchase, and 25 percent off a ticket bought 10 days in advance. The offer was extended to March 31 from Dec. 31, it said in a statement. The airline, owned by the UAL Corporation, is based in Chicago.

headline.main: DISCOUNTS FOR BUSINESS TRAVELERS TO BE EXTENDED

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: DISCOUNTS FOR BUSINESS TRAVELERS TO BE EXTENDED

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Spirit Airlines said today that it would not charge anyone for flying Sept. 11, the first anniversary of deadly terrorist attacks on the United States. The company said the offer was good for those booking flights by Sept. 8 through the airline's Web site or travel agents.

headline.main: No Charge to Fly Sept. 11

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: No Charge to Fly Sept. 11

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: European airlines must return to commercial insurers to cover the war and terror risks that have been guaranteed by governments since the Sept. 11 attacks, the European Commission said. A commission spokesman, Gilles Gantelet, said European states would no longer provide insurance guarantees after Oct. 31.

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Air Insurance Returning To Normal

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Air Insurance Returning To Normal

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Crew members aboard the Paris-to-Miami jet that stopped a man accused of carrying a bomb in his shoes admitted they made mistakes, including carrying the shoes into the cockpit. One crew member said that yanking the shoes off the feet of the suspect, Richard C. Reid, and bringing them into the American Airlines cockpit ''was the dumbest thing I ever did.''

headline.main: Crew Criticizes Airline's Training on Bomb Threats
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: SHOE BOMB CASE

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Crew Criticizes Airline's Training on Bomb Threats

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The operators of two farmers' markets that had been at the World Trade Center complex have sued the airlines and airport security companies for the loss of their business. The operators, Adem Arici and Omer Ipek, ran the World Trade Farmers Market at 130 Cedar Street and 2 World Trade Center. They filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan against American Airlines, United Airlines, Huntleigh, Huntleigh U.S.A. and Globe Airport Security Services yesterday. The suit accused them of negligence in allowing hijackers to board and take control of the planes that crashed into the towers, and are seeking at least $75,000 in damages. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Airport Security Firms Sued

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Airport Security Firms Sued

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Some pilots and flight attendants are criticizing airlines for not passing on to flight crews general warnings of terrorist threats that the federal government gave to the carriers before Sept. 11. But others say such vague warnings are useless and would have made little difference in the way they went about their daily routine. From last June to August, the Federal Aviation Administration issued 11 advisories to security directors in the airline industry, most of them of a general nature like ''American interests may be targeted by extremist groups.''

headline.main: Flight Crews' Reaction Mixed On a Lack of Pre-9/11 Alerts

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Flight Crews' Reaction Mixed On a Lack of Pre-9/11 Alerts

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Airlines are improperly withholding more than $20 million they owe Afghanistan, American officials said. The State Department has urged the International Air Transport Association to turn over the money, which airlines paid to fly over Afghanistan. The funds were collected under a contract with the Ministry of Civil Aviation and Tourism and delivered to the Taliban until United Nations sanctions were applied in 1999; after that, some payments were made under United Nations supervision, the last in August 2001. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

headline.main: Briefly Noted; AIRLINES' DEBTS

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Briefly Noted; AIRLINES' DEBTS

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Highway Patrol officers have begun carrying weapons on intrastate commercial flights to augment the federal air marshal program. A Highway Patrol spokesman said all 7,000 officers were ''trained to apply the law enforcement abilities they already have in a limited space at 35,000 feet.'' Airlines participating are Southwest, United and America West. Catherine Billey (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Highway Patrol In The Air

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: National Briefing | West: California: Highway Patrol In The Air

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Looking to lure a wide group of travelers, the cruise industry is offering everything from Broadway-style shows to Barbie-themed cabins.

headline.seo: Cruise Lines Serve a Growing Buffet of Options
headline.main: Is There Anything We Can’t Do on a Cruise?
headline.print_headline: The Buffet of Styles and Amenities Gets Bigger

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Is There Anything We Can’t Do on a Cruise?

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The US Airways Group Inc. said yesterday that it would resume daily nonstop flights between Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington and six destinations. Reagan Airport was closed by the Department of Transportation after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, and the agency allowed carriers to phase in service beginning in October when the airport reopened. US Airways said it would also offer online discount fares ranging from $112 to $160 for round-trip service to the six destinations. On Sunday, the carrier will begin service from Reagan Airport to Hartford; Huntsville, Ala.; New Orleans; Providence, R.I.; and Tampa and West Palm Beach, Fla.

headline.main: AIRLINE TO RESUME FLIGHTS FROM REAGAN NATIONAL

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: AIRLINE TO RESUME FLIGHTS FROM REAGAN NATIONAL

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The flag that flew over the United States Capitol on Sept. 11, 2001, was among several artifacts destroyed in a fire at the Flight 93 National Memorial in Shanksville, Pa.

headline.main: 9/11 Flag Is Destroyed in Fire at Memorial
headline.print_headline: 9/11 Flag Is Destroyed in Fire at Memorial

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: 9/11 Flag Is Destroyed in Fire at Memorial

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Here are the government's rankings of the leading airlines and their on-time performance for September. Some airlines, including Spirit and Allegiant, are not included because they operate fewer flights. The federal government counts a flight as on-time if it arrives within 14 minutes of schedule.

headline.main: Hawaiian Tops US Airlines at On-Time Arrivals
headline.print_headline: Hawaiian Tops US Airlines at On-Time Arrivals

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Hawaiian Tops US Airlines at On-Time Arrivals

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: As growing number of Chinese business travelers flock to the United States, major hotel brands are starting programs that cater to the needs and preferences of Chinese visitors.

headline.seo: American Hotels Embrace Chinese Business Travelers
headline.main: American Hotels Embrace Chinese Business Travelers
headline.print_headline: Embracing China

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: American Hotels Embrace Chinese Business Travelers

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The specter of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks hangs over the Royal Air Force operation at the Olympics, and the lessons learned from those attacks are central to its planning.

headline.seo: At Olympics, Royal Air Force on Terrorism Alert
headline.main: An Olympics Vigil, From 30,000 Feet
headline.print_headline: An Olympics Vigil, From 30,000 Feet
headline.content_kicker: Royal Air Force Station Northolt Journal

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: An Olympics Vigil, From 30,000 Feet

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The government announced a settlement on Friday with Continental Airlines over accusations that the airline discriminated after the Sept. 11 terror attacks against travelers believed to have been of Arab, Middle Eastern or Southeast Asian descent. The Transportation Department started getting complaints about Continental flights in the weeks after the attacks, a spokesman, Bill Mosley, said. Mr. Mosley said four passengers complained that they were removed from flights because of their ethnic background or national origin.

headline.main: U.S. and Airline Settle Bias Complaints

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: U.S. and Airline Settle Bias Complaints

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The government announced a settlement with Delta Air Lines over accusations that it discriminated after the Sept. 11 terror attacks against travelers believed to have been Muslim or of Arab, Middle Eastern or Southeast Asian descent. The Transportation Department said its investigation found that Delta had acted in a manner inconsistent with federal laws barring discrimination. Though Delta acknowledged no wrongdoing, it agreed to provide civil rights training over the next two years to its pilots, flight attendants and passenger service agents. This is the fourth such settlement for airlines stemming from the weeks after the attacks.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Delta Settles Bias Complaint

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: Delta Settles Bias Complaint

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Northwest Airlines said in a statement on Sunday evening that its chief executive and a spokesman were wrong last September when they denied that Northwest had provided the government with data on its passengers for security studies. The airline said the two men did not know that their company's security department had given the information to a NASA laboratory in the third quarter of 2001. After the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, researchers from the space agency were seeking to experiment with statistical techniques for identifying terrorists.

headline.main: Airline Addresses Data-Sharing Denials

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Airline Addresses Data-Sharing Denials

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The government has reached a settlement with American Airlines over complaints that after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the airline unlawfully removed passengers it thought were of Arab, Middle Eastern or Southeast Asian descent. The airline, a unit of the AMR Corporation, agreed to spend about $1.5 million over three years for civil rights training for employees who deal with the public. It did not admit that it broke federal antidiscrimination laws.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Settlement In Bias Case

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: Settlement In Bias Case

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: President Obama and his wife, Michelle, placed a large wreath at the memorial in Shanksville, Pennsylvania.

headline.main: In Pennsylvania, a Wall of Names
headline.print_headline: In a Pennsylvania Field, Memories of Loved Ones

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: In Pennsylvania, a Wall of Names

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Flush with success in building an increasingly high-profile airline industry, Middle East Gulf states now want to get into aerospace manufacturing too.

headline.main: From Nothing to a Global Hub for Aviation
headline.print_headline: From Nothing to a Global Hub for Aviaiton

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: From Nothing to a Global Hub for Aviation

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The federal government has little control over who gets behind the wheel of discount tour buses.

headline.seo: Lax Regulation of Discount Buses Is Cited After I-95 Crash
headline.main: Lax Rules for Discount Buses Cited After I-95 Crash
headline.print_headline: Lax Regulation of Discount Buses Is Cited After I-95 Crash

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Lax Rules for Discount Buses Cited After I-95 Crash

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The hotel lounge was once a simple affair, offering a television, perhaps, and a small buffet to its regular customers. But as business travel has started to pick up, and revenue along with it, a number of major hotel brands are once more turning to sprucing up their executive club lounges, making them more residential in feel and providing healthier food and improved technology like free Wi-Fi. ''The time is appropriate,'' said Bjorn Hanson, dean of the Preston Robert Tisch Center for Hospitality, Tourism and Sports Management at New York University. Upgrades were a priority from 2005 to 2007, but since then, many hotels have deferred investments, Mr. Hanson said. ''Frankly, some of these facilities need to be refurbished and redesigned.''

headline.main: Pampering Premium Customers

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Pampering Premium Customers

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: United Airlines could not have foreseen the events that led to the destruction of Tower 7, Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein ruled.

headline.seo: Judge Clears United Airlines in a 9/11 Collapse
headline.main: Judge Rules United Not Liable for 9/11 Collapse
headline.print_headline: Judge Rules United Not Liable for 9/11 Collapse

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Judge Rules United Not Liable for 9/11 Collapse

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: A group of airlines and public transportation agencies sued the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. yesterday, seeking permission to interview five special agents and two intelligence officers who may have knowledge helpful in their defense of wrongful death lawsuits arising from the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The lawsuit was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan by American, United, Continental, US Airways and Delta Air Lines, and the public agencies that run the airports in Boston and Washington, after the bureau and the agency refused to grant access. Richard Kolko, an F.B.I. spokesman, declined to discuss the suit. The C.I.A. press office did not return phone calls seeking comment yesterday.

headline.main: Manhattan: Airlines Seek Agents' Testimony

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Manhattan: Airlines Seek Agents' Testimony

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Ellen Saracini wants airlines to have to install a second security door to the cockpit, but the airline industry says that isn’t necessary.

headline.main: Widow of Sept. 11 Pilot Seeks More Cockpit Security
headline.print_headline: Widow of Sept. 11 Pilot Seeks More Cockpit Security

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Widow of Sept. 11 Pilot Seeks More Cockpit Security

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The office of the chief medical examiner said yesterday that it had matched the remains of three 9/11 victims with new and additional DNA samples provided by their families. Two were identified as Karen Ann Martin, 40, the head flight attendant on American Airlines Flight 11, which struck the north tower, and Douglas Joel Stone, 54, a passenger on the flight. The name of the third victim was not released, at his family's request. The newly identified remains were not among those discovered recently in a manhole near the World Trade Center site, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner. The remains of 1,601 of the 2,749 victims have now been identified. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More 9/11 Victims' Remains Identified

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More 9/11 Victims' Remains Identified

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Donations for the victims of Hurricane Katrina have come in at a blistering pace that exceeds that of other recent disasters, charities are saying. Almost all of the money is going to the American Red Cross, in large part because other international relief and development organizations simply do not have significant operations in the United States. Some groups, like Oxfam and Mercy Corps, are now reassessing their long-held assumption that the federal government is equipped to handle American crises and are taking steps to help as well.

headline.main: Charitable Giving Outpaces That From Other Disasters

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Charitable Giving Outpaces That From Other Disasters

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Fourteen hours elapsed between celebratory news conferences at the US Airways Center in Phoenix, and they told the story of the Suns' bumpy but still relevant season. Late Saturday night, the Suns exhaled after grinding through a taut seven-game series against the Los Angeles Lakers. Coach Mike D'Antoni praised his entire roster, from the guys who seemingly came out of nowhere (Leandro Barbosa, Boris Diaw) to the star who was always there whenever they needed him (Steve Nash).

headline.main: Road Is Tougher, but Nash and Suns Find Success Again

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Road Is Tougher, but Nash and Suns Find Success Again

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday the Airport 9/11 Memorial is to be unveiled at Logan International Airport in Boston, The Boston Globe reported. The memorial, which was designed by the local firm Moskow Architects and cost $3.5 million, is on a two-acre slip of land. It consists of two paths that wind up a wooded slope through 102 ginkgo trees to a glass cube sculpture called ''The Place of Remembrance.'' The cube contains the names of the 148 passengers and crew members aboard American Airlines Flight 11 and United Airlines Flight 175, the two planes that departed Logan and were flown into the World Trade Center towers. According to the Massachusetts Port Authority, the idea to create the memorial ''began with the airport's employees, who were seeking a way to honor those lost and a place to reflect on the events of 9/11.''

headline.main: Boston Airport Memorial

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Boston Airport Memorial

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Commercial airlines knew there was a risk that their jets could be hijacked, but should they have foreseen the possibility that hijackers would turn their aircraft into weapons of mass destruction? That question is at the heart of a proceeding in Federal District Court in Manhattan, where the families of more than 65 people who died in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, are suing American and United Airlines, whose planes struck the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, alleging negligence.

headline.main: Airlines Want 9/11 Lawsuits From Families Thrown Out

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: Airlines Want 9/11 Lawsuits From Families Thrown Out

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The Belgian airline Sabena may be knocked into bankruptcy by last week's attacks on the United States, the airline's chairman, Fred Chaffart, said. Mr. Chaffart said reservations were drying up and fuel, insurance and other costs were climbing fast. The airline, which has not made a profit in nearly two decades, is embroiled in a fight with its unions over a proposed $399 million bailout plan that calls for eliminating 1,600 jobs. Paul Meller (NYT)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: Sabena At The Edge

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: Sabena At The Edge

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Blizzard Leads Airlines To Relax Ticket Rules As airports shut one after another in yesterday's blizzard, airlines temporarily relaxed strict policies that penalize travelers with nonrefundable tickets who change their flight plans. Policies differ, and airline Web sites were updating information all day yesterday as the East Coast storm affected flights all over the country. American Airlines, for example, said that customers with reservations, for Sunday or yesterday, to or from cities hit by the storm could make one-time changes without penalty for alternate flights through Friday. Changes can be made through American's reservations office, (800) 433-7300.

headline.main: MEMO PAD

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: MEMO PAD

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: Investigators now theorize that a hijacker in the cockpit aboard United Airlines Flight 93 instructed the terrorist pilot to crash the jetliner into a Pennsylvania field because of a passenger uprising in the cabin. This theory, based on analysis of cockpit recordings, discounts the popular perception of passengers grappling with terrorists to seize the plane's controls.

headline.main: 9/11 Flight 93 Crash Is Seen as Deliberate

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: 9/11 Flight 93 Crash Is Seen as Deliberate

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: In Lower Manhattan, the security continues to be very tight — too tight for some New Yorkers who remember living in a more freewheeling city.

headline.main: More Than a Decade After 9/11, a Bull Market for Barriers and Checkpoints
headline.print_headline: More Than a Decade After 9/11, a Bull Market for Barriers and Checkpoints

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: More Than a Decade After 9/11, a Bull Market for Barriers and Checkpoints

Air Travel Industry.lead_paragraph: The United States and Japan reached a landmark agreement Friday to relax limits on flights between the two countries, opening up the possibility of broader cross-border airline alliances and more options for air travelers. Under the agreement, which still must be finalized by both governments, airlines from both countries would be allowed to select routes and destinations based on consumer demand for both passenger and cargo services without limitations on the number of United States or Japanese carriers that can fly between the two countries or the number of flights they can operate.

headline.main: U.S. and Japan Reach Deal for More Open Air Traffic

Air Travel Industry.mainheadline: U.S. and Japan Reach Deal for More Open Air Traffic

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: New York City is expected to announce as early as today that it has agreed to let the federal government review key city documents long sought for a federal inquiry into the city's emergency response to the terror attack on Sept. 11, 2001. The city has argued that the material is confidential, although it never formally rejected the federal request, saying only that it needed more time. The documents are Fire and Police Department records that federal investigators requested a year ago as part of an inquiry by the National Institute of Standards and Technology, which wants to review police 911 tapes as well as transcripts of interviews with hundreds of surviving firefighters so that it can understand how the city handled the trade center evacuation. The institute has said that its goal is to save lives in any future building catastrophes. Eric Lipton (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City May Release 9/11 Documents

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City May Release 9/11 Documents

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The Small Business Administration has granted $75 million in loans so far to 770 business owners and individuals who suffered losses in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, an agency official told the City Council yesterday. The agency has received 3,107 loan applications so far after responding to 27,914 requests for information, a lower response rate than is typical for other disasters in which federal agencies offer aid, according to the official, Cynthia A. Steed, an S.B.A. loan officer. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: S.B.A. Loans After Terror Attack

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: S.B.A. Loans After Terror Attack

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Anthrax tests at a dozen family planning centers that provide abortions came back negative, Lisa Bull, a spokeswoman for the F.B.I., said yesterday. The state centers received letters on Nov. 8 containing a white powder and a note saying that the powder was anthrax, state and federal officials said. The letters were sent via Federal Express to two clinics in Hartford, two in Danbury, two in New Haven and one each in Bridgeport, Norwalk, Waterbury, Meriden, New London and Avon.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Anthrax Tests Negative

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Anthrax Tests Negative

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Despite a surge in blood donations after the World Trade Center attack, the New York Blood Center, a nonprofit collection and distribution agency, is making an emergency appeal for blood and platelet donors. Because of a misperception that donation centers had more blood than they needed, donations since November have been far lower than normal, according to the center. Center officials project that by next week there will be less than a one-day supply of O-negative blood, the type that can be used by any patient in case of an emergency. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Center Reports Blood Shortage

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Center Reports Blood Shortage

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: An emergency radio system will link all 85 acute-care hospitals in the state by the end of the year, as preparation for communicating in a disaster, officials announced yesterday. The hospitals are spending more than $1.5 million for 85 radios, and the state will spend more than $225,000 for 15 radios so its emergency workers and the governor can keep in touch with the hospitals, said the state commissioner of health and senior services, Dr. Clifton R. Lacy. Emergency communications were overwhelmed on Sept. 11.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Hospitals Plan Radio Links

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Hospitals Plan Radio Links

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: American Trans Air said yesterday that it would apply for up to $165 million in federal loan guarantees. The company is trying to steady its business in the aftermath of Sept. 11 and a slow economic recovery. The carrier, which has already received $43 million in federal emergency grants since last year's terrorist attacks, is also planning to ask the government for an additional $31 million cash infusion. The loan guarantee would make it easier for the company, based in Indianapolis, to borrow money.

headline.main: AMERICAN TRANS AIR PLANS TO SEEK U.S. LOAN GUARANTEES

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: AMERICAN TRANS AIR PLANS TO SEEK U.S. LOAN GUARANTEES

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The final installment of the roughly $21.5 billion aid package President Bush pledged to New York after the Sept. 11 terror attack appears headed for approval, the staffs of United States Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday. House and Senate negotiators have agreed to provide $5.5 billion for the package. The package includes $2.7 billion for disaster relief through the Federal Emergency Management Agency, $1.8 billion to build a new transit hub in Lower Manhattan, and $750 million to help major utilities rebuild equipment damaged in the attack. The aid package is included in a larger spending bill that both houses of Congress are expected to pass next week, according to Mr. Schumer's aides. Raymond Hernandez (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: New York Aid Package Advances

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: New York Aid Package Advances

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on a resolution calling on the Federal Emergency Management Agency to reimburse nearly $280 million for New York Police Department expenses, including overtime, related to the World Trade Center attack. Committee Room, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (212) 788-7124.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Unreimbursed Police Expenses

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Unreimbursed Police Expenses

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: New York University said yesterday that the federal government had agreed to cover some of the expenses incurred from the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The decision by the Federal Emergency Management Agency reverses an earlier determination that the university would not qualify for such reimbursement. N.Y.U. said the turnabout was a result of strong support from New York's Congressional delegation and Gov. George E. Pataki. N.Y.U. had submitted a list of about $10 million in expenses, which included the cost of rehousing students and removing debris from dormitories near the World Trade Center. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: N.Y.U. To Receive FEMA Aid

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: N.Y.U. To Receive FEMA Aid

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The City Council's Environmental Protection Committee has scheduled a public hearing on improving air quality at the World Trade Center site and designating the Department of Environmental Protection as the lead agency on the terror attack's environmental impact. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (718) 217-4969.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Ground Zero Air Quality

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Ground Zero Air Quality

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The cost of the anthrax cleanup at the Hart Senate Office Building has reached $23 million, $2 million shy of the ceiling approved last year by Environmental Protection Agency, officials said. The figures were released by Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the ranking Republican on the Finance Committee, who had questioned whether the agency had spent the money properly.

headline.main: ANTHRAX

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: ANTHRAX

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The Jan. 11 deadline for victims of the World Trade Center attack to apply for federal assistance has been extended to March 11, state and federal officials said yesterday. Under the program, disaster victims are eligible for crisis counseling, and those whose homes or belongings were lost or damaged, as well as business owners whose businesses were harmed, are eligible for low-interest loans or grants. Those seeking assistance should call the Federal Emergency Management Agency, (800) 462-9029, or check the Web site at www.fema.gov.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Disaster Aid Deadline Is Extended

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Disaster Aid Deadline Is Extended

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Jack Resnick & Sons rechristened its 14-story office tower in the financial district this past weekend, giving it the new name 255 Greenwich Street. The building, which is home to several New York City agencies including the Office of Management and Budget, had been known as 75 Park Place since it opened in 1987. The renaming is the latest move by landlords and developers to take advantage of a repositioning of Greenwich Street, which is poised to become a main thoroughfare running through the World Trade Center site when a long-closed stretch finally reopens next year.

headline.main: Sundered Greenwich Street Will Be Rejoined

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Sundered Greenwich Street Will Be Rejoined

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The federal official overseeing the controversial cleanup and environmental testing of apartments near ground zero has submitted her resignation. In a letter dated Oct. 12, the official, Jane M. Kenny, said she would leave her job as the Environmental Protection Agency's Region 2 administrator on Nov. 12 for a ''new opportunity,'' but was not more specific. Ms. Kenny, who was appointed to her post in 2001, has rejected claims that residents and workers were allowed to return to the area around ground zero too soon. She also oversaw the cleanup and testing of thousands of apartments in Lower Manhattan, some of which will have to be retested.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: E.P.A. Official To Quit

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: E.P.A. Official To Quit

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The estimated cost of rebuilding the World Trade Center has grown to at least $14.8 billion, up from $11 billion in 2008, according to an audit commissioned by the bistate agency.

headline.seo: Port Authority Called ‘Dysfunctional’ by Auditors
headline.main: Port Authority Called ‘Dysfunctional’ as Trade Center Costs Rise
headline.print_headline: Port Authority Called ‘Dysfunctional’ as Trade Center Costs Rise

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Port Authority Called ‘Dysfunctional’ as Trade Center Costs Rise

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: A federal health official's ruling has cleared the way for 50 different types of cancer to be added to the list of sicknesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund set up to compensate and treat people exposed to the toxic smoke, dust and fumes in the months after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. The decision, released on Friday, came as a vindication for hundreds and perhaps thousands of people who have claimed -- often in the face of resistance from public health officials -- that their cancers were caused by their exposure to the dust cloud and debris thrown up by the attacks.

headline.main: 9/11 Health Fund Given Clearance To Cover Cancer

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: 9/11 Health Fund Given Clearance To Cover Cancer

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: A report on the exposure of workers and residents near ground zero to toxic dust and chemicals provided new details on health problems they face. The report, based on a study conducted by six research centers on behalf of federal and city government agencies, published in this month's issue of Environmental Health Perspectives, found that fragments of glass and pulverized cement, breathed first by firefighters and later by cleanup workers, had caused severe coughs and asthma. The report also said the exposure had increased the risk of mesothelioma, a type of cancer associated with inhaling asbestos. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Health Report On Ground Zero

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Health Report On Ground Zero

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported yesterday that more than 41,000 people had signed up with the World Trade Center Health Registry, which was created last September to track the health consequences of the 9/11 terrorist attack over the next 20 years. The registry is open to people who might have been exposed to dust and smoke from the disaster. The enrollment period ends in 10 weeks. Information is available at (866) 692-9827 and at 311, the city's information number. Details are also online at wtcregistry.org. Officials called the registry the largest public health registry of its kind in United States history.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Signup For 9/11 Health Study Is Ending

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Signup For 9/11 Health Study Is Ending

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: A group of workers has filed a class-action lawsuit against the companies hired to clean up after the World Trade Center attack. The workers claim they were exposed to toxic fumes and debris at ground zero. The lawsuit, which also names the entities that leased and managed the trade center, was filed on Friday in federal court in Manhattan and announced yesterday. The companies have not yet responded. The plaintiffs also intend to sue the City of New York, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the federal Environmental Protection Agency, David E. Worby, the lawyer for the workers, said. He was joined at a news conference by 13 people who he said had physical ailments directly related to their exposure to what he said were 9/11 toxins. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Workers Sue

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Workers Sue

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The disclosure in August of a terrorist plot by Al Qaeda has caused more damage to American counterterrorism efforts than the vast trove of data from Edward Snowden, the former N.S.A. consultant, analysts said.

headline.main: Qaeda Plot Leak Has Undermined U.S. Intelligence
headline.print_headline: Qaeda Plot Leak Has Undermined U.S. Intelligence

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Qaeda Plot Leak Has Undermined U.S. Intelligence

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: A medical privacy breach led to the public posting on a commercial Web site of data for 20,000 emergency room patients at Stanford Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif., including names and diagnosis codes, the hospital has confirmed. The information stayed online for nearly a year. Since discovering the breach last month, the hospital has been investigating how a detailed spreadsheet made its way from one of its vendors, a billing contractor identified as Multi-Specialty Collection Services, to a Web site called Student of Fortune, which allows students to solicit paid assistance with their schoolwork.

headline.main: Medical Data Of Thousands Posted Online

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Medical Data Of Thousands Posted Online

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The alarm was not fully activated to avoid waking up the crew, and so did not sound during the disaster.

headline.seo: Oil Rig’s Siren Was Kept Silent, Technician Says
headline.main: Oil Rig’s Siren Was Kept Silent, Technician Says
headline.print_headline: SIREN ON OIL RIG WAS KEPT SILENT, TECHNICIAN SAYS

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Oil Rig’s Siren Was Kept Silent, Technician Says

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The federal government has little control over who gets behind the wheel of discount tour buses.

headline.seo: Lax Regulation of Discount Buses Is Cited After I-95 Crash
