Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The rave at the Cow Palace on May 29 carried a high cost in dollars and lives, a cost that continues to rise.

headline.main: Costs and Questions Continue to Mount Following Cow Palace Rave
headline.print_headline: Costs and Questions Continue to Mount Following Cow Palace Rave

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Costs and Questions Continue to Mount Following Cow Palace Rave

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: In response to requests from members of Congress and to at least one news report, the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York opened a preliminary inquiry on Thursday into allegations that News Corporation journalists sought to gain access to the phone records of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, according to several people briefed on the matter. The investigation is in its earliest stages, two of the people said, and its scope is not yet clear. It also is unclear whether the F.B.I. has identified possible targets of the investigation or possible specific criminal violations.

headline.main: F.B.I. Looks Into Hacking Of 9/11 Victims' Phones

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: F.B.I. Looks Into Hacking Of 9/11 Victims' Phones

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Religious leaders held an “emergency summit” to denounce bigotry toward Muslim Americans.

headline.main: Concern Is Voiced Over Religious Intolerance
headline.print_headline: Concern Is Voiced Over Religious Intolerance

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Concern Is Voiced Over Religious Intolerance

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: For Obama administration officials, the searching for a new C.I.A. director comes at a particularly challenging time.

headline.seo: Petraeus Replacement Search Is Under Way
headline.main: Amid Upheaval, Obama Loses ‘Source of Stability’
headline.print_headline: Amid Upheaval, Obama Loses ‘Source of Stability’

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Amid Upheaval, Obama Loses ‘Source of Stability’

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The study by the New York City health department, the largest to date, was released mere months after cancer was added to the list of sicknesses covered by the World Trade Center compensation fund.

headline.seo: No Clear Link Between Cancer and 9/11 Debris, New York Health Dept. Study Finds
headline.main: No Clear Link Between Cancer and 9/11 Debris, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: City Study Finds No Clear Link Between 9/11 Debris and Cancer

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: No Clear Link Between Cancer and 9/11 Debris, Study Finds

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Lawyers representing New York City announced yesterday that they would appeal a recent federal decision denying their motion to dismiss thousands of lawsuits brought against the city and private contractors working for the city during the ground zero cleanup. More than 6,000 workers have sued, alleging that the city failed to protect them from toxic pollutants. Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of Federal District Court ruled last month that the city's immunity from such lawsuits was limited, allowing the cases to go forward. ANTHONY DEPALMA

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Appeal In Ground Zero Lawsuit

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Appeal In Ground Zero Lawsuit

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The state and city will receive $250 million from the federal government to help pay the pensions of police officers and firefighters killed in the attack on the World Trade Center, Gov. George E. Pataki and federal officials said yesterday. The grants from the Federal Emergency Management Agency will cover the unforeseen increases in contributions to the pension system. The state and city had to pay the increases to cover benefits for the families of 343 firefighters and 23 police officers who died in the attack. The funds are part of about $8.8 billion in FEMA grants already pledged to the city and state, state officials said. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pension Aid Received

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pension Aid Received

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg opened an emergency operations center yesterday to replace the one in 7 World Trade Center that was destroyed on 9/11. Creating the center, at 165 Cadman Plaza East, involved a $50 million federally financed renovation of a building once used by the American Red Cross. The four-story, 65,000-square-foot building, which will serve as the headquarters of the Office of Emergency Management, has a center for representatives of 130 agencies who will gather during emergencies; a press briefing room; and conference rooms. The building was designed to be environmentally sensitive, with columns and floors reused from the old building, heat-reflecting roof tiles and water-saving bathroom fixtures. SEWELL CHAN

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Emergency Command Center Opened

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Emergency Command Center Opened

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: An appeals court ruled this week that Environmental Protection Agency officials are not liable for making rosy declarations about air quality in the days after the World Trade Center's destruction on 9/11. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit issued its ruling on Thursday in a lawsuit brought by five government employees who did rescue and cleanup work at ground zero. The opinion said that putting agency workers at risk of lawsuits for giving out bad information during a crisis could have catastrophic effects.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: E.P.A. Not Liable For Comments

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: E.P.A. Not Liable For Comments

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline.main: Science Credentials And the E.P.A.

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Science Credentials And the E.P.A.

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: A plan to test for slag wool, a type of insulating material used in the World Trade Center, as evidence that dust from the center is still present in Lower Manhattan and Brooklyn will undergo a scientific peer review in the next several weeks, despite strong opposition from people who live and work in the buildings to be tested. Under the plan, 150 buildings would be checked for traces of slag wool to determine the extent of any future cleanup. E.Timothy Oppelt, interim chairman of the technical panel of experts advising the federal Environmental Protection Agency, defended the proposal and said it would be thoroughly reviewed by other independent experts. At the panel's hearing in Manhattan yesterday, residents and workers called the plan inadequate and scientifically unsound. In 2002, the federal agency oversaw the cleanup of 4,100 apartments, but there are concerns that those residences may have been re-contaminated, and that others that were never cleaned may pose a health hazard. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Cleanup Review Planned

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Cleanup Review Planned

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: To replace Michael D. Brown at the head of the nation's emergency agency, President Bush reached out to a manager who, at least on paper, is different in some important ways. R. David Paulison, chosen on Monday to take temporary control of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, started out in the Miami-Dade Fire Rescue Department at the age of 19, rising through the ranks over three decades to become chief.

headline.main: Pick as Acting FEMA Leader Has Disaster Relief Experience

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Pick as Acting FEMA Leader Has Disaster Relief Experience

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The former director of records at the city's chief medical examiner's office pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to stealing millions of dollars in federal aid that was sent to the city after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack to help identify the remains gathered from ground zero. The former official, Rosa Abreu, 40, was indicted in December 2005 and accused of using shadow companies and fake contract bids to steal funds sent by the Federal Emergency Management Agency when the medical examiner's office was overwhelmed by the task of identifying nearly 3,000 victims. Ms. Abreu will face a maximum sentence of 55 years in prison when she is sentenced next year on charges of embezzlement and money laundering, prosecutors said.

headline.main: Manhattan: Guilty Plea In Theft of 9/11 Aid

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Manhattan: Guilty Plea In Theft of 9/11 Aid

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Initial tests at 53 apartments and in the common areas of nine buildings within 1,500 feet of ground zero found three dust samples that were contaminated with asbestos above safe levels and 71 samples that were laced with lead that exceeded federal standards, environmental officials said yesterday. The spaces were tested under a controversial program of the Environmental Protection Agency. Since the testing began this year, most of the 5,600 samples the agency has analyzed have fallen below federal benchmarks for exposure. Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the agency, said that 272 apartments and 25 buildings below Canal Street will be tested within the next year, and any contamination will be cleaned. Complete test results can be seen at www.epa.gov /wtc/testandclean.

headline.main: Metro Briefing: New York: Manhattan: Environmental Tests Downtown

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing: New York: Manhattan: Environmental Tests Downtown

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The White House announced its intention to nominate Vice Adm. Thad W. Allen to be commandant of the United States Coast Guard. President Bush put Admiral Allen, right, in charge of the federal relief effort related to Hurricane Katrina in September, after Michael D. Brown, director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, was stripped of his oversight duties. Since 2002, Admiral Allen has been chief of staff of the Coast Guard, an agency that provides military-style security and support like search-and-rescue missions, environmental cleanups, maritime safety and law enforcement. Admiral Allen also commanded the Coast Guard's response along the Atlantic Seaboard after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. JOHN FILES (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Coast Guard Commandant Candidate

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: Coast Guard Commandant Candidate

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street will not begin this month, as had been anticipated, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation said yesterday. On Monday, the federal Environmental Protection Agency raised questions about the proposed handling of waste materials containing polychlorinated biphenyls and cadmium in the heavily contaminated 41-story tower opposite ground zero. The corporation hopes to begin demolition later this summer, a spokesman said. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Razing Postponed

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Razing Postponed

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The search for human remains on the roof of a vacant skyscraper near ground zero, suspended more than two months ago by environmental officials, is scheduled to resume tomorrow, officials said. Workers wearing protective masks will continue removing toxic materials and searching for remains on the roof of the former Deutsche Bank building, which was badly damaged on Sept. 11, 2001, said John Gallagher, spokesman for the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The Environmental Protection Agency suspended work on the roof in April, citing the corporation for failing to properly protect workers from asbestos, but said in June that work could resume.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Search For Remains

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Search For Remains

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Delayed by what the fire commissioner says was ''poor management,'' the city plans to release a new avalanche of documentary records from Sept. 11, including more than 1,600 phone calls made to emergency services that morning. While most of these are calls made by people outside the buildings or watching television, officials say about 31 were from people who were part of the morning's narrative of struggle and loss: 21 firefighters who died and 10 civilians who were also in the World Trade Center towers.

headline.main: Fire Department Releasing More 9/11 Emergency Calls

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Fire Department Releasing More 9/11 Emergency Calls

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Not long before Hurricane Katrina made landfall, James Lee Witt, the former director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, and his colleagues called officials on the Gulf Coast to offer their help. Soon after the storm hit, the State of Louisiana signed up with Witt Associates, a disaster consulting firm. Within days, Mr. Witt had become a fixture at the state's emergency operations center in Baton Rouge, advising the governor and sleeping in a trailer. He even figured out a way for FEMA to reimburse the state for his firm's fees, which the company estimates at $4 million to $6 million over the next year.

headline.main: FEMA Leader Under Clinton Makes It Pay

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: FEMA Leader Under Clinton Makes It Pay

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Jay G. Conrad, of Tennessee, and Andrew J. Zarauskas, of New Jersey, face four kinds of charges in a 29-count indictment filed in federal court late last year.

headline.seo: 2 Linked to Smuggling Narwhal Tusks Plead Not Guilty
headline.main: Tusks of Whimsical-Looking Whales Lead to Charges for 2 in a Maine Courtroom
headline.print_headline: Tusks of Whimsical-Looking Whales Lead to Charges for 2 in a Maine Courtroom

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Tusks of Whimsical-Looking Whales Lead to Charges for 2 in a Maine Courtroom

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of emergency responders will stage an emergency drill this weekend at ground zero. The drill, which will take place on Sunday morning, will simulate a response to an explosion at a PATH commuter rail train in the tunnel between the World Trade Center site and northern New Jersey.

headline.main: Rescue Drill at Ground Zero on Sunday

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Rescue Drill at Ground Zero on Sunday

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The New York City Council held a rare public hearing in Washington yesterday to draw attention to the city's dire fiscal condition and to lobby for aid from the federal government. Speakers said the city's situation was in part a result of the disruption that occurred in Lower Manhattan after the attack on the World Trade Center in 2001. Many speakers complained that the federal government, now dominated by Republicans, had not done enough to help the city recover. Council Speaker Gifford Miller, a Democrat, noted that while the federal government had pledged to give the city $20 billion in recovery aid, some studies put the city's overall losses at $80 billion. Raymond Hernandez (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: City Council Goes To Washington

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: City Council Goes To Washington

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Ferry service between the Brooklyn Army Terminal in Sunset Park and Pier 11 in Lower Manhattan will continue, officials said yesterday, although after today it will no longer be free. The city had said it would not be able to provide the service, started after the Sept. 11 attack, once the Federal Emergency Management Agency ended its $290,000 monthly subsidy. But a Brooklyn company, New York Water Taxi, responded to the city's invitation to take over the route. Starting tomorrow, commuters can ride the ferry every 20 minutes during the morning and evening rush for $4 each way. Fares will rise on June 1 to $5 for a single trip, $45 for a 10-trip book and $175 monthly. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Ferry Service Is Saved

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Ferry Service Is Saved

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Local elected officials and community groups demanded yesterday that the Federal Emergency Management Agency extend a housing assistance program that is to expire on Friday. The FEMA program, started shortly after the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks, has paid almost $100 million to nearly 11,000 applicants who lived or worked in Manhattan and have faced eviction or foreclosure. But, the officials said, the deadline should be extended, partly because of New York's continuing economic problems, and partly because the program has not done enough to reach out to potential applicants throughout the metropolitan area. The officials included Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Manhattan Democrat; William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller; and the Rev. Thomas W. Goodhue, executive director of the Long Island Council of Churches. David W. Chen (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Extended Federal Aid Urged

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Extended Federal Aid Urged

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: At the time the Pentagon and World Trade Center were being attacked yesterday, Joe Allbaugh, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, and representatives from the 50 state emergency management agencies were attending an annual conference of emergency response officials at a resort in Big Sky, Mont. One of the day's main seminar topics was how to prepare for terrorist attacks.

headline.main: Attacks Halt Meeting
headline.kicker: A DAY OF TERROR: DISASTER PLANNING

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Attacks Halt Meeting

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials have concluded that it is ''very unlikely'' that dust from the World Trade Center attack posed a significant health risk to people who lived downtown. The study, published yesterday by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, compared air and surface dust samples collected in November and December 2001 in 30 downtown buildings with samples from buildings above 59th Street. The downtown samples had more glass fibers and asbestos than those uptown, but in concentrations below those considered hazardous, the study said. The report, however, encouraged residents concerned about dust to continue using damp mops and HEPA vacuums, or to seek federal cleanup assistance. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Little Risk Seen In Downtown Air

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Little Risk Seen In Downtown Air

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called yesterday for Congressional hearings into whether the Environmental Protection Agency played down health risks in a report on the air quality of neighborhoods affected by the destruction of the World Trade Center. ''A week after Sept. 11, the E.P.A. put out a statement which said the air was safe and that there were no concerns,'' she said during a luncheon at the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. ''And we now know they didn't have the analysis and the data to make that statement.'' She cited asthma and bronchial problems among rescue workers and volunteers at ground zero and called for further testing of indoor air in Lower Manhattan and Brooklyn. Howard O. Stier (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Clinton Wants Hearings On E.P.A.

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Clinton Wants Hearings On E.P.A.

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The city will review a report by the inspector general of Environmental Protection Agency that says the White House sought to play down possible health risks posed by World Trade Center dust and debris, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Mr. Bloomberg said he would send the report to Christopher O. Ward, commissioner of the city's Department of Environmental Protection. The mayor, a Republican, said he had not seen the report by Nikki L. Tinsley, the inspector general, but added that he trusts President Bush. The report, released Thursday, said that the White House encouraged the agency to play down air-quality problems caused by the destruction of the trade center.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City To Review 9/11 E.P.A. Report

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City To Review 9/11 E.P.A. Report

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: Residents of Lower Manhattan who want their apartments to be inspected for cleaning by the Environmental Protection Agency now have until Dec. 28 to sign up, the E.P.A. said yesterday. Only a quarter of the eligible residents have accepted the offer, which had been due to expire today. The government will conduct free cleaning and testing of apartments that may have been contaminated by dust and ash from the World Trade Center attack. Anyone living south of Canal, Pike and Allen Streets can request an air quality test and cleaning, or the test alone, by calling (877) 796-5471 or going online at www.epa.gov/wtc. Kirk Johnson (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Cleaning Deadline Is Extended

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Cleaning Deadline Is Extended

Federal Emergency Management.lead_paragraph: The judge’s ruling was the latest contribution to a debate among courts and a presidential review group about how to balance security and privacy in the era of big data.

headline.main: Judge Upholds N.S.A.’s Bulk Collection of Data on Calls
headline.print_headline: A Judge Upholds N.S.A. Collection Of Data on Calls

Federal Emergency Management.mainheadline: Judge Upholds N.S.A.’s Bulk Collection of Data on Calls

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: The German government has frozen 214 bank accounts it believes are linked to terrorists as part of an effort by allies of the United States to comply with a request by the Bush administration, the Economics Ministry said today. According to the ministry, the frozen accounts total $3.7 million.

headline.main: Berlin Freezes Assets

The Hijackers.mainheadline: Berlin Freezes Assets

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: An Indonesian man named in F.B.I. documents as a contact for Mohammed Atta, the suspected leader of the Sept. 11 attacks, was arrested today and charged with helping to get false identification for another man listed in the same documents as a contact for Osama bin Laden.

headline.main: More False I.D. Charges

The Hijackers.mainheadline: More False I.D. Charges

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: Iraq's ambassador to Turkey, who has been linked in news reports to contacts between Iraqi intelligence and Mohamed Atta, the suspected ringleader of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, left Turkey for Baghdad yesterday. The ambassador, Farouk Yahya al-Hijazi, who spent three years in Turkey, said that he had had no contact with Mr. Atta and that he had been recalled ''after the normal period of time,'' not because of the reported links to Mr. Atta.

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Envoy Denies Terror Link

The Hijackers.mainheadline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Envoy Denies Terror Link

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: German prosecutors brought charges yesterday against a Moroccan man accused of supporting members of the Hamburg cell suspected of helping to plan and carry out the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States. The indictment of the man, Mounir el-Motassadeq, 28, was the first formal criminal charge brought by German authorities in connection with the attacks.

headline.main: Germans Issue First Indictment in the 9/11 Plot

The Hijackers.mainheadline: Germans Issue First Indictment in the 9/11 Plot

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: A year after Sept. 11 investigators are still struggling to piece together the planning, preparation and connections between the leaders of the attacks. Below, the suspected leaders, some of what the authorities have revealed and questions they continue to try to answer. SARAH SLOBIN

headline.main: The Plot Leaders and Lingering Questions

The Hijackers.mainheadline: The Plot Leaders and Lingering Questions

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: A spokesman for the German Foreign Ministry said it had requested information from the State Department about the whereabouts of Mohamed Heidar Zammar, a German citizen under investigation for involvement in the Hamburg plot that led to the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. The official said the Foreign Ministry was responding to a report in The Washington Post, which quoted an American counterterrorism official who suggested that American officials knew where Zammar was and that he ''is not walking the streets.'' The German Foreign Ministry said there had not yet been a response from the State Department. Mr. Zammar, who was in Germany at the time of the attacks, left in October for Morocco. Though he was under investigation, German police say that there was insufficient evidence to charge him and that he was issued a one-year passport immediately before his departure. His family in Hamburg has reported him missing and requested information from the Foreign Ministry.

headline.main: LOOKING FOR SUSPECT

The Hijackers.mainheadline: LOOKING FOR SUSPECT

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: The Spanish authorities have prepared a 700-page report on a meeting, held on the Spanish coast last July, of presumed conspirators in the Sept. 11 attacks, and have forwarded it to the F.B.I., a leading Spanish newspaper reported today. The meeting, which the authorities previously knew about, involved Mohamed Atta, the suspected mastermind of the attacks, and was held in the town of Tarragona, in northeastern Spain. The newspaper El País, citing the report, said that Marwan al-Shehhi, another suspect, may also have been at the meeting.

headline.main: New Report Details 9/11 Talks in Spain

The Hijackers.mainheadline: New Report Details 9/11 Talks in Spain

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: The German police have warned security officials that there could soon be a Qaeda attack in Germany, a spokesman said. The German BKA criminal agency confirmed that it had warned security officials on Tuesday that an attack might occur sometime over the next 20 days but said they did not know of a specific target or plan of action. The Frankfurter Allgemeine has reported that a Qaeda member from Pakistan worked out a plan to take 300 to 400 hostages in Germany, France and Britain in an effort to win the freedom of Qaeda prisoners.

headline.main: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; QAEDA WARNING

The Hijackers.mainheadline: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; QAEDA WARNING

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities have concluded that there is no evidence that Mohamed Atta, the suspected ringleader of the Sept. 11 attacks, met with an Iraqi intelligence officer before the hijackings. Reports that Mr. Atta had met with an Iraqi agent in Prague in early 2001 circulated widely after the attacks, suggesting a possible connection with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

headline.main: U.S. Drops Last Link of Iraq to 9/11

The Hijackers.mainheadline: U.S. Drops Last Link of Iraq to 9/11

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: Testimony by Osama bin Laden’s youngest wife has offered the most detailed account yet of the family’s life on the run preceding the raid in May 2011 that killed the Qaeda leader.

headline.seo: On Run, Bin Laden Had 4 Children and 5 Houses, a Wife Says
headline.main: In Hiding, Bin Laden Had Four Children and Five Houses
headline.print_headline: On the Run, Bin Laden Had 4 Children and 5 Houses, a Wife Says

The Hijackers.mainheadline: In Hiding, Bin Laden Had Four Children and Five Houses

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: A court in Hamburg postponed the verdict in the trial of Abdelghani Mzoudi, accused of involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks, after prosecutors dramatically announced the emergence of a new witness just one day before the court had scheduled its final decision. The unnamed witness is an Iranian intelligence agent who told investigators that Mr. Mzoudi played a logistical role within the Hamburg cell that planned the attacks, according to a lawyer close to the case. Desmond Butler (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Delays Qaeda Verdict

The Hijackers.mainheadline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Delays Qaeda Verdict

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: German prosecutors said that Islamic radicalism may have motivated a Kosovar to open fire on an American military bus at the Frankfurt airport.

headline.main: Inquiry Eyes Extremism in Attack on U.S. Soldiers
headline.print_headline: Germany: Motive Sought in 2 Killings

The Hijackers.mainheadline: Inquiry Eyes Extremism in Attack on U.S. Soldiers

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: The European Court of Human Rights ruled that Macedonia violated the rights of Khaled el-Masri when it arrested him and turned him over to the United States.

headline.seo: Europe Court Finds Violation in C.I.A. Rendition
headline.main: Court Finds Rights Violation in C.I.A. Rendition Case
headline.print_headline: Court Finds Rights Violation in C.I.A. Rendition Case

The Hijackers.mainheadline: Court Finds Rights Violation in C.I.A. Rendition Case

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: A Hamburg court began a hearing on whether to give a stiffer prison sentence to Mounir el-Motassadeq, the Moroccan who was a friend of the three 9/11 pilots. He was convicted in 2005 of belonging to a terrorist organization and sentenced to seven years in prison. But an appeals court ruled in November that he had been wrongly acquitted of direct involvement in the attacks. Now he may face 15 years in prison. A decision is expected next month. MARK LANDLER

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Sentence Trial For 9/11 Friend

The Hijackers.mainheadline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Sentence Trial For 9/11 Friend

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: A detainee at Guantánamo Bay who has been described as a financier of the Sept. 11 attacks said at a closed hearing that top operatives of Al Qaeda informed him of the impending attacks the night before they occurred, according to a transcript released yesterday. The detainee, Mustafa Ahmed al-Hawsawi, said he was told by Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who has been identified as a top Qaeda operative, ''that next night there would be an operation.'' In the transcript of the March 21 hearing, he said he also discussed the attack with Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who was quoted earlier this month as telling a similar closed hearing that he was the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks. WILLIAM GLABERSON

headline.main: National Briefing | Terrorism: Detainee Says He Was Told Of Sept. 11 Attacks

The Hijackers.mainheadline: National Briefing | Terrorism: Detainee Says He Was Told Of Sept. 11 Attacks

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: The authorities in the United Arab Emirates said they had arrested seven members of a “terrorist cell” accused of plotting attacks in the emirates and their neighbors.

headline.seo: Emirates Seize Terror Suspects
headline.main: Emirates Said to Seize Qaeda Supporters
headline.print_headline: United Arab Emirates: Officials Say They Broke Up ‘Terrorist Cell’

The Hijackers.mainheadline: Emirates Said to Seize Qaeda Supporters

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: German prosecutors indicted Abdelghani Mzoudi, a 30-year-old Moroccan and a suspected member of Al Qaeda who is accused of providing logistical support to the pilots in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington. He was charged on 3,066 counts of accessory to murder in connection with the attacks. Mr. Mzoudi, who is in jail in Hamburg, has denied the charges. He is the second suspected member of Al Qaeda to be charged from the small Hamburg-based terrorist cell that played a central role in the Sept. 11 plot. Mounir el-Motassadeq, a former roommate of Mr. Mzoudi, is serving a 15-year sentence on similar charges after his conviction by a Hamburg court in February.

headline.main: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; GERMANY: SEPT. 11 INDICTMENT

The Hijackers.mainheadline: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; GERMANY: SEPT. 11 INDICTMENT

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: The United States military has taken into custody an Iraqi intelligence official who is reported to have met the ringleader of the Sept. 11, 2001, hijackers just months before the attacks, a United States official said today. The military took the intelligence official, Ahmad Khalil Ibrahim Samir al-Ani, into custody last week, the official said.

headline.main: Iraqi, Possibly Tied To 9/11, Is Captured

The Hijackers.mainheadline: Iraqi, Possibly Tied To 9/11, Is Captured

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: The composer Karlheinz Stockhausen caused outrage in Germany when he described the terrorist attacks in the United States last week as ''the greatest work of art ever,'' Agence France-Presse reported yesterday. Mr. Stockhausen, 73, who made the remark to journalists in Hamburg on Sunday, retracted it at once and asked that it not be reported.

headline.main: Attacks Called Great Art

The Hijackers.mainheadline: Attacks Called Great Art

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: A suspected member of the Hamburg terrorist cell behind the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in New York and Virginia will go on trial in Hamburg on Thursday. The Moroccan-born defendant, Abdelghani Mzoudi, 30, is charged with 3,066 counts of abetting murder and aiding a terrorist organization. Mr. Mzoudi was a friend of Mohamed Atta, one of the terrorist pilots, and was a witness for his will. Mr. Atta and two other pilots in the attacks were from the Hamburg cell. If found guilty, Mr. Mzoudi faces the same 15-year jail term to which a fellow Moroccan, Mounir el-Motassadeq, was sentenced in February for aiding the hijackers. The trial, with 125 witnesses, could last into early next year. Victor Homola (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Second 9/11 Trial

The Hijackers.mainheadline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Second 9/11 Trial

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: The United States Justice Department has denied a German court's request for testimony from two suspected members of Al Qaeda who are in American custody, but will allow court representatives to question Ahmed Ressam, who is accused of trying to bomb the Los Angeles airport in December 1999. The Justice Department will not allow questioning of Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who was detained in Pakistan in September, or Zacarias Moussaoui, who is being held in the United States on suspicion he was intended to be the 20th hijacker in the attacks of Sept. 11.

headline.main: Germans Lose a Bid for Qaeda Suspects

The Hijackers.mainheadline: Germans Lose a Bid for Qaeda Suspects

The Hijackers.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Mounir el-Motassadeq, who is being tried in Hamburg for involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks, have called on judges to halt the trial and release their client on the ground that the United States is preventing an important witness from testifying in his defense. Last month the Justice Department refused requests for testimony from the witness, Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who is believed to have played a direct role in the planning of the attacks. Mr. bin al-Shibh, who once lived in Hamburg with Mohamed Atta, the suspected ringleader of the attacks, was arrested in Pakistan in September and is in American military detention at an undisclosed location. Officials say he has been forthcoming with investigators.

headline.main: Saying U.S. Hinders Its Case, Defense Seeks Halt to German Trial

The Hijackers.mainheadline: Saying U.S. Hinders Its Case, Defense Seeks Halt to German Trial

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: Larry Silverstein, the World Trade Center leaseholder, lost his bid to reverse an appeals court ruling that the Sept. 11, 2001, attack on the twin towers did not entitle him to a $7 billion insurance payment. The three-judge appellate panel that issued the ruling in September denied his petition for a rehearing. Mr. Silverstein had made the request on the ground that the panel misinterpreted New York law when it found that a policy issued by the Travelers Indemnity Company did not require that the two plane crashes be seen as separate events, each requiring a loss payment of $3.55 billion.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Leaseholder Loses Court Fight

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Leaseholder Loses Court Fight

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: A federal judge yesterday ordered the developer Larry A. Silverstein and his insurers to arbitration on Nov. 6 to try to settle their battle over billions of dollars in insurance proceeds for rebuilding at the World Trade Center site. If the process fails, Judge Michael B. Mukasey said, the first of what could be three successive trials will begin in February. Mr. Silverstein's lawyer, Herbert M. Wachtell, expressed reservations about the proposed arbitrator, John S. Martin, a retired federal judge. He said Mr. Martin was a friend of his but had ruled against Mr. Silverstein in earlier stages of the case. But Mr. Wachtell agreed to the choice when Judge Mukasey said that ''you couldn't conceivably have anyone better to mediate this case.'' Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arbitration For Trade Center Dispute

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arbitration For Trade Center Dispute

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: The large Dutch financial services company ING Groep cut its forecast for earnings growth this year. The company said profit would be hurt by slowing sales and increased insurance claims related to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. ING, which owns the ReliaStar insurance company in the United States, doubled the impact that the attack-related claims would have on its earnings, to 100 million euros ($91 million). It said earnings for all of 2001 would probably grow 5 percent, down from previous estimates of 17 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer Lowers Forecast

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer Lowers Forecast

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: The Taisei Fire and Marine Insurance Company, Japan's 12th-largest casualty insurer, filed for bankruptcy yesterday because of claims stemming from the terrorist attacks in the United States. The insurer, which planned to merge with Yasuda Fire and Marine Insurance and Nissan Fire and Marine Insurance next April, said its liabilities exceeded assets by 40 billion yen ($325 million). The company held 74 billion yen ($602 million) in claims related to the attacks in September, analysts estimated. Ken Belson (NYT)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Insurer Files For Bankruptcy

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Insurer Files For Bankruptcy

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: The French insurance giant AXA warned that profits for 2001 would fall 53 percent, to 1.2 billion euros, and announced 525 layoffs in the United States. The job cuts, which total 625 for the year, are part of a plan to reduce costs by 700 million euros in 2002. The Paris-based company, which had not given a 2001 forecast since the Sept. 11 attacks, said the decline was a result of the effects of the attacks. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer Expects Profit To Fall

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer Expects Profit To Fall

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: The multibillion-dollar battle over insurance claims at the World Trade Center will be decided during two separate trials, Judge John S. Martin of United States District Court ruled Thursday. First, a jury trial scheduled to begin on Nov. 4 will determine whether the attack on the trade center last September represented two separate occurrences, entitling Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who had leased the huge complex, to a double payment totaling about $7 billion. Mr. Silverstein would get only half that amount if a jury determines that the attack was a single event.

headline.main: First of Two Possible Trials Is Set In Trade Center Insurance Case

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: First of Two Possible Trials Is Set In Trade Center Insurance Case

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: European airlines must return to commercial insurers to cover the war and terror risks that have been guaranteed by governments since the Sept. 11 attacks, the European Commission said. A commission spokesman, Gilles Gantelet, said European states would no longer provide insurance guarantees after Oct. 31.

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Air Insurance Returning To Normal

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Air Insurance Returning To Normal

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: Larry A. Silverstein, the real estate developer who controlled the World Trade Center, suffered a legal setback this week in his attempt to recover more than $7 billion in insurance for the Sept. 11 terror attack. Mr. Silverstein has argued that he is entitled to two $3.6 billion payments for two separate attacks on the two buildings; the insurers argue it was one attack. But a federal judge in Manhattan ruled on Wednesday that employees at Willis, Mr. Silverstein's insurance broker, must testify about conversations last fall with Mr. Silverstein's lawyers. The insurers suspect that Mr. Silverstein and the broker initially considered the destruction a single event for insurance purposes. Lawyers for Swiss Re, one of the insurance companies, could start deposing Willis brokers next week. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arguing Over 9/11 Insurance

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arguing Over 9/11 Insurance

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: Swiss Reinsurance Ltd. said its earnings for the first half would be down because of falling investment income, but it was gaining market share as demand rose for reinsurance protection. Worries over claims from the World Trade Center attacks have hovered over the reinsurance industry. Swiss Re, the world's second-largest reinsurer, is readying itself to expand into China, one of the biggest untapped insurance markets. The company plans to report first-half results on Aug. 29. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Expects Lower Profit

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Expects Lower Profit

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: Annual insurance premiums for San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge will double, to $1.1 million, and coverage for terrorist attacks will end when its policy is renewed on Monday. Of more than 20 insurers approached, only two offered limited terrorism coverage, and at high rates, so the bridge's board opted to keep the current insurer, ACE USA. Catherine Billey (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Limited Insurance For Golden Gate

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: National Briefing | West: California: Limited Insurance For Golden Gate

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: The holder of the lease to the World Trade Center complex, Larry A. Silverstein, announced yesterday that he had settled a dispute with two of the companies insuring the complex. Under the terms of the settlement, one insurer, Ace Bermuda Insurance Ltd., will pay $298 million and the other, XL Insurance Ltd., also of Bermuda, will pay $67 million.

headline.main: Holder of Trade Center Lease Settles With Two Insurers

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: Holder of Trade Center Lease Settles With Two Insurers

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: The insurance companies that stand to lose the most from the disaster at the World Trade Center are forming a united front in their legal battle over whether the World Trade Center's leaseholder is entitled to payment for one attack or two, one of the biggest insurers said yesterday. The big insurance company, Swiss Re, made its assertions yesterday in a statement about the insurance payout on the trade center. The leaseholder, Larry A. Silverstein, has said repeatedly that the disaster involved two attacks, and that he is therefore owed $7.2 billion in insurance payments. The more than 20 insurance companies involved have said that there was one attack and therefore that they are obligated to pay only half that, or $3.6 billion.

headline.main: Towers' Insurers Argue Payment to Leaseholder

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: Towers' Insurers Argue Payment to Leaseholder

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: Developer Larry Silverstein has secured the funds to build his long-planned 3 World Trade Center.

headline.print_headline: Developer Secures Funds to Build 3 WTC

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: Nearly everyone pursuing a bachelor’s degree is borrowing money, and as prices soar, a college degree often comes with an unprecedented financial burden.

headline.seo: Student Loans Weighing Down a Generation With Heavy Debt
headline.main: A Generation Hobbled by the Soaring Cost of College
headline.print_headline: A Generation Hobbled by College Debt

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: Larry A. Silverstein's effort to rebuild 7 World Trade Center suffered a setback yesterday when Moody's Investors Service sharply downgraded its assessment of his $383 million in debt on the property. The bond rating agency tied the downgrade to the developer's lack of progress in settling an insurance dispute over the original building after obtaining new financing and a tenant for the 52-story tower he has begun to build, said James Church, a senior analyst at Moody's. The original building was destroyed in the trade center attack. Although Mr. Silverstein has been at odds with Industrial Risk Insurers over the value of the property, he has started building a $700 million skyscraper on the site, at Washington and Vesey Streets. But rents downtown have fallen sharply, and there are few prospective tenants. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Silverstein Debt Downgraded

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Silverstein Debt Downgraded

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: The family of Mark Bavis, a passenger on United Airlines Flight 175, said its stance was not about money but about proving what it believes was negligence.

headline.seo: One Family Is Last Holdout on 9/11 Settlements
headline.main: Among 9/11 Families, a Last Holdout Remains
headline.print_headline: Among 9/11 Families, the Final Holdout On a Settlement Wants Its Day in Court

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: Among 9/11 Families, a Last Holdout Remains

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: The White House threatened on Monday to veto a bill that would add 15 years to a post-Sept. 11 government insurance program that supporters say is critical for major projects like the new World Trade Center. The legislation, known as the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act, was originally passed by Congress after the 2001 attacks. It is due to expire this year, and the House had planned to vote this week on a 15-year extension.

headline.main: Bill to Extend Terror Insurance Faces Bush Veto

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: Bill to Extend Terror Insurance Faces Bush Veto

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: The developer Larry A. Silverstein, at left, and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey won a victory in their campaign to rebuild ground zero when two insurers effectively agreed to pay more than $100 million for construction at the World Trade Center site. The two companies -- Zurich American Insurance and Wausau -- were among seven insurers sued in June by Mr. Silverstein and the Port Authority after they indicated that they might not pay full coverage because of a new rebuilding plan at ground zero. Zurich and Wausau agreed to withdraw their objections last weekend, after Gov. George E. Pataki, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Senator Charles E. Schumer and other politicians publicly and privately urged the insurers to pay what they owe and let the rebuilding go forward. The five remaining insurers, including Allianz, are obligated to provide a total of $1.36 billion, according to Silverstein Properties. ''Clearly, the pressure from elected officials is paying off,'' Janno Lieber, the World Trade Center project director for Silverstein Properties, said yesterday. CHARLES V. BAGLI (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Trade Center Insurers Yield

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Trade Center Insurers Yield

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: The destruction of the World Trade Center produced calls for a wholesale re-evaluation of the way tall buildings are designed and built, but five years later, the changes to New York City's building code, and others across the nation, have been few and modest. Recommendations from a major federal investigation into the collapse are still being debated and may yet result in modifications to a national building code that the city plans to adopt. So far, though, 9/11 has not been a turning point for code revision, in the way past disasters were -- like the Triangle Shirtwaist fire of 1911.

headline.main: Sept. 11 Has Spurred Only Modest Changes in City and National Building Codes

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: Sept. 11 Has Spurred Only Modest Changes in City and National Building Codes

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: Endurance Specialty Holdings said yesterday that it bought most of the Hartford Financial Services Group's reinsurance operation. The companies did not disclose terms of the deal. The transaction is a leap for Endurance, which had about $765 million in premiums in 2002. It is taking on about $400 million of premiums from HartRe, which had total premiums last year of about $700 million. Endurance, partly owned by the insurance broker Aon Corporation, is one of the handful of rapidly growing reinsurers set up in Bermuda at the end of 2001 to take advantage of soaring premium rates and scarce capacity after the destruction of the World Trade Center.

headline.main: ENDURANCE SAYS IT BOUGHT HARTFORD'S REINSURANCE UNIT

Insurance Liability.mainheadline: ENDURANCE SAYS IT BOUGHT HARTFORD'S REINSURANCE UNIT

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: The Marsh & McLennan Companies, the insurance broker, said yesterday that it was forming a new company to deal with industry cutbacks in coverage that have occurred since the Sept. 11 attacks. The new firm, to be called Axis Specialty Ltd., is being created to capitalize on the shortage of services as insurance companies are hit by losses stemming from the attacks, Marsh & McLennan said. The attacks are expected to be the most expensive disaster for the insurance industry, with costs expected to exceed the record $20 billion payout from Hurricane Andrew in 1992.

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration will release about $2 billion in federal assistance to cover costs stemming from the attack on the World Trade Center, according to three members of the state's Congressional delegation. Senator Charles E. Schumer, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative James T. Walsh said the money would be used to cover Police Department and Fire Department expenses, defray the cost of insurance for contractors and pay for other expenses not covered under a federal aid package. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank sued New York State yesterday, contending that the state was negligent in failing to protect the bank's headquarters building, at 130 Liberty Street, after the collapse of the World Trade Center towers. The lawsuit follows the dismissal last month of a similar complaint against New York City. Both actions were filed in United States District Court in Manhattan. A spokeswoman for the bank said the lawsuit was required by the bank's insurance policies on the building, which was severely damaged by debris from the World Trade Center. The bank wants to tear down the building and is fighting two of its insurers, which say the building can be repaired and reoccupied. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

Thompson Jr., confirmed yesterday what New York businesspeople have been saying for more than a year: insurance prices are soaring. But Mr. Thompson said a survey he conducted shows that insurance prices have risen more in New York than elsewhere in the country, and he asserted that insurers were taking advantage of the city.

headline.main: Insurers Are Taking Advantage Of New York, City Official Says

Insurance Liability.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court yesterday upheld jury verdicts requiring insurance companies to pay the developer Larry A. Silverstein an extra $1.1 billion to rebuild the World Trade Center complex. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit said it found no error that would require it to set aside the verdicts. Mr. Silverstein, who had insured the twin towers for $3.5 billion, had sought to recover twice that amount, arguing that there were two attacks. In one trial that ended in April 2004, a federal jury found that most of the insurers, holding more than $1.8 billion of the policy, were bound by a form that defined the destruction of the twin towers as a single event. In a second trial, which ended in December 2004, another jury concluded that nine insurance companies were bound by insurance form language that defined the destruction as two events. That verdict meant that Mr. Silverstein will get $1.1 billion, on top of his $3.5 billion, to rebuild.

Iraq and Saddam Hussein.lead_paragraph: Bush administration officials on Thursday played down the significance of an Iraqi effort to avert war by holding last-ditch negotiations with Washington through a back channel in the weeks before the war began in March. Top Iraqi intelligence officials tried to open a secret communications channel with the administration, according to intermediaries and others familiar with the channel. The Iraqis told a Lebanese-American businessman that they no longer had any illicit weapons, that Baghdad would allow American experts to conduct an independent search and that Saddam Hussein would turn over a suspect in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing.

The suit, filed in United States District Court in Manhattan, seeks more than a trillion dollars in damages for the wrongful death of 300 Americans and injuries to 1,100. The victims include people who were in the World Trade Center or the Pentagon; on the hijacked planes that crashed into them or into a field in Shanksville, Pa.; and rescuers.

''Immediately after September the 11th, there was quite a fall-off in the incidents over the no-fly zones,'' said Mr. Hoon, who spoke to reporters aboard Defense Secretary Donald H. Iraq and Saddam Hussein.lead_paragraph: As the Iraqi insurgency intensified in early 2004, an elite Special Operations forces unit converted one of Saddam Hussein's former military bases near Baghdad into a top-secret detention center. There, American soldiers made one of the former Iraqi government's torture chambers into their own interrogation cell. They named it the Black Room. In the windowless, jet-black garage-size room, some soldiers beat prisoners with rifle butts, yelled and spit in their faces and, in a nearby area, used detainees for target practice in a game of jailer paintball. Their intention was to extract information to help hunt down Iraq's most-wanted terrorist, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, according to Defense Department personnel who served with the unit or were briefed on its operations.

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: In the most tangible way yet, the site of the former World Trade Center began its slow metamorphosis into something more than a place of loss: commuters returned aboard the PATH train. Last Sunday, the ceremonial reopening of the rebuilt World Trade Center station was mostly attended by the important and the curious. But by Monday, the station was filled with the suited, workaday crowds of Lower Manhattan. A few cried as they gripped the station's latticework walls and stared at ground zero, but others just charged up the escalators to get to work. Michael Luo

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: With the city's permission, a twin-engine plane from EarthData International flies almost daily over the World Trade Center site. The plane is equipped with an instrument that can detect small changes in the amount of heat coming to the surface. After flying over other parts of Lower Manhattan to measure normal temperatures, the plane heads for the site, where the instrument registers any temperature difference higher than 1.8 degrees. The hot spots shown are hotter than normal by about 60 degrees or more. STEVE DUENES

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, became the latest official yesterday to visit ground zero with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in the months since the terrorist attack. The almost daily visits by lawmakers, celebrities and world leaders are part of the mayor's strategy to shock people with the severity of the devastation -- particularly those in a position to influence the flow of money to the city -- a strategy that appears to be working.

headline.main: A Visit to Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: A Visit to Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: With smaller and smaller pieces of debris being excavated from the World Trade Center site, it is getting harder for salvage crews to sort through them for recognizable objects. So Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that about 70 police officers and firefighters would be added to the crews at the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island, where the debris is sent, that are searching for remains, possessions and anything else that could help identify victims of the terror attack or advance the criminal investigation of it. The searchers -- about 40 or 50 police officers and 25 firefighters -- will join more than 200 workers already there. Andy Newman (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Workers Added At Landfill

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Workers Added At Landfill

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Three coin-sized human bone fragments were found Wednesday night on the roof of a building near the World Trade Center site, the authorities said yesterday. It was unclear if the bones came from the same person. Construction workers found them shortly before 7 p.m. on the rooftop of 130 Liberty Street, on the southern edge of the excavation site. The fragments will be tested to determine if they match DNA samples provided by relatives of those killed Sept. 11. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More 9/11 Remains Found

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More 9/11 Remains Found

Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that they would press the federal government for future aid to New York for its recovery from the terrorist attack last fall. In addition to seeking money to study the health of workers at ground zero, the senators said they had introduced legislation to extend unemployment insurance to June 1, 2003, for eligible New Yorkers, and would push legislation to forgive student loans for spouses of those killed or permanently disabled in the attack. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Senators Seek More 9/11 Aid

Egan and Archbishop Leonardo Sandri, representing Pope John Paul II, placed flowers at the World Trade Center site yesterday and announced a Vatican-sponsored scholarship fund for the children of victims of the Sept. 11 attack. Cardinal Egan said the fund -- an undisclosed amount -- would benefit the children of police officers, firefighters, emergency workers and health care workers who died on Sept. 11 if they wished to study medicine at New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y.

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: The city will mark the end of its efforts to recover human remains from the rubble of the World Trade Center today with a ceremony at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, where more than a million and a half tons of debris have been sifted for clues. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Gov. George E. Pataki and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly are expected to speak at the ceremony, which is scheduled for 9:30 a.m.

headline.main: Search for Remains Ends With Ceremony

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city had begun planning a ceremony for when the cleanup at ground zero ends. The ceremony would be for those who died in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and those who have labored at the site. The site will be shut down sometime in late May, Mr. Bloomberg said, depending on the weather and other factors. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Members of several families who lost relatives in the Sept. 11 terror attack plan to hold their own ceremony on June 2, a Sunday, to mark the end of efforts to recover remains from ground zero. The city, which will hold its official ceremony next Thursday, will issue a permit to the group as long as it complies with safety regulations, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Mr. Bloomberg has pointed out that next Thursday was chosen because it will not interfere with religious observances, while the families want a weekend observance. Mr. Bloomberg said he did not know if he would be invited to the group's ceremony, but he added that ''if people want to have other days that's perfectly appropriate.'' Diane Cardwell (NYT)

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called for several measures yesterday to help improve air quality near the World Trade Center site, including requirements for reducing emissions from heavy-duty construction vehicles there. Senator Clinton, who conducted a hearing yesterday at the United States Customs House, near the site, also called for the federal government to track the health of people who have worked or lived at or near ground zero. She also urged the city to expand testing of indoor air quality in Lower Manhattan. Andy Newman (NYT)

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: The remains of 3 firefighters were uncovered at the World Trade Center site yesterday, a day after the remains of at least 11 were unearthed in the biggest find in weeks. Firefighter Louis Giaconelli, a department spokesman, said that none of those discovered yesterday had been identified. He said two of the firefighters uncovered on Tuesday were identified as Michael F. Lynch and John Tipping II, both 33. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: The Fire Department has banned fire companies from rushing to ground zero when a firefighter's remains are found. Firefighters had developed an informal policy of going to the site in keeping with the tradition in which firefighters carry their fallen brethren from the scene of a disaster. In explaining the new policy, reported yesterday in The Daily News, Deputy Commissioner Francis X. Gribbon said the department was seeking to maintain order. ''We are trying to keep an official notification process, where a body is removed respectfully by those who are at the site,'' he said.

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- The car was unloaded by midafternoon, heat rising off the concrete in the vast stadium parking lot on a stifling day in mid-June when burgers might have grilled on the ground. Richard Mize had come early to tailgate and ponder a rare Royals game that had the feel of a special occasion. ''Greinke pitching against us tonight,'' he said, referring to Milwaukee's Zack Greinke, a former Cy Young Award winner with the Royals who lobbied hard after the 2010 season to be traded from one of baseball's worst teams. ''Should be pretty good.''

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: The federal official overseeing the controversial cleanup and environmental testing of apartments near ground zero has submitted her resignation. In a letter dated Oct. 12, the official, Jane M. Kenny, said she would leave her job as the Environmental Protection Agency's Region 2 administrator on Nov. 12 for a ''new opportunity,'' but was not more specific. Ms. Kenny, who was appointed to her post in 2001, has rejected claims that residents and workers were allowed to return to the area around ground zero too soon. She also oversaw the cleanup and testing of thousands of apartments in Lower Manhattan, some of which will have to be retested.

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: For some fans of Antoni Gaudí, the towers going up at the World Trade Center site are a sad reminder of what might have been. The Catalan architect may be best known for Barcelona's Sagrada Família, a neo-gothic cathedral that looks as if it's melting, but in 1908 he designed a pearlescent, glass-studded spaceship of a hotel, which would at that time have been the world's tallest building, for the site that is now ground zero. Although it's unclear whether construction of such a skyscraper was feasible then, Hotel Attraction was intended to rise almost as high as the Empire State Building would 23 years later. In 2003, Spanish artists advocated building it as a 9/11 memorial and a ''present from Barcelona, like the Statue of Liberty.'' An American architect, Paul Laffoley, joined the campaign, saying the hotel could become the New York symbol Gaudí intended.

headline.main: The Historical Record

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: The Historical Record

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam -- Construction crews got as far as the first floor of what was to be Saigon Residence, a high-end apartment building in the center of Ho Chi Minh City. All that remains today of the abandoned project are piles of moldy bricks, rusting steel rods and a small team of security guards who have transformed the cement foundation into a parking lot for motorcycles.In Vietnam 's major cities, a once-booming property market has come crashing down. Hundreds of abandoned construction sites are the most obvious signs of a sickly economy.

headline.main: Property Crash in Vietnam's Cities Drags Down Nation's Economy

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Property Crash in Vietnam's Cities Drags Down Nation's Economy

headline.seo: Trinity Church, a Sanctuary for Music, Cuts Back

headline.print_headline: Churchly Sanctuary For Music Cuts Back

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Churchly Sanctuary for Music Cuts Back

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: The financial dispute that has hobbled construction of the museum at ground zero for eight months entered a new stage this week with a struggle over who will control the overall memorial and the eight-acre site. The Sept. 11 memorial foundation, which is led by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has been responsible for the planning, development and programming of the memorial at the trade center site, as well as the visitor center and the National Sept. 11 Memorial and Museum, under a 2006 agreement. The foundation, which has raised $430 million in private donations, has also controlled the site and overseen annual events commemorating the deaths of nearly 3,000 people in the terrorist attack.

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: In Latest Phase of Ground Zero Building Dispute, a New Call for Oversight

headline.print_headline: Islam Center Offers Look At Its Design

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: First Look Inside the Proposed Islamic Center

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: A report on the exposure of workers and residents near ground zero to toxic dust and chemicals provided new details on health problems they face. The report, based on a study conducted by six research centers on behalf of federal and city government agencies, published in this month's issue of Environmental Health Perspectives, found that fragments of glass and pulverized cement, breathed first by firefighters and later by cleanup workers, had caused severe coughs and asthma. The report also said the exposure had increased the risk of mesothelioma, a type of cancer associated with inhaling asbestos. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Health Report On Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Health Report On Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: WHAT functions can we eliminate? What uses can we subtract? These seem to me among the most constructive questions that can be asked today about the planning of ground zero, particularly about cultural programming. Up to now, the planners have been thinking along opposite lines. How much can we add, they ask, as if an accumulation of functions is needed to produce the desired lively effect. Opera house, museum, and so on: these proposals are signs of cultural failure. At best, they denote impatience to arrive at some creative response that really requires more time and thought. More ominously, they represent distractions from the forces that have mired ground zero in politics and propaganda.

headline.main: Back to Basics: Twin Towers II

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Back to Basics: Twin Towers II

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: A group of family members of World Trade Center victims announced yesterday the formation of the 9/11 Campaign, an effort to raise money for programs that will be associated with the memorial at ground zero. The immediate goal ''is to raise $9,110,000 by Sept. 11 of this year,'' said Monica Iken, founder of September's Mission, a victims' family advocacy group. The money will be used to create an endowment that can finance children's programs, conferences and other educational outreach efforts. Glenn Collins (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Campaign Is Started

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Campaign Is Started

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: A 30-by-60-inch electronic sign over the Cortlandt Street subway station, which consistently broadcasts brief advertisements on the edge of the World Trade Center site, was removed yesterday, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said. Clear Channel Outdoor, which operated it, took it down at the request of the M.T.A. chairman, Peter S. Kalikow, above. ''It was felt that it was not a proper setting, so close to ground zero,'' said Tom Kelly, an authority spokesman. Among those who complained about the sign were Assemblyman Scott Stringer of Manhattan and Stan Simon, who lost a brother and nephew in the 9/11 attack. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sign Removed At Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sign Removed At Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: A group of workers has filed a class-action lawsuit against the companies hired to clean up after the World Trade Center attack. The workers claim they were exposed to toxic fumes and debris at ground zero. The lawsuit, which also names the entities that leased and managed the trade center, was filed on Friday in federal court in Manhattan and announced yesterday. The companies have not yet responded. The plaintiffs also intend to sue the City of New York, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the federal Environmental Protection Agency, David E. Worby, the lawyer for the workers, said. He was joined at a news conference by 13 people who he said had physical ailments directly related to their exposure to what he said were 9/11 toxins. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Workers Sue

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Workers Sue

headline.print_headline: The Joyce Ponders New Sites

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: In one of the haunting legacies of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, the remains of 1,123 of the victims, 41 percent of the total, have not been identified, leaving many of their relatives yearning for closure. At the same time, nearly 10 years later, 9,041 pieces of human remains -- mainly bone fragments but also tissue that has been dehydrated for preservation -- are still being sorted through by the city's medical examiner for DNA, though the last time a connection was made was in 2009. Now, a dispute over what to do with those remains is simmering between some of the victims' families and the officials planning the National September 11 Memorial and Museum underneath where the twin towers stood.

headline.main: An Unsettled Legacy for 9/11 Remains

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: An Unsettled Legacy for 9/11 Remains

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Condé Nast Publications, whose stable of magazines chronicles the American zeitgeist as meticulously as any anthropologist, has reached an agreement to lease one million square feet at 1 World Trade Center, giving ground zero a much-needed corporate anchor with a proven ability to attract other businesses. The company signaled its interest in moving to 1 World Trade Center several months ago. But that was just the beginning of a marathon courtship befitting one of the country's most influential buildings and one of its trend-setting media empires, which went far beyond the typical landlord-tenant transaction.

headline.main: A Stylish Anchor for 1 World Trade Center
