Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Lawyers representing New York City announced yesterday that they would appeal a recent federal decision denying their motion to dismiss thousands of lawsuits brought against the city and private contractors working for the city during the ground zero cleanup. More than 6,000 workers have sued, alleging that the city failed to protect them from toxic pollutants. Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of Federal District Court ruled last month that the city's immunity from such lawsuits was limited, allowing the cases to go forward. ANTHONY DEPALMA

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Appeal In Ground Zero Lawsuit

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Appeal In Ground Zero Lawsuit

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Workers will start dismantling the facade of the former Deutsche Bank building today as a prelude to its demolition, which is to begin in January, the Lower Manhattan Construction Command Center said yesterday. The building stands opposite ground zero at 130 Liberty Street, and was badly damaged and contaminated on Sept. 11, 2001. The command center said workers would dismantle aluminum column covers and windows at the top of the building, moving down from the 39th floor to the 35th. They will cut up the material and wrap it in plastic for removal from the site. DAVID W. DUNLAP

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Demolition To Begin

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Demolition To Begin

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Searchers recovered nine bone fragments that they believe to be human from the World Trade Center haul road along West Street yesterday. Four were found at the site and five others as material was being inspected at a sifting center in Brooklyn, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the chief medical examiner. The bones ranged in size from one to four inches. Since September 2005, 990 human remains have been found around ground zero. DAVID W. DUNLAP

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Remains At Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Remains At Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: A viewing room at the southern edge of ground zero where relatives of 9/11 victims have gathered privately and left mementos since 2002 will be closed on Feb. 27 for excavation and construction, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. It will be replaced. On March 5 a trailer closer to the north end of the World Trade Center site, off Church Street, will take its place. Personal items left in the viewing room will be moved to the trailer by family members. ''We will maintain this special space for as long as we possibly can,'' said the authority's executive director, Anthony E. Shorris, ''in the hope that perhaps some of the families will take solace in the rejuvenation of the site going on around them.'' DAVID W. DUNLAP

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Room To Close

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Room To Close

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: City officials pledged at a City Council hearing yesterday to work with the state, the Signature Theater and the Joyce Theater to produce a feasibility study in eight weeks on cultural development at ground zero. The cultural affairs commissioner, Kate D. Levin, said she hoped to have a better sense of the artistic programming, construction costs and a timetable in the next two months. The Joyce, which presents dance, will be the sole occupant of a performing arts center at the ground zero site; the Signature Theater was supposed to share the center, but is considering a move into nearby Fiterman Hall because sharing seems too complicated. ROBIN POGREBIN

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cultural Development Studied For Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cultural Development Studied For Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: The Sept. 11 anniversary remembrance will not be held at its original location at ground zero this year because construction on the site has made it unsafe for a large public gathering, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The ceremony will be held at a plaza near the southeast corner of the site. Some family members of victims have protested, but the mayor said that the decision was final and that ''it would be a big shame'' if anyone skipped the event out of anger.

headline.main: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Ceremony To Relocate

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Ceremony To Relocate

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed yesterday to contribute $3 million to the Tribute Center, the temporary 9/11 memorial that is scheduled to open in the spring at 120 Liberty Street, near the World Trade Center site. The center's Introductory/Orientation Gallery will be named for the Port Authority, and Port Authority employees will lead tours of the site from there. Supporting the center ''is in line with our mission of revitalizing Lower Manhattan and redeveloping the World Trade Center site,'' said James Connors, a Port Authority executive. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Port Authority Gives To 9/11 Memorial

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Port Authority Gives To 9/11 Memorial

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Most construction work can resume at the new headquarters of Goldman Sachs near ground zero, an official in the Department of Buildings said Saturday, a day after an architect was critically injured in an accident there. The department lifted a full stop-work order, but left in place a partial one forbidding crane operations, according to Robin Brooks, a spokeswoman for the department. She said the department was investigating a nylon sling that is believed to have snapped, allowing seven tons of steel studs to plummet about 13 floors from a crane and crush a trailer that sat on the building's scaffolding.

headline.main: Most Work to Resume at Goldman Site

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Most Work to Resume at Goldman Site

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Initial tests at 53 apartments and in the common areas of nine buildings within 1,500 feet of ground zero found three dust samples that were contaminated with asbestos above safe levels and 71 samples that were laced with lead that exceeded federal standards, environmental officials said yesterday. The spaces were tested under a controversial program of the Environmental Protection Agency. Since the testing began this year, most of the 5,600 samples the agency has analyzed have fallen below federal benchmarks for exposure. Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the agency, said that 272 apartments and 25 buildings below Canal Street will be tested within the next year, and any contamination will be cleaned. Complete test results can be seen at www.epa.gov /wtc/testandclean.

headline.main: Metro Briefing: New York: Manhattan: Environmental Tests Downtown

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing: New York: Manhattan: Environmental Tests Downtown

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: SOMEWHERE in the wilds of Fresh Kills, within view of a Gold's Gym and a shuttered movie house that sit on service roads to the West Shore Expressway, the trash fears of Staten Island are still alive. The fears are embodied by the Staten Island Transfer Station, a warehouse-style building soon to open on the site of the former Fresh Kills landfill. And though the building is an innocuous midnight blue, in the eyes of many islanders, its purpose is ominous and unwelcome.

headline.main: STREET LEVEL: Fresh Kills; The Dump Was Closed, But the Rancor Never Ends

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: STREET LEVEL: Fresh Kills; The Dump Was Closed, But the Rancor Never Ends

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: For the first time, the federal government is financing health care treatments for thousands of firefighters, police officers and other first responders sickened by their work at ground zero in the weeks after the attack on the twin towers. The Bush administration announced yesterday how it will disburse $75 million in health care funds it had attempted to rescind until members of New York's Congressional delegation objected. The money will go to several screening and treatment programs, including one at Mount Sinai Medical Center that has examined more than 10,000 workers and ground zero volunteers. The money will also help finance the Fire Department's medical treatment program, a Police Department mental health program and the city department of health's World Trade Center Health Registry. ANTHONY DEPALMA (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Money For Ground Zero Workers' Treatment

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Money For Ground Zero Workers' Treatment

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Officials have identified the remains of Harry Blanding Jr., a victim of the World Trade Center attack, through DNA testing, the medical examiner's office announced yesterday. Mr. Blanding, 38, of Blakeslee, Pa., was a claims analyst. Officials have identified 1,598 of the 2,749 people who died in the attack, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Victim's Remains Identified

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Victim's Remains Identified

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: With mounting evidence that exposure to the toxic smoke and ash at ground zero during the nine-month cleanup has made many people sick, attention is now focusing on the role of air-filtering masks, or respirators, that cost less than $50 and could have shielded workers from some of the toxins. More than 150,000 such masks were distributed and only 40,000 people worked on the pile, but most workers either did not have the masks or did not use them.

headline.main: Use of Air Masks at Issue In Claims of 9/11 Illnesses

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Use of Air Masks at Issue In Claims of 9/11 Illnesses

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: The search for human remains on the roof of a vacant skyscraper near ground zero, suspended more than two months ago by environmental officials, is scheduled to resume tomorrow, officials said. Workers wearing protective masks will continue removing toxic materials and searching for remains on the roof of the former Deutsche Bank building, which was badly damaged on Sept. 11, 2001, said John Gallagher, spokesman for the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The Environmental Protection Agency suspended work on the roof in April, citing the corporation for failing to properly protect workers from asbestos, but said in June that work could resume.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Search For Remains

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Search For Remains

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Schumer asked the Defense Department yesterday to assign a specialized military team to assist in identifying human remains found at a building near the site of the World Trade Center. Hundreds of bone fragments have been found at the Deutsche Bank building, which is being prepared for demolition. Many of the fragments are tiny, some as small as one-sixteenth of an inch. In a letter to the defense secretary, Mr. Schumer asked the department to assign one of the teams that specialize in identifying the remains of missing soldiers to assist the city medical examiner's office.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Help Sought On Remains

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Help Sought On Remains

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: The rooftop cleanup at the former Deutsche Bank building opposite ground zero has been suspended by the federal Environmental Protection Agency until regulators meet with the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which is overseeing demolition of the heavily contaminated tower. On March 31 and April 19, inspectors found ''visible debris and residual fines commingled with the roof ballast'' in areas that were supposedly clean, said Pat Evangelista, the agency's World Trade Center coordinator, in an April 27 letter to the corporation. (Fines are tiny particles.) The corporation said it voluntarily stopped the cleanup on April 20 after a ''fragment of asbestos-containing material'' was discovered in the ballast during the search for human remains from 9/11. The corporation's spokesman, John P. Gallagher, said that the finding should not pose a health risk to workers. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Cleanup Halted

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Cleanup Halted

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: A construction manager is being sought for the memorial and memorial museum at ground zero, under a request for proposals issued yesterday by the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. John C. Whitehead, the chairman of both groups, said the manager would help ensure that construction starts early next year, sticks to a three-year timetable and stays within its budget, estimated at $500 million. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the site, said that it would not submit a proposal but ''would be willing to serve as construction manager if asked.'' David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Manager Sought For Memorial

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Manager Sought For Memorial

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: A piece of landing gear, apparently from one of the jets that crashed into the twin towers on Sept. 11, 2001, was discovered wedged between two buildings on Wednesday.

headline.main: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero
headline.print_headline: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: The city has stopped construction on an office tower near ground zero after a chunk of steel fell 18 stories onto a ball field where children were playing on Saturday afternoon. The Department of Buildings said no one was hurt in the accident at 200 Murray Street, where the Goldman Sachs headquarters is under construction. The builder, Tishman Construction, was cited with five violations.

headline.main: Steel Falls 18 Floors Onto Field

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Steel Falls 18 Floors Onto Field

headline.main: Comments Of the Week

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Companies, universities and lawmakers in the United States are preparing for a world in which remote-controlled planes will be ubiquitous in civilian air space.

headline.seo: Domestic Drones on Patrol
headline.main: Domestic Drones Stir Imaginations, and Concerns
headline.print_headline: Domestic Drones on Patrol

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Domestic Drones Stir Imaginations, and Concerns

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: On July Fourth two years ago, eight weeks before the Republican National Convention in New York City, Gov. George E. Pataki traveled from the Hamptons summer home of his senior economic adviser, Charles A. Gargano, to the dusty crater in the center of Lower Manhattan. Draped in the symbolism of Independence Day, the two men descended into the baking-hot pit at ground zero. There they oversaw the ceremonial laying of a 20-ton Adirondack granite cornerstone -- flecked with garnet, the state gem -- for what was to be the first building to rise at the new World Trade Center: the 1,776-foot Freedom Tower.

headline.main: The Hole in the City's Heart

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: The Hole in the City's Heart

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of emergency responders will stage an emergency drill this weekend at ground zero. The drill, which will take place on Sunday morning, will simulate a response to an explosion at a PATH commuter rail train in the tunnel between the World Trade Center site and northern New Jersey.

headline.main: Rescue Drill at Ground Zero on Sunday

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Rescue Drill at Ground Zero on Sunday

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: An Our Towns column last Thursday described Michael Bellone, a former nightclub bouncer who worked as a volunteer with firefighters and the police at ground zero in Lower Manhattan for months after Sept. 11, 2001. He helped recover the remains of victims and, as part of an effort to keep alive the memory, now has a fire truck that bears the names of all 343 members of the Fire Department who died that day. The column omitted one pertinent element of Mr. Bellone's relationship with the Fire Department. As other news organizations reported at the time, he was briefly arrested in 2005 and accused of misrepresenting himself and using official equipment illegally as part of presentations on the disaster to school children and others. The Manhattan District Attorney's office decided on the day of his arrest not to prosecute him, and the equipment was returned to the Fire Department.

headline.main: Postscript

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Postscript

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, yesterday endorsed a resolution that called for the future World Trade Center memorial to list the names of firefighters, police officers and rescue workers separately from those of other victims of the Sept. 11 attacks. The resolution asks Gov. George E. Pataki and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to honor rescue workers by listing them together, by department, including rank, badge number and unit ''in the context within which they gave their lives.'' The current guidelines for the memorial competition say there should be no hierarchy in listing the victims. Winnie Hu (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Proposal For Names On 9/11 Memorial

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Proposal For Names On 9/11 Memorial

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: A painter at ground zero died while working at the site, and the cause of death is unclear, a Port Authority official said. The painter, Hugo V. Martinez, 36, of Long Island, who worked for L & L Painting, was the first worker to die at the site of the World Trade Center since September 11, 2001, said the spokesman, Pasquale DiFulco. Mr. Martinez was found early Tuesday morning, shortly after midnight, he said. The Port Authority police and the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration are investigating the death. Tina Kelley (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Worker Dies

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Worker Dies

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: While high-profile architectural firms have offered competing proposals for the World Trade Center site, students from Stuyvesant High School, just blocks from ground zero, have formed an after-school club to offer their own ideas. The club, Stuyvesant Rebuilds, met once a week last semester to discuss the architectural and environmental issues they might face in redesigning Lower Manhattan. Guest speakers included MITCHELL MOSS, a professor of urban planning at New York University, and HUGH O'NEILL, a former assistant executive director of the Port Authority. The students will build a model conforming to architectural guidelines from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation next semester and plan to submit it for review in the spring. Mark Glassman

headline.main: Tackling Trade Center Design

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Tackling Trade Center Design

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: A Scarsdale-based Web site that provides listings of part-time and temporary jobs is offering free postings to businesses in an effort to help families affected by the attack on the World Trade Center. The site, ePartTimeJobs (www.eparttimejobs.com), hopes the free postings will help those who may have to work now that their loved ones are gone. Job seekers can continue to post résumés at no charge, as they had before.

headline.main: Free Job Postings to Aid Those Affected by Attacks

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Free Job Postings to Aid Those Affected by Attacks

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: PATH stations in Jersey City and lower Manhattan, closed since the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, will reopen this year and will eventually become part of a hub in Lower Manhattan that will link trains, subways, ferry service and buses to accommodate commuters and visitors to the planned memorial at Ground Zero. The Exchange Place station in New Jersey is to reopen in June and the Ground Zero station in December, Port Authority officials said last week. Karen DeMasters

headline.main: PATH STATIONS TO REOPEN

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: PATH STATIONS TO REOPEN

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: A jury has acquitted a city engineer who was charged with assaulting Port Authority police officers during a scuffle at ground zero last year. The engineer, Michael Kenny, 41, faced up to one year in jail before the jury cleared him in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday. Mr. Kenny, who works for the Department of Design and Construction, which oversees the ground zero cleanup, was accused of interfering with the arrest of a laborer involved in a dispute with the officers. Mr. Kenny resisted arrest, the complaint said. Last Friday, he testified that he was trying to help a man and did not know he was interfering with an arrest. Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Cleared In Ground Zero Scuffle

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Cleared In Ground Zero Scuffle

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: More than 100 firefighters protested outside a book reading last night by William Langewiesche, author of a best selling account of the cleanup operation at ground zero. The reading from ''American Ground,'' a book based on Mr. Langewiesche's observations and interviews, was part of a series at the South Street Seaport Museum. Protesters near the museum entrance waved placards calling Mr. Langewiesche a liar, and some complained bitterly of a brief section in the book implying that firefighters might have engaged in looting. ''The author of this book is a disgrace,'' Peter Gorman, president of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association, said at the rally. Mr. Langewiesche said he had written ''frankly,'' using information from ''sources who proved reliable over months.'' Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Protest Over Ground Zero Book

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Protest Over Ground Zero Book

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: The fathers of two victims of the attack on the World Trade Center presented pieces of steel from the site to officials in Somerset County, Pa., for inclusion in the permanent memorial to be built at the site where United Flight 93 crashed. Tom Johnson's son Scott worked on the 88th floor of the south tower, and Lee Ielpi's son Jonathan was a firefighter with Squad 288. The fathers traveled to the crash site with representatives of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation who are visiting memorial sites across the country as part of their planning for the memorial at the trade center site. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Pennsylvania Memorial To Include Steel From Trade Center Site

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Pennsylvania Memorial To Include Steel From Trade Center Site

Ground Zero Cleanup.lead_paragraph: Workers excavating a manhole at ground zero yesterday found human remains, including bones big enough to be arm or leg bones, officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said. The medical examiner's office is trying to determine whether the remains belong to victims of the World Trade Center attack. Con Edison workers and a private contractor found the remains in abandoned manholes on the north edge of the site, the Port Authority said. Con Edison said that more debris that had been dug up on Tuesday and hauled to a Con Edison property on West 28th Street also turned out to contain human remains, which were turned over to the medical examiner's office. ANDY NEWMAN (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Remains Found At Ground Zero

Ground Zero Cleanup.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Remains Found At Ground Zero

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Months of architectural wrangling over plans for the tallest building at the World Trade Center site -- and in the world -- have apparently ended in a 1,776-foot compromise that would include an asymmetrical spire favored by Daniel Libeskind rising atop a cable-framed wind farm proposed by David M. Childs. Though the design will not be made public until Friday, an announcement yesterday by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation seemed to indicate that agreement had been reached on the broad outlines of the building, called Freedom Tower.

headline.main: Trade Tower To Reflect Compromise

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Trade Tower To Reflect Compromise

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields, said yesterday that she had created emergency grants for shops, restaurants and other small businesses below Canal Street in danger of closing. The $30,000 fund will be administered by the Manhattan Borough Development Corporation. To be eligible for a $1,500 grant, a business must have been open for three years. Terry Pristin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Emergency Business Grants

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Emergency Business Grants

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday announced a $20 million program to provide grants of up to $10,000 for small and medium-size businesses hurt by the Sept. 11 terror attack. Owners of retail businesses with fewer than 50 employees and who intend to remain in New York will be eligible. The Empire State Development Corporation will review applications and disburse grants within 10 days at a center at 199 Church Street. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Grants For Retail Businesses

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Grants For Retail Businesses

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Officials last week announced plans to to rebuild the PATH system in Lower Manhattan using $4.55 billion released by the federal government. The plans include a new terminal near the World Trade Center site, with moving walkways to the subways, a concourse with shops and restaurants, access to a ferry terminal and a new bus terminal. PATH trains conveyed more than 65,000 commuters a day between New Jersey and Lower Manhattan before Sept. 11. If construction begins by 2004, officials say the terminal could be completed by 2008. A temporary PATH station for New York-bound commuters at the trade center site is expected to open by December 2003. John Holl

headline.main: PATH REBUILDING

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: PATH REBUILDING

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Sidney J. Caspersen, who was an F.B.I. agent at the World Trade Center site when it was struck by the second hijacked plane, was named as the state's antiterror chief last week. Mr. Caspersen, 54 and a Fanwood resident, will leave his job as deputy director of the New York State Office of Public Security. He succeeds Kathryn Flicker, who announced that she would step down on Sept. 30.

headline.main: State Antiterror Chief

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: State Antiterror Chief

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation appointed Anita F. Contini as vice president and director for its memorial, cultural and civic programs yesterday. Ms. Contini will be responsible for overseeing the development of a memorial for victims of the terrorist attack of Sept. 11 at the former site of the World Trade Center. In addition, she will coordinate efforts to bring cultural institutions to Lower Manhattan. Since 1999, she has served as a first vice president for global sponsorships and events marketing at Merrill Lynch. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Memorial Chief

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Memorial Chief

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The city is repaving the streets on roughly 240 city blocks in Lower Manhattan that were damaged by heavy trucks carting away debris from the World Trade Center site, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The project, which is to be completed by June 1, is being paid for by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Officials said that roughly two-thirds of the streets will have to be ripped up again and repaved later, as the supporting infrastructure below them is replaced. Michael Cooper (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Road Repair

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Road Repair

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: City Council members have scolded representatives of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the agency overseeing rebuilding of the World Trade Center site, for not having a more racially and ethnically diverse board and staff. Council members also said on Monday that they wanted a greater voice in planning the redevelopment. James Sanders Jr., chairman of the Council's Committee on Economic Development, said the agency's 11-member board did not resemble ''the city that it hopes to rebuild.'' Louis Tomson, executive director of the agency, said he would work harder to recruit more women and minorities. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Site Group Criticized

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Site Group Criticized

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Grants up to $50,000 and monthly rent subsidies of up to $5,000 for small businesses hurt by the Sept. 11 terror attack were proposed yesterday to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The roughly $200 million required for the initiative would come from federal Community Development Block Grants. Councilman Alan J. Gerson, above, one of the plan's supporters, said that too much aid had gone to businesses with revenues of more than $1 million. Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid Urged for Small Businesses

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid Urged for Small Businesses

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: A New Jersey company has been hired to install a 500-foot-long temporary bridge at the World Trade Center site. The two-lane bridge, which is to cost about $2 million, will let trucks climb in and out of the site's seven-story pit. Trucks now drive precariously on muddy roads that are supported by packed debris. The bridge will be installed over the next six to eight weeks to aid the final stages of the cleanup. It will be built by Acrow Corporation of Carlstadt, N.J., and run parallel to West Street. It will also be used to help with any rebuilding at the site. Eric Lipton (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bridge Set For Ground Zero

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bridge Set For Ground Zero

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The financial dispute that has hobbled construction of the museum at ground zero for eight months entered a new stage this week with a struggle over who will control the overall memorial and the eight-acre site. The Sept. 11 memorial foundation, which is led by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has been responsible for the planning, development and programming of the memorial at the trade center site, as well as the visitor center and the National Sept. 11 Memorial and Museum, under a 2006 agreement. The foundation, which has raised $430 million in private donations, has also controlled the site and overseen annual events commemorating the deaths of nearly 3,000 people in the terrorist attack.

headline.main: In Latest Phase of Ground Zero Building Dispute, a New Call for Oversight

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: In Latest Phase of Ground Zero Building Dispute, a New Call for Oversight

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: A committee of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation on Wednesday recommended that the corporation allocate at least $100 million for the performing arts center planned for ground zero. The money would come from a pool of some $200 million formerly designated for utility companies. At the corporation's board meeting on Wednesday, Kate D. Levin, the New York City cultural affairs commissioner, said the money was important ''to fulfill this critical part of the master plan.'' The financing, which requires approval by the full board, would add to $50 million in federal money set aside for the project, which is controlled by the development corporation. Still unresolved is whether to build the center on the World Trade Center site, as called for in the master plan, or at 130 Liberty Street, site of the former Deutsche Bank building. The center's primary tenant is to be the Joyce Theater, which presents dance.

headline.main: Arts At Ground Zero: $100 Million or More?

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Arts At Ground Zero: $100 Million or More?

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The state has received 688 entries in a competition to find a design for a memorial to the nearly 700 New Jersey residents killed in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, officials announced yesterday. A professional advisory committee will narrow the field of contestants to several finalists, said an administration spokeswoman, Ellen Mellody. A panel of family members of victims and survivors will choose a winning design by July. The memorial will be installed in Liberty State Park, in Jersey City, across from the World Trade Center site.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Entries Received For 9/11 Memorial

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Entries Received For 9/11 Memorial

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: A meeting of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation this week is expected to produce a decision on a cultural component for the World Trade Center site, people involved in the process say. They said the main candidates were the Joyce Theater, which presents dance; the Signature Theater Company; and a Museum of Freedom. Other groups expected to provide programming on the site are the New York Hall of Science in Queens and the Drawing Center, which exhibits historical and contemporary drawings. The decision would bring to a close a competition among cultural institutions that began a year ago with an invitation to arts groups worldwide. The invitation brought 113 proposals in September, which were narrowed to 15 finalists in February. The board of the development corporation is to make its decision in coordination with the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs and the New York State Council on the Arts. ROBIN POGREBIN

headline.main: Ground Zero Decision Expected

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Ground Zero Decision Expected

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Elizabeth H. Berger, who died on Aug. 5, was president of the Downtown Alliance and influenced many projects, like the Fulton Center.

headline.main: Remembering a Zealous Advocate of Lower Manhattan
headline.print_headline: Remembering a Zealous Advocate of Lower Manhattan

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Remembering a Zealous Advocate of Lower Manhattan

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The first great public works project of the 21st century in New York is emerging, proof that we live in an age in which some things actually get done.

headline.seo: Returning Ground Zero to New Yorkers
headline.main: Returning Ground Zero to New Yorkers
headline.print_headline: Returning Ground Zero To New Yorkers

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Returning Ground Zero to New Yorkers

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Christopher O. Ward, who jump-started development of the stalled World Trade Center site and memorial and oversaw a significant toll increase on the Hudson River crossings, intends to resign as executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, according to two people familiar with his plans. Mr. Ward's departure is planned for the end of October. It will create a formidable challenge for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who must now appoint a new chief for two of the most influential agencies under his purview: the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Jay H. Walder, also plans to leave next month, having announced his resignation in July.

headline.main: Director Said To Be Leaving Port Authority Next Month

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Director Said To Be Leaving Port Authority Next Month

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Downtown business leaders propose narrowing Water Street, installing a planted median and redesigning eight acres of public plazas.

headline.seo: Downtown, a Plan to Redefine Water Street
headline.main: Trying to Breathe Life Into a Canyon of Concrete
headline.print_headline: Trying to Breathe Life Into a Canyon of Concrete

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Trying to Breathe Life Into a Canyon of Concrete

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The poll indicated that support for a center planned near ground zero is tepid in its home town.

headline.seo: New Yorkers Divided Over Islamic Center, Poll Finds
headline.main: New York Poll Finds Wariness for Muslim Site
headline.print_headline: New York Poll Finds Wariness for Muslim Site

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: New York Poll Finds Wariness for Muslim Site

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Illuminating a task takes beauty and smarts. So says the architect Daniel Libeskind, who is shrinking his projects.

headline.main: Task Lighting
headline.print_headline: Sweating the Small Stuff

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Task Lighting

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The boundaries of the World Trade Center redevelopment project were expanded yesterday by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to include the 7 World Trade Center parcel immediately to the north, across Vesey Street. This could eventually permit the reopening of Greenwich Street, between Vesey and Barclay Streets, as a two-lane southbound roadway. It is now a dead end, used for drop-offs at 7 World Trade Center. South of Vesey Street, Greenwich Street is to be recreated through the main trade center site as a four-lane southbound roadway. It was closed in the 1960s to make way for the trade center superblock. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: World Trade Center Site Expands

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: World Trade Center Site Expands

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: As an architecture student at Cooper Union three decades ago, Daniel Libeskind watched the World Trade Center being built. ''It was such an inspiring and controversial and wonderful moment,'' Mr. Libeskind said last week -- second only, perhaps, to the moment his design was chosen as the plan to rebuild the trade center. Centered on a recessed memorial to the victims of the 9/11 attack, the plan includes a spiral of buildings rising to a tower standing 1,776 feet -- ''a date or a number,'' he said, ''that will never be surpassed in world history.'' Edward Wyatt

headline.main: DESIGN FOR GROUND ZERO

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: DESIGN FOR GROUND ZERO

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has named Avi Schick the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which is overseeing the rebuilding at ground zero, and has named David Emil the corporation's president. Mr. Schick is president of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's economic development agency, and was a deputy attorney general under Mr. Spitzer. Mr. Emil owned Windows on the World, the restaurant on top of the World Trade Center. Mr. Schick, whose salary in the state job is $213,000, will not be further compensated; Mr. Emil's annual salary will be $185,000. DANNY HAKIM

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Chairman For Development Corporation

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Chairman For Development Corporation

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Saying that the International Freedom Center planned for the World Trade Center site had become ''very controversial,'' Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that he had instructed his appointees to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation board to carefully read the center's new report on how it would operate. ''Then we'll discuss it and try to come to some resolution,'' the mayor said. The center was intended to put 9/11 in the context of the world's history of freedom but it has faced criticism that it would detract from the memorial and deprive the memorial museum of space. Speaking of exhibitions planned for the center, Mr. Bloomberg said, ''Some things you might want to put elsewhere.'' David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor And The Freedom Center

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor And The Freedom Center

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The state agency that owns the former Deutsche Bank building hopes to resume work dismantling it next month, and the delays after a deadly fire should not affect the rebuilding schedule at the World Trade Center site, an agency official said yesterday. Avi Schick, the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, would not estimate the completion date for dismantling the tower, which now stands at 26 stories. Before the fire, the agency had said that the building, heavily damaged by the collapse of the trade center on Sept. 11, would be removed by the end of the year. Work to dismantle the tower floor by floor -- and clean several floors of toxic debris left by the trade center's collapse -- stopped after the Aug. 18 blaze, which killed two firefighters.

headline.main: Manhattan: Bank Dismantling To Resume

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Manhattan: Bank Dismantling To Resume

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Even by the standards of New York City, one of the earliest settlements in North America, 282 years is a long time. That is how long the Collegiate Church Corporation has owned the land where the Corbin Building sits at 11 John Street and Broadway in Lower Manhattan. But on Friday, the land and the building will be taken by eminent domain (along with three other buildings owned by the church) for the new Fulton Street Transit Center. Originally all four buildings were to be demolished, but after a community tussle, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority agreed to incorporate the basement and first floor of the Corbin Building, built in 1888-89, into the design of the station and to leave the rest of the edifice intact.

headline.main: Pressing a Claim for Dutch History

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Pressing a Claim for Dutch History

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: There may be some fine tuning added to the design of the World Trade Center memorial to meet security concerns, the state's top antiterror official, James K. Kallstrom, said yesterday. Mr. Kallstrom, a senior adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki and director of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said that the plans were reviewed months ago by the Police Department and that he did not foresee significant changes, but added that the design might be modified ''so that we can react to whatever threat we're at here in the city.'' At the same corporation board meeting, John C. Whitehead, the chairman, said the waterfalls within the twin memorial voids would be able to run year round. Construction of the memorial is to begin in March. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Design Revisions To 9/11 Memorial

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Design Revisions To 9/11 Memorial

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street will not begin this month, as had been anticipated, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation said yesterday. On Monday, the federal Environmental Protection Agency raised questions about the proposed handling of waste materials containing polychlorinated biphenyls and cadmium in the heavily contaminated 41-story tower opposite ground zero. The corporation hopes to begin demolition later this summer, a spokesman said. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Razing Postponed

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Razing Postponed

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The search for human remains on the roof of a vacant skyscraper near ground zero, suspended more than two months ago by environmental officials, is scheduled to resume tomorrow, officials said. Workers wearing protective masks will continue removing toxic materials and searching for remains on the roof of the former Deutsche Bank building, which was badly damaged on Sept. 11, 2001, said John Gallagher, spokesman for the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The Environmental Protection Agency suspended work on the roof in April, citing the corporation for failing to properly protect workers from asbestos, but said in June that work could resume.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Search For Remains

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Search For Remains

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: A lawsuit by the Coalition of 9/11 Families seeking to compel the preservation of the concrete floor slab where 1 World Trade Center stood has been dismissed by Justice Shirley Werner Kornreich of the State Supreme Court. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the lead defendant, received the decision yesterday. Justice Kornreich said it had been known since April 2004 that the slab would not be subject to historical preservation review, meaning that the lawsuit was filed too late. She wrote that the historical review process ''has been met'' restored text here and that the development corporation had acted in ''a commendable and sensitive manner.'' DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lawsuit Dismissed On Trade Center Floor Slab

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lawsuit Dismissed On Trade Center Floor Slab

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Science Applications International Corporation of San Diego has been chosen to develop a security plan for the World Trade Center redevelopment project, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday. James Kallstrom, a senior adviser to the governor, said the company would provide experts in counterterrorism, law enforcement, intelligence, military affairs, corporate security, emergency services, transportation, engineering and site development. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Security Plan

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Security Plan

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: A construction manager is being sought for the memorial and memorial museum at ground zero, under a request for proposals issued yesterday by the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. John C. Whitehead, the chairman of both groups, said the manager would help ensure that construction starts early next year, sticks to a three-year timetable and stays within its budget, estimated at $500 million. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the site, said that it would not submit a proposal but ''would be willing to serve as construction manager if asked.'' David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Manager Sought For Memorial

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Manager Sought For Memorial

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: A piece of landing gear, apparently from one of the jets that crashed into the twin towers on Sept. 11, 2001, was discovered wedged between two buildings on Wednesday.

headline.main: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero
headline.print_headline: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Residents of Lower Manhattan have until Saturday to apply for up to $14,500 in grants through a federal program meant to increase the residential population of downtown and help the area recover from the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation is administering the $306 million program, which offers grants to residents of three zones in Lower Manhattan. Most of the grants require two years' residency. Details are available at the development corporation's Web site, www.renewnyc.com, or by calling (866) 736-3969. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deadline For Grants

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deadline For Grants

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, yesterday endorsed a resolution that called for the future World Trade Center memorial to list the names of firefighters, police officers and rescue workers separately from those of other victims of the Sept. 11 attacks. The resolution asks Gov. George E. Pataki and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to honor rescue workers by listing them together, by department, including rank, badge number and unit ''in the context within which they gave their lives.'' The current guidelines for the memorial competition say there should be no hierarchy in listing the victims. Winnie Hu (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Proposal For Names On 9/11 Memorial

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Proposal For Names On 9/11 Memorial

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: While high-profile architectural firms have offered competing proposals for the World Trade Center site, students from Stuyvesant High School, just blocks from ground zero, have formed an after-school club to offer their own ideas. The club, Stuyvesant Rebuilds, met once a week last semester to discuss the architectural and environmental issues they might face in redesigning Lower Manhattan. Guest speakers included MITCHELL MOSS, a professor of urban planning at New York University, and HUGH O'NEILL, a former assistant executive director of the Port Authority. The students will build a model conforming to architectural guidelines from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation next semester and plan to submit it for review in the spring. Mark Glassman

headline.main: Tackling Trade Center Design

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Tackling Trade Center Design

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has reopened the exhibit of design concepts for the World Trade Center site. The exhibit, at the World Financial Center Winter Garden, has been reorganized to display the two designs under consideration: Memory Foundations by Studio Daniel Libeskind and the World Cultural Center by the Think team (Shigeru Ban, Frederic Schwartz, Ken Smith and Rafael Viñoly). The exhibit will continue until the end of this month, when a winner will be chosen and displayed through April. The exhibit is open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. daily.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Design Finalists On Display

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Design Finalists On Display

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The fathers of two victims of the attack on the World Trade Center presented pieces of steel from the site to officials in Somerset County, Pa., for inclusion in the permanent memorial to be built at the site where United Flight 93 crashed. Tom Johnson's son Scott worked on the 88th floor of the south tower, and Lee Ielpi's son Jonathan was a firefighter with Squad 288. The fathers traveled to the crash site with representatives of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation who are visiting memorial sites across the country as part of their planning for the memorial at the trade center site. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Pennsylvania Memorial To Include Steel From Trade Center Site

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Pennsylvania Memorial To Include Steel From Trade Center Site

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.lead_paragraph: The president of the agency overseeing the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan warned yesterday that real estate and other business executives were in danger of not being heard. ''You're the people with the most knowledge about what would help,'' Louis R. Tomson, president of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said in a speech sponsored by Commercial Property News. He said discussions of the future of Lower Manhattan were in danger of being dominated by advocates like family members of Sept. 11 victims and area residents. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Speak Up, Executives Are Urged

Rebuilding the World Trade Center.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Speak Up, Executives Are Urged

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Postcards bearing two pictures of Osama bin Laden -- apparently sent by someone seeking to get voters to the polls on Tuesday -- instead sparked anger in Middletown, which lost 37 residents in the terrorist attacks of September 2001. Along with the photos of the leader of Al Qaeda, the postcards says on one side: ''Show the world you don't care about America. Don't vote on Tuesday, Nov. 4.'' Hundreds of people in Middletown and several other nearby Monmouth County towns received the cards. ''It's a pretty sick joke," Police Detective Robert Cullen of Hazlet, who received one at his home on Saturday, told The Asbury Park Press. ''I couldn't believe it.''

headline.main: POSTCARDS FROM THE EDGE

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: POSTCARDS FROM THE EDGE

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton said he "could have killed" Osama bin Laden in remarks to an audience in Australia the day before al Qaeda's 2001 attacks on the United States, according to an audio tape that emerged this week.

headline.main: Tape Emerges of Clinton Discussing Bin Laden Day Before 9/11 Attack
headline.print_headline: Tape Emerges of Clinton Discussing Bin Laden Day Before 9/11 Attack

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: Tape Emerges of Clinton Discussing Bin Laden Day Before 9/11 Attack

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: The Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan, who has embraced the Libyan leader Muammar el-Qaddafi and condemned Zionism, said President Bush should make public the evidence that Osama bin Laden was involved in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. ''The nation would be more secure if you give the American people a reason to fight,'' Mr. Farrakhan said.

headline.main: National Briefing | Religion: Farrakhan Wants Proof

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: National Briefing | Religion: Farrakhan Wants Proof

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Security around the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony in Oslo next month will be heightened as a result of the attacks on the United States and statements by Osama bin Laden, the police say. The winner of the prize is Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, and in a recent videotape Mr. bin Laden called Mr. Annan a ''criminal.''

headline.main: World Briefing | World: Tighter Security For Nobel Peace Ceremony

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: World Briefing | World: Tighter Security For Nobel Peace Ceremony

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: In the videotape released by the United States last week, Osama bin Laden uttered the names of more of the hijackers in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack than previously disclosed, a translator working for the government said tonight. George Michael, who helped provide the Bush administration with the translation that was beamed around the world, said that a more meticulous review of the tape had helped him to discern additional names mentioned by Mr. bin Laden.

headline.main: Tape Review Finds More Plotters Named

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: Tape Review Finds More Plotters Named

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Family members of more than 900 victims of the Sept. 11 attacks filed a lawsuit against three Saudi princes, seven internalional banks operating mainly in the Middle East, eight Islamic foundations and charities and the government of Sudan for allegedly funding Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda. The suit, in federal district court in Washington, is one of several expected in coming months against foreign governments and individuals who may have aided the terrorist network. The defendants named in the lawsuit include Mr. bin Laden and several family members, as well as three members of the Saudi royal family: Turki al Faisal al Saud, Sultan bin Abdul Aziz al Saud and Mohammed al Faisal al Saud.

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: United States: Sept. 11 Survivors Sue

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: World Briefing | Americas: United States: Sept. 11 Survivors Sue

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Some of Osama bin Laden's personal bodyguards have been apprehended and are now being held at the American military base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, government officials said today. The officials said the bodyguards had not been able to provide any conclusive evidence to suggest that Mr. bin Laden was still alive.

headline.main: Bin Laden Guards Held

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: Bin Laden Guards Held

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: The Dutch police today detained four suspected members of an Algerian Islamic group believed to be linked to Osama bin Laden, according to prosecutors. The police in Spain re-arrested a man they said had helped finance Al Qaeda operations. And in Britain, a court dismissed the remaining charges against Lotfi Raissi, a British-based Algerian pilot originally accused by the United States of training the Sept. 11 hijackers.

headline.main: Dutch Detain 4; bin Laden Links Cited

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: Dutch Detain 4; bin Laden Links Cited

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: First, the police in Brooklyn discovered that drug dealers were peddling a brand of heroin called Twin Towers, which officials said appeared soon after Sept. 11. Now authorities in Queens say they have found a brand of the drug called bin Laden, as in Osama. Yesterday, four women were arrested and charged with drug possession after police in Hollis discovered they were carrying cocaine, marijuana and the bin Laden heroin. It was in glassine envelopes with bin Laden in red letters on the front and the image of an airplane heading toward the World Trade Center on the back. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Heroin Named After Bin Laden

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Heroin Named After Bin Laden

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Osama bin Laden was irritable, lonely and in pain just before the terror attacks, according to one of his four wives. In an interview with a London-based Arabic weekly, Al Majallah, the woman, identified only as A.S., said her husband suffered from kidney and stomach pains and told her he wanted to die in Afghanistan. A.S. said she had not heard from her husband since Sept. 11, when she was hiding in a cave in southern Afghanistan before being moved to a secret location in Pakistan by one of Mr. bin Laden's sons. She said he had not talked about the attacks on New York and Washington, but had said he had a ''big plan'' to confront the United States.

headline.main: BIN LADEN'S MOOD

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: BIN LADEN'S MOOD

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: OSAMA BIN LADEN: In the United States, and across those parts of the world that identify their fortunes with America's, it is a name that will live in infamy, synonymous for all time with mass murder. And to those who celebrate America's successes in striking back at the perpetrators of Sept. 11, one of the salutary things to come from that doleful day was the rediscovery of a world united, of nations near and far that pledged support, moral or political or military, for all that was to be done to avenge the crime. And then there is that other world where Osama bin Laden is loved and lauded, where Osama is a favored name for newborn sons and where children play Osama eluding the evil forces of America. These photographs, taken last month, show a world where Mr. bin Laden has also become a marketing tool -- for cologne in Pakistan, for a box of sweets in Afghanistan -- and where hawkers do roaring trade in Osama T-shirts and Osama posters and Osama key-rings.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends: Purchasing Power; When Seeing Osama Is Not Enough

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: Ideas & Trends: Purchasing Power; When Seeing Osama Is Not Enough

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- The Pakistani government appeared Thursday to have moved to expel international staff members at the aid agency Save the Children , apparently over accusations that one of its employees helped the C.I.A. recruit a Pakistani doctor who played a role in tracking Osama bin Laden last year. In a statement issued from its London office early Thursday, Save the Children said the Pakistani Interior Ministry had ordered that ''visas for our six international staff in Pakistan may not be renewed.'' A senior aid official in Pakistan, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the staff members had been given until Sept. 12 to leave the country.

headline.main: Pakistan May Be Expelling Aid Group's Foreign Staff

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: Pakistan May Be Expelling Aid Group's Foreign Staff

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- An American aid expert being held hostage by Al Qaeda in Pakistan was shown making an emotional appeal to President Obama to negotiate for his release in a video released on Monday in what analysts described as a jihadist counter against the wave of publicity that marked the first anniversary of the death of Osama bin Laden. The hostage, Warren Weinstein, a 70-year-old development consultant who was kidnapped in the eastern city of Lahore in August, appeared in the video released on the Internet. Wearing traditional Pakistani clothes, he appealed to Mr. Obama to bow to his captors' demands.

headline.main: Kidnapped American Makes Appeal to Obama in Qaeda Video

Osama Bin Laden.mainheadline: Kidnapped American Makes Appeal to Obama in Qaeda Video

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Gen. Wesley K. Clark asserted that the federal government had not done all it could to thwart either the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks or future such attacks, and that terrorism in this country was not inevitable. ''I think that it's clear that more could have been done to prevent 9/11 than was done,'' General Clark said Friday, speaking to reporters in Lebanon, N.H. He was quoted in Friday's Concord Monitor as saying that ''the two greatest lies'' of the last two years were that the Sept. 11 attacks could not have been prevented and that more attacks were inevitable. He said the fact that the nation's terrorist threat status had been put at ''high'' over the Christmas holidays indicated that President Bush had erred in invading Iraq before Osama bin Laden was captured and his terror network dismantled. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: Al Qaeda's media arm said Thursday that Osama bin Laden planned a new video, to be released in the coming days. The announcement apparently means the video will be released ahead of the sixth anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. The video would be the first new bin Laden images in nearly three years.

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: A Yemeni cleric was arrested in Germany on charges of financing terrorism, and United States prosecutors charged that he used a Brooklyn mosque to raise millions of dollars for Osama bin Laden. The cleric, Sheik Muhammad Ali Hassan al-Mouyad, told an F.B.I. informant that he was Mr. bin Laden's spiritual adviser, and authorities said they traced suspicious bank deposits to five people associated with the Al Farooq mosque in Brooklyn. The mosque, which denied any knowledge of the plot, is the same one where Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman -- convicted in the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center -- served as imam in 1990. Eric Lichtblau

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: In a new videotape posted on the Internet on Tuesday, Osama bin Laden reasserted his role as the planner of the Sept. 11 attacks and declared that Zacarias Moussaoui had played no role in the 2001 plot. Mr. Moussaoui was sentenced May 4 to life in federal prison for failing to warn American authorities of the attacks. He had told jurors that he had conspired with Richard Reid, the so-called shoe bomber, to fly a plane into the White House on the day of the hijackings, but American intelligence officials have said there was no evidence to support that claim.

headline.main: Bin Laden Is Said to Talk Of Moussaoui

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: A man who said he had two one-on-one meetings with Osama bin Laden a few months before the Sept. 11 terror attacks pleaded guilty today to aiding Al Qaeda, the terrorist organization. The defendant, Sahim Alwan, was the fourth of the ''Lackawanna six'' -- six young Yemeni-Americans from the Buffalo area -- to plead guilty to charges that they attended Al Farooq, a training camp run by Al Qaeda in Afghanistan. As part of a plea agreement, Mr. Alwan, 30, pleaded guilty to one count of providing material assistance to a terrorist group.

Osama Bin Laden.lead_paragraph: An audiotaped message broadcast earlier this week that was said to be the voice of Osama bin Laden is ''probably'' authentic, an official at the Central Intelligence Agency said today. The conclusion was reached after sophisticated voice analysis, but did not determine when the message was recorded, the official said.

In a poignant ceremony, President Barack Obama dedicated the museum, saying it's a symbol of America that says: "Nothing can ever break us."

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki unveiled a memorial for the victims of the World Trade Center attack yesterday at the New York State Museum. The exhibits will open to the public on Nov. 23. Tiny aluminum tiles suspended from the ceiling in the shape of the towers will each represent one of the victims. The memorial will also include a plaque and artifacts from the scene.

A tribute ''of some kind'' will occur in the hour before the show's start, Salt Lake Organizing Committee President Mitt Romney said.

headline.main: Sept. 11 Tribute Won't Be on TV

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Sept. 11 Tribute Won't Be on TV

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: In an ambitious effort to address the emotional needs of disaster victims, two charities agreed to underwrite extended mental health treatment for people directly affected by last year's terrorist attacks. About 150,000 families meet the eligibility requirements set by the American Red Cross and the September 11th Fund, including relatives of people killed in the World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks, people injured in those attacks, rescue workers and displaced residents.

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Two 20-ton marble sculptures, intended as a memorial for the victims of Sept. 11, were moved yesterday from Sandy Hook, a national park that is part of the Gateway National Recreation Area, to a temporary home in Veterans Memorial Park in Highlands, a municipal park. The sculptures were built in Sandy Hook by Stephen Shaheen, who designed them, and two Italian artisans. Mr. Shaheen and his business partner, Evan Urbania, received a permit to build the sculptures in the park, but federal regulations do not allow commemorative artworks in national parks until 25 years after the event they commemorate, unless they are approved by Congress or the National Park Service director.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Highlands: 9/11 Sculptures Moved

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Highlands: 9/11 Sculptures Moved

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: City Hall is soliciting suggestions for observing the first anniversary of the events of Sept. 11, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. ''We want a memorial ceremony that is suitable, and lots of people have lots of different ideas, and so we've started to solicit,'' Mr. Bloomberg said on his weekly radio program on WABC-AM. ''We're sending e-mails and letters to all of the families that tragically lost people on 9/11.''

headline.main: City Seeks Ideas For a Ceremony

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: City Seeks Ideas For a Ceremony

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation appointed Anita F. Contini as vice president and director for its memorial, cultural and civic programs yesterday. Ms. Contini will be responsible for overseeing the development of a memorial for victims of the terrorist attack of Sept. 11 at the former site of the World Trade Center. In addition, she will coordinate efforts to bring cultural institutions to Lower Manhattan. Since 1999, she has served as a first vice president for global sponsorships and events marketing at Merrill Lynch. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Memorial Chief

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Memorial Chief

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city had begun planning a ceremony for when the cleanup at ground zero ends. The ceremony would be for those who died in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and those who have labored at the site. The site will be shut down sometime in late May, Mr. Bloomberg said, depending on the weather and other factors. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ceremony At End Of Ground Zero Cleanup

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ceremony At End Of Ground Zero Cleanup

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: The agency overseeing the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site agreed yesterday to add a representative from the families of victims of the 1993 terror attack on the twin towers. The agency, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said it would add Michael Macko, whose father, William J. Macko, a Port Authority mechanical supervisor, died nine years ago today, to one of its advisory committees. Senator Charles E. Schumer said he would ask President Bush to extend some benefits that are available to families of last year's victims to families of the victims of the 1993 attack. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: An influential state senator is opposing measures that would waive some taxes and fees and provide free college education for families of the 59 Marylanders killed in the Sept. 11 attacks. The lawmaker, Walter M. Baker, an Eastern Shore Democrat who is chairman of the powerful Judicial Proceedings Committee, said it was unfair to give breaks to victims of terrorism but not victims of other violence. One bill would exempt terrorism victims' families from probate fees and inheritance taxes; another would waive tuition at state universities. Gary Gately (NYT)

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: The financial dispute that has hobbled construction of the museum at ground zero for eight months entered a new stage this week with a struggle over who will control the overall memorial and the eight-acre site. The Sept. 11 memorial foundation, which is led by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has been responsible for the planning, development and programming of the memorial at the trade center site, as well as the visitor center and the National Sept. 11 Memorial and Museum, under a 2006 agreement. The foundation, which has raised $430 million in private donations, has also controlled the site and overseen annual events commemorating the deaths of nearly 3,000 people in the terrorist attack.

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: New York City is the most popular tourist destination in the country, and the National September 11th Memorial at the World Trade Center plaza is becoming one of its most popular sites. Though the memorial has been open for under nine months, 2.7 million people -- averaging 10,000 a day -- have already visited it. Not as many as the Metropolitan Museum of Art attracts, but then again, that spot doesn't require reservations or a photo ID.

The state has received 688 entries in a competition to find a design for a memorial to the nearly 700 New Jersey residents killed in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, officials announced yesterday. A professional advisory committee will narrow the field of contestants to several finalists, said an administration spokeswoman, Ellen Mellody. A panel of family members of victims and survivors will choose a winning design by July. The memorial will be installed in Liberty State Park, in Jersey City, across from the World Trade Center site.

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: A group of family members of World Trade Center victims announced yesterday the formation of the 9/11 Campaign, an effort to raise money for programs that will be associated with the memorial at ground zero. The immediate goal ''is to raise $9,110,000 by Sept. 11 of this year,'' said Monica Iken, founder of September's Mission, a victims' family advocacy group. The money will be used to create an endowment that can finance children's programs, conferences and other educational outreach efforts. Glenn Collins (NYT)

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: The design for an interim memorial to the six victims of the 1993 explosion at the World Trade Center was unveiled yesterday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The authority said it had won the approval of all the surviving family members. Jacqueline Hanley, senior architect for the Port Authority, working with the Pentagram studio, has designed a stainless-steel pylon about nine and a half feet tall, echoing the tower's proportions. Set within it would be a fragment of the original fountain, inscribed with ''John D,'' the partial name of a victim, John DiGiovanni. Ever since the original memorial was destroyed on Sept. 11, 2001, survivors of the 1993 attack have had no focal point for remembrance services or visits. The pylon is to be installed by the end of fall in the family viewing area at the southwest corner of the site. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

Ultimately, visitors will be able to approach the memorial and its green spaces and cobblestone plazas from all sides. But for years, said Joe Daniels, the president of the National September 11 Memorial & Museum, the memorial will be surrounded by the construction sites of skyscrapers and a transit hub, and visitors will be able to use only one entrance.
