Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: In one of the haunting legacies of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, the remains of 1,123 of the victims, 41 percent of the total, have not been identified, leaving many of their relatives yearning for closure. At the same time, nearly 10 years later, 9,041 pieces of human remains -- mainly bone fragments but also tissue that has been dehydrated for preservation -- are still being sorted through by the city's medical examiner for DNA, though the last time a connection was made was in 2009. Now, a dispute over what to do with those remains is simmering between some of the victims' families and the officials planning the National September 11 Memorial and Museum underneath where the twin towers stood.

headline.main: An Unsettled Legacy for 9/11 Remains

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: An Unsettled Legacy for 9/11 Remains

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: The family of Mark Bavis, a passenger on United Airlines Flight 175, said its stance was not about money but about proving what it believes was negligence.

headline.seo: One Family Is Last Holdout on 9/11 Settlements
headline.main: Among 9/11 Families, a Last Holdout Remains
headline.print_headline: Among 9/11 Families, the Final Holdout On a Settlement Wants Its Day in Court

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Among 9/11 Families, a Last Holdout Remains

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: The main floor of the National September 11 Memorial Museum, still under construction nearly 70 feet below the memorial plaza at the World Trade Center, filled with at least seven feet of water.

headline.main: Floodwater Pours Into 9/11 Museum, Hampering Further Work on the Site
headline.print_headline: Floodwater Pours Into 9/11 Museum, Hampering Further Work on the Site

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Floodwater Pours Into 9/11 Museum, Hampering Further Work on the Site

headline.main: Joining a Grim Roster

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Joining a Grim Roster

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: The office of the chief medical examiner said yesterday that it had matched the remains of three 9/11 victims with new and additional DNA samples provided by their families. Two were identified as Karen Ann Martin, 40, the head flight attendant on American Airlines Flight 11, which struck the north tower, and Douglas Joel Stone, 54, a passenger on the flight. The name of the third victim was not released, at his family's request. The newly identified remains were not among those discovered recently in a manhole near the World Trade Center site, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner. The remains of 1,601 of the 2,749 victims have now been identified. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More 9/11 Victims' Remains Identified

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More 9/11 Victims' Remains Identified

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: As an architecture student at Cooper Union three decades ago, Daniel Libeskind watched the World Trade Center being built. ''It was such an inspiring and controversial and wonderful moment,'' Mr. Libeskind said last week -- second only, perhaps, to the moment his design was chosen as the plan to rebuild the trade center. Centered on a recessed memorial to the victims of the 9/11 attack, the plan includes a spiral of buildings rising to a tower standing 1,776 feet -- ''a date or a number,'' he said, ''that will never be surpassed in world history.'' Edward Wyatt

headline.main: DESIGN FOR GROUND ZERO

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: DESIGN FOR GROUND ZERO

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who is also chairman of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, told the foundation's board yesterday that the foundation had raised $253.8 million toward its $300 million goal. Almost $52 million, about one-fifth of the total raised so far, has been pledged in the last six weeks. A spokeswoman for the foundation declined to identify any of the new contributors. The memorial is expected to cost more than $500 million. DAVID W. DUNLAP

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: $253 Million For 9/11 Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: $253 Million For 9/11 Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: The World Trade Center Memorial Foundation has raised more than $300 million toward its $350 million goal, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday, with more than $165 million raised since he took over as chairman of the foundation roughly six months ago. The money, which includes gifts from across the country and overseas, is to pay capital and planning costs as well as an endowment to operate the memorial and museum. Officials announced yesterday that the foundation board had selected Thinc Design as the lead exhibition design firm. DIANE CARDWELL

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Foundation Nearing Goal

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Foundation Nearing Goal

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: The Sept. 11 anniversary remembrance will not be held at its original location at ground zero this year because construction on the site has made it unsafe for a large public gathering, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The ceremony will be held at a plaza near the southeast corner of the site. Some family members of victims have protested, but the mayor said that the decision was final and that ''it would be a big shame'' if anyone skipped the event out of anger.

headline.main: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Ceremony To Relocate

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Ceremony To Relocate

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Saying that the International Freedom Center planned for the World Trade Center site had become ''very controversial,'' Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that he had instructed his appointees to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation board to carefully read the center's new report on how it would operate. ''Then we'll discuss it and try to come to some resolution,'' the mayor said. The center was intended to put 9/11 in the context of the world's history of freedom but it has faced criticism that it would detract from the memorial and deprive the memorial museum of space. Speaking of exhibitions planned for the center, Mr. Bloomberg said, ''Some things you might want to put elsewhere.'' David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor And The Freedom Center

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor And The Freedom Center

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Rejecting a request to immediately halt work at the World Trade Center site, a State Supreme Court justice said yesterday that site preparation for the World Trade Center Memorial could continue until late April. ''It seems to me that there's no building going on here, so we certainly don't need a temporary restraining order,'' Justice Shirley Werner Kornreich said, responding to a request by the families of trade center victims to halt construction of a $330 million memorial and a $160 million museum because, they argued, it would damage historic remnants in violation of state statutes. Lower Manhattan Development Corporation lawyers promised that only inspection, cleaning and protection of the remnants would proceed until an April 27 hearing. GLENN COLLINS (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Allows Work At Ground Zero

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Allows Work At Ground Zero

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: There may be some fine tuning added to the design of the World Trade Center memorial to meet security concerns, the state's top antiterror official, James K. Kallstrom, said yesterday. Mr. Kallstrom, a senior adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki and director of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said that the plans were reviewed months ago by the Police Department and that he did not foresee significant changes, but added that the design might be modified ''so that we can react to whatever threat we're at here in the city.'' At the same corporation board meeting, John C. Whitehead, the chairman, said the waterfalls within the twin memorial voids would be able to run year round. Construction of the memorial is to begin in March. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Design Revisions To 9/11 Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Design Revisions To 9/11 Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki reiterated his support yesterday for government financing of the underground infrastructure at ground zero, leaving the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation responsible only for meeting the $500 million budget now assigned to the memorial and museum. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to pay $100 million of the memorial's share of infrastructure costs. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Government Financing For Ground Zero

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Government Financing For Ground Zero

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Gretchen Dykstra, the president and chief executive of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, said after a board meeting yesterday that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the trade center land, should ''be delivering to us a buildable site'' for the memorial and memorial museum, meaning the authority alone should pay the cost of the underground infrastructure. At the meeting, Christine A. Ferer, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's liaison to the families of 9/11 victims and a Port Authority commissioner, joined the board. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Memorial Chief Seeks Port Authority Financing

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Memorial Chief Seeks Port Authority Financing

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Julie Menin, a director of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation and the chairwoman of Community Board 1 in Lower Manhattan, objected publicly yesterday to an announcement that the foundation would not solicit any more money until it had a clearer idea of the cost and design of the memorial and museum. Writing to Thomas S. Johnson, the chairman of the foundation's executive committee, Ms. Menin said, ''By suspending fund-raising (and more pointedly by suspending it without a board vote), more doubt and turmoil has been created.'' She called for a vote at the next board meeting. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dissent In Memorial Foundation

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dissent In Memorial Foundation

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: A construction manager is being sought for the memorial and memorial museum at ground zero, under a request for proposals issued yesterday by the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. John C. Whitehead, the chairman of both groups, said the manager would help ensure that construction starts early next year, sticks to a three-year timetable and stays within its budget, estimated at $500 million. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the site, said that it would not submit a proposal but ''would be willing to serve as construction manager if asked.'' David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Manager Sought For Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Manager Sought For Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday the Airport 9/11 Memorial is to be unveiled at Logan International Airport in Boston, The Boston Globe reported. The memorial, which was designed by the local firm Moskow Architects and cost $3.5 million, is on a two-acre slip of land. It consists of two paths that wind up a wooded slope through 102 ginkgo trees to a glass cube sculpture called ''The Place of Remembrance.'' The cube contains the names of the 148 passengers and crew members aboard American Airlines Flight 11 and United Airlines Flight 175, the two planes that departed Logan and were flown into the World Trade Center towers. According to the Massachusetts Port Authority, the idea to create the memorial ''began with the airport's employees, who were seeking a way to honor those lost and a place to reflect on the events of 9/11.''

headline.main: Boston Airport Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Boston Airport Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Insurgents and the government accused each other in the killing of at least 50 people, most of them men in their 20s and 30s, whose bodies were found in a suburb of Aleppo.

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Over the last six weeks, center fielder Coco Crisp has hit 12 home runs and driven in 26 runs, while batting .293 with 5 stolen bases from his leadoff spot.

headline.main: A’s Follow Crisp’s Lead Back Into the Playoffs
headline.print_headline: Following Their Leader

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: A’s Follow Crisp’s Lead Back Into the Playoffs

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed a bill that would have prohibited admission or other fees at the World Trade Center memorial, museum or visitor center, his office said yesterday. Mr. Pataki said the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation could not rule out charging the public, given what he estimated would be the $50 million annual cost of operating a memorial and museum at ground zero. State Senator Martin J. Golden, the Brooklyn Republican who introduced the bill, had said ''there should be no barriers,'' including fees, that would prevent people from paying their respects. DANNY HAKIM (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Governor Vetoes Bill Blocking 9/11 Memorial Fee

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Governor Vetoes Bill Blocking 9/11 Memorial Fee

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: A section of steel girder from the World Trade Center given to the British will be buried rather than displayed in a planned memorial garden in London, to prevent distress to victims' relatives, officials said yesterday. The Department of Culture, Media and Sport is overseeing the memorial's construction. The blackened, twisted piece of metal from the north tower was given to Britain by the mayor's office in New York for a memorial in Grosvenor Square, opposite the United States Embassy. Sixty-seven Britons were killed in the terrorist attack.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Sept. 11 Memorial In London

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Sept. 11 Memorial In London

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, yesterday endorsed a resolution that called for the future World Trade Center memorial to list the names of firefighters, police officers and rescue workers separately from those of other victims of the Sept. 11 attacks. The resolution asks Gov. George E. Pataki and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to honor rescue workers by listing them together, by department, including rank, badge number and unit ''in the context within which they gave their lives.'' The current guidelines for the memorial competition say there should be no hierarchy in listing the victims. Winnie Hu (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Proposal For Names On 9/11 Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Proposal For Names On 9/11 Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: About 100 people attended a public hearing at Rutgers University here to discuss new designs and guidelines for a memorial at the World Trade Center, and many complained that organizers had not planned more hearings in New Jersey, which lost hundreds of people on Sept. 11. Many of the speakers made emotional pleas to the planners of the memorial to include the remains of unidentified victims that now lie in a landfill in Staten Island. ''Where do I go to see my son,'' said Krystynacq Boryczewskicq, 63, of Parsipanny, whose son Martin, 29, was died on 9/11. Maria Newman (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Piscataway: Hearing On Trade Center Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Piscataway: Hearing On Trade Center Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: The police said yesterday that they had arrested two people on charges of falsely reporting relatives among the missing at the World Trade Center. A Toronto woman, Sara Hekriy, 44, went to a center for victims' families and submitted a notarized document saying her husband had been inside one of the towers, the police said. Ms. Hekriy later admitted that she had falsified the document, they said, and was charged with perjury.

headline.main: 2 Accused of False Reports

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: 2 Accused of False Reports

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: Plans for rebuilding the World Trade Center site became more concrete as New York City and state officials chose two finalists to design the future of ground zero. Rebuilding officials will choose by the end of the month between a proposal from Studio Daniel Libeskind, which would set the memorial to victims in a 70-foot pit where most remains were found, and one from a team of architects called Think, which would build two latticework towers, evoking the original ones but including cultural and educational facilities. Each plan includes what would be the world's tallest tower but neither has office space at the top. Edward Wyatt

headline.main: February 2-8: NATIONAL; REBUILDING PLANS

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: February 2-8: NATIONAL; REBUILDING PLANS

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: The fathers of two victims of the attack on the World Trade Center presented pieces of steel from the site to officials in Somerset County, Pa., for inclusion in the permanent memorial to be built at the site where United Flight 93 crashed. Tom Johnson's son Scott worked on the 88th floor of the south tower, and Lee Ielpi's son Jonathan was a firefighter with Squad 288. The fathers traveled to the crash site with representatives of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation who are visiting memorial sites across the country as part of their planning for the memorial at the trade center site. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Pennsylvania Memorial To Include Steel From Trade Center Site

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Pennsylvania Memorial To Include Steel From Trade Center Site

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: TOMORROW A public comment period begins with the opening of a six-week exhibit of plans with videos of architects explaining their work at the Winter Garden in the World Financial Center. Open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. daily, through Feb. 3. Plans are also online at www.LowerManhattan.info and RenewNyc.org. Videos will also be distributed to public libraries in the city.

headline.main: What's Next

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: What's Next

Memorial to the Victims.lead_paragraph: In his new role as chairman of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg backed away yesterday from his insistence that the names of the dead be displayed in random order, a position that had pitted him against many relatives of the victims and representatives of those who died in the 9/11 rescue effort. ''Where we'll come out on the names or a couple of other issues, we'll just have to see,'' Mr. Bloomberg told reporters at a news conference. Other officials have suggested displaying the victims' names around the footprint of the tower in which they died and grouping them by affiliation, like the company or emergency service unit where they worked. DIANE CARDWELL (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Relents On Memorial

Memorial to the Victims.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Relents On Memorial

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: Representative J. C. Watts Jr., Republican of Oklahoma, who says he supports tighter airport security, had a confrontation with a police officer who ticketed him for violating new security rules at Oklahoma City's airport and has apologized, his office said. After being issued a $15 ticket for leaving his car unattended in a no-parking zone on Sept. 28, Mr. Watts, a member of the House Republican leadership, stuffed the ticket under the officer's badge.

headline.main: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Apology For Airport Incident

Airport Security.mainheadline: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Apology For Airport Incident

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: A Massachusetts judge has ruled that a security company screening passengers at Logan International Airport should not have its work terminated because the airport revoked its permit illegally. The judge, Allen van Gestel, issued a temporary restraining order on Tuesday, reinstating the license of the company, Argenbright Security.

headline.main: Security Company Gets License Back

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: A terminal at Kennedy Airport was evacuated after a passenger found a knife past a security checkpoint at 5:45 p.m. yesterday. Flights out of the terminal were grounded, and passengers who had boarded planes had to return to the terminal. Police dogs checked the entire building, Terminal 3, which houses Delta Airlines, and passengers waiting for 11 planes had to be screened again. The rescreening was completed by 10 p.m., said Jim Peters, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The knife, found between the cushions of a seat in one of the boarding areas, had a four-inch serrated blade, an F.A.A. official said. It was not known how long the knife had been there. Tina Kelley (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Kennedy Terminal Evacuated

Airport Security.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Kennedy Terminal Evacuated

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: The first crew of 150 federal X-ray screeners began work yesterday at Newark International Airport, Newark's first wave in a nationwide transition from private sector airport security to federal security personnel. Newark, one of 32 airports that now have federal screeners, is scheduled to add almost 900 more before Nov. 19, the deadline the Transportation Security Administration set to replace all private screeners. Danise Daville, above, and the other screeners were placed in Terminal A, the facility that United Flight 93 left before being hijacked by terrorists on Sept. 11 and then crashing in a Pennsylvania field. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Airport Gets New Federal Screeners

Airport Security.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Airport Gets New Federal Screeners

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: One hundred ten people who work at Denver International Airport were indicted today on charges of lying to get airport security badges. The airport was the 19th investigated by a federal government security program begun in response to the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline.main: 110 Accused of Fraud at Denver Airport

Airport Security.mainheadline: 110 Accused of Fraud at Denver Airport

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: Because of increased security since the Sept. 11 terror attacks, drug traffickers are avoiding the airports they usually use and customs seizures of the illegal party drug Ecstasy have declined, the United States Customs Service said yesterday. Thomas E. Manifase, an assistant special agent for the Customs Service, said that inspectors at Newark International Airport, Kennedy International Airport and Miami International Airport had seized less Ecstasy. Newark seized 736,224 Ecstasy tablets between October 2001 and July 2002, down about 12 percent from the same period a year ago. Stacy Albin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Ecstasy Drug Seizures Down

Airport Security.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Ecstasy Drug Seizures Down

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: To keep airport security running through a federal takeover on Nov. 19, the government is offering $500 bonuses to entice privately hired screeners to stay on the job until then. The Transportation Security Administration has to hire 57,500 people to screen passengers and check luggage. Blaine Harden (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Bonus For Airport Screeners

Airport Security.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: Bonus For Airport Screeners

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: The government has told airlines to close the V.I.P. lines that allow their most valued customers, mainly business travelers, to avoid long waits for security checks at airports, officials said today. The move was ordered by the Transportation Security Administration, which took over airport passenger and baggage screening from the airlines at more than 420 airports this week.

headline.main: U.S. Orders Airlines To End V.I.P. Lines

Airport Security.mainheadline: U.S. Orders Airlines To End V.I.P. Lines

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: A passenger who ran around a security checkpoint and led officials to close Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta, one of the world's busiest, for three hours was fined the maximum $3,300, regulators said. The Federal Aviation Administration said the passenger, Michael S. Lasseter, 32, of Gainesville, an executive, violated federal rules by entering a secure area without the required screening on Nov. 16.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Georgia: $3,300 Fine For Evasive Passenger

Airport Security.mainheadline: National Briefing | South: Georgia: $3,300 Fine For Evasive Passenger

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: Two men face possible life sentences in a plan to detonate fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport and set off cascading explosions along a fuel pipeline.

headline.print_headline: After Day of Intense Talks, Muslim Leaders Unite Behind Community Center

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: Russell Defreitas and Abdul Kadir face possible life sentences after being convicted of conspiring to commit acts of terrorism.

headline.seo: 2 Guyanese Guilty in Plot to Bomb J.F.K. Airport
headline.main: 2 Men Convicted in Kennedy Airport Plot
headline.print_headline: 2 Men Convicted Of Airport Plot

Airport Security.mainheadline: 2 Men Convicted in Kennedy Airport Plot

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: A Queens man working as an airport cashier has been indicted on charges that he phoned in two false bomb threats to Kennedy Airport, federal prosecutors announced yesterday. The man, Marcelo Almeida, 27, of Richmond Hill, is accused of phoning 911 at 8:34 a.m. and 9:27 a.m. on Monday and saying that a bomb was inside the international arrivals terminal. The calls were traced to a private work area inside the airport for the food-court operator there, Select Service Partner Airport Restaurants, and workers were interrogated by the F.B.I. Mr. Almeida's lawyer did not immediately return phone calls.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Indictment In Bomb Threats

Airport Security.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Indictment In Bomb Threats

Airport Security.lead_paragraph: The judge’s ruling was the latest contribution to a debate among courts and a presidential review group about how to balance security and privacy in the era of big data.

headline.print_headline: A Judge Upholds N.S.A. Collection Of Data on Calls

headline.main: Rajat Gupta’s Lust for Zeros
headline.print_headline: A Lust for Zeros

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Senior Saudi officials rejected today American accusations that the kingdom is not choking off the money supply to Osama bin Laden, accusing Washington of again leveling charges against groups or individuals here without providing any proof. ''We believe firmly that fighting terrorism is done by removing the infrastructure, and one of the main elements of the infrastructure is the financial element,'' said Prince Saud al-Faisal, the Saudi foreign minister, in an interview. ''So there is absolutely no truth in saying we have not been cooperating in this.''

headline.main: Saudis Reject U.S. Accusation They Balked on Terror Money

Saudi Arabia.mainheadline: Saudis Reject U.S. Accusation They Balked on Terror Money

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia has ordered a freeze on the assets of people and organizations that the United States has identified as sponsors of terrorism, Bush administration officials said today. President Bush has been saying for weeks that Saudi officials were cooperating in the fight against terrorism, and his aides have often repeated a statement that Saudi Arabia has ''done everything we've asked them to do'' to help combat Al Qaeda and Osama bin Laden.

headline.main: Saudis Freeze Funds Of 66 on U.S. List

Saudi Arabia.mainheadline: Saudis Freeze Funds Of 66 on U.S. List

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: A senior American diplomat met here today with top Saudi officials, including Crown Prince Abdullah, for talks intended in part to seek further Saudi help in cutting off money to suspected terrorist groups. Before the meeting, senior Saudi officials complained that the United States had not shared the evidence necessary for them to freeze bank accounts permanently and to take other actions it sought.

headline.main: U.S. Diplomat Meets Saudis Over Accounts

Saudi Arabia.mainheadline: U.S. Diplomat Meets Saudis Over Accounts

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: While exports to the United States might rebound this year, in the long run the decline in western demand and the growing importance of China represent a fundamental shift for the oil market.

headline.seo: More Saudi Oil Goes to China Than to U.S.
headline.main: China’s Growth Shifts the Geopolitics of Oil
headline.print_headline: China’s Rapid Growth Shifts the Geopolitics of Oil

Saudi Arabia.mainheadline: China’s Growth Shifts the Geopolitics of Oil

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Family members of more than 900 victims of the Sept. 11 attacks filed a lawsuit against three Saudi princes, seven internalional banks operating mainly in the Middle East, eight Islamic foundations and charities and the government of Sudan for allegedly funding Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda. The suit, in federal district court in Washington, is one of several expected in coming months against foreign governments and individuals who may have aided the terrorist network. The defendants named in the lawsuit include Mr. bin Laden and several family members, as well as three members of the Saudi royal family: Turki al Faisal al Saud, Sultan bin Abdul Aziz al Saud and Mohammed al Faisal al Saud.

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: United States: Sept. 11 Survivors Sue

Saudi Arabia.mainheadline: World Briefing | Americas: United States: Sept. 11 Survivors Sue

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: A Saudi Arabian who lives in Arizona has been convicted in federal court of lying to the F.B.I. about his link to a hijacker who flew an airliner into the Pentagon on Sept. 11. The Saudi, Faisal al-Salmi, 34, was found guilty on Thursday of making false statements in denying knowledge of the hijacker, Hani Hanjour. Mr. Salmi faces six months in prison when sentenced on March 14.

headline.main: SAUDI CONVICTED

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: In coordination with the Saudi government, the Bush administration moved today to seize the assets of a Saudi charity group, asserting that the organization uses the cover of supporting Islamic schools and orphanages to funnel money to terrorists. The crackdown was the first since Sept. 11 to result from a joint effort by the United States and Saudi Arabia. Administration officials said it was a sign of increasing cooperation with the kingdom, which was home to 15 of the 19 hijackers involved in the terrorist attacks and which the United States feels has been slow to take action against suspected supporters of Osama bin Laden and other terrorist organizations.

headline.main: U.S. Moves to Seize Saudi Charity Assets

Saudi Arabia.mainheadline: U.S. Moves to Seize Saudi Charity Assets

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: A Muslim doctor in San Antonio who was arrested after the Sept. 11 attacks but later released was prohibited from re-entering the country last month after a trip to Saudi Arabia. A State Department official said the doctor, Al-Badr Al Hazmi, was issued a visa on Saturday and would be allowed to return. Muslim leaders in San Antonio had expressed outrage over the situation. On Sept. 12, Dr. Hazmi was handcuffed and dragged away from his San Antonio home in his pajamas. After 12 days of questioning, he was released. Jim Yardley (NYT)

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Ontario -- As the United States continues to play political Ping-Pong with the fate of the Keystone XL pipeline, Canadian officials and companies are desperately seeking alternatives to get the country's nearly 200 billion barrels in oil reserves -- almost equal to that of Saudi Arabia -- to market from landlocked Alberta. Oil companies complain that they are losing revenues from pipeline bottlenecks. So Canada is plunging ahead with plans to build more pipelines of its own.

headline.main: Canada Seeks Alternatives To Transport Oil Reserves

Saudi Arabia.mainheadline: Canada Seeks Alternatives To Transport Oil Reserves

U.S. Received
Early Warning
On Qaeda Plot

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia and the United States have worked closely together against a militant network in Yemen, most recently foiling an effort to smuggle a bomb onto a jetliner.

headline.seo: Years of U.S.-Saudi Teamwork Led to Airline Plot’s Failure

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: A Saudi suspected of being a member of Al Qaeda, who had appeared on a videotape with Osama bin Laden, was flown back to the kingdom from Iran after he surrendered under a government amnesty, state television said Tuesday. Khaled al-Harbi, also known as Abu Suleiman al-Makki, had been living in the wild lands along the Iranian-Afghan border and had contacted the Saudi Embassy in Tehran in response to the amnesty offer.

headline.main: Saudi Tied to bin Laden Turns Himself In Under Amnesty Offer

Saudi Arabia.mainheadline: Saudi Tied to bin Laden Turns Himself In Under Amnesty Offer

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- A 20-year-old Saudi college student who was arrested Wednesday night on bomb charges in Texas wrote in his journal that he sought a student visa three years ago so he could carry out terrorist attacks inside the United States, according to an F.B.I. document released Thursday. By the time that the student, Khalid Aldawsari, who attended community college in Lubbock, Tex., came to the attention of the authorities this month, he had obtained two of the three chemicals needed for a bomb and was researching potential targets -- including the Dallas residence of former President George W. Bush, the homes of three former military guards at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq and dams in Colorado and California, an F.B.I. affidavit said.

headline.main: Saudi Student Is Charged in Texas With Plotting Attacks in the U.S.

Saudi Arabia.mainheadline: Saudi Student Is Charged in Texas With Plotting Attacks in the U.S.

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Six Muslim militants and two policemen were killed today in a firefight in a Saudi security sweep, which Riyadh says shows it is serious about waging war on terror. The firefight occurred at a farm in Qassim Province, a northern stronghold of Islamic militants, in a crackdown on wanted militants, the Interior Ministry said in a statement, which also said that eight policemen and one suspect were wounded.

headline.main: 8 Killed in Saudi Sweep Against Militants

Saudi Arabia.mainheadline: 8 Killed in Saudi Sweep Against Militants

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: The Gulf Arab states promised ''total support and cooperation'' today for the effort to find and punish those responsible for the suicide attacks in New York and Washington but pointedly coupled the pledge with a call for action against what they called terror acts by Israel against the Palestinians. In a joint statement issued after an emergency meeting in the Saudi port city, Jidda, the foreign ministers of the six Gulf Cooperation Council nations -- Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Oman and Qatar -- offered no clue as to how much military or other assistance the United States could expect from its Gulf allies.

headline.main: Six Arab States Offer Support

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: A Saudi Arabian government official said today that a Saudi citizen identified in a recent Congressional report on the September 2001 attacks as a likely intelligence operative was an accountant who never worked as a Saudi government agent. The Saudi official, who is responsible for terrorism investigations, said that Omar al-Bayoumi, who befriended two of the 9/11 hijackers in California more than a year before the attacks, was employed by a contractor for the Saudi civil aviation authority.

headline.main: Saudi Denies U.S. Report Of Likely Link To a Suspect

Saudi Arabia.mainheadline: Saudi Denies U.S. Report Of Likely Link To a Suspect

Saudi Arabia.lead_paragraph: Senior Bush administration officials praised the government of Saudi Arabia today for its efforts in tracking down suspected terrorists even as White House officials urged greater Saudi cooperation with investigations into Saudi financiers and charities that may be aiding terror networks. Ari Fleischer, President Bush's press secretary, said, ''I see no reason to believe that Saudi Arabia is not committed to the campaign against terrorism.''

headline.main: Bush Officials Praise Saudis For Aiding Terror Fight

Saudi Arabia.mainheadline: Bush Officials Praise Saudis For Aiding Terror Fight

Iran.lead_paragraph: Fearful that famine and war will force hundreds of thousands of Afghan refugees to pour into the country, Iran has set up a corridor in the northeast to send aid into Afghanistan. Since the American-led airstrikes against Afghanistan began on Sunday, tons of food and relief items have gone through Khorasan Province to be distributed in Afghanistan. Much of the work is being supervised by foreign relief networks whose distribution of food and medicine in Afghanistan has been disrupted.

headline.main: The Iranians Seek to Stem Refugee Flow

Iran.mainheadline: The Iranians Seek to Stem Refugee Flow

Iran.lead_paragraph: United Nations officials accused Iran and Pakistan today of forcing Afghan refugees to return to Afghanistan despite continued fighting and instability in the country. They said that Iran had forcibly deported several thousand refugees and that Pakistan had forcibly expelled 300 refugees since Taliban forces were driven out of Kabul and most other major cities.

headline.main: Iran and Pakistan Deport Afghans, U.N. Aides Say

Iran.mainheadline: Iran and Pakistan Deport Afghans, U.N. Aides Say

Iran.lead_paragraph: The Afghan warlord Gulbuddin Hekmatyar has left exile in Iran to return home, his spokesman in Pakistan said, raising the likelihood of a new threat to Afghanistan's interim government. Iran told Mr. Hekmatyar to leave after he called the new Afghan government a puppet regime and said he had fighters inside Afghanistan ready to expel foreign troops there.

Iran.lead_paragraph: Iran's cabinet spokesman today rebutted reports that 12 Iranians, including a high-ranking general, were arrested in Afghanistan after they tried to buy influence with Afghan warlords. ''According to the foreign ministry's report today at the cabinet meeting, there are no Iranian nationals among those arrested because we have no military presence in Afghanistan,'' said Abdullah Ramezanzadeh, the spokesman, at a news conference.

headline.main: No Iranians Among 12 Seized In Afghanistan, Tehran Declares

Iran.mainheadline: No Iranians Among 12 Seized In Afghanistan, Tehran Declares

Iran.lead_paragraph: Iran has denied a report that it had contacts with members of Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network, newspapers reported today. ''Iran's clear position on the phenomenon of terrorism, the Taliban and the Al Qaeda group indisputably proves that such claims and reports are baseless and false,'' the daily Iran News quoted a foreign ministry spokesman, Hamid Reza Asefi, as saying.

Iran.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan -- Two new reports addressing human rights issues in Afghanistan have raised questions about how NATO troops are conducting the war. Both reports center on a question that has vexed international forces since the war began: How can the military be sure it has killed, detained or made deals with the right people? A report by the Afghanistan Analysts Network challenges the accuracy of American intelligence used in what are known as targeted killings, and makes a case study of the killing of an alleged Qaeda-affiliated operative in Takhar Province who was attacked by NATO jets as he traveled in a convoy through a rural area. The report offers evidence that NATO forces got the wrong man and that the insurgent commander they were seeking is alive in Pakistan -- an interview with him is included in the report. [The public television program Frontline also addressed the case in this segment of its program ''Kill/Capture.'']

headline.main: Murky Identities and Ties Hinder NATO's Hunt for Afghan Insurgents, Report Says

Iran.mainheadline: Murky Identities and Ties Hinder NATO's Hunt for Afghan Insurgents, Report Says

Iran.lead_paragraph: Iran's national wrestling team will boycott the world freestyle championships at Madison Square Garden in September because of a Defense Department decision to fingerprint all participants. ''The Americans insisted that fingerprinting would be enforced, so we decided not to go,'' Javad Rofougar, an Iranian Wrestling Federation official, said yesterday.

Iran.mainheadline: Iran Will Boycott Meet in U.S.

Iran.lead_paragraph: The rise in oil prices turned into a stampede on Friday with futures jumping a staggering $11 a barrel to set a record above $138 a barrel. The unprecedented surge came as the dollar fell sharply against the euro and a senior Israeli politician once again raised the possibility of an attack against Iran. Friday's jump capped a second day of strong gains on energy markets, and fed suspicions that commodities might be caught in an investment bubble.

headline.main: Oil Prices Take a Nerve-Rattling Jump Past $138

Iran.mainheadline: Oil Prices Take a Nerve-Rattling Jump Past $138

Iran.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court rejected an appeal from a man trying to hold Iran accountable for the killing of his daughter in a Middle Eastern terrorist bombing. The court did not comment in turning down the father, Stephen Flatow of West Orange, N.J., who won a $247.5 million verdict against Iran, but has been unable to collect most of the money. His daughter, Alisa Flatow, a 20-year-old college student, died in a 1995 bus bombing in the Gaza Strip. Her parents sued under a 1996 law that authorized lawsuits for damages suffered in acts of terror by countries designated by the United States as sponsors of terrorism.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Bombing Victim's Father Loses Appeal

Iran.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: Bombing Victim's Father Loses Appeal

Iran.lead_paragraph: Britain's foreign secretary, Jack Straw, who is to arrive here on Monday night as the highest-ranking Briton since the Islamic revolution of 1979, said today that he hoped the visit would open a new era in relations with Iran. Mr. Straw noted in a message to the Iranian people that the visit, originally planned in November, was taking place now ''in the shadow of the horrific atrocities'' in the United States and the possibility of war in Afghanistan, which borders Iran to the east.

headline.main: Visiting Briton to Meet Iranian Leaders

Iran.mainheadline: Visiting Briton to Meet Iranian Leaders

Iran.lead_paragraph: Ayatollah Muhammad Yazdi, a member of Iran's conservative Guardian Council, lashed out at statements in President Bush's State of the Union address that said Iran was violating human rights and trying to develop weapons of mass destruction. Ayatollah Yazdi rejected the president's claims and responded with his own: that White House policies after the Sept. 11 terror attacks violated the rights of Muslim immigrants. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

headline.main: IRANIAN CLERIC REBUKES BUSH

Iran.mainheadline: IRANIAN CLERIC REBUKES BUSH

Immigration.lead_paragraph: President Vicente Fox visits President Bush today to discuss border security issues and to promote broad immigration reforms. Mr. Fox's hastily arranged visit to the United States is also a response to criticism that the Mexican government has not forcefully expressed its support for the United States during the terrorism crisis. Later today Mr. Fox is scheduled to travel to New York to tour the wreckage of the World Trade Center with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Fox To Visit Bush And Giuliani

Immigration.mainheadline: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Fox To Visit Bush And Giuliani

Immigration.lead_paragraph: The Division of Motor Vehicles has stopped issuing licenses to immigrants whose visas expire in one year or less, and those whose visas are a year or longer will get licenses good only for the length of the visa rather than for four years. The purpose is to curb fraudulent use of licenses as proof of legal residence; 2 of the Sept. 11 hijackers used New Jersey licenses to rent cars and buy airline tickets. John Holl

headline.main: IMMIGRANTS' LICENSES LIMITED

Immigration.lead_paragraph: On Sept. 6, President Vicente Fox of Mexico urged a rare joint meeting of Congress to grant legal status to millions of his countrymen, saying they brought cultural and economic benefits to the United States. President Bush expressed support for Mr. Fox's proposals. Five days later, all that seemed like a dream, and since then, American immigration policy has undergone a sea change. Gone are the lofty words from Mr. Bush about how hard-working immigrants seeking a better life should be given a chance. In their place is a darker, more mistrustful view of immigrants. Congress last week easily approved legislation requiring visas issued to foreigners after 2003 to be tamper-resistant and include biometric data. The bill also tightens the screening of foreign students and authorizes the hiring of 1,000 new border inspectors and 1,000 immigration investigators over the next five years.

headline.main: Imagine; For Immigrants, a Colder World

Immigration.mainheadline: Imagine; For Immigrants, a Colder World

Immigration.lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled today that a Muslim clergyman accused of funneling money to terrorists should be freed in 10 days or have a new hearing open to the news media and the public with a different immigration judge. The clergyman, Rabih Haddad, a Lebanese citizen living in Ann Arbor, Mich., has been jailed since Dec. 14 at an immigration prison for overstaying his visa.

headline.main: Judge May Require Release of Detainee

Immigration.mainheadline: Judge May Require Release of Detainee

Immigration.lead_paragraph: A state appellate court ruled last week that the federal government can keep the names of detainees being held in custody a secret. Since Sept. 11 more than 1,100 detainees have been held nationally, many of them in Hudson and Passaic County jails, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The ruling said that the release of detainees' names could compromise investigations and public safety. Civil liberties advocates wanted the names released to monitor detainees' treatment in custody and to ensure adequate legal representation. A representative of the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union said the group planned to appeal the ruling to the State Supreme Court. John Holl

headline.main: WITHHOLDING DETAINEES' NAMES

Immigration.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department last month quietly deported 131 Pakistani citizens who had been swept up in the post-Sept. 11 crackdown on foreigners in the country illegally, officials said tonight. The department chartered a plane on June 28 to return the Pakistanis, who had received deportation orders from an immigration judge, according to Russell A. Bergeron, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

headline.main: Scores of Pakistanis Are Deported by U.S.

Immigration.mainheadline: Scores of Pakistanis Are Deported by U.S.

Immigration.lead_paragraph: President Bush signed legislation to improve border security and to toughen enforcement of immigration laws. The legislation provides for more immigration investigators, directs colleges and universities to use the Internet to track foreign students and requires foreign visitors to carry visas that include biometric identifiers like fingerprints. Carla Baranauckas (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Bush Signs Border-Security Measure

Immigration.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: Bush Signs Border-Security Measure

Immigration.lead_paragraph: About half the nearly 100 people jailed in Middlesex County, N.J., on immigration charges are refusing to eat some meals. Among their complaints are the length of their detentions and inadequate medical treatment, several detainees said. Kerry Gill, Immigration and Naturalization Service spokesman in Newark, said it was hard to say how many detainees were involved. The warden, Michael T. Abode, said that rather than go hungry, some detainees had bought food at the commissary, which sells candy and instant soup. Immigration and jail officials denied there were serious problems at the jail but said they would look into the complaints. Christopher Drew (NYT)

headline.main: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; PROTEST IN NEW JERSEY

Immigration.mainheadline: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; PROTEST IN NEW JERSEY

Immigration.lead_paragraph: A New Jersey judge ruled yesterday that the Hudson and Passaic County jails should turn over the names and incarceration dates of immigration detainees held there under contract with the federal government in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The ruling, which the government plans to appeal, stems from a lawsuit filed in January by the American Civil Liberties of New Jersey in State Superior Court, after the government began detaining immigrants anonymously. A similar suit against the government is pending in federal court, but the New Jersey group sued the jails directly under state laws. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

headline.main: Briefly Noted; RULING ON DETAINEES

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Reversing itself, the Immigration and Naturalization Service will permit civil-liberties lawyers to advise hundreds of foreign nationals held since the Sept. 11 attacks. The decision, issued Jan. 11 but not received by the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey until Jan. 24, followed two lawsuits accusing the government of illegally withholding the names of detainees and the charges against them. The decision will allow members of the A.C.L.U. to determine whether detainees require legal assistance. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: I.N.S. To Allow Legal Aid

Immigration.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: I.N.S. To Allow Legal Aid

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has asked the Bush administration to allow relatives of immigrants who died in the Sept. 11 attacks to remain in the United States while they seek permanent residency status. In a Nov. 11 letter to the administration that was released by the mayor's office yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg said a reprieve from deportation that had been granted by the USA Patriot Act of 2001 had ''long expired, leaving families again deeply vulnerable.'' The letter continued, ''Approximately 100 spouses and children are in this desperate condition and need immediate immigration relief to move forward with their lives.'' Mike McIntire (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Residency Plea For 9/11 Relatives

Immigration.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Residency Plea For 9/11 Relatives

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Prosecutors filed terrorism charges against the radical cleric Abu Bakar Bashir in connection with the suicide attack last year on the JW Marriott hotel in Jakarta that killed 12 people. He was charged under Indonesia's antiterror law. Mr. Bashir, 66, the spiritual leader of the Islamic group Jemaah Islamiyah, which has been labeled a terrorist organization by the United States, has been in prison since 2002, when he was cleared of terror charges but sentenced to 18 months in jail for immigration violations. Jane Perlez (NYT)

Immigration.lead_paragraph: Unfair tactics. Lying. Spying. And that is just what the Republican candidates are accusing one another of in a Congressional primary here that veteran political watchers are calling wild even by Arizona's sometimes unconventional standards. There are primaries in nine states and the District of Columbia on Tuesday, but both parties are closely watching the campaign in the Eighth Congressional District here because it is a swing district and one of a handful nationwide that Democrats think they can capture in their bid to reclaim the House. The candidates have spent more than $2.5 million, making it among the most expensive House races in the country.

Smallpox and Bioterrorism.lead_paragraph: The National Guard is providing extra security at the company that is the nation's sole producer of the anthrax vaccine. Pentagon officials called on the Guard after examining company security measures at the BioPort Corporation, in Lansing. The company supplies the military with a vaccine for anthrax, which can be used as a biological weapon. The vaccine is not available to the public. A company spokesman said BioPort had not been threatened. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: More Security For Producer Of Vaccine

Smallpox and Bioterrorism.mainheadline: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: More Security For Producer Of Vaccine

Smallpox and Bioterrorism.lead_paragraph: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, warned tonight that procuring 246 million doses of smallpox vaccine would cost more than the $509 million he had previously predicted. Mr. Thompson said that he told the Office of Management and Budget today that the cost would be higher, although he did not specify what it would be. The government had sought to pay a little more than $2 a dose.

headline.main: Smallpox Vaccine Costlier Than Expected

Smallpox and Bioterrorism.lead_paragraph: The nation's only manufacturer of anthrax vaccine expressed confidence today that it would soon win federal approval to distribute the vaccine. The manufacturer, the BioPort Corporation of Lansing, has been making the vaccine since 1998 but has been unable to ship it after failing federal inspections of its laboratories in 1999 and 2000.

headline.main: Vaccine Maker Hopeful Over License

Smallpox and Bioterrorism.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon wants to abandon its policy of anthrax vaccinations for all troops and limit shots to those with the highest risk, officials said today. The program to vaccinate all 2.4 million members of the active and reserve military was started in 1998, but it was radically reduced after safety and other violations by the nation's sole anthrax vaccine manufacturer left the Pentagon with a dwindling supply. In addition, some soldiers were highly reluctant to take the shots.

headline.main: Anthrax Shots for Military Personnel to Be Limited to High Risks

Smallpox and Bioterrorism.mainheadline: Anthrax Shots for Military Personnel to Be Limited to High Risks

Smallpox and Bioterrorism.lead_paragraph: A building at the Army Reserve Command headquarters in Fort McPherson on the south side of Atlanta was evacuated yesterday after a powder on a mailed package tested positive for anthrax, Army officials said. Six people in the mailroom were decontaminated after they were exposed to the package, a spokesman said. It was taken to the Centers for Disease Control for further tests. David Firestone (NYT)

headline.main: Briefly Noted; ANTHRAX EXPOSURE?

Smallpox and Bioterrorism.lead_paragraph: The anthrax vaccine does not appear to harm women's fertility, a study of Army women has found. The study involved women who were not believed to have been pregnant when they got their anthrax shots. It found that the vaccine appeared to have had no ill effects on pregnancy rates and birthrates.

headline.main: Fertility Isn't Hurt By Anthrax Shots

Smallpox and Bioterrorism.mainheadline: Fertility Isn't Hurt By Anthrax Shots

Smallpox and Bioterrorism.lead_paragraph: The city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported yesterday that more than 41,000 people had signed up with the World Trade Center Health Registry, which was created last September to track the health consequences of the 9/11 terrorist attack over the next 20 years. The registry is open to people who might have been exposed to dust and smoke from the disaster. The enrollment period ends in 10 weeks. Information is available at (866) 692-9827 and at 311, the city's information number. Details are also online at wtcregistry.org. Officials called the registry the largest public health registry of its kind in United States history.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Signup For 9/11 Health Study Is Ending

headline.main: Victims to Again Face Gunman in Fort Hood Trial
headline.print_headline: Victims to Again Face Gunman in Fort Hood Trial

Smallpox and Bioterrorism.lead_paragraph: The old smallpox warrior sat quietly in the audience today, his blue briefing book in his lap, wire-rimmed glasses resting on ruddy cheeks, as President Bush announced his long-awaited decision on who should get the smallpox vaccine. For Dr. Donald A. Henderson, it was a moment tinged with sadness. Dr. Henderson is the man who made the world safe from smallpox. From 1966 to 1977, he ran the worldwide effort to wipe out the disease. He oversaw countless public health workers who toiled under the most grueling conditions, living in villages without water or electricity and slipping in and out of war-torn nations to vaccinate people exposed to the virus, until the disease was no longer a threat.

headline.main: New Fight for an Old Warrior

Smallpox and Bioterrorism.mainheadline: New Fight for an Old Warrior

Taliban.lead_paragraph: A Muslim clergyman was attacked Tuesday night in the Bronx by three men who walked into a mosque and, without a word, struck him over the head with a piece of wood, the police said. Details were sketchy yesterday, but the mullah suffered only minor injuries. The police said the assault on the mullah, who is also black, was being investigated as a possible hate crime. The mullah, 35, whose name was not immediately released, was confronted about 8 p.m. by three men inside the Islamic Cultural Center at 371 East 166th Street, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Muslim Clergyman Attacked

Taliban.lead_paragraph: Aid workers in Kandahar, Afghanistan, have buried a man originally identified by the Taliban as an American, the International Committee of the Red Cross said today. Citing privacy concerns, Red Cross officials here would not identify the man or release his nationality, saying only that he was not an Afghan or an American.

headline.main: Taliban's Dead Man Wasn't From U.S.

Taliban.mainheadline: Taliban's Dead Man Wasn't From U.S.

Taliban.lead_paragraph: A man claiming to be an American was among more than 80 Taliban fighters who straggled out of a flooded basement days after their prison rebellion was crushed at an Afghan fort. ''U.S. military forces in Afghanistan have in their control a man who calls himself a U.S. citizen,'' Lt. Col. Jim Cassella, a Pentagon spokesman, said in Washington. ''He was among the Al Qaeda and Taliban prisoners held by the Northern Alliance in Mazar-i-Sharif.''

headline.main: Captive Fighter In Taliban Says He Is American

Taliban.lead_paragraph: Thousands of people in Khost, in the southeast, protested the new Afghan government for the fourth day. Khost is one of the nation's least secure areas, where the United States military continues operations to hunt Al Qaeda and Taliban members. The protesters are supporters of the powerful local warlord Bacha Khan Zadran, who is demanding that he be consulted on appointments of governors in the region. In the west, outside Herat, as many as 70 people were reported killed in fighting among ethnic Tajik and Pashtun soldiers. The Pashtuns appealed for help from the central government. Ian Fisher (NYT)

Taliban.lead_paragraph: President Pervez Musharraf said today that Americans were helping to provide communications support for Pakistani forces tracking down Al Qaeda and Taliban militants in Pakistan. ''There are some officials inside Pakistan for communication purposes but they are not fighting,'' General Musharraf told reporters. ''Americans not even in double figures are with us. They are communication experts.''

Taliban.lead_paragraph: An Islamic scholar who taught the American-born Taliban soldier John Walker Lindh for six months has been arrested in a United States-Pakistan operation, a Muslim leader said today. The scholar, Mufti Muhammad Iltimas, was arrested near the Afghan border in the village of Bannu, according to Qari Abdullah, a local leader of one of Pakistan's largest Islamic groups, Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam. Mufti Iltimas said he had learned of the arrest from residents of a nearby village.

Taliban.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors denied claims by lawyers for John Walker Lindh that he had been threatened with torture by the American military after his capture with Taliban forces in Afghanistan, saying Mr. Lindh got medical treatment, healthy meals and a haircut. The prosecutors were responding to court papers filed by the defense that requested a broad variety of government documents and access to captured Al Qaeda and Taliban prisoners. A court hearing on the request is scheduled for Monday. Mr. Lindh, a Californian who converted to Islam and joined the Taliban, faces an Aug. 26 federal trial on a 10-count indictment that accuses him of conspiring to kill Americans abroad.

The former wife, Kathryn King, who grew up in northwestern Alabama, died on Friday and was buried in suburban Washington. She was 30.

Taliban.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- The Pakistani government appeared Thursday to have moved to expel international staff members at the aid agency Save the Children , apparently over accusations that one of its employees helped the C.I.A. recruit a Pakistani doctor who played a role in tracking Osama bin Laden last year. In a statement issued from its London office early Thursday, Save the Children said the Pakistani Interior Ministry had ordered that ''visas for our six international staff in Pakistan may not be renewed.'' A senior aid official in Pakistan, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the staff members had been given until Sept. 12 to leave the country.

Taliban.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Over the last year, Marc Grossman, a veteran but low-key diplomat, led a small team of American officials who met secretly from Doha, Qatar, to Munich with a shadowy representative of Afghanistan's Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, in hopes of starting peace talks. The Obama administration's efforts to negotiate an end to the war, initially brokered by Germany's spy service, showed promise but have been scuttled more than once by rumors, deliberate leaks in Kabul, Islamabad and Washington and the assassination of the top Afghan negotiator in September by a supposed envoy wearing a bomb in his turban, Afghan and Western officials said.

Taliban.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- An American aid expert being held hostage by Al Qaeda in Pakistan was shown making an emotional appeal to President Obama to negotiate for his release in a video released on Monday in what analysts described as a jihadist counter against the wave of publicity that marked the first anniversary of the death of Osama bin Laden. The hostage, Warren Weinstein, a 70-year-old development consultant who was kidnapped in the eastern city of Lahore in August, appeared in the video released on the Internet. Wearing traditional Pakistani clothes, he appealed to Mr. Obama to bow to his captors' demands.

headline.main: Kidnapped American Makes Appeal to Obama in Qaeda Video

Taliban.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- After fleeing Afghanistan when the United States invaded the country in 2001, a group of terrorism suspects regrouped at a Pakistani safe house and began training for new kinds of operations -- building detonators for roadside bombs and learning ''Americanized'' English, according to a document made public by the military on Thursday. The document was a nine-page ''stipulation of fact'' signed with a thumbprint by Noor Uthman Muhammed, a Sudanese detainee at the military prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. He pleaded guilty this week in a military tribunal to providing material support for terrorism. A military jury is taking evidence for his sentencing hearing.

headline.main: Detainee Who Pleaded Guilty Describes Terror Training

Taliban.lead_paragraph: Afghanistan announced it had set up a commission to track down those responsible for the assassination of the anti-Taliban commander Ahmed Shah Masoud, as the country celebrated the 11th anniversary of the defeat of the Communist government. Mr. Massoud, also a famed anti-Soviet fighter, was killed by two suicide bombers posing as journalists in northern Afghanistan two days before the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

The station, Al Jazeera, said it was faxed a one-page statement from Mullah Omar. It provided no other details.

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Cuban officials objected today to Washington's plans for housing Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners at the American Navy base at Guantanamo Bay. Cuba's attorney general, Juan Escalona, scoffed at the plan, announced Thursday by Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld to bring detainees from the conflict in Afghanistan half-way around the world to the base on Cuba's southeast tip.

headline.main: Cuba Criticizes Plan

Guantanamo Bay.mainheadline: Cuba Criticizes Plan

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: A federal judge provided a significant legal victory for the Bush administration today when she dismissed lawsuits brought by two groups of detainees at Guantánamo Bay, saying United States courts had no jurisdiction over prisoners there. The judge, Colleen Kollar-Kotelly, said that the American naval base at Guantánamo, Cuba, where the detainees are being held, was not formally part of the United States and that as a result the detainees did not have constitutional protections. Under well-established principles, even noncitizens have some constitutional protections once they are inside the United States.

headline.main: Judge Rebuffs Detainees at Guantánamo

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: A reporter for the Arab satellite station Al Jazeera is being held at the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba, suspected of having links with the terror network of Al Qaeda, according to a statement issued by the station. Al Jazeera identified the reporter as Sami al-Hajj, a Sudanese, who it said was arrested in southern Afghanistan on Dec. 15.

headline.main: U.S. Holds Reporter, Arab Station Says

Guantanamo Bay.mainheadline: U.S. Holds Reporter, Arab Station Says

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: A state appellate court ruled last week that the federal government can keep the names of detainees being held in custody a secret. Since Sept. 11 more than 1,100 detainees have been held nationally, many of them in Hudson and Passaic County jails, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The ruling said that the release of detainees' names could compromise investigations and public safety. Civil liberties advocates wanted the names released to monitor detainees' treatment in custody and to ensure adequate legal representation. A representative of the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union said the group planned to appeal the ruling to the State Supreme Court. John Holl

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Some of Osama bin Laden's personal bodyguards have been apprehended and are now being held at the American military base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, government officials said today. The officials said the bodyguards had not been able to provide any conclusive evidence to suggest that Mr. bin Laden was still alive.

headline.main: Bin Laden Guards Held

Guantanamo Bay.mainheadline: Bin Laden Guards Held

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: In a harsh evaluation of American policy, Amnesty International says the United States has violated several international laws in its treatment of those captured during the war in Afghanistan and has failed to live up to its statements that it is complying with the Geneva Convention. ''Despite repeated statements that it is committed to international law and standards, the U.S. government is failing to meet its obligation to apply such law and standards to those it has in its custody in Afghanistan and Guantánamo Bay,'' the human rights organization says in a report to be released on Monday. ''In so doing, it has not only violated the rights of those individuals but threatens to undermine the rule of law everywhere.''

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: British Royal Marines preparing for a joint operation against remnants of Al Qaeda and Taliban forces in eastern Afghanistan said today that they would not hand any prisoners directly into American custody but would turn them over initially to the Afghan government. Lt. Col. Paul Harradine, a spokesman for British troops in Afghanistan, told a news conference at the Bagram base outside Kabul that lawyers in Britain had advised the military to take such action.

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: After nearly three months in prisons here, more than 320 Taliban fighters seized by Northern Alliance forces during the capture of the Afghan capital in mid-November were released tonight by the interim government headed by Hamid Karzai. The prisoners, many of them in light cotton clothing and plastic sandals, waited in 20-degree temperatures for Mr. Karzai to address them, on a lawn inside the old royal palace.

The prosecutors were responding to court papers filed by the defense that requested a broad variety of government documents and access to captured Al Qaeda and Taliban prisoners. A court hearing on the request is scheduled for Monday. Mr. Lindh, a Californian who converted to Islam and joined the Taliban, faces an Aug. 26 federal trial on a 10-count indictment that accuses him of conspiring to kill Americans abroad.

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The United States shipped 30 more Taliban and Qaeda detainees to the Navy base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, today, bringing to 50 the number sent there so far for interrogation and possible trial before military tribunals on terrorism charges. The detainees, flown from Kandahar, Afghanistan, on a C-17 transport jet, were shackled and wearing taped-over ski goggles and two-piece orange jump suits, as were the initial 20 who arrived at Guantánamo on Friday, said Lt. Col. Martin Compton of the Air Force, a spokesman for the Central Command in Tampa, Fla. In addition, he said, the detainees wore surgical masks because some had tested positive for tuberculosis.

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba -- As the United States restarts its effort to prosecute -- and ultimately execute -- five detainees accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks, it has fallen to Brig. Gen. Mark S. Martins both to prove them guilty and to show the world that the tribunal system is now legitimate. ''We're going to have a fair trial,'' General Martins, the chief prosecutor in the military commissions system, said in an interview this week. ''There are a lot of people who come to this with preconceptions about unfairness, and I would just ask people to withhold judgment. The initial version of commissions was flawed, but there has been a lot of work on reforms.''

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon announced on Saturday that it had transferred 35 detainees from the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to Pakistani custody, as part of a continuing effort by the Bush administration to reduce the number of prisoners at the naval base there. Under the terms of the transfer, which a Pentagon spokesman said Saturday had already been completed, Pakistan will hold 29 of the detainees while releasing another six. Pakistani officials said the detainees, 34 Pakistanis and one Afghan, arrived there late Saturday, Agence France-Presse reported. A Pentagon spokesman refused to confirm whether one of the released detainees was from Afghanistan.

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon said on Tuesday that it planned to begin hearings this week on the status of 14 prisoners who were transferred from secret prisons to the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The reviews are to determine formally if the prisoners, who include the accused mastermind of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, and 13 others, are properly held as enemy combatants and may be tried by special military courts.

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Vice President Dick Cheney strongly defended the American prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, on Monday, saying that it was essential to the administration's efforts to combat terrorism and that detainees there had been treated better by the United States than they could expect to be treated ''by virtually any other government on the face of the earth.'' To bolster his remarks, made in a speech at the National Press Club, Mr. Cheney added to the administration's previous warnings about the dangers of moving too quickly to free the more than 500 prisoners held at Guantánamo. He provided new details about what he said had been at least 10 released detainees who later turned up on battlefields to try to kill American troops.

headline.main: Cheney Calls Guantánamo Prison Essential

Guantanamo Bay.mainheadline: Cheney Calls Guantánamo Prison Essential

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: As the Iraqi insurgency intensified in early 2004, an elite Special Operations forces unit converted one of Saddam Hussein's former military bases near Baghdad into a top-secret detention center. There, American soldiers made one of the former Iraqi government's torture chambers into their own interrogation cell. They named it the Black Room. In the windowless, jet-black garage-size room, some soldiers beat prisoners with rifle butts, yelled and spit in their faces and, in a nearby area, used detainees for target practice in a game of jailer paintball. Their intention was to extract information to help hunt down Iraq's most-wanted terrorist, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, according to Defense Department personnel who served with the unit or were briefed on its operations.

headline.main: TASK FORCE 6-26: Inside Camp Nama; In Secret Unit's 'Black Room,' A Grim Portrait of U.S. Abuse

Guantanamo Bay.mainheadline: TASK FORCE 6-26: Inside Camp Nama; In Secret Unit's 'Black Room,' A Grim Portrait of U.S. Abuse

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: SOME debates are so polarized, with the competing sides so certain that any compromise would be dangerous, that it's hard to imagine any middle ground emerging. The argument over how to try the 14 terror suspects recently transferred from Central Intelligence Agency prisons to military custody at Guantánamo Bay seems to be one of them.

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The world has become more dangerous, and governments more repressive, since the effort to fight terrorism began after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on the United States, the human rights group Amnesty International said today. Releasing its annual report, the group singled out the United States for particular opprobrium, condemning its detention of 600 foreign nationals at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, as a ''human rights scandal'' and calling on the government to release or charge those held there.

headline.main: Amnesty Calls World Less Safe

Guantanamo Bay.mainheadline: Amnesty Calls World Less Safe

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Suicide attempts among terrorism suspects held at Guantánamo Bay in Cuba are on the rise, the Pentagon said yesterday. At least 5 of the more than 600 detainees at the naval base have tried to hang themselves in the past three weeks, said a Pentagon spokeswoman, Lt. Cmdr. Barbara Burfeind. Amnesty International urged the United States authorities to investigate the suicide attempts to determine whether the manner in which interrogations are conducted may have contributed.

headline.main: GUANTÁNAMO SUICIDE ATTEMPTS

Guantanamo Bay.mainheadline: GUANTÁNAMO SUICIDE ATTEMPTS

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court today blocked a challenge to the detention of the 600 Afghan war prisoners held at the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base, ruling that a group of clergy members and professors had no legal standing to represent them. The group, the Coalition of Clergy, Lawyers and Professors, sued on behalf of the prisoners, who they said had been deprived of their liberty without lawyers and had not been informed of the accusations against them.

headline.main: Guantánamo Detention Challenge Is Rejected

Guantanamo Bay.mainheadline: Guantánamo Detention Challenge Is Rejected

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: The American military said today that a man in United States custody at Bagram Air Base just north of Kabul had died. In a tersely worded statement, American authorities here said only that the man died Tuesday night, apparently from natural causes. ''The matter will be fully investigated,'' the statement read.

headline.main: Detainee at Base in Afghanistan Dies

Guantanamo Bay.mainheadline: Detainee at Base in Afghanistan Dies
