Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: A team from the Red Cross has met in recent days at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, with Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who is thought to have been the chief planner of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, and 13 other prisoners identified by the United States government as senior officials of Al Qaeda, Red Cross officials said Thursday. Until recently, the 14 had been held by the Central Intelligence Agency at undisclosed prisons for as long as four years. The meetings with the delegation from the International Committee of the Red Cross are believed to be, for many, their first contact since their capture with someone not connected with the United States government.

headline.main: Red Cross Interviews 14 Qaeda Terrorism Suspects at Guantánamo

Guantanamo Bay.mainheadline: Red Cross Interviews 14 Qaeda Terrorism Suspects at Guantánamo

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, suspected of being a Qaeda terrorist, was captured in Pakistan in 2004, held in secret prisons run by the C.I.A. and then moved to the naval base at Guantánamo Bay. During about five years of detention, he says, he was confined in harsh conditions, abused during interrogation and denied a lawyer. Since the spring, Mr. Ghailani has also been a defendant in federal court in Manhattan, the first Guantánamo detainee to be moved to the civilian courts.

headline.main: Terrorism Trial May Point Way For 9/11 Cases

Guantanamo Bay.mainheadline: Terrorism Trial May Point Way For 9/11 Cases

Guantanamo Bay.lead_paragraph: An Algerian man held for seven years at the American prison at Guantánamo Bay arrived in France on Tuesday, the French government and his lawyers said. The man, Saber Lahmar, 39, was the last of five Algerians to be released from the prison after a judge ruled last year that there was insufficient evidence to detain them. Robert C. Kirsch, a lawyer for Mr. Lahmar, said his client had been kept in isolation for about two and a half years.

headline.main: France: Algerian Freed From Guantánamo Prison

Cahill, agreed on Friday to arrange talks among television executives, state officials and Mr. Bloomberg. The mayor has opposed building a tower on Governors Island, which tops the broadcasters' list of choices. Station executives are also considering the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City. Although many organizations like movie studios and television production companies have deleted the towers from films and other images as a too-raw reminder of the Sept. 11 attack, the Fire Department has decided to keep the towers. ''There are absolutely no plans to change the emblem of the Fire Department,'' Nicholas Scoppetta, the new fire commissioner, said yesterday. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Jack Resnick & Sons rechristened its 14-story office tower in the financial district this past weekend, giving it the new name 255 Greenwich Street. The building, which is home to several New York City agencies including the Office of Management and Budget, had been known as 75 Park Place since it opened in 1987. The renaming is the latest move by landlords and developers to take advantage of a repositioning of Greenwich Street, which is poised to become a main thoroughfare running through the World Trade Center site when a long-closed stretch finally reopens next year.

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: For some fans of Antoni Gaudí, the towers going up at the World Trade Center site are a sad reminder of what might have been. The Catalan architect may be best known for Barcelona's Sagrada Família, a neo-gothic cathedral that looks as if it's melting, but in 1908 he designed a pearlescent, glass-studded spaceship of a hotel, which would at that time have been the world's tallest building, for the site that is now ground zero. Although it's unclear whether construction of such a skyscraper was feasible then, Hotel Attraction was intended to rise almost as high as the Empire State Building would 23 years later. In 2003, Spanish artists advocated building it as a 9/11 memorial and a ''present from Barcelona, like the Statue of Liberty.'' An American architect, Paul Laffoley, joined the campaign, saying the hotel could become the New York symbol Gaudí intended.

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam -- Construction crews got as far as the first floor of what was to be Saigon Residence, a high-end apartment building in the center of Ho Chi Minh City. All that remains today of the abandoned project are piles of moldy bricks, rusting steel rods and a small team of security guards who have transformed the cement foundation into a parking lot for motorcycles.In Vietnam 's major cities, a once-booming property market has come crashing down. Hundreds of abandoned construction sites are the most obvious signs of a sickly economy.

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: The 15-story Postal Service building at 90 Church Street, which has been closed since the adjacent World Trade Center collapsed three years ago, is to reopen on Monday, postal officials said yesterday. The building was contaminated with asbestos, mercury, mold and other substances and had to be gutted and have 800 of its windows replaced. The ornate marble lobby also had to be restored. ''We are excited to return this postal facility to the community,'' Postmaster Vinnie Malloy said.

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Larry A. Silverstein's effort to rebuild 7 World Trade Center suffered a setback yesterday when Moody's Investors Service sharply downgraded its assessment of his $383 million in debt on the property. The bond rating agency tied the downgrade to the developer's lack of progress in settling an insurance dispute over the original building after obtaining new financing and a tenant for the 52-story tower he has begun to build, said James Church, a senior analyst at Moody's. The original building was destroyed in the trade center attack. Although Mr. Silverstein has been at odds with Industrial Risk Insurers over the value of the property, he has started building a $700 million skyscraper on the site, at Washington and Vesey Streets. But rents downtown have fallen sharply, and there are few prospective tenants. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: There are roughly 400 million square feet of commercial real estate in Manhattan, an amount equal to more than 9,000 acres. For the last three decades, as the office market grew and matured, brokers and tenants began slicing that space into classes that signaled a building's amenities and location and, of course, the rent that its landlord could charge. Traditionally, four classifications are used for office buildings: trophy properties, which are mostly new construction that offer tenants the latest technologies, best locations and most exclusive tenancies; Class A, where the vintage may be somewhat older but the location or landmark architecture demands above-average rents; and Class B, mostly on Midtown side streets or peripheral locations, with average rents, services and building systems. Rounding it out are Class C properties, which are often simply Class B buildings that lack services. Often, Class C buildings will be upgraded to achieve higher rents and make better use of valuable real estate or be converted into residential units.

headline.main: Class-Consciousness in the Office Building Market

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: Class-Consciousness in the Office Building Market

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: The time to finish cleaning the basement of the former Deutsche Bank building in 2006 was so short that supervisors were getting antsy. Salvatore DePaola, an asbestos abatement foreman, constantly urged his team to hurry, Adolpho Ortiz, one of the cleaning workers, testified on Thursday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The director of the abatement work, Mitchel Alvo, angrily gestured and told workers to pick up the pace, Mr. Ortiz said. Mr. Alvo even slammed his construction helmet once, Mr. Ortiz said.

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: As an architecture student at Cooper Union three decades ago, Daniel Libeskind watched the World Trade Center being built. ''It was such an inspiring and controversial and wonderful moment,'' Mr. Libeskind said last week -- second only, perhaps, to the moment his design was chosen as the plan to rebuild the trade center. Centered on a recessed memorial to the victims of the 9/11 attack, the plan includes a spiral of buildings rising to a tower standing 1,776 feet -- ''a date or a number,'' he said, ''that will never be surpassed in world history.'' Edward Wyatt

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Workers will start dismantling the facade of the former Deutsche Bank building today as a prelude to its demolition, which is to begin in January, the Lower Manhattan Construction Command Center said yesterday. The building stands opposite ground zero at 130 Liberty Street, and was badly damaged and contaminated on Sept. 11, 2001. The command center said workers would dismantle aluminum column covers and windows at the top of the building, moving down from the 39th floor to the 35th. They will cut up the material and wrap it in plastic for removal from the site. DAVID W. DUNLAP

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: THE rise of the One Beacon Court tower at 58th Street and Third Avenue, site of Bloomberg L.P.'s new headquarters and multimillion-dollar condos, has increased the real estate stakes in what was once an area of unassuming mid-19th-century buildings. One of those remaining -- the most ambitious -- is the 1874 bank and apartment house at 201 East 57th Street, which was built when Third Avenue was the East Side's dominant thoroughfare.

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Most construction work can resume at the new headquarters of Goldman Sachs near ground zero, an official in the Department of Buildings said Saturday, a day after an architect was critically injured in an accident there. The department lifted a full stop-work order, but left in place a partial one forbidding crane operations, according to Robin Brooks, a spokeswoman for the department. She said the department was investigating a nylon sling that is believed to have snapped, allowing seven tons of steel studs to plummet about 13 floors from a crane and crush a trailer that sat on the building's scaffolding.

headline.main: Most Work to Resume at Goldman Site

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: Most Work to Resume at Goldman Site

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: The state agency that owns the former Deutsche Bank building hopes to resume work dismantling it next month, and the delays after a deadly fire should not affect the rebuilding schedule at the World Trade Center site, an agency official said yesterday. Avi Schick, the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, would not estimate the completion date for dismantling the tower, which now stands at 26 stories. Before the fire, the agency had said that the building, heavily damaged by the collapse of the trade center on Sept. 11, would be removed by the end of the year. Work to dismantle the tower floor by floor -- and clean several floors of toxic debris left by the trade center's collapse -- stopped after the Aug. 18 blaze, which killed two firefighters.

headline.main: Manhattan: Bank Dismantling To Resume

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: Manhattan: Bank Dismantling To Resume

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: The United States Green Building Council, a nonprofit group that promotes energy efficiency in construction and design, today will designate 7 World Trade Center, a 52-story skyscraper at ground zero, as the first office tower in New York City to be certified as ''green.'' The building, at Greenwich and Barclay Streets, developed by Silverstein Properties, is scheduled to open in May. The council cited the use of such design strategies as energy-conserving ultraclear glass, the recycling of rainwater to cool the tower, and construction from recycled materials. GLENN COLLINS (NYT)

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Silverstein Properties announced yesterday that a large Chinese developer, the Beijing Vantone Real Estate Company, has agreed in principle to rent 200,000 square feet on the top five floors of 7 World Trade Center. The space, to be leased for 10 years, would be used to establish a business and cultural institution called the China Center. The center would become the third paying tenant in the 52-story, 1.7-million-square-foot tower. GLENN COLLINS (NYT)

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street will not begin this month, as had been anticipated, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation said yesterday. On Monday, the federal Environmental Protection Agency raised questions about the proposed handling of waste materials containing polychlorinated biphenyls and cadmium in the heavily contaminated 41-story tower opposite ground zero. The corporation hopes to begin demolition later this summer, a spokesman said. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Razing Postponed

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Razing Postponed

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Workers preparing the former Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan for demolition have found additional bone fragments on the roof, bringing the total to more than 500 this month, city officials said yesterday. The building was heavily damaged and contaminated on Sept. 11, 2001, by the collapse of 2 World Trade Center, the south tower. Last week alone, 456 fragments -- some as small as one-sixteenth of an inch -- were separated from the rooftop ballast, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Remains Found At Bank

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Remains Found At Bank

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: A piece of landing gear, apparently from one of the jets that crashed into the twin towers on Sept. 11, 2001, was discovered wedged between two buildings on Wednesday.

headline.main: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero
headline.print_headline: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: The city has stopped construction on an office tower near ground zero after a chunk of steel fell 18 stories onto a ball field where children were playing on Saturday afternoon. The Department of Buildings said no one was hurt in the accident at 200 Murray Street, where the Goldman Sachs headquarters is under construction. The builder, Tishman Construction, was cited with five violations.

headline.main: Steel Falls 18 Floors Onto Field

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: Steel Falls 18 Floors Onto Field

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Larry Davis, owner of DCM Erectors Inc., is expected to be charged with evading requirements on hiring subcontractors, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline.print_headline: Trade Center Contractor Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry Into Misuse of Funds

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: World Trade Center Contractor Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry Into Misuse of Funds

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Mills Hotel No. 3, once a lodging house for working men in New York City, is now up for landmark designation.

headline.print_headline: A Decent Bed, and With Luck a Dry Towel

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: A Decent Bed, and With Luck a Dry Towel

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: The administration of Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. is considering selling the state-owned Baltimore-Washington International Airport and the World Trade Center, a landmark 32-story building on Baltimore's Inner Harbor. Henry Fawell, a spokesman for Mr. Ehrlich, a Republican, said selling the properties could ease the state's budget difficulties. He had no estimate on asking prices for the sites. Gary Gately (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: State Considers Real Estate Sales

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: State Considers Real Estate Sales

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: A section of steel girder from the World Trade Center given to the British will be buried rather than displayed in a planned memorial garden in London, to prevent distress to victims' relatives, officials said yesterday. The Department of Culture, Media and Sport is overseeing the memorial's construction. The blackened, twisted piece of metal from the north tower was given to Britain by the mayor's office in New York for a memorial in Grosvenor Square, opposite the United States Embassy. Sixty-seven Britons were killed in the terrorist attack.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Sept. 11 Memorial In London

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Sept. 11 Memorial In London

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: An office building severely damaged in the attack on the World Trade Center has been sold, and its buyer is considering converting it into condominiums. The buyer, Brack Capital Real Estate Ltd., an international real estate company, paid $12.25 million to Aegon USA Realty Advisors for the 23-story office building at 90 West Street. But Brack will have to spend more than $50 million to repair the fire-scarred building, built in 1907, and restore architectural features. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Building Near Ground Zero Is Sold

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Building Near Ground Zero Is Sold

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Running for Cover ''I saw people jumping out of the building. A lady in a green suit jumping out of the building. A man in jeans jumping out of the building. When I saw people jumping out of the building I just couldn't take it anymore. I just ran.''

headline.main: Personal Accounts of a Morning Rush That Became the Unthinkable
headline.kicker: A DAY OF TERROR: THE VOICES

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: Personal Accounts of a Morning Rush That Became the Unthinkable

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Plans for rebuilding the World Trade Center site became more concrete as New York City and state officials chose two finalists to design the future of ground zero. Rebuilding officials will choose by the end of the month between a proposal from Studio Daniel Libeskind, which would set the memorial to victims in a 70-foot pit where most remains were found, and one from a team of architects called Think, which would build two latticework towers, evoking the original ones but including cultural and educational facilities. Each plan includes what would be the world's tallest tower but neither has office space at the top. Edward Wyatt

headline.main: February 2-8: NATIONAL; REBUILDING PLANS

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: February 2-8: NATIONAL; REBUILDING PLANS

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank sued New York State yesterday, contending that the state was negligent in failing to protect the bank's headquarters building, at 130 Liberty Street, after the collapse of the World Trade Center towers. The lawsuit follows the dismissal last month of a similar complaint against New York City. Both actions were filed in United States District Court in Manhattan. A spokeswoman for the bank said the lawsuit was required by the bank's insurance policies on the building, which was severely damaged by debris from the World Trade Center. The bank wants to tear down the building and is fighting two of its insurers, which say the building can be repaired and reoccupied. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Building Owner Sues

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Building Owner Sues

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: Ed Greene was trudging home to the Upper West Side along Eighth Avenue with memories of Sept. 11, 2001, the day he had walked down to safety from the 71st floor of the North Tower. ''I only walked down seven floors today,'' said Mr. Greene, a computer analyst for the Port Authority. Mr. Greene said he had been working at his desk, of course, in his office at 1 Madison Avenue at 23rd Street, ''when suddenly it seemed that something melted.''

headline.main: Memories of Sept. 11

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: Memories of Sept. 11

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: The rise of skyscrapers that dwarf their neighbors, sometimes elegantly but too often not, has prompted an argument: Should New York City put more limits on its skyline?

headline.print_headline: Seeing a Need for Oversight of New York’s Lordly Towers

WTC Structure and Engineering.lead_paragraph: In Lower Manhattan, the security continues to be very tight — too tight for some New Yorkers who remember living in a more freewheeling city.

headline.print_headline: More Than a Decade After 9/11, a Bull Market for Barriers and Checkpoints

WTC Structure and Engineering.mainheadline: More Than a Decade After 9/11, a Bull Market for Barriers and Checkpoints

Taliban - Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: Northern Alliance soldiers attacked a stranded and desperate Taliban force early this morning here, about 12 miles west of Kabul. The Taliban were surrounded, according to alliance commanders. A week of negotiations had foundered before troops began to move toward the forward posts of the trapped militia.

headline.main: Alliance Strikes Taliban Troops Outside Kabul

Taliban - Afghanistan.mainheadline: Alliance Strikes Taliban Troops Outside Kabul

Taliban - Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: A government security force trying to exert control over Mazar-i-Sharif, northern Afghanistan's largest city, has told militia factions to withdraw within two days, the force commander, Gen. Majid Rouzi, said. The militias appeared to heed the warning and called their fighters back to barracks outside the city.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; WARNING IN MAZAR

Taliban - Afghanistan.lead_paragraph: Turkey’s foreign minister offered his vision of a new order for the Arab world, where the country’s former allies in Syria and Israel fall into deeper isolation.

headline.seo: Turkey Predicts Partnership With Egypt as Regional Anchors

headline.print_headline: Partnership With Egypt Is Predicted By Turkey

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller and Councilman Michael E. McMahon introduced a resolution yesterday calling on Congress to bestow the Presidential Medal of Freedom on the Rev. Mychal F. Judge, above. Father Judge, a Roman Catholic priest who was the chaplain of the New York Fire Department, was killed during the Sept. 11 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center as he gave last rites to one of the victims. ''Father Mike was a man who offered spiritual uplift and moral compass to all,'' Mr. Miller said at a news conference at City Hall. Officials of the Fire Department flanked Mr. Miller during the announcement. Winnie Hu (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Honor Urged For Chaplain

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Honor Urged For Chaplain

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Fire Commissioner Thomas Von Essen said yesterday that the city and the International Association of Firefighters would stage a memorial service on Nov. 18 at Madison Square Garden for the 343 firefighters who died in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. At a news conference with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Von Essen said the city hoped to accommodate ''most of our firefighters'' and families of the firefighters who were lost.

headline.main: Tribute for Firefighters Will Have a Global Reach

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Tribute for Firefighters Will Have a Global Reach

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: A man who authorities say posed as a firefighter and received free meals and other amenities while pretending to help with the Sept. 11 rescue effort was extradited to New York yesterday to face criminal charges, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. The man, Jerome Brandl, 34, was arrested in Pennsylvania on an unrelated charge of driving a stolen vehicle. From Sept. 18 to 25, posing as a volunteer firefighter from Milwaukee, Mr. Brandl stayed at Engine Company 39 in Manhattan, where he ate catered meals, collected relief donations and stole a Fire Department parking pass, officials said. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged With Fraud Is Extradited

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged With Fraud Is Extradited

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: A Manhattan judge dismissed charges yesterday that had been filed against 18 firefighters who scuffled with police officers last month. The charges stemmed from the firefighters' Nov. 2 protest march and confrontation with the police after city officials limited the number of the city's firefighters who could search the World Trade Center rubble for bodies. At the request of the district attorney's office, Judge Gregory Carro of Criminal Court dismissed trespass charges against all the firefighters and an assault charge that was filed against one who had been accused of hitting a police officer. ''The interest of justice would not be served by proceeding with the prosecution,'' Assistant District Attorney Kavita Gopwani told the judge.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters' Charges Dropped

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters' Charges Dropped

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Over the next few weeks, the Fire Department will be testing new hand-held radios designed to penetrate deep into high-rise buildings like the World Trade Center. The city had pulled the radios from service in March 2001 and resumed using older equipment after a firefighter's call for help during a Queens fire went unheard. But the performance of the older radios on Sept. 11 has been criticized by some fire officers who say communication problems contributed to the deaths of 343 firefighters. Tests began in the Bronx on Saturday, and firefighters in Staten Island will get the radios on Aug. 26 during an eight-week pilot program. If all goes well, the radios will be distributed citywide in the fall. Alan Feuer (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Testing Begins On New Fire Radios

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Testing Begins On New Fire Radios

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: City firefighter unions have prepared full-page newspaper advertisements to criticize the city for blocking proposed changes in their pension system, the unions said yesterday. The ads, set to run today under the headline ''Save the FDNY,'' argue that the changes would help prevent retirements. Many firefighters say they cannot afford to pass up the opportunity to retire on salaries increased by the overtime they earned after the World Trade Center attack. The changes would allow firefighters to use their highest-earning year, not their last year, when calculating pension benefits. City officials say that the city has already made significant pension adjustments sought by the unions and that this proposal would cost too much money. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters To Use Ads

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters To Use Ads

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Joe Theismann was trying to counsel the New York City firefighters Tom McCain, Kevin O'Brien and Guy Warren yesterday on how to handle pressure situations. Not the kind of pressure Theismann, now a broadcast analyst for ESPN, faced when he quarterbacked the Washington Redskins to victory in Super Bowl XVII. This was the kind of pressure he feels when he tees off at the American Century celebrity golf tournament in Lake Tahoe, Nev.

headline.main: Firefighters Hear Tips About Pressure

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Firefighters Hear Tips About Pressure

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: New York City will expand its hazardous-materials training for firefighters with a $3.2 million federal grant, fire officials said yesterday. The Fire Department, which is facing budget cuts, lost nearly a quarter of the firefighters it had certified to handle hazardous materials on Sept. 11. The training will be done by the International Association of Firefighters, a labor organization that sought the funds on behalf of city firefighter unions. ''We are especially pleased it covers 100 percent of the costs to the department,'' said Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Dept. Training Grant

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Dept. Training Grant

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Officials of the union that represents New York City firefighters said yesterday that the Fire Department has done an inadequate job of cleaning trucks that might have been exposed to toxic substances when the World Trade Center collapsed. Five of the 200 fire trucks that were present when the buildings fell have tested positive for the presence of asbestos and either have, or will be, decontaminated, fire officials said.

headline.main: Union Asks Better Cleaning of Fire Trucks

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Union Asks Better Cleaning of Fire Trucks

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Nextel Communications said yesterday that it would pay an undisclosed sum to be the underwriter of a two-hour special that will be on CBS on March 10 and is based on the videotape shot by two French filmmakers of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center.

headline.main: Nextel Will Underwrite TV Special on Attacks

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Nextel Will Underwrite TV Special on Attacks

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The remains of 3 firefighters were uncovered at the World Trade Center site yesterday, a day after the remains of at least 11 were unearthed in the biggest find in weeks. Firefighter Louis Giaconelli, a department spokesman, said that none of those discovered yesterday had been identified. He said two of the firefighters uncovered on Tuesday were identified as Michael F. Lynch and John Tipping II, both 33. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters' Remains Found

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters' Remains Found

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The Fire Department has banned fire companies from rushing to ground zero when a firefighter's remains are found. Firefighters had developed an informal policy of going to the site in keeping with the tradition in which firefighters carry their fallen brethren from the scene of a disaster. In explaining the new policy, reported yesterday in The Daily News, Deputy Commissioner Francis X. Gribbon said the department was seeking to maintain order. ''We are trying to keep an official notification process, where a body is removed respectfully by those who are at the site,'' he said.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Dept. Sets New Rules On Recovery

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Dept. Sets New Rules On Recovery

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Angelo R. Mozilo, Countrywide Financial’s chief executive, was publicly buoyant about its ability to ride out the mortgage crisis. Privately, he was gloomier.

headline.seo: Public Bravado, Private Doubts at Countrywide
headline.main: How Countrywide Covered the Cracks
headline.sub: Angelo Mozilo’s Public Bravado and Private Doubts ;
headline.print_headline: How Countrywide Covered the Cracks

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: How Countrywide Covered the Cracks

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the New York Fire Department would buy 1,500 new air masks that protect firefighters from hazardous materials like nerve agents and other dangerous chemicals. The new masks, which Mr. Bloomberg described during a graduation ceremony for 233 probationary firefighters yesterday in Brooklyn, will cost $3.5 million. In his remarks, Mr. Bloomberg also defended his decision to transfer some responsibilities of the Fire Department to the Police Department, including major control over the city's response to biological or chemical attacks.

headline.main: Bloomberg Defends Changes To Fire Dept.

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Bloomberg Defends Changes To Fire Dept.

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Project Liberty, a crisis-counseling program for people and groups affected by Sept. 11, which was to close down at the end of this month, will be allowed to continue at least until September, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton announced yesterday. Senator Clinton, who has been an advocate of the program, learned of the extension from a letter sent this month by the Department of Health and Human Services, said Jennifer Hanley, the senator's press secretary. Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said he hoped the extension would give Senator Clinton and others a chance to press for another year of services. About 9,000 Fire Department members have already used the program, he said. Mary Spicuzza (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Counseling Program Extended

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Counseling Program Extended

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, agreed yesterday to hear an appeal by The New York Times, which is seeking the New York Fire Department's unedited records of the Sept. 11 terror attack. The records include oral histories by firefighters and other Fire Department employees, the department's radio dispatch tapes and tapes of 911 emergency calls. The department has cited privacy concerns and possible interference with the pending prosecution of Zacarias Moussaoui, who is accused of helping plan the attack. The Court of Appeals may hear oral arguments in the case as early as the fall. In January, a panel of the Supreme Court's Appellate Division upheld a lower court's ruling that portions of the records -- including the opinions of firefighters and the voices of 911 callers -- could be withheld from the news media under exemptions to the state Freedom of Information Law.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: High Court To Hear Times Suit

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: High Court To Hear Times Suit

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: A federal lawsuit accusing New York City of supplying firefighters with faulty radio equipment on Sept. 11, 2001, has been expanded to blame the manufacturer for the equipment failures. In the expanded suit, filed on Tuesday, lawyers for the families of a dozen New York firefighters who died at the World Trade Center charged that the manufacturer, Motorola, knew about the flaws when it sold the radios to the city in 1999, but deceived officials to win an additional contract. A spokeswoman for Motorola said yesterday that there was no basis for the lawsuit, which was filed in Federal District Court in December. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters' Lawsuit Expands

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters' Lawsuit Expands

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan dismissed a lawsuit yesterday that accused the City of New York City and Motorola of providing firefighters with faulty radio equipment that was in use on Sept. 11, 2001. Representatives of 12 firefighters who died in the collapse of the World Trade Center filed the suit. They claimed that the faulty radios deprived the firefighters of information that could have saved their lives. Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of United States District Court dismissed the case, saying that the plaintiffs waived their right to sue when they decided to participate in the Victim Compensation Fund. Susan M. Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suit Involving Fire Radios Is Dismissed

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suit Involving Fire Radios Is Dismissed

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan yesterday threw out a lawsuit against New York City by eight firefighters who claimed that their constitutional rights were violated when they were arrested at a protest at ground zero on Nov. 2, 2001. The firefighters, including Michael Carter, a vice president of the Uniformed Firefighters' Association, joined a march that day to protest orders from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to cut back on police officers and firefighters searching for victims' remains in the ruins of the World Trade Center. All charges against people arrested at the protest were dropped a month later. Judge Richard J. Holwell ruled that the firefighters' arrests were not malicious because it was clear they were not authorized to march to the trade center site. Julia Preston (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Protest Suit Is Dismissed

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Protest Suit Is Dismissed

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The alarm was not fully activated to avoid waking up the crew, and so did not sound during the disaster.

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The state and city will receive $250 million from the federal government to help pay the pensions of police officers and firefighters killed in the attack on the World Trade Center, Gov. George E. Pataki and federal officials said yesterday. The grants from the Federal Emergency Management Agency will cover the unforeseen increases in contributions to the pension system. The state and city had to pay the increases to cover benefits for the families of 343 firefighters and 23 police officers who died in the attack. The funds are part of about $8.8 billion in FEMA grants already pledged to the city and state, state officials said. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pension Aid Received

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pension Aid Received

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The International Association of Fire Fighters said Rudolph W. Giuliani committed ''egregious acts'' against firefighters who died in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. In a letter to its members, the union excoriated Mr. Giuliani, the Republican presidential candidate and former mayor of New York, for his November 2001 decision to cut back the number of firefighters searching the rubble of the World Trade Center for the remains of some 300 comrades. The 280,000-member union accused him of carelessly speeding the cleanup after the recovery of millions of dollars in assets from the Bank of Nova Scotia that had been buried. Mr. Giuliani's campaign insisted that he respected and supported the first responders.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Firefighters Criticize Giuliani Over 9/11

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: Firefighters Criticize Giuliani Over 9/11

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: Delayed by what the fire commissioner says was ''poor management,'' the city plans to release a new avalanche of documentary records from Sept. 11, including more than 1,600 phone calls made to emergency services that morning. While most of these are calls made by people outside the buildings or watching television, officials say about 31 were from people who were part of the morning's narrative of struggle and loss: 21 firefighters who died and 10 civilians who were also in the World Trade Center towers.

headline.main: Fire Department Releasing More 9/11 Emergency Calls

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Fire Department Releasing More 9/11 Emergency Calls

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: A day after a blast in West, Tex., so powerful it registered as an earthquake, the cause was unclear but the effects — as many as 15 dead, up to 180 hurt and much of a town gone — were plain.

headline.seo: Huge Blast at Texas Fertilizer Plant Kills at Least 5
headline.main: Plant Explosion Tears at the Heart of a Texas Town
headline.print_headline: Blast at Plant Tears at Heart Of Texas Town

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Plant Explosion Tears at the Heart of a Texas Town

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: After a five-year battle, the United States government has dropped its effort to prevent a volunteer firefighter killed at the World Trade Center from receiving a death benefit for public safety officers who die on the job. The firefighter, Glenn J. Winuk, was a longtime member of the Jericho Volunteer Fire Department who rushed to the burning towers on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline.main: Family of 9/11 Rescuer Wins Case for Benefit

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Family of 9/11 Rescuer Wins Case for Benefit

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The story of her improbable rescue by New York City firefighters was among the most enduring to emanate from the horror of Sept. 11, 2001. It was told and retold: how a weary woman, Josephine Harris, was coaxed and carried to safety by six men from Ladder Company 6 in Chinatown who had rushed to the World Trade Center that morning. It was a feat of timing, engineering and plain luck that when the rush of wind and noise came and the north tower fell away, the firefighters and Ms. Harris were not crushed in a sea of concrete, dust and steel as they were spread along the stairwell between the fourth and first floors. Rather, the building fell around them.

headline.main: Mourning A Woman Who Shared A 9/11 Escape

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Mourning A Woman Who Shared A 9/11 Escape

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: An Our Towns column last Thursday described Michael Bellone, a former nightclub bouncer who worked as a volunteer with firefighters and the police at ground zero in Lower Manhattan for months after Sept. 11, 2001. He helped recover the remains of victims and, as part of an effort to keep alive the memory, now has a fire truck that bears the names of all 343 members of the Fire Department who died that day. The column omitted one pertinent element of Mr. Bellone's relationship with the Fire Department. As other news organizations reported at the time, he was briefly arrested in 2005 and accused of misrepresenting himself and using official equipment illegally as part of presentations on the disaster to school children and others. The Manhattan District Attorney's office decided on the day of his arrest not to prosecute him, and the equipment was returned to the Fire Department.

headline.main: Postscript

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Postscript

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: While the WPP Group owns Madison Avenue icons like J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather, its chief executive, Sir Martin Sorrell, is not well known in New York. He is not even a resident, preferring his home in London and his villa in France. So it came as something of a surprise to learn that he is supporting Keep NYC's Firehouses Open, a nonprofit campaign raising money to save eight New York City firehouses from being closed by the city to cut costs.

headline.main: Private Sector; Out-of-Town Help for New York City

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Private Sector; Out-of-Town Help for New York City

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: For decades, the remains of firefighters who died in the line of duty were carried to funerals on a fire engine that had been dedicated to that solemn purpose and no other. But the caisson, as the Fire Department calls the equipment, was not used at the burials last weekend of Chief Peter Ganci, First Deputy Commissioner William Feehan, or Chaplain Mychael Judge. Nor was it to be used at the four funerals for firefighters today.

headline.main: Pressed Back Into Service

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Pressed Back Into Service

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration will release about $2 billion in federal assistance to cover costs stemming from the attack on the World Trade Center, according to three members of the state's Congressional delegation. Senator Charles E. Schumer, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative James T. Walsh said the money would be used to cover Police Department and Fire Department expenses, defray the cost of insurance for contractors and pay for other expenses not covered under a federal aid package. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: $2 Billion In U.S. Aid To Be Released

NY Fire Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: $2 Billion In U.S. Aid To Be Released

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: More than 100 firefighters protested outside a book reading last night by William Langewiesche, author of a best selling account of the cleanup operation at ground zero. The reading from ''American Ground,'' a book based on Mr. Langewiesche's observations and interviews, was part of a series at the South Street Seaport Museum. Protesters near the museum entrance waved placards calling Mr. Langewiesche a liar, and some complained bitterly of a brief section in the book implying that firefighters might have engaged in looting. ''The author of this book is a disgrace,'' Peter Gorman, president of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association, said at the rally. Mr. Langewiesche said he had written ''frankly,'' using information from ''sources who proved reliable over months.'' Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: A college student was charged yesterday with using a parking permit from a fire commissioner who died in the World Trade Center attack, fire officials said yesterday. The student, Vadim Reznikov, 20, of Brooklyn, was charged with possession of stolen property and other crimes. The dead commissioner, William Feehan, 71, was the Fire Department's second in command and had left his car on Broadway when he rushed inside the trade center on Sept. 11. Yesterday, fire marshals investigating the improper use of placards spotted Mr. Feehan's permit in the windshield of an Oldsmobile parked near Pace University. Nine other people have been arrested by marshals since September on charges of using fake parking permits. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

NY Fire Department.lead_paragraph: A city firefighters union has sued the Fire Department to stop it from reducing engine staffing in the face of budget shortfalls. The Uniformed Firefighters Association contends that the plan to reduce the size of crews on dozens of fire engines would endanger lives and violate a collective bargaining agreement. The department responded yesterday that the plan was legal and that firefighters would be able to work safely. ''This is a contractual provision that the union agreed to,'' said Francis X. Gribbon, a Fire Department spokesman. The department plans to reduce crew sizes to four from five on more than 50 engines under an agreement allowing it to do so if firefighters' sick leave climbs above a preset level. The firefighters' union claims that the sick leave rate has been artificially inflated by staff reductions and illnesses caused by the World Trade Center attack.

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A man who pleaded guilty in June to fraud by soliciting donations for a bogus charity for families of New York police officers killed in the line of duty -- including the World Trade Center attack -- was sentenced yesterday to eight years and one month in prison. The defendant, Justin Patrick White, 59, of Queens, paid out less than six cents of every dollar donated. In 2000 and 2001, he collected $441,075 in donations from businesses and individuals for the Police Survivor's Fund, but paid out only $24,500 to slain officers' families, a federal indictment said. Susan Saulny (NYT)

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: New York City is expected to announce as early as today that it has agreed to let the federal government review key city documents long sought for a federal inquiry into the city's emergency response to the terror attack on Sept. 11, 2001. The city has argued that the material is confidential, although it never formally rejected the federal request, saying only that it needed more time. The documents are Fire and Police Department records that federal investigators requested a year ago as part of an inquiry by the National Institute of Standards and Technology, which wants to review police 911 tapes as well as transcripts of interviews with hundreds of surviving firefighters so that it can understand how the city handled the trade center evacuation. The institute has said that its goal is to save lives in any future building catastrophes. Eric Lipton (NYT)

Details were sketchy yesterday, but the mullah suffered only minor injuries. The police said the assault on the mullah, who is also black, was being investigated as a possible hate crime. The mullah, 35, whose name was not immediately released, was confronted about 8 p.m. by three men inside the Islamic Cultural Center at 371 East 166th Street, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: As the city's largest police union prepared for a rally today in Times Square to call for larger salary increases, it posted law enforcement job openings from across the nation on its Web site, highlighting the differences between officers' salaries in New York and those in places like Seattle and Champaign, Ill. The link to the job openings, an image of a brown leather suitcase with the word ''Employment'' on it, began appearing Monday night on the Web site of the union, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association (www.nycpba.org), and was first reported yesterday in The Daily News. The starting wages for the positions listed were generally higher than the $31,305 that New York City officers earn: $46,146 in Seattle; $46,463 in Irvine, Calif.; $37,079 in Jackson, Wyo.; $39,686 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The police are searching for a man who apparently stole the identity of a man who died in the attack on the World Trade Center. The widow of Sean Booker alerted the authorities after a letter addressed to her husband indicated he had received a traffic ticket May 5 in Tarboro, N.C. The police have not been able to find the man, whom they identified as Anthony Andrew Fernandez, also known as Leslie Patrick Cumberbatch. His last known address was in Brooklyn, but the police say he no longer lives there. The police say Mr. Fernandez is in the country illegally, but they do not know when he returned after being deported to his native Guyana in 1998 because of a drug charge.

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The New York City Police Department installed its first radiation detector outside police headquarters yesterday. The detector, which people must walk through to enter the building, is one of four the department has, a senior police official said. Another will be in the garage of police headquarters, one will be used by the Emergency Services Unit, and another will be given to the bomb squad, the official said. The detector, called a radiation portal monitor, consists of two upright black poles, about three inches in diameter and six to eight feet apart. ''They're easily deployable,'' the official said, calling the detectors a precautionary measure. ''There was no trigger, it's just another counterterrorism response,'' he said. It was unclear last night whether similar measures were being taken at other buildings across the city and how much the devices cost. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The Spanish police rounded up four more men suspected of belonging to Al Qaeda cells in Spain. In a pile of homemade videos taken from one of the suspects, the police found hours of what they described as surveillance tapes filmed in 1997 at the World Trade Center and other American landmarks. The tapes were taken at the Statue of Liberty, Disneyland and other sites, and were shot from various angles and distances, with an unusual interest in structures and access. Tim Golden

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has sent a team of investigators to Israel for training on how to detect suicide bombers and prevent them from carrying out attacks here. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that the department must be prepared for myriad terrorist threats, including suicide bombings like the one yesterday at an open-air market in Netanya, Israel. The training in Israel, first reoprted yesterday in The Daily News, is the latest effort by the police to prepare for terrorist attacks, and to seek to prevent them. Mr. Kelly announced recently that he would send 30 of his executive staff members to the Naval War College in Newport, R.I., to study mock disasters. Last month, he assigned investigators to work full time at F.B.I. headquarters in Washington. Al Baker (NYT)

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Four Port Authority police officers have been reassigned from ground zero after tests showed they had elevated levels of mercury in their blood, said Allen Morrison, a Port Authority spokesman. The officers are in good health, and were reassigned as a precautionary measure. The normal range of mercury is 0 to 13 micrograms per liter of blood, and two of the four officers tested at 14, one at 18, and one at 24, Mr. Morrison said. The Port Authority's medical department has voluntarily tested 58 officers working at the World Trade Center site since mid-November, and is continuing to monitor their health. ''Even though we can't be certain it came from working at ground zero, we thought it would be prudent to reassign these officers,'' Mr. Morrison said. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Crime at airports, bus terminals and other sites operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey fell by 8.3 percent last year and has dropped by 44.8 percent since the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, officials said. Crime is defined as robbery, larceny, or assault, said Tony Ciavolella, a Port Authority spokesman. He said the decline was attributed largely to the 550 new police officers the authority had hired since the attacks, and to a $300 million security upgrade. The agency now has more than 1,600 officers. The authority, which also operates the PATH commuter trains, has been on a heightened state of alert since 2001. The authority, which lost 37 of its officers in the attack on the World Trade Center, now has 1,600 officers. John Holl (NYT)

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan yesterday threw out a lawsuit against New York City by eight firefighters who claimed that their constitutional rights were violated when they were arrested at a protest at ground zero on Nov. 2, 2001. The firefighters, including Michael Carter, a vice president of the Uniformed Firefighters' Association, joined a march that day to protest orders from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to cut back on police officers and firefighters searching for victims' remains in the ruins of the World Trade Center. All charges against people arrested at the protest were dropped a month later. Judge Richard J. Holwell ruled that the firefighters' arrests were not malicious because it was clear they were not authorized to march to the trade center site. Julia Preston (NYT)

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: The state and city will receive $250 million from the federal government to help pay the pensions of police officers and firefighters killed in the attack on the World Trade Center, Gov. George E. Pataki and federal officials said yesterday. The grants from the Federal Emergency Management Agency will cover the unforeseen increases in contributions to the pension system. The state and city had to pay the increases to cover benefits for the families of 343 firefighters and 23 police officers who died in the attack. The funds are part of about $8.8 billion in FEMA grants already pledged to the city and state, state officials said. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Bernard Kerik, left, the former police commissioner, acknowledged yesterday through a spokesman that he had received thousands of dollars in royalties for a 282-word foreword to a 2001 book praising the work of firefighters and police officers who were killed on Sept. 11, but a spokesman said he had contributed the money to various 9/11 charities. Mr. Kerik also chose photographs for and did other editorial work on the book, ''In The Line of Duty,'' which was published in hardcover and paperback by Regan Books. The spokesman, Robert Leonard, said that in early 2002, Mr. Kerik signed papers concerning the book but did not realize that they authorized the payment of royalties. The royalties, which totaled nearly $76,000, were reported yesterday in The New York Daily News. Since late 2001, Mr. Kerik has contributed $120,000, including the book royalties, to Sept. 11 charities, Mr. Leonard said.

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Some New York City police officers who arrived here over the last few days were serving on the front lines of a national crisis for a second time. They had been there, too, when the attack on the World Trade Center, a man-made disaster, took the lives of 23 members of their department. The New York police volunteers arrived in caravans only a few days before the fourth anniversary of the Sept. 11 attack and set out, often without sleep, on search-and-rescue, security, evacuation and patrol missions. To exhausted police and emergency crews in Louisiana, they are an army of relief, their numbers and discipline providing steady hands in a challenging situation.

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: For the first time, the federal government is financing health care treatments for thousands of firefighters, police officers and other first responders sickened by their work at ground zero in the weeks after the attack on the twin towers. The Bush administration announced yesterday how it will disburse $75 million in health care funds it had attempted to rescind until members of New York's Congressional delegation objected. The money will go to several screening and treatment programs, including one at Mount Sinai Medical Center that has examined more than 10,000 workers and ground zero volunteers. The money will also help finance the Fire Department's medical treatment program, a Police Department mental health program and the city department of health's World Trade Center Health Registry. ANTHONY DEPALMA (NYT)

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A knife-wielding deli worker at a Memphis supermarket wounded eight co-workers, injuring one critically, before he was tackled outside the store, the police said. The man, Elartrice Ingram, 21, was in custody after the attack at the Schnucks grocery store on the outskirts of Memphis, said Sgt. Vince Higgins of the Memphis Police Department. Sergeant Higgins said the man attacked a female employee in a manager's office at 9:25 a.m. She screamed, and other employees came to her assistance, the sergeant said. The man then attacked six other workers. Sergeant Higgins said it was not clear what had preceded the attack. THEO EMERY (NYT)

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A jury has acquitted a city engineer who was charged with assaulting Port Authority police officers during a scuffle at ground zero last year. The engineer, Michael Kenny, 41, faced up to one year in jail before the jury cleared him in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday. Mr. Kenny, who works for the Department of Design and Construction, which oversees the ground zero cleanup, was accused of interfering with the arrest of a laborer involved in a dispute with the officers. Mr. Kenny resisted arrest, the complaint said. Last Friday, he testified that he was trying to help a man and did not know he was interfering with an arrest. Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Cleared In Ground Zero Scuffle

NY Police Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Cleared In Ground Zero Scuffle

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: A state judge has ruled that the New York Police Department must take the first steps toward removing security barricades that have angered Chinatown residents, but it stopped short of ordering the reopening of the street. The barricades, north on Park Row from Frankfort Street to Chatham Square, helped protect nearby police headquarters after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack. But Chinatown residents complained they were not consulted about the street closing and were unable to invite family members or friends to their homes. In a decision Monday, Justice Walter B. Tolub of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ordered the department to have an independent agency conduct an environmental analysis of traffic congestion and pollution. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that the department was studying the ruling, but that ''obviously we'll do whatever the court directs us to do.'' Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ruling On Barriers In Chinatown

NY Police Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ruling On Barriers In Chinatown

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Eight firefighters have filed a lawsuit against the city, senior officials of the Giuliani administration and several police officers, accusing them of false arrest and imprisonment in a violent confrontation a year ago during a protest march to the ruins of the World Trade Center. The suit, seeking unspecified compensatory and punitive damages, will be followed by others by firefighters arrested during or after the protest, said Ronald E. Kliegerman, a lawyer for the firefighters.

headline.main: 8 New York Firefighters Sue Over Arrests in Protest March

NY Police Department.mainheadline: 8 New York Firefighters Sue Over Arrests in Protest March

NY Police Department.lead_paragraph: Joanne D. Chesimard, who was convicted of murder and fled to Cuba, was placed on the F.B.I.’s list of Most Wanted Terrorists, the first woman named to the list.

headline.seo: Chesimard, Sought in New Jersey Turnpike Killing, Is Put on F.B.I.’s Most Wanted List

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Heavy fighting left dozens dead in the north on Wednesday as factional militias battled for control of a local district, officials there said. The ethnic Tajik faction, Jamiat-i-Islami, reported 50 men killed or wounded, according to Wasiqullah, a spokesman for the group. The fighting broke out when an opposing ethnic Uzbek faction, Jumbeish-i-Milli, attacked the Tajik positions, he said.

headline.main: Dozens Killed as Afghan Factions Clash

Hamid Karzai.mainheadline: Dozens Killed as Afghan Factions Clash

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: About 150 students walked out of classes at Wesleyan University yesterday to protest the American and British bombing in Afghanistan. Demonstrators said a violent response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks would only provoke more violence. They urged government leaders to develop a peaceful solution. Last month, students formed a coalition against violent retaliation.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Middletown: Wesleyan Students Walk Out

Hamid Karzai.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Middletown: Wesleyan Students Walk Out

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: A British Army general said today that he had arrived in Kabul to discuss the size and composition of an international peacekeeping force, even as Afghan leaders have voiced doubts about the need for the troops. Maj. Gen. John McColl arrived at Bagram air base on Saturday night, met today with Hamid Karzai, the provisional leader, and was expected to see the man chosen to be defense minister, Muhammad Fahim, and the one picked for foreign minister, Abdullah Abdullah, on Monday.

headline.main: General in Talks On Peacekeepers

Hamid Karzai.mainheadline: General in Talks On Peacekeepers

headline.print_headline: In Afghan Fields, a Challenge to Opium’s Luster

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Thousands of people in Khost, in the southeast, protested the new Afghan government for the fourth day. Khost is one of the nation's least secure areas, where the United States military continues operations to hunt Al Qaeda and Taliban members. The protesters are supporters of the powerful local warlord Bacha Khan Zadran, who is demanding that he be consulted on appointments of governors in the region. In the west, outside Herat, as many as 70 people were reported killed in fighting among ethnic Tajik and Pashtun soldiers. The Pashtuns appealed for help from the central government. Ian Fisher (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Protests And Fighting

Hamid Karzai.mainheadline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Protests And Fighting

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: The Security Council extended the tenure of international troops in Afghanistan today for another six months but chose not to expand their ranks, as Afghanistan's interim government and some senior United Nations officials had urged. The 15-member body unanimously approved the resolution to maintain the 4,500-member International Security Assistance Force, once its initial mandate expires on June 20.

headline.main: U.N. Extends Tenure Of Afghan Forces

Hamid Karzai.mainheadline: U.N. Extends Tenure Of Afghan Forces

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Hamid Karzai, chairman of the interim government, visited Herat, in western Afghanistan, on his first trip to the countryside since taking office in December. Mr. Karzai was given a warm welcome in the city, which is in one of the country's most troubled regions. But government efforts to end a bloody power struggle in Gardez, in the east, were set back when the ousted governor declined an offer of mediation.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; FRACTIOUS NATION

Hamid Karzai.mainheadline: Briefly Noted; FRACTIOUS NATION

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Mohammed Zahir Shah, the exiled king of Afghanistan, denounced the American-led military campaign in his country, as ''stupid and useless'' in an interview with the Italian daily La Stampa. King Zahir, 87, who is to return in two weeks for a meeting of tribal elders to decide Afghanistan's future, said the campaign should be called off.

headline.main: WORDS FROM EXILED KING

Hamid Karzai.mainheadline: WORDS FROM EXILED KING

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: A two-day international donor conference on rebuilding Afghanistan ended here today with more than $4.5 billion in pledges through 2005. ''We are happy with the result of the conference we had yesterday and today,'' said Hamid Karzai, head of Afghanistan's interim government.

headline.main: Afghan Aid Meeting Ends

Hamid Karzai.mainheadline: Afghan Aid Meeting Ends

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: The retired head of Israel’s internal security agency accused the government of “misleading the public,” ratcheting up criticism of Israel’s leadership from its security establishment.

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Afghanistan's landmark national elections, which were scheduled for June, will be delayed until September, President Hamid Karzai said Sunday. Mr. Karzai said the delay was needed to allow the United Nations to hold both presidential and parliamentary elections at the same time.

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan -- Two new reports addressing human rights issues in Afghanistan have raised questions about how NATO troops are conducting the war. Both reports center on a question that has vexed international forces since the war began: How can the military be sure it has killed, detained or made deals with the right people? A report by the Afghanistan Analysts Network challenges the accuracy of American intelligence used in what are known as targeted killings, and makes a case study of the killing of an alleged Qaeda-affiliated operative in Takhar Province who was attacked by NATO jets as he traveled in a convoy through a rural area. The report offers evidence that NATO forces got the wrong man and that the insurgent commander they were seeking is alive in Pakistan -- an interview with him is included in the report. [The public television program Frontline also addressed the case in this segment of its program ''Kill/Capture.'']

headline.main: Murky Identities and Ties Hinder NATO's Hunt for Afghan Insurgents, Report Says

Hamid Karzai.mainheadline: Murky Identities and Ties Hinder NATO's Hunt for Afghan Insurgents, Report Says

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Four American soldiers were killed Saturday when their vehicle struck a land mine in southeast Afghanistan, the United States military said. The United States has lost more than 100 military personnel since sending troops to Afghanistan in late 2001, but most of the deaths have been accidents.

headline.main: 4 G.I.'s Killed Near Kabul

Hamid Karzai.mainheadline: 4 G.I.'s Killed Near Kabul

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Afghanistan announced it had set up a commission to track down those responsible for the assassination of the anti-Taliban commander Ahmed Shah Masoud, as the country celebrated the 11th anniversary of the defeat of the Communist government. Mr. Massoud, also a famed anti-Soviet fighter, was killed by two suicide bombers posing as journalists in northern Afghanistan two days before the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Afghan security forces have discovered 55 pounds of explosives at a power plant here, averting a potential attack on the city's electrical supply, a spokesman for the force said today. The explosives were found on Monday in the generator room of the Sarobi Dam in the city's east, said Maj. Mike Edwards, a British spokesman for the multinational force that patrols Kabul, the capital.

headline.main: Attack on Afghan Power Plant Averted

Hamid Karzai.mainheadline: Attack on Afghan Power Plant Averted

Hamid Karzai.lead_paragraph: Two American Special Forces soldiers and their Afghan translator were injured when an attacker threw a grenade into their jeep at a busy intersection in downtown Kabul this afternoon, American and Afghan military officials said. It was the first direct attack on American soldiers in Kabul since the Taliban fell from power late last year.

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: A top aide to Osama bin Laden appeared in a videotaped message tonight and implied that airplane hijackings like those that killed thousands of Americans at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon could be repeated. ''The Americans must know that the storm of airplane will not stop, and there are yet thousands of young people who look forward to death like the Americans look forward to living,'' said the aide, Sleiman Abou-Gheith.

headline.main: Bin Laden Aide Threatens More Strikes

Al Jazeera.mainheadline: Bin Laden Aide Threatens More Strikes

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: Establishing what could become a pattern of direct response by videotape to statements by President Bush, Osama bin Laden's chief lieutenant said yesterday that the president had lied in a speech on Thursday night when he said the United States was destroying Al Qaeda and the Taliban forces. A videotape of the the man, Ayman al-Zawahiri, was delivered to the Arabic-language network Al Jazeera just 20 hours after President Bush's speech in Atlanta. On Nov. 3, American officials rushed to condemn a taped message from Osama bin Laden broadcast on Al Jazeera.

headline.main: Little Airplay for Al Qaeda Rebuttal to Bush

Al Jazeera.mainheadline: Little Airplay for Al Qaeda Rebuttal to Bush

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: The major TV news networks gave Osama bin Laden's latest message significant weight yesterday, even though most of what he said was not really new. All stayed true to promises made to the White House in October that they would handle Al Qaeda videotapes carefully lest they contain hidden messages to terrorist operatives. None showed the tape in its entirety.

headline.main: Networks Find Tape Provides Little News

Al Jazeera.mainheadline: Networks Find Tape Provides Little News

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: A reporter for the Arab satellite station Al Jazeera is being held at the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba, suspected of having links with the terror network of Al Qaeda, according to a statement issued by the station. Al Jazeera identified the reporter as Sami al-Hajj, a Sudanese, who it said was arrested in southern Afghanistan on Dec. 15.

headline.main: U.S. Holds Reporter, Arab Station Says

Al Jazeera.mainheadline: U.S. Holds Reporter, Arab Station Says

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: Efforts by Russian government reformers to reduce red tape for small businesses have not succeeded, said German Gref, the minister of economy and trade, citing a new study by the Moscow-based Center for Economic and Financial Research. The study, a survey of 2,000 businesses in 20 Russian regions, found that companies have seen little improvement in business conditions since the state simplified the rules. Russia's economy is in its fourth year of growth, but economists say the growth is confined to large companies. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Red Tape Persists

Al Jazeera.mainheadline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Red Tape Persists

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: The Arab television station Al Jazeera said in a statement that it never aired an October interview with Osama bin Laden because it was conducted under duress and the questions were dictated to its correspondent. The statement was the latest Al Jazeera said CNN, which aired the interview on Thursday, had obtained the tape illegally. A CNN official denied that and said Al Jazeera should explain why it had never made the tape public.

headline.main: BIN LADEN INTERVIEW

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: The authorities in the United Arab Emirates said they had arrested seven members of a “terrorist cell” accused of plotting attacks in the emirates and their neighbors.

The conclusion was reached after sophisticated voice analysis, but did not determine when the message was recorded, the official said.

Al Jazeera.mainheadline: C.I.A. Says bin Laden Tape Is Likely Authentic

Al Jazeera.lead_paragraph: A statement attributed to Mullah Muhammad Omar, the ousted leader of the Taliban, says the United States will face more ''hostility, chaos and destruction'' if it attacks Iraq, an Arab television station reported today. The station, Al Jazeera, said it was faxed a one-page statement from Mullah Omar. It provided no other details.

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: Officials said Tuesday that they were analyzing recently collected terrorism intelligence to determine why a handful of American cities were mentioned, but they cautioned that the locales were not necessarily considered targets. Separate bits of intelligence collected from sources who are tied to extremist groups refer to cities like New York, Washington, Los Angeles and Las Vegas -- sites often considered possible terrorist targets -- as well as remote areas in rural Virginia and Alaska, said an F.B.I. official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The locales were first reported Tuesday by The Los Angeles Times.

CIA Intelligence.mainheadline: Intelligence Cites Some U.S. Cities

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: President Bush took another step today toward loosening his recent restrictions on sharing classified information with Congress. The president agreed to allow George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, to resume briefings for all members of the House and Senate panels that oversee the nation's intelligence agencies, said Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman.

headline.main: Bush Easing Stand on Sharing Of Secret Data

CIA Intelligence.mainheadline: Bush Easing Stand on Sharing Of Secret Data

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: Iraq's ambassador to Turkey, who has been linked in news reports to contacts between Iraqi intelligence and Mohamed Atta, the suspected ringleader of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, left Turkey for Baghdad yesterday. The ambassador, Farouk Yahya al-Hijazi, who spent three years in Turkey, said that he had had no contact with Mr. Atta and that he had been recalled ''after the normal period of time,'' not because of the reported links to Mr. Atta.

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Envoy Denies Terror Link

CIA Intelligence.mainheadline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Envoy Denies Terror Link

headline.print_headline: Americans Conclude North Korean Leader Authorized Attack on South
