CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. has interviewed dozens of members of the House and Senate intelligence committees and asked them to submit to lie detector tests as part of an effort to learn who leaked classified material to reporters in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Congressional officials said today. But a number of the lawmakers on the committees have refused to take the polygraph tests and have voiced uneasiness over the constitutional precedent of being investigated by the agency they oversee, the officials said.

headline.main: F.B.I. Inquiry on 9/11 Leak Upsets Lawmakers on Committees

CIA Intelligence.mainheadline: F.B.I. Inquiry on 9/11 Leak Upsets Lawmakers on Committees

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: A 1998 Central Intelligence Agency report, revealed by the joint Congressional panel investigating the intelligence failures of Sept. 11, was the first public evidence that there was specific intelligence about terrorist plans to crash airplanes into the World Trade Center. Officials said, though, that those plans did not appear to be connected to the Sept. 11 attack.

headline.main: Sept. 15-21: INTERNATIONAL; THREATS IGNORED

CIA Intelligence.mainheadline: Sept. 15-21: INTERNATIONAL; THREATS IGNORED

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The lead investigator of a House-Senate inquiry into the intelligence failures surrounding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks has resigned under pressure, Congressional officials said today. Britt Snider, a former C.I.A. inspector general, resigned on Friday after lawmakers from both parties found his staffing decisions unacceptable, the officials said. Mr. Snider did not respond to a message left at his home tonight.

headline.main: Lead Investigator In Inquiry Quits

CIA Intelligence.mainheadline: Lead Investigator In Inquiry Quits

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday defended the Bush administration's handling of intelligence information before Sept. 11, saying he did not believe the federal government could have anticipated the terrorist attacks. Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, suggested that the Clinton administration should also be accountable given that much of the intelligence now coming under scrutiny was collected during its watch. ''Remember, the Bush administration when this attack took place was a very new administration, and they had just inherited the intelligence apparatus put in place by the Clinton administration, so when you look at this you're going to have look at both,'' Giuliani told The Associated Press after a speech to graduates of Georgetown Law School in Washington.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Giuliani Defends Bush

CIA Intelligence.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Giuliani Defends Bush

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: An American Army soldier was wounded by a land mine south of Kandahar, but his injuries are not life-threatening, the United States Central Command said. Nineteen American troops and one C.I.A. agent have died in Afghanistan or in the region in support of the war; 76 have been wounded. Only two of the deaths were due to hostile fire.

headline.main: Briefly Noted; MINE WOUNDS G.I.

CIA Intelligence.mainheadline: Briefly Noted; MINE WOUNDS G.I.

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- The Pakistani government appeared Thursday to have moved to expel international staff members at the aid agency Save the Children , apparently over accusations that one of its employees helped the C.I.A. recruit a Pakistani doctor who played a role in tracking Osama bin Laden last year. In a statement issued from its London office early Thursday, Save the Children said the Pakistani Interior Ministry had ordered that ''visas for our six international staff in Pakistan may not be renewed.'' A senior aid official in Pakistan, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the staff members had been given until Sept. 12 to leave the country.

U.S. Received
Early Warning
On Qaeda Plot

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: President Obama has placed himself at the helm of a top secret process to designate terrorists for kill or capture, reserving the final say on approving lethal action, say current and former aides.

headline.seo: Secret ‘Kill List’ Tests Obama’s Principles

headline.print_headline: Secret ‘Kill List’ Proves a Test Of Obama’s Principles and Will

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: In Washington-speak, it is the P.D.B. or President's Daily Brief. An intelligence digest prepared six mornings a week, by the Central Intelligence Agency, it is one of the most highly classified documents prepared by the government, its distribution limited under President Bush to fewer than a dozen senior administration officials. Compiled in a loose-leaf notebook, and consisting of about a dozen items a day, the P.D.B. in some ways serves as a kind of newspaper, with reports on current developments around the world and on broader trends. On Aug. 6, 2001, the digest presented to Mr. Bush in Crawford, Tex., included a memorandum titled ''Bin Laden Determined to Attack Inside the U.S.'' Until Thursday, when it was publicly disclosed by Condoleezza Rice in her testimony before the special commission looking in the Sept. 11 attacks, even that title was classified.

headline.main: A Little Light Is Shed on Intelligence Digests

CIA Intelligence.mainheadline: A Little Light Is Shed on Intelligence Digests

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: A court in Hamburg postponed the verdict in the trial of Abdelghani Mzoudi, accused of involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks, after prosecutors dramatically announced the emergence of a new witness just one day before the court had scheduled its final decision. The unnamed witness is an Iranian intelligence agent who told investigators that Mr. Mzoudi played a logistical role within the Hamburg cell that planned the attacks, according to a lawyer close to the case. Desmond Butler (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Delays Qaeda Verdict

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The director of central intelligence on Tuesday defended his agency's handling of information it received about one of the Sept. 11 hijackers some two and a half years before the attacks, saying, ''We didn't sit on our hands.'' German intelligence officials gave the C.I.A. the first name of the hijacker, Marwan al-Shehhi, and his phone number in early 1999 after monitoring conversations of a well-known Islamic extremist in Hamburg. The commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks said it was trying to determine what American intelligence officials did with that information.

headline.main: C.I.A. Chief Defends Handling of Hijacker Data

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: Senator Bob Graham, the Florida Democrat who is a former chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, accused the White House on Tuesday of covering up evidence that might have linked Saudi Arabia to the Sept. 11 hijackers. Mr. Graham made the accusation in a new book and repeated it at a news conference Tuesday arranged by Senator John Kerry's presidential campaign. Republicans called the accusations ''bizarre conspiracy theories,'' and the Saudis said they were unsubstantiated and reckless.

headline.main: Senator Accuses Bush of Cover-Up

CIA Intelligence.mainheadline: Senator Accuses Bush of Cover-Up

CIA Intelligence.lead_paragraph: The disclosure in August of a terrorist plot by Al Qaeda has caused more damage to American counterterrorism efforts than the vast trove of data from Edward Snowden, the former N.S.A. consultant, analysts said.

headline.print_headline: Qaeda Plot Leak Has Undermined U.S. Intelligence

The lawsuit was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan by American, United, Continental, US Airways and Delta Air Lines, and the public agencies that run the airports in Boston and Washington, after the bureau and the agency refused to grant access. During about five years of detention, he says, he was confined in harsh conditions, abused during interrogation and denied a lawyer. Since the spring, Mr. Ghailani has also been a defendant in federal court in Manhattan, the first Guantánamo detainee to be moved to the civilian courts.

Historical American Wars.lead_paragraph: Carrying signs and chanting, ''One world, no war,'' about 75 Princeton University students, staff members and town residents yesterday protested United States air strikes against Afghanistan. ''We're asking for the bombing to stop,'' said Zia Mian, above, a member of the Princeton Peace Network, which organized the event on the Princeton campus. ''No more innocent lives have to be lost.'' Calling the attacks against New York and Washington ''evil crimes,'' Mr. Mian, a member of the Princeton research faculty, said the perpetrators should be brought to justice in an international court.

It is the first to be held while Republicans control the White House, but it will not have the benefit of a White House headliner. Historical American Wars.lead_paragraph: Passenger traffic at Japan's main gateway, Narita Airport, fell to a 10-year low after the terrorist attacks in the United States and the war in Central Asia. Arrivals and departures at the airport, which handles just over half of Japan's international traffic, fell to 1.5 million in November, 32 percent less than the same month a year earlier. It was the first time since April 1991, just after the war in the Persian Gulf, that traffic slipped below 1.6 million passengers. Ken Belson (NYT)

Historical American Wars.lead_paragraph: MY father, William G. Long Sr., was part of the crew charged with loading the atom bomb into the Enola Gay in World War II. His unit was the 509th Composite Group, reporting to Col. Paul W. Tibbets Jr., the pilot. Dad's military service shaped his life, and consequently it shaped mine. My family moved to Pennsylvania when I was a baby, and to Florida when I was 6. In 1972, when I graduated from the University of Florida with an English degree, I didn't know what I wanted to do or how to job-hunt. I knew I wanted to travel, but when I interviewed at a travel agency, the owner said: ''Why would I hire a pretty little girl like you? You'll just get married and leave.''

Historical American Wars.lead_paragraph: FORWARD OPERATING BASE MOCORON, Honduras -- The United States military has brought lessons from the past decade of conflict to the drug war being fought in the wilderness of Miskito Indian country, constructing this remote base camp with little public notice but with the support of the Honduran government. It is one of three new forward bases here -- one in the rain forest, one on the savanna and one along the coast -- each in a crucial location to interdict smugglers moving cocaine toward the United States from South America.

Historical American Wars.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- After fleeing Afghanistan when the United States invaded the country in 2001, a group of terrorism suspects regrouped at a Pakistani safe house and began training for new kinds of operations -- building detonators for roadside bombs and learning ''Americanized'' English, according to a document made public by the military on Thursday. The document was a nine-page ''stipulation of fact'' signed with a thumbprint by Noor Uthman Muhammed, a Sudanese detainee at the military prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. He pleaded guilty this week in a military tribunal to providing material support for terrorism. A military jury is taking evidence for his sentencing hearing.

Historical American Wars.lead_paragraph: FORT JACKSON, S.C. -- Growing up on a farm in Ohio, the son of an Army medic in World War II, David Bowlus often sneaked into the attic to try on his father's uniform as if it were a destiny. At 16, on a family trip to West Point, he watched the cadets drill and knew what he wanted for the future. After graduating from the academy, an armor officer trained for war, he entered a military doing the peacetime duties of the 1990s. The closest Mr. Bowlus got to combat before retiring from the Army in 1998 was a round of war games, fought with weapons that fired only laser beams.

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: Leonard W. Hatton's final case was the prosecution of a man suspected of being the getaway driver in a Queens bank robbery, and it is still chilling to see his name signed on the last page of the federal complaint. Mr. Hatton was the only agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to die in the World Trade Center attack. Yesterday, a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled that his robbery case would not be dismissed even though the government had failed to win a timely indictment because of his unexpected death.

headline.main: Judge Accepts F.B.I. Agent's Death in Attack as Excuse for Late Indictment

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Schumer proposed legislation yesterday that would make terrorist hoaxes a federal crime punishable by up to five years in prison, fines of at least $10,000 and reimbursement of all expenses, such as police overtime. Senator Schumer said no federal law outlaws false alarms and pranks, such as falsely writing that a letter contains anthrax spores. In the first three months of October, Senator Schumer said, the F.B.I. alone responded to 2,500 anthrax reports.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Schumer Urges Terror Penalties

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: A Syrian-born businessman who received $15,000 in donations after his computer equipment was smashed and the words ''We hate Arabs'' were spray-painted at his printing company has been charged with bank fraud. The man, Nezar Khaled Maad, left, was arrested on Tuesday and jailed without bail after F.B.I. agents investigating the vandalism discovered that he had lied about the value of his business equipment in order to get hundreds of thousands of dollars in loans and leased gear, a federal prosecutor, Dan Cooper, said.

Caspersen, who was an F.B.I. agent at the World Trade Center site when it was struck by the second hijacked plane, was named as the state's antiterror chief last week. Mr. Caspersen, 54 and a Fanwood resident, will leave his job as deputy director of the New York State Office of Public Security. He succeeds Kathryn Flicker, who announced that she would step down on Sept. 30.

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: A lawyer for Lynne F. Stewart, the lawyer accused of helping her Egyptian client to direct terrorist operations from his prison cell, asked a federal judge yesterday for an investigation of how a secret F.B.I. affidavit in the case became public. It was posted on thesmokinggun.com Web site of Court TV. The government has said that the affidavit's release was inadvertent, and that it was not ''properly sealed at the time it was signed'' by a magistrate. Ms. Stewart is charged with improperly assisting her client, the imprisoned sheik Omar Abdul Rahman. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: Federal investigators are conducting raids nationwide on jewelry stores owned mostly by Pakistanis, hoping to break up fronts for terrorist groups or their financial backers, officials said. The raids have taken place over the last two weeks in several cities, including New York, Atlanta, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh. About 75 jewelry stores have been raided, a law enforcement official said. Tariq Hussain, 27, a recently discharged United States Army mechanic whose Intrigue Jewelers kiosk in suburban Pittsburgh was searched on June 26, said F.B.I. agents questioned him about connections to the Qaeda terrorist network or its leader, Osama bin Laden.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Raids On Pakistani-Owned Stores

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: The head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation office in Lafayette, La., said that the more than 100 threatening letters recently sent to homes, businesses and government offices appeared to be a hoax. Many of the letters arrived on Friday, and some contained white powder. Preliminary tests found no trace of anthrax or any other chemical agents, the state police said. It could take several days for every piece to be tested, the authorities said. An F.B.I. agent, Rick McHenry, said 114 letters had been counted as of Saturday.

headline.main: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; ANTHRAX HOAXES

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: A Saudi Arabian who lives in Arizona has been convicted in federal court of lying to the F.B.I. about his link to a hijacker who flew an airliner into the Pentagon on Sept. 11. The Saudi, Faisal al-Salmi, 34, was found guilty on Thursday of making false statements in denying knowledge of the hijacker, Hani Hanjour. Mr. Salmi faces six months in prison when sentenced on March 14.

headline.main: SAUDI CONVICTED

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, said Al Qaeda followers in the United States and abroad remained committed to participating in terror attacks in the United States. Mr. Mueller, speaking at a hearing of the House Appropriations Committee on his bureau's budget, said counterterrorism officials had thwarted some attempted terrorist plots. ''But,'' he warned, ''the mere fact that there have been successes does not in any way, shape or form mean that we are confident that there will not be another attack.'' David Johnston (NYT)

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: Saying ''it is very likely that one or more of you know this individual,'' the Federal Bureau of Investigation has asked the world's largest group of microbiologists for help in tracking down whoever mailed the anthrax that killed five people in the fall. The group, the American Society of Microbiology in Washington, said yesterday that it mailed an electronic copy of the letter, from Van Harp, assistant director of the Washington field office of the F.B.I., on Tuesday to its 32,000 members in the United States. The society has 43,000 members worldwide.

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- In a new memoir, a former F.B.I. agent who tracked Al Qaeda before and after the Sept. 11 attacks paints a devastating picture of rivalry and dysfunction inside the government's counterterrorism agencies. The book describes missed opportunities to defuse the 2001 plot, and argues that other attacks overseas might have been prevented, and Osama bin Laden found earlier, if interrogations had not been mismanaged. The account offered by the agent, Ali H. Soufan, is the most detailed to date by an insider concerning the American investigations of Al Qaeda and the major attacks that the group carried out, including bombings of American Embassies in East Africa and the American destroyer Cole, as well as the Sept. 11 attacks. The book is scheduled to be published Monday, with redactions to several chapters by the Central Intelligence Agency, the target of much of Mr. Soufan's criticism.

headline.main: 9/11 May Have Been Stopped but for High-Level Dysfunction, Ex-F.B.I. Agent Writes

FBI Investigation.mainheadline: 9/11 May Have Been Stopped but for High-Level Dysfunction, Ex-F.B.I. Agent Writes

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- A review of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's scientific work on the investigation of the anthrax letters of 2001 concludes that the bureau overstated the strength of genetic analysis linking the mailed anthrax to a supply kept by Bruce E. Ivins, the Army microbiologist whom the investigators blamed for the attacks. The review, by a panel convened by the National Academy of Sciences, says the genetic analysis ''did not definitively demonstrate'' that the mailed anthrax spores were grown from a sample taken from Dr. Ivins's laboratory at Fort Detrick in Frederick, Md. It does add, however, that the evidence is ''consistent with and supports an association'' between Dr. Ivins's flask and the attack anthrax.

headline.main: Expert Panel Is Critical of F.B.I. Work in Investigating Anthrax Letters

FBI Investigation.mainheadline: Expert Panel Is Critical of F.B.I. Work in Investigating Anthrax Letters

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: In response to requests from members of Congress and to at least one news report, the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York opened a preliminary inquiry on Thursday into allegations that News Corporation journalists sought to gain access to the phone records of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, according to several people briefed on the matter. The investigation is in its earliest stages, two of the people said, and its scope is not yet clear. It also is unclear whether the F.B.I. has identified possible targets of the investigation or possible specific criminal violations.

FBI Investigation.mainheadline: F.B.I. Looks Into Hacking Of 9/11 Victims' Phones

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: A group of airlines and public transportation agencies sued the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. yesterday, seeking permission to interview five special agents and two intelligence officers who may have knowledge helpful in their defense of wrongful death lawsuits arising from the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The lawsuit was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan by American, United, Continental, US Airways and Delta Air Lines, and the public agencies that run the airports in Boston and Washington, after the bureau and the agency refused to grant access. Richard Kolko, an F.B.I. spokesman, declined to discuss the suit. The C.I.A. press office did not return phone calls seeking comment yesterday.

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: A war with Iraq or a terrorist attack against American interests could prompt a wave of hate crimes against Arab-Americans, Muslims and other minorities in the United States, the F.B.I. said today. The F.B.I. said the September 2001 hijackings led to a ''spike'' in attacks against Arab-Americans, Muslim-Americans and members of Indian, Sikh and other minorities. But, it said, after about three weeks, such attacks decreased sharply.

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: The trial of a London businessman who prosecutors say agreed to provide weapons to a Federal Bureau of Investigation informer posing as a Somali terrorist has been delayed once again, until April 18. The defendant, Hemant Lakhani, 69, left, who runs an import-export business, was charged with providing material support to terrorists. His trial has been delayed by three operations he underwent. Mr. Lakhani told Judge Katharine Hayden of federal court he needed ''three to four weeks'' to regain his strength. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: IF it is true that, as an old Chinese proverb says, crisis equals opportunity, then the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, have yielded a bonanza. Billions of dollars have been poured into homeland security by the cabinet department of the same name, the Pentagon, law enforcement and corporations. With so much money available, more than 500 exhibitors at a security conference here last week were out to reap their share. The most futuristic tools and weapons for tracking and catching potential terrorists were presumably not on display. But if the goods and services hawked at the conference are any measure, the urgent quest for greater security has stirred creative juices among inventors -- and marketers.

headline.main: It's a New World, And Everybody Gets To Play Maxwell Smart

FBI Investigation.mainheadline: It's a New World, And Everybody Gets To Play Maxwell Smart

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: A former F.B.I. agent who blew the whistle on the bureau's failings in its investigation of Zacarias Moussaoui before Sept. 11, 2001, was criticized on Monday in a government report for her own actions in the case. The whistle-blower, Coleen Rowley, a former lawyer in the F.B.I.'s Minneapolis field office who is now running for Congress as a Democrat, received praise and criticism in the report, prepared by the Justice Department's inspector general.

headline.main: F.B.I. Whistle-Blower Is Criticized in Report

FBI Investigation.mainheadline: F.B.I. Whistle-Blower Is Criticized in Report

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: A veteran F.B.I. agent who helped lead investigations of the World Trade Center bombing in 1993, the East Africa embassy bombings in 1998 and the attack on the Navy destroyer Cole in Yemen in 2000 was named today by Robert S. Mueller III, the bureau's director, to head its New York office. The agent, Pasquale J. D'Amuro, is currently assigned to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's headquarters as a senior official in charge of counterterrorism and counterintelligence, areas that are a primary responsibility of the bureau's New York office, which is regarded by agents as the most important of the 56 field offices.

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: As if the city needed further evidence that life is truly upside down, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said last night that he would attend a Mets game. Yes. He said he wanted to thank them for wearing Fire Department hats, and to show that all partisan bets were off, even in baseball.A reporter could write here now that the mayor is a rabid Yankees fan, but that would insult the reader.

FBI Investigation.mainheadline: Changing His Pinstripes

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: Hate crimes against Muslims and people who are or appear to be of Middle Eastern descent soared to record levels last year, in all likelihood as a consequence of the Sept. 11 attacks, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. In its annual report on hate crimes, the bureau found that incidents in which people, institutions and businesses identified with the Islamic faith were the targets increased 1,600 percent, to 481 in 2001 from 28 in 2000. Muslims had previously been among the religious groups least frequently victimized by hate crimes.

headline.main: Hate Crimes Up Against Muslims

FBI Investigation.mainheadline: Hate Crimes Up Against Muslims

FBI Investigation.lead_paragraph: An Egyptian student, wrongly suspected of aiding the Sept. 11 hijackers with a sophisticated aviation radio in his hotel room, yesterday sued the hotel and the security guard who raised suspicions about him. The federal suit by the student, Abdallah Higazy, left, seeks $20 million in damages for wrongful arrest and imprisonment. It also names an F.B.I. agent, Michael Templeton, who obtained a false confession from the student about owning the radio. The guard, Ronald Ferry, pleaded guilty to making a false statement when he said the student had a radio in his room at Millenium Hilton Hotel near the World Trade Center. A lawyer for Mr. Ferry said his client denied any liability. The hotel declined to comment. The F.B.I. noted that the Justice Department had cleared Agent Templeton of misconduct. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has admonished Attorney General John Ashcroft for violating a court order by making remarks about defendants in the nation's first major terror trial after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. The judge, Gerald E. Rosen of Federal District Court, said in an opinion released Tuesday that Mr. Ashcroft's statements could have compromised the defendants' rights to a fair trial but that the violations did not warrant contempt charges or require Mr. Ashcroft to appear in court to explain himself.

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal judge yesterday ordered the developer Larry A. Silverstein and his insurers to arbitration on Nov. 6 to try to settle their battle over billions of dollars in insurance proceeds for rebuilding at the World Trade Center site. If the process fails, Judge Michael B. Mukasey said, the first of what could be three successive trials will begin in February. Mr. Silverstein's lawyer, Herbert M. Wachtell, expressed reservations about the proposed arbitrator, John S. Martin, a retired federal judge. He said Mr. Martin was a friend of his but had ruled against Mr. Silverstein in earlier stages of the case. But Mr. Wachtell agreed to the choice when Judge Mukasey said that ''you couldn't conceivably have anyone better to mediate this case.'' Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

The judge, Thomas Sullins, ruled that hostility toward Muslims and people from the Middle East might result in jury prejudice. The Pakistani, Rehan Bhutto, 30, is accused of shooting his girlfriend, Valerie McCarthy, 25, in their home on April 25. He has pleaded not guilty. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

Prosecutors have accused the student, Osama Awadallah, who attended college in San Diego at the time of his arrest, of lying about his associations with Khalid al-Midhar, above, one of the people suspected in the hijacking of the jetliner that crashed into the Pentagon on Sept. 11. Mr. Awadallah's lawyer, Jesse Berman, said he would seek his client's release in a bail hearing. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan has rejected a request that prosecutors be ordered to disclose whether they are covertly monitoring the conversations of Lynne F. Stewart, a prominent lawyer charged with supporting terrorism. Lawyers for Ms. Stewart, who is free on bond, argued that the prospect of such monitoring was hampering her ability to discuss pretrial strategy with them. But Judge John G. Koeltl of United States District Court said that mechanisms were in place to ensure that privileged communications would not be used against her, and he asked how prosecutors could engage in ''covert investigations'' if they were ''required to disclose any such investigations in advance.'' Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled today that a Muslim clergyman accused of funneling money to terrorists should be freed in 10 days or have a new hearing open to the news media and the public with a different immigration judge. The clergyman, Rabih Haddad, a Lebanese citizen living in Ann Arbor, Mich., has been jailed since Dec. 14 at an immigration prison for overstaying his visa.

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A lawyer for Lynne F. Stewart, the lawyer accused of helping her Egyptian client to direct terrorist operations from his prison cell, asked a federal judge yesterday for an investigation of how a secret F.B.I. affidavit in the case became public. It was posted on thesmokinggun.com Web site of Court TV. The government has said that the affidavit's release was inadvertent, and that it was not ''properly sealed at the time it was signed'' by a magistrate. Ms. Stewart is charged with improperly assisting her client, the imprisoned sheik Omar Abdul Rahman. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union lost a round yesterday in its effort to learn the names of foreigners who were arrested after Sept. 11 and detained in New Jersey jails. The New Jersey Supreme Court denied the group's appeal of a June appellate court ruling that said the federal government could pre-empt the state's right-to-know laws in the interest of national security. A.C.L.U. officials said they were considering an appeal to the United States Supreme Court. The Justice Department issued a statement saying that disclosing the detainees' names ''could provide terrorists a road map of the department's investigations.'' Susan Sachs (NYT)

The police in Spain re-arrested a man they said had helped finance Al Qaeda operations. And in Britain, a court dismissed the remaining charges against Lotfi Raissi, a British-based Algerian pilot originally accused by the United States of training the Sept. 11 hijackers.

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person arrested so far in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, has met with a court-appointed psychiatrist who is helping a federal judge determine if he is mentally competent to defend himself at trial, according to court papers made public today. The conclusions of the psychiatric report, which was filed with the Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., outside Washington, were not revealed. But the court papers do reveal that Mr. Moussaoui backed down from his refusal to meet with the psychiatrist, Raymond Patterson, a former administrator of St. Elizabeth's Hospital for the criminally insane in Washington.

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The assault trial of a man suspected of being a top aide to Osama bin Laden should not be moved out of New York City because of the Sept. 11 terror attack, federal prosecutors have told a judge. The defendant, Mamdouh Mahmud Salim, is accused of attacking a guard in the Metropolitan Correctional Center in November 2000 while awaiting trial on terrorism conspiracy charges. The guard was stabbed in the eye with a comb made into a knife. Mr. Salim has pleaded not guilty to all charges. In their court papers, filed Monday, prosecutors rejected claims that Mr. Salim could not receive a fair trial in New York. The assault case, they wrote, ''has nothing to do with terrorism in general or the World Trade Center attack in particular.'' Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Change Of Venue Is Opposed

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Change Of Venue Is Opposed

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors denied claims by lawyers for John Walker Lindh that he had been threatened with torture by the American military after his capture with Taliban forces in Afghanistan, saying Mr. Lindh got medical treatment, healthy meals and a haircut. The prosecutors were responding to court papers filed by the defense that requested a broad variety of government documents and access to captured Al Qaeda and Taliban prisoners. A court hearing on the request is scheduled for Monday. Mr. Lindh, a Californian who converted to Islam and joined the Taliban, faces an Aug. 26 federal trial on a 10-count indictment that accuses him of conspiring to kill Americans abroad.

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: An Irvington man, conforming to an order by a federal judge, agreed to stop soliciting charitable contributions for thousands of body bags needed after the attack on the World Trade Center. The man, Bobby Ellis, 52, did not plead guilty to any crime, but prosecutors said he had no connection to any official relief effort. Judge John W. Bissell of Federal District Court in Newark signed an order yesterday barring Mr. Ellis from soliciting contributions through the mail for the Brotherhood Emergency Collection, the charity he had created. Mr. Ellis, who represented himself in court, could not be reached for comment because he does not have a published telephone number. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Seventeen men were indicted on racketeering charges of defrauding the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey of as much as $2.5 million, prosecutors said yesterday. District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said that the men overcharged the Port Authority in asbestos contracts and included fake employees in a contract to clean artifacts recovered from the World Trade Center attack. Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A State Supreme Court justice, Walter B. Tolub, dismissed a lawsuit brought by a Wall Street parking garage against the New York Stock Exchange that claimed security blockades set up by the exchange after Sept. 11, 2001, were illegal and had eroded its business. The judge first heard the case earlier this year and ruled favorably for the garage, Wall Street Garage Parking Corp. But a higher court overturned that ruling. Yesterday, Justice Tolub dismissed the case, ruling that the garage had not ''suffered an injury exceeding that suffered by the community at large'' and had not proved that the blocked areas were a public nuisance. He was charged under Indonesia's antiterror law. Mr. Bashir, 66, the spiritual leader of the Islamic group Jemaah Islamiyah, which has been labeled a terrorist organization by the United States, has been in prison since 2002, when he was cleared of terror charges but sentenced to 18 months in jail for immigration violations. Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba -- Khalid Shaikh Mohammed fingered his long, henna-dyed beard and stared down in silence on Saturday, pointedly ignoring a military commissions judge asking in vain whether the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 attacks understood what was being said and whether he was willing to be represented by his defense lawyers. Minutes later, Ramzi bin al Shibh, another of the five detainees arraigned on Saturday as accused conspirators in the attacks, stood, knelt and started praying. Later, he shouted at the judge that he should address their complaints about prison conditions because ''maybe you are not going to see me again.''

headline.main: At a Hearing, 9/11 Detainees Show Defiance

Federal Courts.mainheadline: At a Hearing, 9/11 Detainees Show Defiance

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in an American court with conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks, filed an appeal on Thursday of a recent ruling allowing prosecutors once again to seek the death penalty in the case, court records show. The filing seeks to have the ruling, made on April 22 by a three-judge federal appeals panel in Richmond, Va., reviewed by the full appeals court. It was placed under seal because of secrecy rules in the case, which involves a variety of classified information.

headline.main: Appeal by Sept. 11 Suspect

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Appeal by Sept. 11 Suspect

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Nabil al-Marabh was No. 27 on the F.B.I.'s list of terror suspects after Sept. 11. He trained in Afghanistan's militant camps, sent money to a roommate convicted in a foiled plot to bomb a hotel, and boasted to an informant about plans to blow up a fuel truck inside a New York tunnel, F.B.I. documents say. But after Mr. Marabh served an eight-month jail sentence, he was sent in January to his native Syria, which is regarded by the United States as a sponsor of terrorism, even though prosecutors had sought to bring criminal cases against him and judges openly expressed concerns about possible terrorist ties. The quiet disposition of his case stands in stark contrast to language F.B.I. agents used to describe him.

headline.main: Despite Fears Of Terror Tie, Suspect Goes Back to Syria

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Despite Fears Of Terror Tie, Suspect Goes Back to Syria

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A justice in State Supreme Court ordered mediation yesterday in the dispute between Larry A. Silverstein, the World Trade Center leaseholder, and Daniel Libeskind, left, the site's master planner, who filed a lawsuit last week claiming that Mr. Silverstein owes him more than $843,000 in architectural fees. Justice Karla Moskowitz issued the order at the request of Mr. Silverstein's lawyers. Edward W. Hayes, a lawyer for Mr. Libeskind, had said that mediation would not be fruitful. Both parties were directed to return to court on Oct. 14.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mediation Ordered In Trade Center Suit

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mediation Ordered In Trade Center Suit

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A court in Hamburg postponed the verdict in the trial of Abdelghani Mzoudi, accused of involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks, after prosecutors dramatically announced the emergence of a new witness just one day before the court had scheduled its final decision. The unnamed witness is an Iranian intelligence agent who told investigators that Mr. Mzoudi played a logistical role within the Hamburg cell that planned the attacks, according to a lawyer close to the case. Desmond Butler (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Delays Qaeda Verdict

Federal Courts.mainheadline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Delays Qaeda Verdict

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan dismissed a lawsuit yesterday that accused the City of New York City and Motorola of providing firefighters with faulty radio equipment that was in use on Sept. 11, 2001. Representatives of 12 firefighters who died in the collapse of the World Trade Center filed the suit. They claimed that the faulty radios deprived the firefighters of information that could have saved their lives. Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of United States District Court dismissed the case, saying that the plaintiffs waived their right to sue when they decided to participate in the Victim Compensation Fund. Susan M. Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suit Involving Fire Radios Is Dismissed

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suit Involving Fire Radios Is Dismissed

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan yesterday threw out a lawsuit against New York City by eight firefighters who claimed that their constitutional rights were violated when they were arrested at a protest at ground zero on Nov. 2, 2001. The firefighters, including Michael Carter, a vice president of the Uniformed Firefighters' Association, joined a march that day to protest orders from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to cut back on police officers and firefighters searching for victims' remains in the ruins of the World Trade Center. All charges against people arrested at the protest were dropped a month later. Judge Richard J. Holwell ruled that the firefighters' arrests were not malicious because it was clear they were not authorized to march to the trade center site. Julia Preston (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Protest Suit Is Dismissed

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Protest Suit Is Dismissed

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Donald Sachtleben, a former bomb technician, agreed to plead guilty to leaking classified details about a foiled bomb plot in Yemen, the Justice Department announced.

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- A 20-year-old Saudi college student who was arrested Wednesday night on bomb charges in Texas wrote in his journal that he sought a student visa three years ago so he could carry out terrorist attacks inside the United States, according to an F.B.I. document released Thursday. By the time that the student, Khalid Aldawsari, who attended community college in Lubbock, Tex., came to the attention of the authorities this month, he had obtained two of the three chemicals needed for a bomb and was researching potential targets -- including the Dallas residence of former President George W. Bush, the homes of three former military guards at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq and dams in Colorado and California, an F.B.I. affidavit said.

headline.main: Saudi Student Is Charged in Texas With Plotting Attacks in the U.S.

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Saudi Student Is Charged in Texas With Plotting Attacks in the U.S.

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: German prosecutors said that Islamic radicalism may have motivated a Kosovar to open fire on an American military bus at the Frankfurt airport.

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The time to finish cleaning the basement of the former Deutsche Bank building in 2006 was so short that supervisors were getting antsy. Salvatore DePaola, an asbestos abatement foreman, constantly urged his team to hurry, Adolpho Ortiz, one of the cleaning workers, testified on Thursday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The director of the abatement work, Mitchel Alvo, angrily gestured and told workers to pick up the pace, Mr. Ortiz said. Mr. Alvo even slammed his construction helmet once, Mr. Ortiz said.

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A group of airlines and public transportation agencies sued the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. yesterday, seeking permission to interview five special agents and two intelligence officers who may have knowledge helpful in their defense of wrongful death lawsuits arising from the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The lawsuit was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan by American, United, Continental, US Airways and Delta Air Lines, and the public agencies that run the airports in Boston and Washington, after the bureau and the agency refused to grant access. Richard Kolko, an F.B.I. spokesman, declined to discuss the suit. The C.I.A. press office did not return phone calls seeking comment yesterday.

headline.main: Manhattan: Airlines Seek Agents' Testimony

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Manhattan: Airlines Seek Agents' Testimony

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Lawyers representing New York City announced yesterday that they would appeal a recent federal decision denying their motion to dismiss thousands of lawsuits brought against the city and private contractors working for the city during the ground zero cleanup. More than 6,000 workers have sued, alleging that the city failed to protect them from toxic pollutants. Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of Federal District Court ruled last month that the city's immunity from such lawsuits was limited, allowing the cases to go forward. ANTHONY DEPALMA

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Appeal In Ground Zero Lawsuit

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Appeal In Ground Zero Lawsuit

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A Superior Court judge in Paterson, N.J., excoriated a naturalized United States citizen for his ''reckless and callous disregard'' for the safety of others in selling fake identification cards to two of the Sept. 11 hijackers, but she let him walk free today based on a plea agreement of last month. Judge Marilyn C. Clark fined Mohamed el-Atriss, a 46-year old Egyptian-American dual citizen, $15,000, sentenced him to five years' probation and gave him credit for the nearly six months he had served in a Passaic County jail for selling ''simulated documents'' to Abdulaziz Alomari and Khalid al-Midhar, two of the hijackers.

headline.main: PROBATION IN FAKE I.D. CASE

Federal Courts.mainheadline: PROBATION IN FAKE I.D. CASE

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A Hamburg court began a hearing on whether to give a stiffer prison sentence to Mounir el-Motassadeq, the Moroccan who was a friend of the three 9/11 pilots. He was convicted in 2005 of belonging to a terrorist organization and sentenced to seven years in prison. But an appeals court ruled in November that he had been wrongly acquitted of direct involvement in the attacks. Now he may face 15 years in prison. A decision is expected next month. MARK LANDLER

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Sentence Trial For 9/11 Friend

Federal Courts.mainheadline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Sentence Trial For 9/11 Friend

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Families of victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks cannot view hundreds of thousands of nonpublic documents used in the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, an appeals court said, overturning a lower court's order. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, said the families were not entitled to view documents that were given to Mr. Moussaoui's lawyers to aid his defense but were not made public. Mr. Moussaoui, 38, is the only person charged in the United States in connection with the attacks.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Court Bars Families From Moussaoui Evidence

Federal Courts.mainheadline: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Court Bars Families From Moussaoui Evidence

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: An appeals court ruled this week that Environmental Protection Agency officials are not liable for making rosy declarations about air quality in the days after the World Trade Center's destruction on 9/11. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit issued its ruling on Thursday in a lawsuit brought by five government employees who did rescue and cleanup work at ground zero. The opinion said that putting agency workers at risk of lawsuits for giving out bad information during a crisis could have catastrophic effects.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: E.P.A. Not Liable For Comments

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: E.P.A. Not Liable For Comments

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that senior federal officials would have to answer questions under oath in a lawsuit accusing them of personally conspiring to violate the rights of Muslim immigrants held in a federal detention center in Brooklyn after 9/11. The ruling, by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan, upholds most of an earlier decision by a federal judge in Brooklyn. The officials, including former Attorney General John Ashcroft and Robert Mueller, the head of the F.B.I., had asked for dismissal of the lawsuit, by Javaid Iqbal, a Pakistani immigrant, arguing in part that the government was entitled to take actions that might not have been lawful before 9/11. Although acknowledging some forms of government action in emergencies may exceed normal constitutional limits, Judge Jon O. Newman rejected the officials' contention, saying some protections against some of the violations claimed, such as needlessly harsh confinement and ethnic discrimination, do not vary with surrounding circumstances. ''The strength of our system of constitutional rights derives from the steadfast protection of those rights in both normal and unusual times,'' he wrote. NINA BERNSTEIN

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Federal Officials Must Testify

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Federal Officials Must Testify

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The trial of a London businessman who prosecutors say agreed to provide weapons to a Federal Bureau of Investigation informer posing as a Somali terrorist has been delayed once again, until April 18. The defendant, Hemant Lakhani, 69, left, who runs an import-export business, was charged with providing material support to terrorists. His trial has been delayed by three operations he underwent. Mr. Lakhani told Judge Katharine Hayden of federal court he needed ''three to four weeks'' to regain his strength. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Terror Trial Delayed Until Next Month

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Terror Trial Delayed Until Next Month

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The National Court said it would prosecute three men on charges that they helped plan the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks in the United States. They were arrested from 2001 to 2003 by Judge Baltasar Garzón during his investigation of Al Qaeda's presence in Spain. Two men, Driss Chebli and Imad Eddin Barakat Yarkas, are charged with helping to organize a meeting in Tarragona, Spain, where details of the attacks may have been worked out, the court said. The third, Ghasoub Al Abrash Ghalyoun, is accused of making videotapes of the World Trade Center in 1997 and delivering them to people connected to the attacks. The trials are expected to begin next month. Prosecutors want each man to receive a sentence of 25 years in prison for each of the nearly 3,000 people killed in the attacks. Renwick McLean (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Trials Set For 3 Sept. 11 Suspects

Federal Courts.mainheadline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Trials Set For 3 Sept. 11 Suspects

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A trial to determine whether the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey should be held liable in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing could begin as early as April, lawyers and a State Supreme Court judge said yesterday. At a meeting with Justice Stanley L. Sklar, lawyers for the Port Authority and for plaintiffs in a lawsuit said they expected the trial to take about three weeks. More than 100 people and companies have filed suit against the authority, claiming it should be liable because it was warned to close its underground parking garage to the public. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: '93 Bombing Trial Imminent

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: '93 Bombing Trial Imminent

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The former director of records at the city's chief medical examiner's office pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to stealing millions of dollars in federal aid that was sent to the city after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack to help identify the remains gathered from ground zero. The former official, Rosa Abreu, 40, was indicted in December 2005 and accused of using shadow companies and fake contract bids to steal funds sent by the Federal Emergency Management Agency when the medical examiner's office was overwhelmed by the task of identifying nearly 3,000 victims. Ms. Abreu will face a maximum sentence of 55 years in prison when she is sentenced next year on charges of embezzlement and money laundering, prosecutors said.

headline.main: Manhattan: Guilty Plea In Theft of 9/11 Aid

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Manhattan: Guilty Plea In Theft of 9/11 Aid

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui resumed his place in a federal courtroom here on Wednesday and sat quietly as lawyers questioned potential jurors after he apparently reversed course and agreed not to disrupt the proceedings. A day earlier, Judge Leonie M. Brinkema ejected Mr. Moussaoui from the courtroom after he refused to heed her warnings to defer to his court-appointed lawyers and stop making speeches about his case. She ruled that Mr. Moussaoui, the only person to face trial in the United States in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, would be able to observe the next few weeks of the proceedings only from a closed-circuit television hookup in a jail cell.

headline.main: Defendant In 9/11 Case Heeds Judge

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Defendant In 9/11 Case Heeds Judge

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor on Monday asked a jury to sentence Zacarias Moussaoui to death, saying his willful decision to conceal his knowledge of the Sept. 11 terrorist plot when he was arrested weeks earlier made him responsible for the thousands of deaths that day. In response, a court-appointed lawyer for Mr. Moussaoui told jurors they could not order the execution of a man on no more than a supposition: that had he revealed his knowledge of Al Qaeda's interest in flying planes into public buildings, the federal authorities would have prevented the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline.main: Prosecutor Urges Death for Concealing Sept. 11 Plot

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Prosecutor Urges Death for Concealing Sept. 11 Plot

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal judge yesterday dismissed a $250 million lawsuit against the city that claimed it was liable for the burning and collapse of 7 World Trade Center after the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, 2001. The suit, brought by Consolidated Edison and its insurance companies, claimed that the city had been negligent in installing two diesel tanks in the building to fuel the electrical system of a command center for emergencies on the 23rd floor. The fuel contributed to the fire and eventual collapse, which heavily damaged a Consolidated Edison substation. Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of Federal District Court in Manhattan ruled that the city had made ''a good faith effort'' in setting up the command center, which complied with statutes governing emergency planning. The ruling puts an end to the last remaining property damage claim facing the city as a result of the 9/11 attack, city officials said. JULIA PRESTON (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suit Against City Is Dismissed In 7 World Trade Collapse

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suit Against City Is Dismissed In 7 World Trade Collapse

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Relatives of 1,100 victims who died in the World Trade Center attack but whose remains have never been found claim there is new evidence that hundreds of body parts remain mixed with debris in the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island. The charge is part of an amended complaint filed yesterday in Federal District Court by the relatives. Their lawyer, Norman Siegel, said the claim is based on his interviews with a former supervisor at the site who would testify at a jury trial. A lawsuit aiming to force the city to search the debris was filed by the relatives in August. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Wrinkle In 9/11 Lawsuit

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Wrinkle In 9/11 Lawsuit

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to stealing from a federal fund established to help businesses recover after Sept. 11, prosecutors said. The man, Chang Sheng Yu, was arrested last October and charged with obtaining $118,000 from a fund under the aegis of the Empire State Development Corporation by submitting fabricated business records, including a doctored rental agreement, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Yu pleaded guilty to wire fraud, prosecutors said.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Disaster Fund Fraud

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Disaster Fund Fraud

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Jury selection began yesterday in Federal District Court in the long-delayed trial of Osama Awadallah, a student from Jordan accused of lying to a grand jury investigating the Sept. 11 attack. A jury was chosen in May 2005, but Judge Shira A. Scheindlin sent the jurors home after the government brought a last-minute appeal seeking to have the case transferred to another judge. That appeal was rejected in January. Yesterday, the jurors were recalled and new ones added to create a pool of 35 for the final selection. The judge questioned the candidates to see if their views had been affected by news about the sentencing trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, who pleaded guilty to conspiring in the 9/11 attacks. Mr. Awadallah is not charged with any role in the attacks. JULIA PRESTON (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jury Selection In 9/11 Case

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jury Selection In 9/11 Case

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A lawsuit by the Coalition of 9/11 Families seeking to compel the preservation of the concrete floor slab where 1 World Trade Center stood has been dismissed by Justice Shirley Werner Kornreich of the State Supreme Court. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the lead defendant, received the decision yesterday. Justice Kornreich said it had been known since April 2004 that the slab would not be subject to historical preservation review, meaning that the lawsuit was filed too late. She wrote that the historical review process ''has been met'' restored text here and that the development corporation had acted in ''a commendable and sensitive manner.'' DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lawsuit Dismissed On Trade Center Floor Slab

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lawsuit Dismissed On Trade Center Floor Slab

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has ruled that Amnesty International and other human rights groups can assert the same privileges that journalists use, allowing them to better protect anonymous sources. The magistrate judge, Viktor Pohorelsky of Federal District Court in New York, said in an order issued Tuesday that the group did not have to disclose the names of lawyers quoted anonymously in a report about them being videotaped while talking to their clients in prison.

headline.main: Ruling Gives Rights Groups Protections of Press

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Ruling Gives Rights Groups Protections of Press

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The request for access to five men accused of participating in the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, criticized as unreasonable by prosecutors, is part of preparation for possible sentencing.

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A judge has ordered the Justice Department to produce White House memorandums that provide the legal basis for the Bush administration's post-Sept. 11 warrantless wiretapping program. The judge, Henry H. Kennedy Jr. of Federal District Court in Washington, signed the order Friday. It requires the department to produce the memorandums by the White House legal counsel's office by Nov. 17. He said he would review the memorandums to determine whether any information could be released publicly without violating attorney-client privilege.

headline.main: Judge Seeks Wiretapping Documents

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Judge Seeks Wiretapping Documents

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A painter who worked at the World Trade Center has been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges that he stole more than $1 million by falsely claiming that he was permanently disabled in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, federal prosecutors said yesterday. The money came from the Department of Justice September 11th Fund. Prosecutors said it was the largest amount anyone had been accused of wrongly receiving from the fund. The painter, Michael Mastellone, 39, of East Windsor, N.J., faces up to 40 years in prison if convicted. He was released yesterday on $1 million bail. Peter Bark, Mr. Mastellone's lawyer, said his back injuries and psychological problems had been confirmed by the fund's doctors. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS (NYT)

headline.print_headline: Supreme Court Refuses Case By Sept. 11 Victims’ Families

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Until his indictment on conspiracy and fraud charges and his abortive nomination to head the Department of Homeland Security, Bernard B. Kerik was perhaps best known for being New York City's police commissioner during the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. Yet the federal judge overseeing his case has ruled that once the trial begins, Mr. Kerik's lawyers cannot mention 9/11 in relation to their client.

headline.main: Federal Judge Forbids Kerik's Lawyers to Mention 9/11 at Trial

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Federal Judge Forbids Kerik's Lawyers to Mention 9/11 at Trial

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui has been allowed to conduct a pre-trial deposition of at least one potential trial witness in his case, a Malaysian terrorism suspect who the authorities say met with Mr. Moussaoui in Southeast Asia before the Sept. 11 terror attacks, according to court papers made public today. The court papers show that Mr. Moussaoui, acting as his own lawyer, questioned the witness, Faiz Bafana, in a videoconference last year, with federal prosecutors cross-examining Mr. Bafana.

headline.main: Suspected Terrorist Questions a Witness

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Suspected Terrorist Questions a Witness

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court rejected an appeal from a man trying to hold Iran accountable for the killing of his daughter in a Middle Eastern terrorist bombing. The court did not comment in turning down the father, Stephen Flatow of West Orange, N.J., who won a $247.5 million verdict against Iran, but has been unable to collect most of the money. His daughter, Alisa Flatow, a 20-year-old college student, died in a 1995 bus bombing in the Gaza Strip. Her parents sued under a 1996 law that authorized lawsuits for damages suffered in acts of terror by countries designated by the United States as sponsors of terrorism.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Bombing Victim's Father Loses Appeal

Federal Courts.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: Bombing Victim's Father Loses Appeal

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The judge in the case of Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person facing trial in the United States in the Sept. 11 attacks, made it clear that she would not decide whether to dismiss the case or impose other sanctions on the Justice Department for at least next month. The judge, Leonie M. Brinkema of Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., said she would delay her decision until prosecutors and defense lawyers had offered their views on what sanctions she should impose for the government's refusal to grant Mr. Moussaoui the chance to interview a captured member of Al Qaeda. Philip Shenon (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: August Decision Seen In Moussaoui Case

Federal Courts.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: August Decision Seen In Moussaoui Case

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A judge today ordered the release of transcripts of bail hearings that were used against a man who sold fake identification cards to two of the Sept. 11 hijackers. The judge, Marilyn C. Clark of Passaic County Superior Court, said she would release the transcripts June 19 if an appeal was not filed by Miles R. Feinstein, a lawyer for the man, Mohamed el-Atriss of Union Township. Mr. Feinstein has said he will object.

headline.main: Judge Releases Transcripts in Fake ID Case

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Judge Releases Transcripts in Fake ID Case

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The manager of a hospital morgue pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing coffins that had been donated to Sept. 11 charities. The manager, Felix Velazquez, 55, pleaded guilty in Manhattan Criminal Court to one count of petty larceny in exchange for a sentence of 15 days of community service and a $1,000 fine.

headline.main: Morgue Manager Guilty of Stealing Coffins

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Morgue Manager Guilty of Stealing Coffins

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has given the Justice Department and Microsoft an extra two days to file a status report in the landmark antitrust case that was to have been filed yesterday, the second such delay. Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly extended the deadline until Thursday morning in light of the recent attacks at the World Trade Center and Pentagon. Additionally, the court delayed a meeting between representatives of both and the judge until Sept. 28 from Sept. 21, in part at the request of Microsoft to facilitate travel by its lawyers. The judge is to hold hearings later this year to decide what sanctions, if any, should be imposed on the company to prevent further antitrust violations.

headline.main: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Deadline Is Extended

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Deadline Is Extended

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The wife of a Tampa podiatrist charged in a plot to blow up a Muslim gathering place has agreed to cooperate with federal prosecutors in a plea bargain, officials said. The podiatrist, Dr. Robert Goldstein, and his wife, Kristi, are accused of planning to blow up an Islamic education center in St. Petersburg. Dr. Goldstein was described in court documents as seeking to retaliate for the Sept. 11 attacks and the Arab-Israeli conflict.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Florida: Plea Deal In Bombing Plot Case

Federal Courts.mainheadline: National Briefing | South: Florida: Plea Deal In Bombing Plot Case

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department renewed its warning that the case against Zacarias Moussaoui might have to be dismissed if the trial judge continued to insist that Mr. Moussaoui have access to captured terrorists of Al Qaeda for questioning. The department acknowledged that its refusal to comply with the order ''obligates the court now to dismiss the indictment unless the court finds that the interests of justice can be served by another action.'' The department made a similar statement earlier this year when Judge Brinkema ordered that Mr. Moussaoui be given access to another captured Qaeda member. Mr. Moussaoui, a French citizen,is charged with conspiring in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Philip Shenon (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Warning On Terror Trial

Federal Courts.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: Warning On Terror Trial

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has thrown out two lawsuits filed by Deutsche Bank in which it seeks more than $500 million for damage caused to the bank's office building at 130 Liberty Street when the World Trade Center collapsed on Sept. 11. Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the United States District Court for the Southern District ruled that among other things, Deutsche Bank had failed to meet a key legal standard necessary for it to sue the city: establishing that the city owed the bank a higher standard of care than it did other residents and businesses. The suits had charged that the city negligently contributed to the collapse of 7 World Trade Center by storing diesel fuel there. The bank also charged in its lawsuit that the city prevented repair crews from entering the bank building when Lower Manhattan was sealed off. A bank spokeswoman declined to comment until the judge's decision could be read. Michael Slackman (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Lawsuits Dismissed

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Lawsuits Dismissed

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan sentenced a man to four years in prison yesterday for trying to fake his own death in the World Trade Center attack to avoid prosecution in a passport fraud case in Hawaii. When the man, Steven Chin Leung, pleaded guilty last spring, he said he had believed the fraud charge in Hawaii would be dismissed if the government thought he had been killed in the attack. He told a judge he had made a terrible mistake. A federal prosecutor, Neil M. Barofsky, said Mr. Leung made ''extraordinary efforts to take advantage of a national tragedy.'' Under federal guidelines, Mr. Leung faced up to two and a half years in prison, but the judge, Denny Chin, imposed a stiffer sentence, calling Mr. Leung's conduct despicable. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Sentenced In 9/11 Hoax

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Sentenced In 9/11 Hoax

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: A Bulgarian law student who attempted to board a plane in Atlantic City last month with scissors and two box cutters pleaded guilty yesterday to a federal charge and will leave the country. The student, Nikolay V. Dzhonev, 21, left, pleaded guilty to a lesser charge of knowingly and willfully violating airport rules. Under a plea agreement with prosecutors, he was sentenced to five years' probation and ordered to leave the country. He was originally charged with attempting to board a plane with a concealed weapon, which carries a penalty of up to 10 years in federal prison. ''It remains a little difficult for this court to believe that given what happened on Sept. 11 a year ago that you wouldn't know people would get greatly upset if you tried to take box cutters on a plane,'' Judge Robert B. Kugler said. ''We'll just chalk it up to incredible stupidity on your part.''

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Man With Box Cutters To Be Deported

Federal Courts.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Man With Box Cutters To Be Deported

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: An Indian man detained in New York for 15 months after possession of a box cutter made him a suspect in the Sept. 11 terror attacks has been deported to Hyderabad, India, after his conviction in an unrelated case of credit card fraud, his family said yesterday. The man, Gul Mohammed Shah, above, was detained with his friend Mohammed Jaweed Azmath as they traveled from New Jersey to Texas on Sept. 12. During their months of incarceration, the men were cleared of involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks, but were charged and convicted in Federal District Court in Manhattan for participating in credit card fraud. Mr. Shah was sentenced in September to a year and a day in prison, but was released early and deported. Mr. Azmath was sentenced in September to nine months. His wife, Tasleem Murad, said that she expects him back in January. In Hyderabad, the police plan to charge Mr. Shah with giving a false name on his passport application.

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: The Federal Court of Justice, Germany's highest criminal court, began considering the appeal of Mounir el-Motassadeq, the Moroccan man convicted in 2005 of belonging to a cell of Al Qaeda in Hamburg whose other members included ringleaders in the Sept. 11 attacks. He was sentenced to seven years in prison, but another court ruled that he not be jailed during his appeal, which prosecutors are using to seek a tougher sentence. While Mr. Motassadeq has acknowledged that he was friends with three of the suicide pilots, he has denied knowing of the 9/11 plot. Judge Klaus Tolksdorf said at the start of the hearing that while Mr. Motassadeq may not have known the planes would be flown into buildings, he clearly knew they would be crashed and intended to ''abet the murder of the passengers and the crew.'' The court is expected to rule on the appeal Nov. 16. VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

Federal Courts.mainheadline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: New Appeal For Man In 9/11 Cell

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, suspected of being a Qaeda terrorist, was captured in Pakistan in 2004, held in secret prisons run by the C.I.A. and then moved to the naval base at Guantánamo Bay. During about five years of detention, he says, he was confined in harsh conditions, abused during interrogation and denied a lawyer. Since the spring, Mr. Ghailani has also been a defendant in federal court in Manhattan, the first Guantánamo detainee to be moved to the civilian courts.

headline.main: Terrorism Trial May Point Way For 9/11 Cases

Federal Courts.lead_paragraph: An Algerian man held for seven years at the American prison at Guantánamo Bay arrived in France on Tuesday, the French government and his lawyers said. The man, Saber Lahmar, 39, was the last of five Algerians to be released from the prison after a judge ruled last year that there was insufficient evidence to detain them. Robert C. Kirsch, a lawyer for Mr. Lahmar, said his client had been kept in isolation for about two and a half years.

headline.main: France: Algerian Freed From Guantánamo Prison

Federal Courts.mainheadline: France: Algerian Freed From Guantánamo Prison

Recession.lead_paragraph: Zurich Financial Services has doubled its estimate, to $900 million, of the claims it expects to pay from the September terrorist attacks in the United States. The company has already twice reduced its earnings forecast this year, causing a sharp drop in the stock price. The Swiss company said it also expected lower investment income in the current economic downturn to cut back its profits. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

Recession.lead_paragraph: The International Monetary Fund cut its forecasts for United States, Japanese, European and world growth for 2001 and next year, after the terrorist strikes on Sept. 11 deepened a world economic slowdown. The I.M.F. reduced its forecast for world economic growth in 2001 and 2002 to 2.4 percent, a cut of 0.2 percentage point this year and 1.1 point next year, said Horst Köhler, the I.M.F.'s managing director.

headline.main: Global Forecast Of Growth Is Cut

Recession.lead_paragraph: Japanese automobile sales will probably decline for the second consecutive year in 2002 as fallout from the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States continues to hurt the global economy, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said. The industry group expects sales to fall 0.7 percent next year, to 5.9 million cars. Sales of passenger cars are expected to fall 4.6 percent while sales of minicars, which have engines of less than 660 cubic centimeters, are expected to rise 1.6 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

Recession.lead_paragraph: Efforts by Russian government reformers to reduce red tape for small businesses have not succeeded, said German Gref, the minister of economy and trade, citing a new study by the Moscow-based Center for Economic and Financial Research. The study, a survey of 2,000 businesses in 20 Russian regions, found that companies have seen little improvement in business conditions since the state simplified the rules. Russia's economy is in its fourth year of growth, but economists say the growth is confined to large companies. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

Recession.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea -- The North Korean leader Kim Jong-un has begun stripping his country's powerful military of its lucrative export rights in a bold attempt intended to both rejuvenate its staggering economy and curtail top generals' influence, according to a Seoul-based Web site run by defectors from North Korea. Although it is impossible to confirm most information about isolated North Korea, there have been hints that Mr. Kim might be unhappy with the stewardship of parts of the economy. In a speech distributed by the state news media in April, he said he intended to keep a tighter control on minerals exports, some of which analysts believe are controlled by the military.

Recession.lead_paragraph: America's economic imbalance with China has been a singular concern of policy makers for more than half a decade. Senators Charles E. Schumer and Lindsey Graham wanted to punish China for pegging the exchange rate to the dollar in 2005 -- arguing that its policy of cheapening the currency to subsidize exports was fueling a huge trade surplus that cost America jobs. Their bill never passed. But reducing China's surpluses has remained at the top of the bilateral agenda ever since.

Recession.lead_paragraph: Investor confidence in Germany fell for the first month in three in August amid concern about record oil prices and slowing growth in the United States and Japan. The index of institutional and analyst sentiment compiled by the ZEW Center for European Economic Research fell to 45.3, from 48.4 in July. The drop in confidence adds to evidence that German economic growth may slow this quarter. ''The recent economic data from the U.S. gives reason to be concerned that the very strong export demand in Germany up to this point could weaken,'' the center said. ''In addition, the high oil price reduces the purchasing power of consumers and puts pressure on domestic demand.''

Recession.lead_paragraph: The hit to the United States' prized credit rating may have come as a surprise Friday, but many analysts say it's not so clear that it will deliver any immediate shock to financial markets or to consumers. That is because it confirmed what the markets, economists and most people already know: the United States has a debt problem and Washington is deeply divided over how to solve it. ''I think this is already baked in the cake,'' said Garett Jones, an economist at the Mercatus Center at George Mason University, suggesting that investors and bond traders had already accounted for a downgrade. ''It's not a disaster. It's just that we're a little bit riskier, a little bit crazier than people thought a month or two ago.''

Recession.lead_paragraph: The broad American economy has largely withstood the early effects of Hurricane Katrina, even as residents of the Gulf Coast suffer through a regional economic disaster with few equals. The flooding has displaced about one million workers in the Gulf Coast region, many of whom will not be able to resume their jobs anytime soon. While some employees of large companies are still receiving paychecks, Wal-Mart stopped paying workers in the area four days after shutting its stores, and McDonald's and UPS have not paid regular wages to idled employees since the storm hit.
