Recession.lead_paragraph: SCHENECTADY, N.Y. -- President Obama, sending another strong signal that he intends to make the White House more business-friendly, named a high-profile corporate executive on Friday as his chief outside economic adviser, continuing his efforts to show more focus on job creation and reclaim the political center. Here in the birthplace of General Electric, Mr. Obama introduced the new appointee, Jeffrey R. Immelt, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, who will serve as chairman of his outside panel of economic advisers. Mr. Immelt succeeds Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, who is stepping down.

Recession.lead_paragraph: The world economy will grow 3.2 percent this year, hindered by concerns over war and terrorism that may also limit the pace of expansion in 2004 and beyond, the International Monetary Fund said today. Recession.lead_paragraph: Reflecting higher local interest rates and a worsening global economic picture after terrorist attacks on the United States, Brazil's central bank lowered the country's economic growth forecast to 2 percent from 2.8 percent for 2001. Fears of a recession were reduced, however, after the government revised the second-quarter gross domestic product up to 1.82 percent from a previously announced growth rate of 0.79 percent. Analysts say that lower economic growth will help keep a lid on inflation, which is already expected to exceed the central bank's goal of 6 percent this year. The government forecasts inflation of 6.5 percent. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Growth Forecast Lowered

Recession.lead_paragraph: Some Federal Reserve policy makers expressed concern in September that the current low rate of inflation might limit their choices in cutting short-term interest rates to bolster the economy, according to meeting minutes released today. ''Some observed that a significant decline in inflation from current levels could imply an unwelcome tightening of monetary policy in real terms,'' according to minutes of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Sept. 24.

headline.main: Notes Show Fed Concern Over Limits

Recession.mainheadline: Notes Show Fed Concern Over Limits

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has admonished Attorney General John Ashcroft for violating a court order by making remarks about defendants in the nation's first major terror trial after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. The judge, Gerald E. Rosen of Federal District Court, said in an opinion released Tuesday that Mr. Ashcroft's statements could have compromised the defendants' rights to a fair trial but that the violations did not warrant contempt charges or require Mr. Ashcroft to appear in court to explain himself.

headline.main: Ashcroft Is Rebuked For Terror Remarks

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Bikers and pedestrians returned to San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge as officials reopened the span's walkways for the first time since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. A spokeswoman for the bridge authority, Mary Currie, said the sidewalks would now remain open only during daylight hours as part of increased security.

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Reopening Of Bridge's Walkways

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: National Briefing | West: California: Reopening Of Bridge's Walkways

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Gov. Judy Martz is scaling back security measures taken at the state Capitol in Helena after the Sept. 11 attacks. Concrete barriers that were installed at the Capitol's driveways will be removed and a requirement that all visitors show identification and sign in when entering the building will be discontinued. Mindy Sink (NYT)

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The French insurance giant AXA warned that profits for 2001 would fall 53 percent, to 1.2 billion euros, and announced 525 layoffs in the United States. The job cuts, which total 625 for the year, are part of a plan to reduce costs by 700 million euros in 2002. The Paris-based company, which had not given a 2001 forecast since the Sept. 11 attacks, said the decline was a result of the effects of the attacks. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: In an effort to increase retail and other sales in Lower Manhattan, city and state officials said yesterday that they had agreed to a moratorium on the 8.25 percent sales tax for nine days during the summer. The temporary exemption applies to shops, restaurants and hotels below Houston Street, where business has been hurt since the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. Goods and services costing up to $500, including restaurant meals and hotel rooms, will be exempt from the tax from this Sunday to Tuesday; July 9 to 11; and Aug. 20 to 22. The tax relief will not apply to gasoline and cigarettes and other tobacco products. Terry Pristin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sales-Tax Holiday Set

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sales-Tax Holiday Set

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Relatives of a police officer killed in the Sept. 11 terror attack have asked a judge to order the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to provide an accounting of how money donated since Sept. 11 to the Widow's and Children's Fund has been paid out. Justice Ira Gammerman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan will decide whether the association will have to open its books. Frank J. Dominguez, whose brother, Officer Jerome Dominguez, died in the attack, said, ''Every single time they mention the numbers, the numbers change.'' The pension consultant for the association, Joseph Maccone, said the families had received adequate accounting and all of the donated money earmarked for them. He called the demand for more information ''a witch hunt.'' Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Charity Dispute Reviewed By Court

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Charity Dispute Reviewed By Court

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city had begun planning a ceremony for when the cleanup at ground zero ends. The ceremony would be for those who died in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and those who have labored at the site. The site will be shut down sometime in late May, Mr. Bloomberg said, depending on the weather and other factors. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ceremony At End Of Ground Zero Cleanup

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ceremony At End Of Ground Zero Cleanup

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: A group of seasonal Michigan businesses that rely on foreign workers for summer staff is suing the Immigration and Naturalization Service over delays in processing temporary work visas since the Sept. 11 attacks. The 13 companies filing suit are on the shores of the Great Lakes and include hotels and restaurants. John Carpenter (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: A Push For More Workers

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: A Push For More Workers

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The Immigration and Naturalization Service changed its policy last week and agreed to allow advocacy groups to visit foreign nationals held in the Hudson and Passaic County jails since Sept. 11. The service will allow such groups as the American Civil Liberties Union and the American Friends Service Committee to help detainees with legal questions and to provide representation. There are 460 aliens held nationwide since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, according to the I.N.S., though how many are in New Jersey is not known. John Holl

headline.main: I.N.S. DETAINEES

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: I.N.S. DETAINEES

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The travel company 800 Travel Systems said yesterday that it had filed a voluntary Chapter 11 reorganization petition with the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Middle District of Florida. The company said that the filing was caused partly by the Sept. 11 attacks and that it needed new debtor-in-possession financing to keep operating. Since September, 800 Travel has closed one reservation center, in San Diego, and substantially reduced the number of its employees.

headline.main: CITING SEPT. 11, TRAVEL COMPANY FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: CITING SEPT. 11, TRAVEL COMPANY FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Lawyers in the case against Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four others said they worry that their communications may be subject to government monitoring.

headline.main: 9/11 Case Is Delayed as Defense Voices Fears on Eavesdropping

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: 9/11 Case Is Delayed as Defense Voices Fears on Eavesdropping

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Reversing itself, the Immigration and Naturalization Service will permit civil-liberties lawyers to advise hundreds of foreign nationals held since the Sept. 11 attacks. The decision, issued Jan. 11 but not received by the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey until Jan. 24, followed two lawsuits accusing the government of illegally withholding the names of detainees and the charges against them. The decision will allow members of the A.C.L.U. to determine whether detainees require legal assistance. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: I.N.S. To Allow Legal Aid

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: I.N.S. To Allow Legal Aid

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has asked the Bush administration to allow relatives of immigrants who died in the Sept. 11 attacks to remain in the United States while they seek permanent residency status. In a Nov. 11 letter to the administration that was released by the mayor's office yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg said a reprieve from deportation that had been granted by the USA Patriot Act of 2001 had ''long expired, leaving families again deeply vulnerable.'' The letter continued, ''Approximately 100 spouses and children are in this desperate condition and need immediate immigration relief to move forward with their lives.'' Mike McIntire (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Residency Plea For 9/11 Relatives

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Residency Plea For 9/11 Relatives

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: WHAT happened in Manhattan on Sept. 11, 2001, was a stunning wake-up call. But in ''New York at War: Four Centuries of Combat, Fear and Intrigue in Gotham'' (Basic Books, $29.99), the historian Steven H. Jaffe skillfully reminds readers that the city had been a tempting target before, that it suffered casualties in earlier conflicts and that other generations of officials worried about immigrants with dual loyalties and about balancing New Yorkers' security and their civil liberties. Mr. Jaffe recounts those conflicts and close calls in a book that was, in fact, inspired by the attack on the World Trade Center a decade ago. At the time, he was working as a curator at the South Street Seaport Museum, he writes, and ''over the ensuing months, it dawned on me that I was in the midst of an urban landscape whose historical affinities to the events of 9/11 were hard to avoid.''

headline.main: Looking at New York as a Target

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Looking at New York as a Target

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Adults who visit the Sept. 11 museum at the World Trade Center will be charged $24 admission.

headline.main: $24 General Admission Price Set for NY 9/11 Museum
headline.print_headline: $24 General Admission Price Set for NY 9/11 Museum

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: $24 General Admission Price Set for NY 9/11 Museum

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Lawyers representing families of Sept. 11 victims won a judgment in a lawsuit claiming Iranian officials aided the hijackers who attacked the World Trade Center and Pentagon.

headline.seo: Ruling Against Iran in Sept. 11 Case
headline.main: Ruling Against Iran in Sept. 11 Case
headline.print_headline: Ruling Against Iran in Sept. 11 Case

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Ruling Against Iran in Sept. 11 Case

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: On Sept. 17, 2001, President George W. Bush visited a mosque and spoke eloquently about respect for Islam — an act of leadership that should be celebrated instead of overlooked.

headline.seo: On Religion: Six Days After 9/11, Another Anniversary Worth Honoring
headline.main: Six Days After 9/11, Another Anniversary Worth Honoring
headline.print_headline: Six Days After 9/11, Another Date Worth Honoring

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Six Days After 9/11, Another Anniversary Worth Honoring

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: It is quite likely the only reprieve Americans will get from what is expected to be an especially heavy and sustained barrage of political advertising this fall. But on Sept. 11, President Obama and Mitt Romney have agreed to suspend their campaign commercials.Their decision follows similar steps taken in 2004 and 2008, when both presidential nominees ceased campaign activities for the day in honor of the lives lost in the 2001 terror attacks.

headline.main: An Advertising Break: Pausing to Commemorate 9/11

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: An Advertising Break: Pausing to Commemorate 9/11

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Testimony by Osama bin Laden’s youngest wife has offered the most detailed account yet of the family’s life on the run preceding the raid in May 2011 that killed the Qaeda leader.

headline.seo: On Run, Bin Laden Had 4 Children and 5 Houses, a Wife Says
headline.main: In Hiding, Bin Laden Had Four Children and Five Houses
headline.print_headline: On the Run, Bin Laden Had 4 Children and 5 Houses, a Wife Says

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: In Hiding, Bin Laden Had Four Children and Five Houses

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Ali Ukla Ursan, who received the Pushkin Medal, has publicly applauded the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and expressed strong anti-Semitic views.

headline.seo: Medvedev Honors Ali Ukla Ursan, a Controversial Syrian Writer
headline.main: Russian Cultural Honor For a Controversial Syrian
headline.print_headline: Russian Cultural Honor For a Controversial Syrian

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Russian Cultural Honor For a Controversial Syrian

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: On a path to becoming a major cultural force downtown, Trinity Church blinks, announcing it would explore “additional funding sources and programming options.”

headline.seo: Trinity Church, a Sanctuary for Music, Cuts Back
headline.main: Churchly Sanctuary for Music Cuts Back
headline.print_headline: Churchly Sanctuary For Music Cuts Back

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Churchly Sanctuary for Music Cuts Back

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Opera on Tuesday disclosed details of a new opera by Christopher Theofanidis based on a book about Rick Rescorla, the head of security for Morgan Stanley who died shepherding people to safety during the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The opera, ''Heart of a Soldier,'' will star the baritone Thomas Hampson, the tenor William Burden and the soprano Melody Moore. Francesca Zambello will direct and Patrick Summers will conduct. It will have its first performance on Sept. 10, the eve of the 10th anniversary of the attack. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline.main: Casting Set for Opera About 9/11 Hero

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Casting Set for Opera About 9/11 Hero

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: A federal health official's ruling has cleared the way for 50 different types of cancer to be added to the list of sicknesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund set up to compensate and treat people exposed to the toxic smoke, dust and fumes in the months after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. The decision, released on Friday, came as a vindication for hundreds and perhaps thousands of people who have claimed -- often in the face of resistance from public health officials -- that their cancers were caused by their exposure to the dust cloud and debris thrown up by the attacks.

headline.main: 9/11 Health Fund Given Clearance To Cover Cancer

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: 9/11 Health Fund Given Clearance To Cover Cancer

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Since 1982, firefighters and police have competed in the New York City Marathon for the Mayor’s Cup.

headline.seo: New York Police and Fire Departments Have Long Running Rivalry in Marathon
headline.main: The Bravest, the Finest, the Fastest
headline.print_headline: Police and Firefighters Have Long Running Rivalry

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: The Bravest, the Finest, the Fastest

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba -- As the United States restarts its effort to prosecute -- and ultimately execute -- five detainees accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks, it has fallen to Brig. Gen. Mark S. Martins both to prove them guilty and to show the world that the tribunal system is now legitimate. ''We're going to have a fair trial,'' General Martins, the chief prosecutor in the military commissions system, said in an interview this week. ''There are a lot of people who come to this with preconceptions about unfairness, and I would just ask people to withhold judgment. The initial version of commissions was flawed, but there has been a lot of work on reforms.''

headline.main: At Guantánamo, Trial for 9/11 Defendants, and for a Revamped Tribunal

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: At Guantánamo, Trial for 9/11 Defendants, and for a Revamped Tribunal

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The state has received 688 entries in a competition to find a design for a memorial to the nearly 700 New Jersey residents killed in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, officials announced yesterday. A professional advisory committee will narrow the field of contestants to several finalists, said an administration spokeswoman, Ellen Mellody. A panel of family members of victims and survivors will choose a winning design by July. The memorial will be installed in Liberty State Park, in Jersey City, across from the World Trade Center site.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Entries Received For 9/11 Memorial

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Entries Received For 9/11 Memorial

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Reports of bias incidents against Muslims increased by about 70 percent in the United States last year, according to a study by the Council on American-Islamic Relations, an advocacy group in Washington. The study showed that Muslims had reported 1,019 incidents of harassment, violence and discriminatory treatment in 2003, up from 602 in 2002. In many cases, the report said, complainants contended that laws were applied to them unfairly or they had been singled out by local and federal law enforcement authorities because of their religion or ethnicity. Among reasons for mistreatment, the report said, was ''a lingering atmosphere'' of fear since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. John Files (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Anti-Muslim Incidents Increase

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: Anti-Muslim Incidents Increase

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The government announced a settlement with Delta Air Lines over accusations that it discriminated after the Sept. 11 terror attacks against travelers believed to have been Muslim or of Arab, Middle Eastern or Southeast Asian descent. The Transportation Department said its investigation found that Delta had acted in a manner inconsistent with federal laws barring discrimination. Though Delta acknowledged no wrongdoing, it agreed to provide civil rights training over the next two years to its pilots, flight attendants and passenger service agents. This is the fourth such settlement for airlines stemming from the weeks after the attacks.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Delta Settles Bias Complaint

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: Delta Settles Bias Complaint

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: After an extensive investigation, the government has found no evidence that terrorists tried to profit from stock and options trading ahead of the Sept. 11 attacks, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Thursday. The S.E.C. was among several federal agencies that investigated possible market manipulation. The agencies, working with stock and options exchanges, reviewed more than 9.5 million transactions that took place during the weeks preceding Sept. 11, 2001.

headline.main: No Profiting Found From 9/11 Attacks

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: No Profiting Found From 9/11 Attacks

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Gen. Wesley K. Clark asserted that the federal government had not done all it could to thwart either the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks or future such attacks, and that terrorism in this country was not inevitable. ''I think that it's clear that more could have been done to prevent 9/11 than was done,'' General Clark said Friday, speaking to reporters in Lebanon, N.H. He was quoted in Friday's Concord Monitor as saying that ''the two greatest lies'' of the last two years were that the Sept. 11 attacks could not have been prevented and that more attacks were inevitable. He said the fact that the nation's terrorist threat status had been put at ''high'' over the Christmas holidays indicated that President Bush had erred in invading Iraq before Osama bin Laden was captured and his terror network dismantled. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Campaign Briefing: THE DEMOCRATS; CLARK ON TERRORISM

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Campaign Briefing: THE DEMOCRATS; CLARK ON TERRORISM

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The government has reached a settlement with American Airlines over complaints that after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the airline unlawfully removed passengers it thought were of Arab, Middle Eastern or Southeast Asian descent. The airline, a unit of the AMR Corporation, agreed to spend about $1.5 million over three years for civil rights training for employees who deal with the public. It did not admit that it broke federal antidiscrimination laws.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Settlement In Bias Case

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: National Briefing | Washington: Settlement In Bias Case

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: “The Flag,” a CNN film about Sept. 11, does more than simply retell a familiar story or push the obvious buttons.

headline.seo: ‘The Flag,’ on CNN, Examines a Lingering Mystery
headline.main: In a Puzzle, a Clearer Look at 9/11
headline.print_headline: In a Puzzle, A Clearer Look at 9/11

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: In a Puzzle, a Clearer Look at 9/11

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The White House has issued detailed guidelines to federal officials on how to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks at home and abroad.

headline.main: White House Issues Guides on Sept. 11 Observances
headline.print_headline: White House Issues Guides on Sept. 11 Observances

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: White House Issues Guides on Sept. 11 Observances

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Publishers are releasing a new round of books timed to the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks despite lukewarm sales of many books about the events in the past. But the question remains whether people will want to read more about Sept. 11, especially after weeks of magazine covers, newspaper articles and wall-to-wall cable news coverage. W. W. Norton and Company has high hopes for one book it plans to release on Sept. 12: the memoir of Ali H. Soufan, a former F.B.I. agent who played a major role in terrorism investigations between 1997 and 2005. A spokeswoman for Norton said that the book, ''The Black Banners,'' will have close to 150,000 copies in print when it is released, a significant number in these days of e-books and struggling brick-and-mortar bookstores.

headline.main: 9/11 Books Released Into a Sea Of Others

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: 9/11 Books Released Into a Sea Of Others

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Mark Anthony Stroman, 41, a stonecutter from Dallas, shot people he believed were Arabs, saying he was enraged by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. He killed at least two: Vasudev Patel, an Indian immigrant who was Hindu, and Waqar Hasan, a Muslim born in Pakistan. A third shooting victim, Rais Bhuiyan, 37, a former Air Force pilot from Bangladesh, survived after Mr. Stroman shot him in the face at close range. Mr. Stroman admitted to the shootings. He is scheduled to be executed on Wednesday.

headline.main: The Hated and the Hater, Both Touched by Crime
headline.kicker: ASKED AND ANSWERED | MARK ANTHONY STROMAN AND RAIS BHUIYAN

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: The Hated and the Hater, Both Touched by Crime

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The Mets were front and center again on Sunday night as fans stood in unison and began chanting “U.S.A.!” when news of Osama bin Laden’s death began to spread.

headline.seo: Catharsis Comes Once Again With Mets on the Field
headline.main: Catharsis Comes Once Again With Mets on the Field
headline.print_headline: Catharsis Comes Once Again With Mets on the Field

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Catharsis Comes Once Again With Mets on the Field

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Hadidjatou Karamoko Traoré is a 9/11 widow who has had to balance an overnight job, three children and her Muslim faith.

headline.seo: A 9/11 Widow Balances Her Family, a Job and Islam
headline.main: Visiting Ground Zero, Asking Allah for Comfort
headline.print_headline: Visiting Ground Zero, Asking Allah for Comfort

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Visiting Ground Zero, Asking Allah for Comfort

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Planners did not seek the advice of established Muslim organizations experienced in volatile post-9/11 politics.

headline.seo: Organizers of Muslim Center Underestimated Its Opponents

headline.print_headline: For Muslim Center Sponsors, Early Missteps Fueled a Storm

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: For Mosque Sponsors, Early Missteps Fueled Storm

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Interviews suggest that though the State Department received many warnings about the deteriorating situation in Benghazi, none focused on the diplomatic compound that was attacked.

headline.seo: No Specific Warnings in Benghazi Attack
headline.main: Libya Warnings Were Plentiful, but Unspecific
headline.print_headline: Libya Warnings Were Plentiful, But Unspecific

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Libya Warnings Were Plentiful, but Unspecific

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The most detailed description to date of the C.I.A.’s role in the Benghazi attack told of security officers racing on foot from a secret base in the city to the American diplomatic mission.

headline.seo: C.I.A. Played Major Defensive Role in Libya Attack
headline.main: C.I.A. Played Major Role Fighting Militants in Libya Attack
headline.print_headline: C.I.A. Played Major Role Fighting Militants in Libya Attack

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: An inquiry into the attack on the American diplomatic mission in Libya criticized the State Department for a lack of seasoned security personnel and for ignoring requests for more guards.

headline.print_headline: Benghazi Panel Strongly Assails State Dept. Role

headline.main: Joining a Grim Roster

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Joining a Grim Roster

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: With alarm over the threat of terrorism in slow decline, both political parties appear to be no longer willing to give national security automatic priority over privacy and civil liberties.

headline.main: Spy Agencies Under Heaviest Scrutiny Since Abuse Scandal of the ’70s
headline.print_headline: Spy Agencies Under Heaviest Scrutiny Since Abuse Scandal of the ’70s

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Spy Agencies Under Heaviest Scrutiny Since Abuse Scandal of the ’70s

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: A war with Iraq or a terrorist attack against American interests could prompt a wave of hate crimes against Arab-Americans, Muslims and other minorities in the United States, the F.B.I. said today. The F.B.I. said the September 2001 hijackings led to a ''spike'' in attacks against Arab-Americans, Muslim-Americans and members of Indian, Sikh and other minorities. But, it said, after about three weeks, such attacks decreased sharply.

headline.main: F.B.I. Warns of Possible Hate Crimes

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: F.B.I. Warns of Possible Hate Crimes

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: A detainee at Guantánamo Bay who has been described as a financier of the Sept. 11 attacks said at a closed hearing that top operatives of Al Qaeda informed him of the impending attacks the night before they occurred, according to a transcript released yesterday. The detainee, Mustafa Ahmed al-Hawsawi, said he was told by Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who has been identified as a top Qaeda operative, ''that next night there would be an operation.'' In the transcript of the March 21 hearing, he said he also discussed the attack with Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who was quoted earlier this month as telling a similar closed hearing that he was the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks. WILLIAM GLABERSON

headline.main: National Briefing | Terrorism: Detainee Says He Was Told Of Sept. 11 Attacks

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: National Briefing | Terrorism: Detainee Says He Was Told Of Sept. 11 Attacks

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The Sept. 11 anniversary remembrance will not be held at its original location at ground zero this year because construction on the site has made it unsafe for a large public gathering, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The ceremony will be held at a plaza near the southeast corner of the site. Some family members of victims have protested, but the mayor said that the decision was final and that ''it would be a big shame'' if anyone skipped the event out of anger.

headline.main: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Ceremony To Relocate

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Ceremony To Relocate

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The National Court said it would prosecute three men on charges that they helped plan the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks in the United States. They were arrested from 2001 to 2003 by Judge Baltasar Garzón during his investigation of Al Qaeda's presence in Spain. Two men, Driss Chebli and Imad Eddin Barakat Yarkas, are charged with helping to organize a meeting in Tarragona, Spain, where details of the attacks may have been worked out, the court said. The third, Ghasoub Al Abrash Ghalyoun, is accused of making videotapes of the World Trade Center in 1997 and delivering them to people connected to the attacks. The trials are expected to begin next month. Prosecutors want each man to receive a sentence of 25 years in prison for each of the nearly 3,000 people killed in the attacks. Renwick McLean (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Trials Set For 3 Sept. 11 Suspects

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Trials Set For 3 Sept. 11 Suspects

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose legacy as mayor of New York City was transformed by his stewardship during and after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, was on a business trip to London yesterday when he found himself half a block from the first blast there. He spoke afterward of the sound of the sirens as rescuers raced toward that explosion, at the Liverpool Street station, and the growing realization, as more explosions were reported, that it had been a terrorist attack.

headline.main: Giuliani Was Near Site of Bombing

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Giuliani Was Near Site of Bombing

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: IF it is true that, as an old Chinese proverb says, crisis equals opportunity, then the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, have yielded a bonanza. Billions of dollars have been poured into homeland security by the cabinet department of the same name, the Pentagon, law enforcement and corporations. With so much money available, more than 500 exhibitors at a security conference here last week were out to reap their share. The most futuristic tools and weapons for tracking and catching potential terrorists were presumably not on display. But if the goods and services hawked at the conference are any measure, the urgent quest for greater security has stirred creative juices among inventors -- and marketers.

headline.main: It's a New World, And Everybody Gets To Play Maxwell Smart

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: It's a New World, And Everybody Gets To Play Maxwell Smart

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Past the razor wire that has been rolled out along the unusable railroad tracks separating the heavily damaged neighborhoods from the destroyed neighborhoods lies the port that gave this city its name. Put generously, it is a mess. The cargo containers are scattered for miles, the poultry freezers are destroyed and 7,300 jobs are in limbo. In the middle of one of the major terminals sits a casino, the Copa, one of a fleet of floating gambling houses that had revitalized the Gulf Coast, pumping taxes into city, county and state governments and providing jobs to some 15,000 people.

headline.main: Coastal Cities Of Mississippi In the Shadows
headline.kicker: STORM AND CRISIS: THE GULF COAST

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Coastal Cities Of Mississippi In the Shadows

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Doris Lessing, the newly chosen Nobel laureate in literature, told a Spanish newspaper that the attacks in the United States on Sept. 11, 2001, were not ''so bad'' compared with the actions of the Irish Republican Army, Agence France-Press reported. Ms. Lessing, 88, right, the British author who said she had recently finished writing a book on war, told the Spanish newspaper El País in an interview published yesterday, ''Sept. 11 was terrible, but if one re-examines the history of the I.R.A., what happened in the United States wasn't so bad.'' She added: ''Some Americans believe I'm crazy. Many people died; two prominent buildings fell, but it was neither as terrible nor so extraordinary as they think.'' In 2005 the Irish Republican Army, after a prolonged struggle against British rule in Northern Ireland, declared an end to its armed campaign.

headline.main: Doris Lessing Says 9/11 Wasnt So Bad
headline.kicker: ARTS, BRIEFLY COMPILED BY LAWRENCE VAN GELDER  | DORIS LESSING SAYS 9/11 WASNT SO BAD

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Doris Lessing Says 9/11 Wasnt So Bad

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor on Monday asked a jury to sentence Zacarias Moussaoui to death, saying his willful decision to conceal his knowledge of the Sept. 11 terrorist plot when he was arrested weeks earlier made him responsible for the thousands of deaths that day. In response, a court-appointed lawyer for Mr. Moussaoui told jurors they could not order the execution of a man on no more than a supposition: that had he revealed his knowledge of Al Qaeda's interest in flying planes into public buildings, the federal authorities would have prevented the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline.main: Prosecutor Urges Death for Concealing Sept. 11 Plot

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Prosecutor Urges Death for Concealing Sept. 11 Plot

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Workers preparing the former Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan for demolition have found additional bone fragments on the roof, bringing the total to more than 500 this month, city officials said yesterday. The building was heavily damaged and contaminated on Sept. 11, 2001, by the collapse of 2 World Trade Center, the south tower. Last week alone, 456 fragments -- some as small as one-sixteenth of an inch -- were separated from the rooftop ballast, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Remains Found At Bank

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Remains Found At Bank

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: In what might be the final major disclosure of records from New York's worst calamity, the city yesterday released recordings of 1,600 emergency calls made on Sept. 11, 2001. With the voices of callers removed for privacy considerations, only the 911 operators can be heard on most of the calls. Even so, the day resonates in short bursts of words on the recordings, providing glimpses of struggle, loss and valor.

headline.main: New Release Of 9/11 Tapes: More Loss And Confusion

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: New Release Of 9/11 Tapes: More Loss And Confusion

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: On the way to his first game in his first year as the coach of the Borough of Manhattan Community College men's soccer team -- the morning of Sept. 11, 2001 -- Kenichi Yatsuhashi was stuck as traffic came to a standstill in the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. He did not know what was happening outside, so he abandoned his van (he retrieved it a few days later) and walked back to his home in Brooklyn. ''Of course, you can't compare that year to anything else,'' Yatsuhashi, a native of Japan, said Friday as his team prepared for practice on the expansive artificial turf field at Pier 40 at West Houston and West Streets in Lower Manhattan.

headline.main: A Team From All Over Is Winning in Manhattan

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: A Team From All Over Is Winning in Manhattan

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: SnagFilms, a new Internet film company, on Friday announced an online program of documentary films dedicated to Sept. 11. The program, ''September 11th Remembrance in Film,'' features five documentaries, including the critically acclaimed ''7 Days in September.'' The films will be available in their entirety, at no charge, at both snagfilms.com and indiewire.com through Friday. Viewers will also be able to contribute funds to the National September 11th Memorial and Museum through the SnagFilms Web site, which will match viewers' contributions during the week.

headline.main: 9/11 Documentaries Available Online

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: 9/11 Documentaries Available Online

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The announcement in the case against Khalid Shaikh Mohammed was the latest twist in a high-level debate that has divided national security officials in the Obama administration.

headline.seo: Pentagon Won’t Drop Conspiracy Charge Against Khalid Shaikh Mohammed
headline.main: Military Prosecutor Battles to Drop Conspiracy Charge in 9/11 Case
headline.print_headline: Military Prosecutor to Keep 9/11 Conspiracy Charge

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Military Prosecutor Battles to Drop Conspiracy Charge in 9/11 Case

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The story of her improbable rescue by New York City firefighters was among the most enduring to emanate from the horror of Sept. 11, 2001. It was told and retold: how a weary woman, Josephine Harris, was coaxed and carried to safety by six men from Ladder Company 6 in Chinatown who had rushed to the World Trade Center that morning. It was a feat of timing, engineering and plain luck that when the rush of wind and noise came and the north tower fell away, the firefighters and Ms. Harris were not crushed in a sea of concrete, dust and steel as they were spread along the stairwell between the fourth and first floors. Rather, the building fell around them.

headline.main: Mourning A Woman Who Shared A 9/11 Escape

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Mourning A Woman Who Shared A 9/11 Escape

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The destruction of the World Trade Center produced calls for a wholesale re-evaluation of the way tall buildings are designed and built, but five years later, the changes to New York City's building code, and others across the nation, have been few and modest. Recommendations from a major federal investigation into the collapse are still being debated and may yet result in modifications to a national building code that the city plans to adopt. So far, though, 9/11 has not been a turning point for code revision, in the way past disasters were -- like the Triangle Shirtwaist fire of 1911.

headline.main: Sept. 11 Has Spurred Only Modest Changes in City and National Building Codes

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Sept. 11 Has Spurred Only Modest Changes in City and National Building Codes

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court in Richmond ordered new arguments in the case of a Sept. 11 conspirator, Zacharias Moussaoui.

headline.main: Virginia: New Arguments in 9/11 Case
headline.print_headline: Virginia: New Arguments in 9/11 Case

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Virginia: New Arguments in 9/11 Case

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: German prosecutors indicted Abdelghani Mzoudi, a 30-year-old Moroccan and a suspected member of Al Qaeda who is accused of providing logistical support to the pilots in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington. He was charged on 3,066 counts of accessory to murder in connection with the attacks. Mr. Mzoudi, who is in jail in Hamburg, has denied the charges. He is the second suspected member of Al Qaeda to be charged from the small Hamburg-based terrorist cell that played a central role in the Sept. 11 plot. Mounir el-Motassadeq, a former roommate of Mr. Mzoudi, is serving a 15-year sentence on similar charges after his conviction by a Hamburg court in February.

headline.main: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; GERMANY: SEPT. 11 INDICTMENT

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; GERMANY: SEPT. 11 INDICTMENT

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Afghanistan announced it had set up a commission to track down those responsible for the assassination of the anti-Taliban commander Ahmed Shah Masoud, as the country celebrated the 11th anniversary of the defeat of the Communist government. Mr. Massoud, also a famed anti-Soviet fighter, was killed by two suicide bombers posing as journalists in northern Afghanistan two days before the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

headline.main: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; AFGHAN PANEL TO INVESTIGATE MASSOUD'S DEATH

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; AFGHAN PANEL TO INVESTIGATE MASSOUD'S DEATH

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Relatives of those killed in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center will have an extra six months to file wrongful-death suits under a bill signed into law yesterday by Gov. George E. Pataki. The measure extends the two-year statute of limitations for filing suits, previously set to expire Sept. 11, 2003, to March 11, 2004. The bill was approved by the Legislature before it completed its regular session last month. Governor Pataki said it is only fair to give the families of the nearly 3,000 people who died in the terrorist attacks on the trade center more time to consider their legal rights.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Sept. 11 Legal Deadline Extended

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Sept. 11 Legal Deadline Extended

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Rugs from Afghanistan and Pakistan have long been regarded as a mark of middle-class affluence and sophistication. But dealers say sales have fallen sharply since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. ''We have seen a dramatic change in the last two weeks. It's unbelievable,'' Sekandar Hadaf, who works at Barat Farzaneh, an Oriental rug dealer in New York, told Reuters last week. He estimated that sales were off about 60 percent.

headline.main: Rug Sales Slow Since Attacks

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Rug Sales Slow Since Attacks

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: The wife of a Tampa podiatrist charged in a plot to blow up a Muslim gathering place has agreed to cooperate with federal prosecutors in a plea bargain, officials said. The podiatrist, Dr. Robert Goldstein, and his wife, Kristi, are accused of planning to blow up an Islamic education center in St. Petersburg. Dr. Goldstein was described in court documents as seeking to retaliate for the Sept. 11 attacks and the Arab-Israeli conflict.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Florida: Plea Deal In Bombing Plot Case

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: National Briefing | South: Florida: Plea Deal In Bombing Plot Case

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: A suspected member of the Hamburg terrorist cell behind the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in New York and Virginia will go on trial in Hamburg on Thursday. The Moroccan-born defendant, Abdelghani Mzoudi, 30, is charged with 3,066 counts of abetting murder and aiding a terrorist organization. Mr. Mzoudi was a friend of Mohamed Atta, one of the terrorist pilots, and was a witness for his will. Mr. Atta and two other pilots in the attacks were from the Hamburg cell. If found guilty, Mr. Mzoudi faces the same 15-year jail term to which a fellow Moroccan, Mounir el-Motassadeq, was sentenced in February for aiding the hijackers. The trial, with 125 witnesses, could last into early next year. Victor Homola (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Second 9/11 Trial

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Second 9/11 Trial

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Hate crimes against Muslims and people who are or appear to be of Middle Eastern descent soared to record levels last year, in all likelihood as a consequence of the Sept. 11 attacks, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. In its annual report on hate crimes, the bureau found that incidents in which people, institutions and businesses identified with the Islamic faith were the targets increased 1,600 percent, to 481 in 2001 from 28 in 2000. Muslims had previously been among the religious groups least frequently victimized by hate crimes.

headline.main: Hate Crimes Up Against Muslims

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Hate Crimes Up Against Muslims

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: * The Advertising Council, New York, which coordinates public service campaigns on behalf of the advertising industry, reported that media companies donated more than $100 million in commercial time and ad space from Sept. 21, 2001, through Sept. 11, 2002, for public service announcements produced in response to the terrorist attacks.

headline.main: Miscellany

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Miscellany

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: An Indian man detained in New York for 15 months after possession of a box cutter made him a suspect in the Sept. 11 terror attacks has been deported to Hyderabad, India, after his conviction in an unrelated case of credit card fraud, his family said yesterday. The man, Gul Mohammed Shah, above, was detained with his friend Mohammed Jaweed Azmath as they traveled from New Jersey to Texas on Sept. 12. During their months of incarceration, the men were cleared of involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks, but were charged and convicted in Federal District Court in Manhattan for participating in credit card fraud. Mr. Shah was sentenced in September to a year and a day in prison, but was released early and deported. Mr. Azmath was sentenced in September to nine months. His wife, Tasleem Murad, said that she expects him back in January. In Hyderabad, the police plan to charge Mr. Shah with giving a false name on his passport application.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Former Hijacking Suspect Deported

September 11 Anniversaries.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Former Hijacking Suspect Deported

September 11 Anniversaries.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was named chairman of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation yesterday, despite strong opposition from several relatives of those killed in the Sept. 11 attacks. Many of the family members say they will continue to press to have the names of the dead, with ages, organized by affiliation and where they died; Mr. Bloomberg wants them listed at random. With a new $10 million gift from American Express, Mr. Bloomberg's chief function will be to raise the additional $155 million needed for the project. Mr. Bloomberg has been cleared for that work by the city's Conflicts of Interest Board, but must either stay out of government decisions affecting people or entities from whom he is seeking donations or not ask them for money. DIANE CARDWELL (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor To Lead Memorial Group

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Thousands of Pakistani soldiers have been deployed on mountain peaks and in hidden valleys along the Afghan border in recent days in a bid to cut off escape routes for Osama bin Laden and his fighters from the remote enclave of Tora Bora in eastern Afghanistan, Pakistan military officials said today. The terrain in northwestern Pakistan across the border from Tora Bora, where some suspect that Mr. bin Laden is making a last stand, is rugged and inhospitable. Mountains top 15,000 feet and the few trails that exist are little more than ruts and donkey paths through the barren, arid landscape.

headline.main: Pakistan Sends Troops to Border to Prevent bin Laden Escape

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Thousands of people in Khost, in the southeast, protested the new Afghan government for the fourth day. Khost is one of the nation's least secure areas, where the United States military continues operations to hunt Al Qaeda and Taliban members. The protesters are supporters of the powerful local warlord Bacha Khan Zadran, who is demanding that he be consulted on appointments of governors in the region. In the west, outside Herat, as many as 70 people were reported killed in fighting among ethnic Tajik and Pashtun soldiers. The Pashtuns appealed for help from the central government. Ian Fisher (NYT)

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Health officials questioned all 1,200 American troops at Khanabad air base in Uzbekistan and found no symptoms of exposure to nerve or other chemical weapons, an Army spokesman said. Traces of the substances were found on base a week ago. Officials will now survey the records of at least 1,800 other troops who passed through the base since American forces were deployed there in October. Officials believe the traces were left by chemical weapons once stored by the Soviet military, which controlled the base until Uzbekistan became independent in 1991.

''There are some officials inside Pakistan for communication purposes but they are not fighting,'' General Musharraf told reporters. ''Americans not even in double figures are with us. They are communication experts.''

headline.main: Pakistani Details Narrow U.S. Role

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Canadian-led troops are searching caves in the Tora Bora region of eastern Afghanistan for the first time since the aerial bombardment of that rugged mountain redoubt ended in December, Pentagon officials said today. More than 300 Canadian light-infantry troops, including engineers and explosives experts, are reopening caves sealed by the American bombing, and scouring the region for signs that Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters may have slipped back into the region. About 90 soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division and some allied Afghan troops are also involved in the operation.

headline.main: Canadian-Led Troops Revisit Caves in Eastern Afghanistan

Tora Bora.mainheadline: Canadian-Led Troops Revisit Caves in Eastern Afghanistan

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: An American Army soldier was wounded by a land mine south of Kandahar, but his injuries are not life-threatening, the United States Central Command said. Nineteen American troops and one C.I.A. agent have died in Afghanistan or in the region in support of the war; 76 have been wounded. Only two of the deaths were due to hostile fire.

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: Pakistan said yesterday that the United States had not consulted it about the possibility of American-led forces crossing into Pakistan to hunt down Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters. Maj. Gen. Frank Hagenbeck told reporters in Afghanistan last week that United States forces might cross into Pakistan to snuff out the extremists' havens. But a Pakistani military spokesman, Maj. Gen. Rashid Qureshi, insisted there had been no such request from the United States-led forces. General Qureshi said Pakistan's policy was clear: ''All actions that are to be taken inside Pakistan are taken by Pakistani forces and Pakistani personnel.''

Tora Bora.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- An American aid expert being held hostage by Al Qaeda in Pakistan was shown making an emotional appeal to President Obama to negotiate for his release in a video released on Monday in what analysts described as a jihadist counter against the wave of publicity that marked the first anniversary of the death of Osama bin Laden. The hostage, Warren Weinstein, a 70-year-old development consultant who was kidnapped in the eastern city of Lahore in August, appeared in the video released on the Internet. Wearing traditional Pakistani clothes, he appealed to Mr. Obama to bow to his captors' demands.

Turkish news reports and Kurdish officials in northern Iraq reported more Turkish warplane sorties late Thursday night.

US Military Officials.lead_paragraph: The Air Force general in charge of the American air war over Afghanistan will be leaving his command within the next few weeks to take up a high-ranking position at the Pentagon, a senior military official said tonight. Lt. Gen. Charles F. Wald, the head of American air forces assigned to the Middle East and Southwest Asia, is being promoted to deputy chief of staff for air and space operations. The position is one of the most coveted billets for a three-star general in the Air Force and has often been a stepping stone to a fourth star.

Rumsfeld to bring detainees from the conflict in Afghanistan half-way around the world to the base on Cuba's southeast tip.

Marc Dumais of Canada will lead an inquiry into why an Air National Guard F-16 pilot who thought he was under attack mistakenly bombed Canadian troops in Afghanistan last week, the Pentagon said today. Four Canadians died. General Sargeant, an experienced F-16 pilot, is commander of the 56th Fighter Wing at Luke Air Force Base, Ariz. The investigation will be conducted in Kuwait.

US Military Officials.lead_paragraph: NATO airborne-radar planes that have circled American skies since last fall will return to Europe this month, alliance and Pentagon officials said today. The arrival of the surveillance planes last October was the first time NATO forces had crossed the Atlantic to defend the United States. They freed Air Force Awacs for missions elsewhere, including near Afghanistan.

US Military Officials.lead_paragraph: An Air Force MC-130 transport plane crashed in Afghanistan on Tuesday but all eight of its crew survived, a spokesman for the Central Command said. Officials said the crash apparently was not caused by enemy fire. Pentagon officials said the plane was on a mission at the time but declined to give details. The MC-130 typically flies night missions and is used to transport Special Operations troops, for search and rescue and to refuel helicopters. Thom Shanker (NYT)

US Military Officials.lead_paragraph: MY father, William G. Long Sr., was part of the crew charged with loading the atom bomb into the Enola Gay in World War II. His unit was the 509th Composite Group, reporting to Col. Paul W. Tibbets Jr., the pilot. Dad's military service shaped his life, and consequently it shaped mine. My family moved to Pennsylvania when I was a baby, and to Florida when I was 6. In 1972, when I graduated from the University of Florida with an English degree, I didn't know what I wanted to do or how to job-hunt. I knew I wanted to travel, but when I interviewed at a travel agency, the owner said: ''Why would I hire a pretty little girl like you? You'll just get married and leave.''

headline.main: Military Metamorphosis

US Military Officials.lead_paragraph: FORWARD OPERATING BASE MOCORON, Honduras -- The United States military has brought lessons from the past decade of conflict to the drug war being fought in the wilderness of Miskito Indian country, constructing this remote base camp with little public notice but with the support of the Honduran government. It is one of three new forward bases here -- one in the rain forest, one on the savanna and one along the coast -- each in a crucial location to interdict smugglers moving cocaine toward the United States from South America.

US Military Officials.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- After fleeing Afghanistan when the United States invaded the country in 2001, a group of terrorism suspects regrouped at a Pakistani safe house and began training for new kinds of operations -- building detonators for roadside bombs and learning ''Americanized'' English, according to a document made public by the military on Thursday. The document was a nine-page ''stipulation of fact'' signed with a thumbprint by Noor Uthman Muhammed, a Sudanese detainee at the military prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. He pleaded guilty this week in a military tribunal to providing material support for terrorism. A military jury is taking evidence for his sentencing hearing.

US Military Officials.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan -- Two new reports addressing human rights issues in Afghanistan have raised questions about how NATO troops are conducting the war. Both reports center on a question that has vexed international forces since the war began: How can the military be sure it has killed, detained or made deals with the right people? A report by the Afghanistan Analysts Network challenges the accuracy of American intelligence used in what are known as targeted killings, and makes a case study of the killing of an alleged Qaeda-affiliated operative in Takhar Province who was attacked by NATO jets as he traveled in a convoy through a rural area. The report offers evidence that NATO forces got the wrong man and that the insurgent commander they were seeking is alive in Pakistan -- an interview with him is included in the report. [The public television program Frontline also addressed the case in this segment of its program ''Kill/Capture.'']

headline.main: Murky Identities and Ties Hinder NATO's Hunt for Afghan Insurgents, Report Says

US Military Officials.mainheadline: Murky Identities and Ties Hinder NATO's Hunt for Afghan Insurgents, Report Says

US Military Officials.lead_paragraph: As the Iraqi insurgency intensified in early 2004, an elite Special Operations forces unit converted one of Saddam Hussein's former military bases near Baghdad into a top-secret detention center. There, American soldiers made one of the former Iraqi government's torture chambers into their own interrogation cell. They named it the Black Room. In the windowless, jet-black garage-size room, some soldiers beat prisoners with rifle butts, yelled and spit in their faces and, in a nearby area, used detainees for target practice in a game of jailer paintball. Their intention was to extract information to help hunt down Iraq's most-wanted terrorist, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, according to Defense Department personnel who served with the unit or were briefed on its operations.

headline.main: TASK FORCE 6-26: Inside Camp Nama; In Secret Unit's 'Black Room,' A Grim Portrait of U.S. Abuse

US Military Officials.lead_paragraph: Four National Guard members filed a class-action suit against Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, the Massachusetts Guard, Gov. Mitt Romney and other military officials contending that the troops were not reimbursed for expenses while on duty after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. A lawyer for the plaintiffs, John Shek, said troops called up by the federal National Guard office were allowed reimbursement, but not those put on active duty by the Massachusetts Guard. One plaintiff in the $73 million suit, Louis P. Tortorella, said he spent more than $14,625 commuting two and a half hours to guard the Quabbin Reservoir from September 2001 to late 2003. A spokesman for the Massachusetts Guard had no comment. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

At least 5 of the more than 600 detainees at the naval base have tried to hang themselves in the past three weeks, said a Pentagon spokeswoman, Lt. Cmdr. Barbara Burfeind. Amnesty International urged the United States authorities to investigate the suicide attempts to determine whether the manner in which interrogations are conducted may have contributed.

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: About 2,800 children who lost parents in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack will each be mailed $1,000 checks as part of a plan to disburse the last $4.1 million in a fund established by Gov. George E. Pataki for families of the victims. In addition to the $2.8 million for the children, about $1.3 million in checks of about $3,000 will be disbursed to 400 to 500 people who were physically injured that day. Michael Marr, a spokesman for the State Department of Taxation and Finance, which administers the New York World Trade Center Relief Fund, said the governor wanted the remaining money distributed in time for the holidays. Altogether, the fund will have distributed $70 million to 5,610 people from 2,678 families, Mr. Marr said, not including the injured people who will be added to the list as they apply. Al Baker (NYT)

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: About 200 lawyers are offering free legal advice to families of the Sept. 11 terror attacks in seeking compensation from a special federal assistance fund, the state attorney general's office said yesterday. The 200 volunteers from the Connecticut Trial Lawyers Association will help families legally prove they have suffered economic and non-economic loss. Officials will publicize how to seek compensation by Dec. 21. Victims' families have two years after that date to file claims and are entitled to a decision no more than 120 days after filing.

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: To help the families of those who died on Flight 587, which crashed on Nov. 12 after takeoff from Kennedy Airport, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced that New York City was setting up a new charity, similar to one created for the families of lost rescue personnel after the World Trade Center attacks. The same spirit of inclusion moved in Washington, where a bill was introduced in the House that would open the federal Sept. 11 Victims Compensation Fund to the families of Americans killed or injured in the terrorist bombings of two embassies in Africa in 1998. Diana B. Henriques

About 150,000 families meet the eligibility requirements set by the American Red Cross and the September 11th Fund, including relatives of people killed in the World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks, people injured in those attacks, rescue workers and displaced residents.

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Handbags made from former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's old neckties will be sold in a charity auction to benefit families of those killed on Sept. 11. Proceeds from the auction, which takes place tomorrow evening at Henri Bendel department store on Fifth Avenue, will benefit the Twin Towers Fund, a charity Mr. Giuliani established to assist families of the uniformed rescue workers who were killed. Mr. Giuliani said he found several dozen neckties while cleaning out his office at City Hall last year. His companion, Judith Nathan, suggested they might be donated to charity, he said. Larry Levy, president of the Twin Towers Fund, said $185 million had been raised for the charity, $155 million of which has been distributed.

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: The Twin Towers Fund has begun distributing its third round of benefits totaling more than $103 million. The distribution will go to rescue workers not included in previous distributions. The fund was established by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to benefit the families of uniformed rescue workers who perished during the terrorist attacks. It has distributed a total of $155 million to 436 families, including 789 children. The typical distributions are $150,000 to each spouse, $60,000 to each child 23 and younger and $25,000 to children 24 and older. The fund continues to seek donations and hopes to include unmarried domestic partners in the next distribution, Laurence Levy, the president of the fund, said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Relatives of a police officer killed in the Sept. 11 terror attack have asked a judge to order the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to provide an accounting of how money donated since Sept. 11 to the Widow's and Children's Fund has been paid out. Justice Ira Gammerman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan will decide whether the association will have to open its books. Frank J. Dominguez, whose brother, Officer Jerome Dominguez, died in the attack, said, ''Every single time they mention the numbers, the numbers change.'' The pension consultant for the association, Joseph Maccone, said the families had received adequate accounting and all of the donated money earmarked for them. He called the demand for more information ''a witch hunt.'' Susan Saulny (NYT)

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Children of New Jersey residents killed in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks can attend college tuition-free, under a $500,000 program financed by state and private funds. Gov. James E. McGreevey issued an executive order on Tuesday retroactive to the fall 2001 semester. The order applies to public and private colleges in and outside of New Jersey, and any tuition paid since then will be reimbursed, said Paul Aronsohn, a spokesman for Mr. McGreevey. At least 15 children of New Jersey victims are enrolled in college, and the World Trade Center Scholarship Fund is also available to victims' children not yet college age, Mr. Aronsohn said. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Seeking to help the families of victims of the Sept. 11 attack, the Legislature gave final approval yesterday to a bill that encourages federal officials to give benefits to same-sex partners of the dead, but stops short of according them the same rights as widows and widowers. Gov. George E. Pataki introduced the bills and has said he will sign them. In September, the governor issued an executive order directing the state crime victim board to give awards to domestic partners. Ken Feinberg, the special master who oversees the distribution of the Federal Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund, has said he will follow state laws in deciding who gets benefits. Mr. Feinberg cautioned, however, that he might still be bound by marriage and probate laws, which do not cover same-sex partners. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

Giuliani, the former mayor, who continues to serve as the unpaid chairman of the Twin Towers Fund, said the 28 included 6 emergency workers for private ambulance companies, 13 Port Authority employees, a Secret Service agent and an F.B.I. agent.

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: After raising $425 million, the September 11th Fund called on people yesterday to direct contributions to other charitable causes. The fund is asking for donations to other causes, officials said, because more than enough government and philanthropic aid is available to victims of the terror attacks. Nonprofit groups, from museums to homeless shelters, have reported a sharp drop in donations. Of the $425 million raised by the fund, a project of the New York Community Trust and the United Way of New York City, more than $160 million has been distributed. David Barstow (NYT)

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, a nonprofit group that supports arts organizations, has received a $5 million grant from the September 11th Fund that will be used to finance dozens of arts groups in Lower Manhattan over the next three years, the council announced yesterday. Starting in January, nonprofit organizations in Lower Manhattan or sponsoring activities there can apply for the grants, which will range from $5,000 to $250,000, said Tom Healy, president of the council. The money is meant to help arts groups with marketing, programming and capital expenses, he said.

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A federal health official's ruling has cleared the way for 50 different types of cancer to be added to the list of sicknesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund set up to compensate and treat people exposed to the toxic smoke, dust and fumes in the months after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. The decision, released on Friday, came as a vindication for hundreds and perhaps thousands of people who have claimed -- often in the face of resistance from public health officials -- that their cancers were caused by their exposure to the dust cloud and debris thrown up by the attacks.

headline.main: 9/11 Health Fund Given Clearance To Cover Cancer

Victim Compensation Fund.mainheadline: 9/11 Health Fund Given Clearance To Cover Cancer

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: No one lived as deeply in the emotional and financial complexities of the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund as the person who designed it and became its public face: Kenneth R. Feinberg. At first, Mr. Feinberg, whose official title was special master, was derided as an arrogant Solomon, even though he was working on the fund with no compensation. But he worked tirelessly to sell his program, and began to win converts after the first awards were made in August 2002.

headline.main: Special Master Steered a Program Through Its Many Curves

Victim Compensation Fund.mainheadline: Special Master Steered a Program Through Its Many Curves

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A group of family members of World Trade Center victims announced yesterday the formation of the 9/11 Campaign, an effort to raise money for programs that will be associated with the memorial at ground zero. The immediate goal ''is to raise $9,110,000 by Sept. 11 of this year,'' said Monica Iken, founder of September's Mission, a victims' family advocacy group. The money will be used to create an endowment that can finance children's programs, conferences and other educational outreach efforts. Glenn Collins (NYT)

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan dismissed a lawsuit yesterday that accused the City of New York City and Motorola of providing firefighters with faulty radio equipment that was in use on Sept. 11, 2001. Representatives of 12 firefighters who died in the collapse of the World Trade Center filed the suit. They claimed that the faulty radios deprived the firefighters of information that could have saved their lives. Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of United States District Court dismissed the case, saying that the plaintiffs waived their right to sue when they decided to participate in the Victim Compensation Fund. Susan M. Saulny (NYT)

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: ASSIGNING a dollar value to a person's life might seem impossible, not to mention unthinkable. But after a wrongful death, the needs of the surviving family - financial, emotional or both - often lead to that grim calculation. Forensic economists advise courts and governments on how to translate lives cut short into money for the living.

headline.main: Putting a Price on the Priceless: One Life

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: The New York City Law Department will discontinue its expedited death certificate program, which helped more than 2,300 relatives and families of victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, attack receive death certificates, a department spokesman has announced. After April 30, families of victims may obtain regular certificates through standard legal procedures. Since September 2001, the department has processed 2,475 applications, issuing 2,392 certificates. The program allowed survivors to get the basic documentation necessary to receive benefits and to administer the estates of the victims. Within 24 hours of the announcement of the program, more than 700 lawyers arrived to learn how to help process the expedited death certificates, said Barbara Berger Opotowsky of the Association of the City Bar of New York. Tina Kelley (NYT)

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Families of victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks cannot view hundreds of thousands of nonpublic documents used in the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, an appeals court said, overturning a lower court's order. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, said the families were not entitled to view documents that were given to Mr. Moussaoui's lawyers to aid his defense but were not made public. Mr. Moussaoui, 38, is the only person charged in the United States in connection with the attacks.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Court Bars Families From Moussaoui Evidence

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to stealing from a federal fund established to help businesses recover after Sept. 11, prosecutors said. The man, Chang Sheng Yu, was arrested last October and charged with obtaining $118,000 from a fund under the aegis of the Empire State Development Corporation by submitting fabricated business records, including a doctored rental agreement, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Yu pleaded guilty to wire fraud, prosecutors said.

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A government money market fund that has been frozen for more than two months began sending a portion of its shareholders' cash back to them on Thursday. But investors still do not know how long they will have to wait for the rest of their money. The initial checks will return about 40 percent of the investment by shareholders in the Reserve U.S. Government Fund, one of more than a dozen funds in the Reserve Fund family that have been locked up since mid-September.

headline.main: Money Fund Thaws a Bit To Return Some Cash

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A painter who worked at the World Trade Center has been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges that he stole more than $1 million by falsely claiming that he was permanently disabled in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, federal prosecutors said yesterday. The money came from the Department of Justice September 11th Fund. Prosecutors said it was the largest amount anyone had been accused of wrongly receiving from the fund. The painter, Michael Mastellone, 39, of East Windsor, N.J., faces up to 40 years in prison if convicted. He was released yesterday on $1 million bail. Peter Bark, Mr. Mastellone's lawyer, said his back injuries and psychological problems had been confirmed by the fund's doctors. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS (NYT)
