Victim Compensation Fund.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Accused Of 9/11 Swindle

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A federal judge yesterday dismissed three lawsuits that claimed the federal fund created to compensate the relatives of Sept. 11 victims was unfair, arbitrary and biased against victims who earned high incomes. In doing so, Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the United States District Court for the Southern District brushed aside what had been the most serious challenge yet to the Victim Compensation Fund, which is expected to cost taxpayers as much as $5 billion. He also vindicated the fund's embattled special master, Kenneth R. Feinberg, who had been accused of trying to deprive the families of the victims who died in New York of hundreds of millions of dollars or more.

headline.main: Judge Dismisses 3 Cases Against 9/11 Fund's Special Master

Victim Compensation Fund.mainheadline: Judge Dismisses 3 Cases Against 9/11 Fund's Special Master

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: Like many of its counterparts in Manhattan, the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers waived its admission fee for several days after the terrorist attacks. Now regular admission fees have resumed, and the museum is asking visitors to contribute to the September 11 Fund in lieu of additional donations to the museum. The fund, established by the United Way and the New York Community Fund, channels money to those directly affected by the Sept. 11 attack.

headline.main: Footlights; Museum Gets Back to Business

Victim Compensation Fund.mainheadline: Footlights; Museum Gets Back to Business

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: The city's Human Resources Administration said yesterday that it would not seek the return of extra financial aid given to families of the victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attack. Typically, the city recovers aid if recipients receive help for the same event from another agency, like the federal Victim Compensation Fund. The city does not have an estimate of the number of recipients or of how much money was given to those who also received federal aid. But the city said the number of New Yorkers receiving public assistance jumped by about 5,500 in the two months after the attack. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: No Refund Sought Of Extra 9/11 Aid

Victim Compensation Fund.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: No Refund Sought Of Extra 9/11 Aid

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A panel of federal appellate judges upheld a decision to dismiss lawsuits from survivors of victims of the World Trade Center attack who charged that the special master of the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund would unfairly limit awards to certain families. On Friday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld a May decision by the United States District Court for the Southern District, which dismissed three lawsuits on behalf of families of victims who worked for Cantor Fitzgerald. The cases involve victims whose income was in the top 2 percent and whose survivors were considering seeking compensation from the fund for their losses, estimated in one case to be up to $52 million. According to court papers, the fund's special master, Kenneth R. Feinberg, has spoken about considering awards of up to $7 million. In their decision, the judges wrote that ''any cap on compensation would be a direct violation of the statute'' governing the fund. They also wrote that they saw no evidence that Mr. Feinberg had established a cap. Tina Kelley (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Decision On 9/11 Suit Is Upheld

Victim Compensation Fund.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Decision On 9/11 Suit Is Upheld

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A fund established for families of Sept. 11 victims has $7 million in undistributed donations, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday. Those who are eligible have until Sept. 30 to submit applications. The remaining money in the New York State World Trade Center Relief Fund is being held for 400 designated families whose members are eligible but have not yet applied for the aid. The fund has distributed slightly more than $63 million to 2,500 families. Notices were mailed yesterday to the 400 families. Those eligible include victims' spouses, domestic partners and fiancées and fiancés, along with children 21 and younger. Parents are eligible if there is no spouse, domestic partner, fiancée or child. Stacy Albin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Millions Left In 9/11 Fund

Victim Compensation Fund.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Millions Left In 9/11 Fund

Victim Compensation Fund.lead_paragraph: A congressman from Staten Island wants the administrator of the federal fund for victims of last year's terror attacks to be fired because he disparaged Staten Island. The congressman, Representative Vito J. Fossella, made the request yesterday in a letter to the Justice Department in response to a comment by the administrator, Kenneth R. Feinberg, in this week's issue of The New Yorker: ''Staten Island, that's a third world country.''

Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: The Coast Guard has tentatively identified the body of a Long Island woman who had been missing after she and a companion began a kayaking trip three days ago. What are believed to be the remains of Mary Jagoda, 20, of Huntington, were found off the coast of Monomoy Island near Cape Cod yesterday, Sgt. James Plath of the Massachusetts State Police said. Ms. Jagoda, a junior at Brandeis University, was the sole remaining child of Louis and Anna May Jagoda. Her brother, Jake, 24, an employee of Cantor Fitzgerald, was killed in the attack on the World Trade Center in 2001. Another child died in infancy 20 years ago. Ms. Jagoda and a friend, Sarah Aronoff, 19, of Bethesda, Md., started at a boat launch in Harwich Port, paddling eight-foot plastic kayaks into foggy conditions on Sunday afternoon. A friend reported them missing later that day. The Coast Guard called off the search for Ms. Aronoff last night.

Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Gov. Judy Martz is scaling back security measures taken at the state Capitol in Helena after the Sept. 11 attacks. Concrete barriers that were installed at the Capitol's driveways will be removed and a requirement that all visitors show identification and sign in when entering the building will be discontinued. Mindy Sink (NYT)

Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: More than 250 National Guard troops from Connecticut will guard ski slopes during the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City. The troops' primary area of responsibility will be the Snowbasin ski area, where downhill events will take place. They will be part of a larger National Guard force mobilized to protect the games from terrorist attacks -- more than 3,000 troops, said Maj. Michael J. Falk, who will be in charge of Connecticut's National Guard presence at the Games, which will be held from Feb. 8 to Feb. 24. Major Falk said that Connecticut would provide the second-largest number of troops, after Utah. The 2002 Winter Olympics, which will be broadcast live to more than 80 nations, are expected to have the tightest security of any Olympic event in history.

Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: A German container ship was allowed to dock in Port Newark today after more than two days of inspections determined that the radioactive readings that it registered were emanating from naturally occurring radiation in ceramic tiles among the cargo. The 708-foot Palermo Senator and its crew of 21 steamed into port here this afternoon after a determination that it and its cargo ''posed no danger or threat,'' said Sandra Carroll, a spokeswoman and special agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline.main: Ship's Radiation Is Traced to Harmless Tiles

Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Schumer called yesterday for a waterfront park to be built with some of the money set aside by the federal government for the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan. He proposed an apron of parkland that would stretch from Canal Street on the West Side to Pier 42 on the East Side, where it would meet East River Park. Mr. Schumer, a Democrat, acknowledged that the plan, which may require approval from Congress, would draw criticism from some, including the Coast Guard, which would lose a building.

Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Annual insurance premiums for San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge will double, to $1.1 million, and coverage for terrorist attacks will end when its policy is renewed on Monday. Of more than 20 insurers approached, only two offered limited terrorism coverage, and at high rates, so the bridge's board opted to keep the current insurer, ACE USA. Catherine Billey (NYT)

Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: A man who was arrested for stealing watches and cash while impersonating a firefighter at the World Trade Center site in October pleaded guilty to the charges yesterday. The man, Johnny Dunham, 26, of the Bronx, an unemployed security guard, was accused of stealing more than $3,000 worth of merchandise from the Tourneau store. He also acknowledged stealing a Fire Department jacket. He will be sentenced on March 21. Robert Worth (NYT)

At first, the Guard will be replaced mostly by officers supplied by state and local police departments, said Michael P. Jackson, the deputy secretary of transportation; later, more federal police officers will be used. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Four National Guard members filed a class-action suit against Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, the Massachusetts Guard, Gov. Mitt Romney and other military officials contending that the troops were not reimbursed for expenses while on duty after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. A lawyer for the plaintiffs, John Shek, said troops called up by the federal National Guard office were allowed reimbursement, but not those put on active duty by the Massachusetts Guard. One plaintiff in the $73 million suit, Louis P. Tortorella, said he spent more than $14,625 commuting two and a half hours to guard the Quabbin Reservoir from September 2001 to late 2003. A spokesman for the Massachusetts Guard had no comment. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Small boats returned to New York Harbor yesterday, a day after federal authorities barred the vessels from entering the harbor because of reports of a possible New Year's Eve terrorist attack. Coast Guard officials reported no arrests as a result of the restriction, which ended at 8 a.m. yesterday, 16 1/2 hours after it was announced. ''We had a couple of incidents of recreational boaters not realizing that a security zone was in place,'' said Petty Officer Mike Hvozda, a spokesman for the Coast Guard. Coast Guard.lead_paragraph: Restrictions on spectators will be in place tomorrow for the Coast Guard Academy's Parents Day football game and two soccer games on the campus in New London, Conn. Because of tightened security on the campus in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, players on the Coast Guard teams and their opponents must provide academy officials with the names of family members who plan to attend the games. Relatives on the lists must produce identification to Coast Guard personnel at the Crystal Mall shopping center in nearby Waterford, where they will have to park their cars before being bused about three miles to Cadet Memorial Field.

Virginia Fields, said yesterday that she had created emergency grants for shops, restaurants and other small businesses below Canal Street in danger of closing. Pataki yesterday announced a $20 million program to provide grants of up to $10,000 for small and medium-size businesses hurt by the Sept. 11 terror attack. Owners of retail businesses with fewer than 50 employees and who intend to remain in New York will be eligible. The groups, Seedco, a nonprofit community aid group, and the Alliance for Downtown New York, said that businesses with 10 or fewer employees could apply for the aid if they were on or below Chambers Street. The grants have a maximum of $50,000 and the low-interest loans, $100,000. Information is available at (866) 473-3326. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Business Aid At Ground Zero

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that they would press the federal government for future aid to New York for its recovery from the terrorist attack last fall. In addition to seeking money to study the health of workers at ground zero, the senators said they had introduced legislation to extend unemployment insurance to June 1, 2003, for eligible New Yorkers, and would push legislation to forgive student loans for spouses of those killed or permanently disabled in the attack. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Senators Seek More 9/11 Aid

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Senators Seek More 9/11 Aid

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service has ruled that small businesses in Lower Manhattan that continued operating after the Sept. 11 terror attack are eligible for tax credits for employing others. The plan calls for companies to receive up to $2,400 in tax credits for each part- and full-time employee. Citing a recent tax code change, the I.R.S. announced yesterday that companies that operated on or south of Canal Street until the attack, and that currently employed no more than 200 employees, were eligible. Stacy Albin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tax Credits For Ground-Zero Jobs

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tax Credits For Ground-Zero Jobs

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Efforts by Russian government reformers to reduce red tape for small businesses have not succeeded, said German Gref, the minister of economy and trade, citing a new study by the Moscow-based Center for Economic and Financial Research. The study, a survey of 2,000 businesses in 20 Russian regions, found that companies have seen little improvement in business conditions since the state simplified the rules. Russia's economy is in its fourth year of growth, but economists say the growth is confined to large companies. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Red Tape Persists

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Red Tape Persists

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Consolidated Edison can temporarily delay a scheduled credit for customer bills until a final tally for costs related to the Sept. 11 terror attack, state regulators have ruled. The state's Public Service Commission ruled on Wednesday that $36.4 million in natural gas service credits could be delayed until it could be determined whether Con Ed's Sept. 11 costs -- about $400 million in damage to plant and equipment -- are covered by insurance or federal aid.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Terror Costs For Con Ed

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Terror Costs For Con Ed

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Members of a cabdrivers group protested what they called a refusal of financial aid by charitable funds and government agencies after their businesses declined following the Sept. 11 terror attack. The group, the New York Taxi Workers Alliance, said that unlike other businesses hurt by the decline, cabdrivers had received little, if any, public attention. The group, which demonstrated in front of City Hall, is also seeking a fare increase of about 17 percent from the Taxi and Limousine Commission, said Chaumtoli Huq, general counsel for the alliance. The commission is considering an increase. The group says it represents more than 3,000 of the city's roughly 12,000 cabbies. Marcos Mocine-McQueen (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Taxi Group Protests

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Taxi Group Protests

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: The Carnegie Corporation has announced that it is awarding $10 million in grants to 137 arts organizations in New York City that are struggling after Sept. 11. The foundation's president, Vartan Gregorian said in a written statement that the $10 million came from an anonymous donor who ''understands the greatness of this city and the centrality of its cultural institutions.''

headline.main: Carnegie Grants Aid in an Emergency

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Carnegie Grants Aid in an Emergency

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Grants up to $50,000 and monthly rent subsidies of up to $5,000 for small businesses hurt by the Sept. 11 terror attack were proposed yesterday to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The roughly $200 million required for the initiative would come from federal Community Development Block Grants. Councilman Alan J. Gerson, above, one of the plan's supporters, said that too much aid had gone to businesses with revenues of more than $1 million. Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid Urged for Small Businesses

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid Urged for Small Businesses

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: The Jan. 11 deadline for victims of the World Trade Center attack to apply for federal assistance has been extended to March 11, state and federal officials said yesterday. Under the program, disaster victims are eligible for crisis counseling, and those whose homes or belongings were lost or damaged, as well as business owners whose businesses were harmed, are eligible for low-interest loans or grants. Those seeking assistance should call the Federal Emergency Management Agency, (800) 462-9029, or check the Web site at www.fema.gov.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Disaster Aid Deadline Is Extended

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Disaster Aid Deadline Is Extended

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, a nonprofit group that supports arts organizations, has received a $5 million grant from the September 11th Fund that will be used to finance dozens of arts groups in Lower Manhattan over the next three years, the council announced yesterday. Starting in January, nonprofit organizations in Lower Manhattan or sponsoring activities there can apply for the grants, which will range from $5,000 to $250,000, said Tom Healy, president of the council. The money is meant to help arts groups with marketing, programming and capital expenses, he said.

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Congress on Thursday extended the Liberty Bond program, which the federal government enacted in the wake of the 9/11 terror attack to help rebuild Lower Manhattan, according to Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Charles E. Schumer. The program -- which allows the city and state to sell bonds that are exempt from federal taxes -- was set to expire at the end of this year. The action taken on Thursday night extends the program until the end of 2009. The program, as it was originally structured, allowed the city and state to sell $8 billion in bonds that were exempt from federal taxes. The bonds were to be used to rebuild businesses affected by the attack.

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Condé Nast Publications, whose stable of magazines chronicles the American zeitgeist as meticulously as any anthropologist, has reached an agreement to lease one million square feet at 1 World Trade Center, giving ground zero a much-needed corporate anchor with a proven ability to attract other businesses. The company signaled its interest in moving to 1 World Trade Center several months ago. But that was just the beginning of a marathon courtship befitting one of the country's most influential buildings and one of its trend-setting media empires, which went far beyond the typical landlord-tenant transaction.

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: The state and city will receive $250 million from the federal government to help pay the pensions of police officers and firefighters killed in the attack on the World Trade Center, Gov. George E. Pataki and federal officials said yesterday. The grants from the Federal Emergency Management Agency will cover the unforeseen increases in contributions to the pension system. The state and city had to pay the increases to cover benefits for the families of 343 firefighters and 23 police officers who died in the attack. The funds are part of about $8.8 billion in FEMA grants already pledged to the city and state, state officials said. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pension Aid Received

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pension Aid Received

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who is also chairman of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, told the foundation's board yesterday that the foundation had raised $253.8 million toward its $300 million goal. Almost $52 million, about one-fifth of the total raised so far, has been pledged in the last six weeks. A spokeswoman for the foundation declined to identify any of the new contributors. The memorial is expected to cost more than $500 million. DAVID W. DUNLAP

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: $253 Million For 9/11 Memorial

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: $253 Million For 9/11 Memorial

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has named Avi Schick the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which is overseeing the rebuilding at ground zero, and has named David Emil the corporation's president. Mr. Schick is president of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's economic development agency, and was a deputy attorney general under Mr. Spitzer. Mr. Emil owned Windows on the World, the restaurant on top of the World Trade Center. Mr. Schick, whose salary in the state job is $213,000, will not be further compensated; Mr. Emil's annual salary will be $185,000. DANNY HAKIM

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Chairman For Development Corporation

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Chairman For Development Corporation

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: FOUR years after Sept. 11, small businesses in Lower Manhattan have advice for their counterparts struggling to recover from Hurricane Katrina: hang tough but act fast. If you have insurance, for starters, pursue your claims vigorously. Look to private sources of help as well as the government. Band together when seeking relief. Most critically, act as fast as you can.

headline.main: Words of Advice From Companies Upended by 9/11

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Words of Advice From Companies Upended by 9/11

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Even by the standards of New York City, one of the earliest settlements in North America, 282 years is a long time. That is how long the Collegiate Church Corporation has owned the land where the Corbin Building sits at 11 John Street and Broadway in Lower Manhattan. But on Friday, the land and the building will be taken by eminent domain (along with three other buildings owned by the church) for the new Fulton Street Transit Center. Originally all four buildings were to be demolished, but after a community tussle, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority agreed to incorporate the basement and first floor of the Corbin Building, built in 1888-89, into the design of the station and to leave the rest of the edifice intact.

headline.main: Pressing a Claim for Dutch History

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Pressing a Claim for Dutch History

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street will not begin this month, as had been anticipated, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation said yesterday. On Monday, the federal Environmental Protection Agency raised questions about the proposed handling of waste materials containing polychlorinated biphenyls and cadmium in the heavily contaminated 41-story tower opposite ground zero. The corporation hopes to begin demolition later this summer, a spokesman said. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Razing Postponed

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deutsche Bank Razing Postponed

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: A Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to stealing from a federal fund established to help businesses recover after Sept. 11, prosecutors said. The man, Chang Sheng Yu, was arrested last October and charged with obtaining $118,000 from a fund under the aegis of the Empire State Development Corporation by submitting fabricated business records, including a doctored rental agreement, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Yu pleaded guilty to wire fraud, prosecutors said.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Disaster Fund Fraud

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Disaster Fund Fraud

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Julie Menin, a director of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation and the chairwoman of Community Board 1 in Lower Manhattan, objected publicly yesterday to an announcement that the foundation would not solicit any more money until it had a clearer idea of the cost and design of the memorial and museum. Writing to Thomas S. Johnson, the chairman of the foundation's executive committee, Ms. Menin said, ''By suspending fund-raising (and more pointedly by suspending it without a board vote), more doubt and turmoil has been created.'' She called for a vote at the next board meeting. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dissent In Memorial Foundation

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Larry Davis, owner of DCM Erectors Inc., is expected to be charged with evading requirements on hiring subcontractors, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline.main: World Trade Center Contractor Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry Into Misuse of Funds
headline.print_headline: Trade Center Contractor Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry Into Misuse of Funds

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: World Trade Center Contractor Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry Into Misuse of Funds

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Residents of Lower Manhattan have until Saturday to apply for up to $14,500 in grants through a federal program meant to increase the residential population of downtown and help the area recover from the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation is administering the $306 million program, which offers grants to residents of three zones in Lower Manhattan. Most of the grants require two years' residency. Details are available at the development corporation's Web site, www.renewnyc.com, or by calling (866) 736-3969. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deadline For Grants

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deadline For Grants

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Aon Corporation, which lost 176 employees in the World Trade Center attack, celebrated the opening of its Lower Manhattan office at 199 Water Street yesterday, where 700 people will work. Aon, a large insurance company, had 1,151 workers in 2 World Trade Center, according to a New York State Web site, which noted that Aon would receive $15 million in city and state tax benefits over 15 years for staying in Lower Manhattan. ''It's a remarkable commitment to Lower Manhattan,'' Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding, said in an interview last night. ''It sends a critical signal to the rest of the business world that Manhattan's coming back, but it also says something really meaningful about the character of that company.'' Tina Kelley (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aon Opens Office In Lower Manhattan

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aon Opens Office In Lower Manhattan

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Local elected officials and community groups demanded yesterday that the Federal Emergency Management Agency extend a housing assistance program that is to expire on Friday. The FEMA program, started shortly after the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks, has paid almost $100 million to nearly 11,000 applicants who lived or worked in Manhattan and have faced eviction or foreclosure. But, the officials said, the deadline should be extended, partly because of New York's continuing economic problems, and partly because the program has not done enough to reach out to potential applicants throughout the metropolitan area. The officials included Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Manhattan Democrat; William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller; and the Rev. Thomas W. Goodhue, executive director of the Long Island Council of Churches. David W. Chen (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Extended Federal Aid Urged

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Extended Federal Aid Urged

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: The State Labor Department has obtained $25 million in emergency federal aid to provide temporary jobs for those who are out of work because of the attack on the World Trade Center. Details are still being worked out, officials said, and it was unclear yesterday how many jobs would be created. But wages would be similar to those for Port Authority or Department of Sanitation jobs. Eligible workers will include those employed at the trade center, as well as at surrounding businesses ruined or closed by the attack, said Betsy McCormack, a department spokeswoman. The jobs will involve cleanup and other renovation duties. The department has 45 days to work out details, Ms. McCormack said, ''but we plan to move faster than that.''

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: AID For Trade Center Workers

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: AID For Trade Center Workers

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: Two groups announced yesterday that they would provide emergency loans of as much as $25,000 and other financial aid for nonprofit organizations hurt by the September 2001 terror attack. The groups, the United Way of New York City and Seedco, a community development organization, said they would provide $9.5 million in loans and technical assistance to nonprofit groups in Lower Manhattan and other neighborhoods financially hobbled by the attack. The groups said the aid, including longer-term loans of up to $500,000, would be provided at below-market interest rates over the next three years. Information is available at (212) 473-0255. David W. Chen (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Aid For Nonprofit Groups

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Aid For Nonprofit Groups

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: The United States Postal Service offers mail-forwarding to make it easier for people who move from one residence to another. It turns out that a change-of-address form is also handy in tracking down fraud. There are, apparently, lots of people who committed to living in Lower Manhattan for two years to receive as much as $12,000 in grant money. The federally financed grants were offered to help attract people downtown after the World Trade Center disaster.

headline.main: Address-Change Forms May Help Track Fraud

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Address-Change Forms May Help Track Fraud

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: A Congressional study made public yesterday gave ammunition to critics and supporters of the major government aid program for small businesses hurt as a result of Sept. 11. As the state and city agencies that run the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program have contended, the program did not overlook the smallest businesses. The study found that about 75 percent of the businesses that received funds had fewer than 10 employees. But as critics have argued, the study by the General Accounting Office also found that the program did not pay ''a substantial portion'' of the losses of most of the businesses in the program. A recent rule change should reduce shortfalls in some cases, the study said. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Assessment Of Small-Business 9/11 Aid

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Assessment Of Small-Business 9/11 Aid

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: The city has announced an aid program to reduce by up to 15 percent the electric bills for nonretail small businesses in Lower Manhattan. The program, created with Consolidated Edison, covers the next three years. It will apply to businesses from Houston Street to the Battery that meet particular electricity-use requirements and that have qualified for aid under either of two other programs, the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program and the Small Firm Attraction and Retention Grant program. The city's Economic Development Corporation said it would soon notify about 2,300 businesses that it believes are qualified. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid For Small Businesses

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid For Small Businesses

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.lead_paragraph: The president of the agency overseeing the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan warned yesterday that real estate and other business executives were in danger of not being heard. ''You're the people with the most knowledge about what would help,'' Louis R. Tomson, president of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said in a speech sponsored by Commercial Property News. He said discussions of the future of Lower Manhattan were in danger of being dominated by advocates like family members of Sept. 11 victims and area residents. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Speak Up, Executives Are Urged

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Speak Up, Executives Are Urged

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has admonished Attorney General John Ashcroft for violating a court order by making remarks about defendants in the nation's first major terror trial after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. The judge, Gerald E. Rosen of Federal District Court, said in an opinion released Tuesday that Mr. Ashcroft's statements could have compromised the defendants' rights to a fair trial but that the violations did not warrant contempt charges or require Mr. Ashcroft to appear in court to explain himself.

headline.main: Ashcroft Is Rebuked For Terror Remarks

Ashcroft Justice Department.mainheadline: Ashcroft Is Rebuked For Terror Remarks

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: In new antiterrorism precautions, the Department of Public Safety has asked stores that sell used clothing to remove badges and military insignia from military or law enforcement uniforms. The department also asked dry cleaners to require identification from customers picking up uniforms to keep impostors from using them to enter restricted areas. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

Ashcroft Justice Department.mainheadline: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: State Says Used Uniforms Should Lose Badges

Ashcroft Justice Department.mainheadline: Miles of Remembrance

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department wants to talk terrorism with 5,000 Middle Eastern men, but not in a confrontational way. ''We're being as kind and fair and gentle as we can,'' Attorney General John Aschcroft said on Tuesday.

Ashcroft Justice Department.mainheadline: Hope You Can Come!

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Marriott International has agreed to pay $115,000 and apologize for telling an Arab-American group in the hours after Sept. 11 that it could not hold its annual meeting at a company hotel in Des Moines, the Justice Department said. Officials said the hotel violated civil rights law by rescinding an offer to be host for the Midwest Federation of American Syrian-Lebanese Clubs. Marriott expressed regret over the incident but denied that it had intended to discriminate.

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Marriott Pays For Rejecting Arab Group

Ashcroft Justice Department.mainheadline: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Marriott Pays For Rejecting Arab Group

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The New York City Law Department has established a new World Trade Center unit to handle more than 1,560 tort claims seeking about $9 billion relating to the Sept. 11 attack. The specialized unit will consist of 25 full-time litigators, about half of whom already work for the Law Department. The rest will be drawn from lawyers in the private sector.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Law Department Sets Up 9/11 Tort Unit

Ashcroft Justice Department.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Law Department Sets Up 9/11 Tort Unit

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: A state appellate court ruled last week that the federal government can keep the names of detainees being held in custody a secret. Since Sept. 11 more than 1,100 detainees have been held nationally, many of them in Hudson and Passaic County jails, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The ruling said that the release of detainees' names could compromise investigations and public safety. Civil liberties advocates wanted the names released to monitor detainees' treatment in custody and to ensure adequate legal representation. A representative of the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union said the group planned to appeal the ruling to the State Supreme Court. John Holl

headline.main: WITHHOLDING DETAINEES' NAMES

Ashcroft Justice Department.mainheadline: WITHHOLDING DETAINEES' NAMES

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union lost a round yesterday in its effort to learn the names of foreigners who were arrested after Sept. 11 and detained in New Jersey jails. The New Jersey Supreme Court denied the group's appeal of a June appellate court ruling that said the federal government could pre-empt the state's right-to-know laws in the interest of national security. A.C.L.U. officials said they were considering an appeal to the United States Supreme Court. The Justice Department issued a statement saying that disclosing the detainees' names ''could provide terrorists a road map of the department's investigations.'' Susan Sachs (NYT)

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: A philanthropic group founded by the billionaire George Soros will award grants to groups seeking to protect the rights of Arab and other immigrant groups in the wave of anti-Arab feeling since the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The Soros group, the Open Society Institute, will give $2.5 million to 29 nonprofit organizations nationwide. The largest grant, $350,000, will go to the Tides Foundation for its fund for Arab, Muslim, Sikh and South Asian organizations responding to ''erosions of civil liberties and rights.'' Unlike other Soros philanthropies that promote democracy internationally, the Open Society said its mission was to correct what it sees as deficiencies in American democracy. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Even a case-by-case process of determining whether immigration hearings for post-Sept. 11 detainees should be kept secret could jeopardize the terrorism investigation, lawyers for the federal government argued today as they battled a lawsuit over whether to open the hearings to the press. The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey sued the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Federal District Court here in March on behalf of several New Jersey newspapers, seeking to overturn a blanket order that hearings for all so-called special interest cases be held in secret. The order was issued Sept. 21 by the nation's top immigration judge, Michael J. Creppy. It involves an unknown number of mainly Arab immigrants who were detained -- many of them in New Jersey jails -- after Sept. 11.

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The Immigration and Naturalization Service changed its policy last week and agreed to allow advocacy groups to visit foreign nationals held in the Hudson and Passaic County jails since Sept. 11. The service will allow such groups as the American Civil Liberties Union and the American Friends Service Committee to help detainees with legal questions and to provide representation. There are 460 aliens held nationwide since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, according to the I.N.S., though how many are in New Jersey is not known. John Holl

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: A New Jersey judge ruled yesterday that the Hudson and Passaic County jails should turn over the names and incarceration dates of immigration detainees held there under contract with the federal government in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The ruling, which the government plans to appeal, stems from a lawsuit filed in January by the American Civil Liberties of New Jersey in State Superior Court, after the government began detaining immigrants anonymously. A similar suit against the government is pending in federal court, but the New Jersey group sued the jails directly under state laws. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

It did not admit that it broke federal antidiscrimination laws.

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The hour is upon American banking regulators. They have been handed 2,000-plus pages of new law in the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act that must be transformed into workable rules and procedures and then put into effect to fulfill the legislation's promise to make the financial system safer. But there is a problem: many of the watchdogs charged with the task face leadership vacuums. This could spell trouble. Without strong chieftains to fight them, special interests may gain the edge in the all-important rule-writing taking place. The risk is that certain provisions will be watered down in practice, or that one segment of the industry will benefit at the expense of another. Without directors given clear power by the president, and ideally the stamp of Congressional approval, it's easier for these regulatory agencies to be captured.

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan -- Two new reports addressing human rights issues in Afghanistan have raised questions about how NATO troops are conducting the war. Both reports center on a question that has vexed international forces since the war began: How can the military be sure it has killed, detained or made deals with the right people? A report by the Afghanistan Analysts Network challenges the accuracy of American intelligence used in what are known as targeted killings, and makes a case study of the killing of an alleged Qaeda-affiliated operative in Takhar Province who was attacked by NATO jets as he traveled in a convoy through a rural area. The report offers evidence that NATO forces got the wrong man and that the insurgent commander they were seeking is alive in Pakistan -- an interview with him is included in the report. [The public television program Frontline also addressed the case in this segment of its program ''Kill/Capture.'']

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: Families of victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks cannot view hundreds of thousands of nonpublic documents used in the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, an appeals court said, overturning a lower court's order. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, said the families were not entitled to view documents that were given to Mr. Moussaoui's lawyers to aid his defense but were not made public. Mr. Moussaoui, 38, is the only person charged in the United States in connection with the attacks.

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that senior federal officials would have to answer questions under oath in a lawsuit accusing them of personally conspiring to violate the rights of Muslim immigrants held in a federal detention center in Brooklyn after 9/11. The ruling, by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan, upholds most of an earlier decision by a federal judge in Brooklyn. The officials, including former Attorney General John Ashcroft and Robert Mueller, the head of the F.B.I., had asked for dismissal of the lawsuit, by Javaid Iqbal, a Pakistani immigrant, arguing in part that the government was entitled to take actions that might not have been lawful before 9/11. Although acknowledging some forms of government action in emergencies may exceed normal constitutional limits, Judge Jon O. Newman rejected the officials' contention, saying some protections against some of the violations claimed, such as needlessly harsh confinement and ethnic discrimination, do not vary with surrounding circumstances. ''The strength of our system of constitutional rights derives from the steadfast protection of those rights in both normal and unusual times,'' he wrote. NINA BERNSTEIN

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: A trial to determine whether the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey should be held liable in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing could begin as early as April, lawyers and a State Supreme Court judge said yesterday. At a meeting with Justice Stanley L. Sklar, lawyers for the Port Authority and for plaintiffs in a lawsuit said they expected the trial to take about three weeks. More than 100 people and companies have filed suit against the authority, claiming it should be liable because it was warned to close its underground parking garage to the public. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: IF it is true that, as an old Chinese proverb says, crisis equals opportunity, then the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, have yielded a bonanza. Billions of dollars have been poured into homeland security by the cabinet department of the same name, the Pentagon, law enforcement and corporations. With so much money available, more than 500 exhibitors at a security conference here last week were out to reap their share. The most futuristic tools and weapons for tracking and catching potential terrorists were presumably not on display. But if the goods and services hawked at the conference are any measure, the urgent quest for greater security has stirred creative juices among inventors -- and marketers.

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: A lawsuit by the Coalition of 9/11 Families seeking to compel the preservation of the concrete floor slab where 1 World Trade Center stood has been dismissed by Justice Shirley Werner Kornreich of the State Supreme Court. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the lead defendant, received the decision yesterday. Justice Kornreich said it had been known since April 2004 that the slab would not be subject to historical preservation review, meaning that the lawsuit was filed too late. She wrote that the historical review process ''has been met'' restored text here and that the development corporation had acted in ''a commendable and sensitive manner.'' DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: A judge has ordered the Justice Department to produce White House memorandums that provide the legal basis for the Bush administration's post-Sept. 11 warrantless wiretapping program. It requires the department to produce the memorandums by the White House legal counsel's office by Nov. 17. Brinkema of Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., said she would delay her decision until prosecutors and defense lawyers had offered their views on what sanctions she should impose for the government's refusal to grant Mr. Moussaoui the chance to interview a captured member of Al Qaeda. Ashcroft Justice Department.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department renewed its warning that the case against Zacarias Moussaoui might have to be dismissed if the trial judge continued to insist that Mr. Moussaoui have access to captured terrorists of Al Qaeda for questioning. The department acknowledged that its refusal to comply with the order ''obligates the court now to dismiss the indictment unless the court finds that the interests of justice can be served by another action.'' The department made a similar statement earlier this year when Judge Brinkema ordered that Mr. Moussaoui be given access to another captured Qaeda member. Bush White House.lead_paragraph: Bush administration officials on Thursday played down the significance of an Iraqi effort to avert war by holding last-ditch negotiations with Washington through a back channel in the weeks before the war began in March. Top Iraqi intelligence officials tried to open a secret communications channel with the administration, according to intermediaries and others familiar with the channel. The Iraqis told a Lebanese-American businessman that they no longer had any illicit weapons, that Baghdad would allow American experts to conduct an independent search and that Saddam Hussein would turn over a suspect in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing.

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: President Bush will travel to New York, Pennsylvania and the Pentagon on Sept. 11 to commemorate the anniversary of the terrorist attacks, the White House announced today. Bush White House.lead_paragraph: President Bush proclaimed today that Sept. 11, 2002, would be called Patriot Day, and he ordered all federal facilities to fly the American flag at half-staff on the anniversary of the terrorist attacks. ''Those whom we lost last Sept. 11 will forever hold a cherished place in our hearts and in the history of our nation,'' Mr. Bush said. Bush White House.lead_paragraph: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday defended the Bush administration's handling of intelligence information before Sept. 11, saying he did not believe the federal government could have anticipated the terrorist attacks. Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, suggested that the Clinton administration should also be accountable given that much of the intelligence now coming under scrutiny was collected during its watch. ''Remember, the Bush administration when this attack took place was a very new administration, and they had just inherited the intelligence apparatus put in place by the Clinton administration, so when you look at this you're going to have look at both,'' Giuliani told The Associated Press after a speech to graduates of Georgetown Law School in Washington.

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: The moment she saw him, Judy Cox knew her son was dead. It was an October morning in 2008, and she had just stepped out the door to run an errand when she found him lying faceup in the driveway, ghost white, covered in purple splotches. He wasn't breathing, and when she couldn't revive him, she ran screaming into the house where her husband, Wayne, was still asleep. ''Chris is dead,'' she cried. ''Call 911!'' Wayne jumped out of bed and raced down to the driveway, where he knelt over his son's limp frame and tried frantically to elicit a breath or a heartbeat. As he pumped Chris's chest and scooped out the vomit that had collected in his mouth, Judy ran to the kitchen and steadied herself long enough to call for an ambulance.

King, a Republican from Nassau County, introduced a resolution yesterday to designate Sept. 11 as a national day of ''service, charity and compassion.'' The House resolution does not seek to create a federal holiday, but rather asks President Bush to issue a proclamation to support voluntary acts as a gesture to the people who aided in the crisis. Bush White House.lead_paragraph: Laughter filled the room Wednesday night at the annual dinner for radio and television correspondents when President Bush displayed a photograph showing him down on his hands and knees looking under furniture in his office and saying, ''Those weapons of mass destruction have got to be somewhere!'' This morning the joke did not seem quite so funny. CNN, which showed a clip of the event, was getting e-mail messages from unhappy viewers. Foreign newspapers were reacting with outrage. And the White House was busy defending the joke that President Bush delivered as he put on a slide show, called the ''White House Election-Year Album,'' at the Radio and Television Correspondents' Association's 60th annual dinner.

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: A White House spokesman said last night that President Bush might meet tomorrow with a New York college student whose father recently died from an illness that may have been linked to his work at ground zero. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton asked the president yesterday to meet with Ceasar Borja Jr., the son of Cesar Borja, 52, a police officer who died last week of pulmonary fibrosis, a type of chronic lung disorder that involves scarring of the tissue between the air sacs. The president is scheduled to visit New York to give a speech to the Association for a Better New York. Mr. Borja died on Jan. 23, hours before his 21-year-old son attended President Bush's State of the Union address. The next day, the son publicly asked for a meeting with the president to tell him about the health problems of ground zero workers.

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: To replace Michael D. Brown at the head of the nation's emergency agency, President Bush reached out to a manager who, at least on paper, is different in some important ways. R. David Paulison, chosen on Monday to take temporary control of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, started out in the Miami-Dade Fire Rescue Department at the age of 19, rising through the ranks over three decades to become chief.

Card Jr., with another longtime loyalist on Tuesday, a step unlikely to satisfy calls within his own party for fresh thinking to address the administration's troubles. In turning to Joshua B. Bolten, his budget director, as the new chief of staff, the president stayed within what one close associate called a ''circle of comfort'' and what Mr. Bush's critics consider a closed world that brooks little doubt or dissent.

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: Less than three months after Hurricane Katrina ravaged New Orleans, relief legislation remains dormant in Washington and despair is growing among officials here who fear that Congress and the Bush administration are losing interest in their plight. As evidence, the state and local officials cite an array of stalled bills and policy changes they say are crucial to rebuilding the city and persuading some of its hundreds of thousands of evacuated residents to return, including measures to finance long-term hurricane protection, revive small businesses and compensate the uninsured.

headline.main: Louisiana Sees Faded Urgency In Relief Effort

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: The winners of White House Redux, the competition sponsored by Storefront for Art and Architecture and by Control Group to design a new residence for the president of the United States, were announced on Monday. The competition, started in January, called on designers around the world to answer the question: ''What if the White House, the ultimate architectural symbol of political power, were to be designed today?'' Five hundred projects were submitted, and the winners were selected by a jury of designers and critics on May 29 at World Trade Center Tower 7. The winning entry, titled ''Revenge of the Lawn'' designed by J. P. Maruszczak, assisted by Roger Connah with Ryan Manning, will be featured in an exhibition at Storefront for Art and Architecture in New York from Oct. 2 through Nov. 8, along with almost 200 of the other entries. The original White House design, by James Hoban, was the result of a competition held in 1792.

headline.main: Maybe An A-Frame With a Golf Course?

Bush White House.mainheadline: Maybe An A-Frame With a Golf Course?

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: SCHENECTADY, N.Y. -- President Obama, sending another strong signal that he intends to make the White House more business-friendly, named a high-profile corporate executive on Friday as his chief outside economic adviser, continuing his efforts to show more focus on job creation and reclaim the political center. Here in the birthplace of General Electric, Mr. Obama introduced the new appointee, Jeffrey R. Immelt, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, who will serve as chairman of his outside panel of economic advisers. Mr. Immelt succeeds Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, who is stepping down.

headline.main: Obama Names G.E. Chairman To Fiscal Panel

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: A judge has ordered the Justice Department to produce White House memorandums that provide the legal basis for the Bush administration's post-Sept. 11 warrantless wiretapping program. The judge, Henry H. Kennedy Jr. of Federal District Court in Washington, signed the order Friday. It requires the department to produce the memorandums by the White House legal counsel's office by Nov. 17. He said he would review the memorandums to determine whether any information could be released publicly without violating attorney-client privilege.

headline.main: Judge Seeks Wiretapping Documents

Bush White House.mainheadline: Judge Seeks Wiretapping Documents

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: President Bush will lay a wreath at ground zero on the eve of Sept. 11, his first stop in a three-state trip to observe the fifth anniversary of the terrorist attacks. The White House said Friday that the president and Laura Bush planned to travel to New York City on Sept. 10 for the wreath-laying ceremony that afternoon. They will then attend a prayer service at St. Paul's Chapel, next to the World Trade Center site.

headline.main: Bush to Visit All Three Sites of 9/11 Attacks

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: Ayatollah Muhammad Yazdi, a member of Iran's conservative Guardian Council, lashed out at statements in President Bush's State of the Union address that said Iran was violating human rights and trying to develop weapons of mass destruction. Ayatollah Yazdi rejected the president's claims and responded with his own: that White House policies after the Sept. 11 terror attacks violated the rights of Muslim immigrants. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: President Bush said today that he had seen no evidence that Saddam Hussein was involved in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, as the White House tried to correct an assertion that Vice President Dick Cheney left extremely murky on Sunday. Mr. Cheney, on ''Meet the Press'' on NBC-TV, was asked about polls that showed that a majority of Americans believed that Mr. Hussein had been involved in the attacks.

headline.main: Bush Reports No Evidence of Hussein Tie to 9/11

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: The city will review a report by the inspector general of Environmental Protection Agency that says the White House sought to play down possible health risks posed by World Trade Center dust and debris, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Mr. Bloomberg said he would send the report to Christopher O. Ward, commissioner of the city's Department of Environmental Protection. The mayor, a Republican, said he had not seen the report by Nikki L. Tinsley, the inspector general, but added that he trusts President Bush. The report, released Thursday, said that the White House encouraged the agency to play down air-quality problems caused by the destruction of the trade center.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City To Review 9/11 E.P.A. Report

Bush White House.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City To Review 9/11 E.P.A. Report

Bush White House.lead_paragraph: The former governor Thomas H. Kean, now president of Drew University, was tapped by President Bush last week to head a national commission to investigate the terrorist attacks. Mr. Kean replaces Henry A. Kissinger, who withdrew after questions were raised about possible conflicts of interest with his business clients. Mr. Kean plans to keep his job at Drew while leading the commission. Jeremy Pearce

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: The federal authorities in Minnesota have arrested a man who is accused of having ties to the terrorist network of Al Qaeda and to Zacarias Moussaoui, law enforcement officials said on Wednesday. The officials said that the jailed suspect had been under surveillance for some time and that he was arrested on Tuesday by members of an F.B.I. terrorism task force in Minnesota, where Mr. Moussaoui was arrested a month before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline.main: Jailed Man Accused of Having Ties to Al Qaeda

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: Jailed Man Accused of Having Ties to Al Qaeda

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A 33-year-old immigrant who has emerged as a key suspect in the investigation of the Sept. 11 terror attacks received $15,000 in unexplained money transfers from Germany in August, say German investigators who are trying to determine if the plot had its origins in their country. American law enforcement officials say they suspect that the man, Zacarias Moussaoui, a French citizen of Moroccan descent, was meant to be the 20th hijacker in the attacks.

headline.main: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE 20th SUSPECT; Man Held in U.S. Was Wired 2 Large Sums From Germany

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE 20th SUSPECT; Man Held in U.S. Was Wired 2 Large Sums From Germany

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Federal investigators say that they now believe a Yemeni citizen may have been meant to be the 20th hijacker on Sept. 11 but that he failed to get into the United States. The man, Ramzi Omar, also known as Ramsi Binalshibh, is the subject of a worldwide manhunt. The suspected ringleader of the hijackers, Mohamed Atta, tried three times to get Mr. Omar into the United States, The Associated Press reported.

headline.main: New Theory on a 20th Hijacker Is Offered

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: New Theory on a 20th Hijacker Is Offered

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Monday upheld the conviction of the only person who has been tried in a United States court on charges of involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline.main: Court Upholds Conviction in 9/11 Case
headline.print_headline: Court Upholds Conviction in 9/11 Case

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: Court Upholds Conviction in 9/11 Case

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A federal judge ordered prosecutors today to provide her with a copy of the cockpit voice recording from United Airlines Flight 93, on which passengers tried to wrest control from hijackers on Sept. 11, so she could determine whether the tape could be used at the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui and possibly be released to the public. Prosecutors had previously announced to the judge, Leonie M. Brinkema of Federal District Court, that they intended to play the Flight 93 tape, along with a cockpit tape from a private plane that was flying nearby, for the jury at the trial of Mr. Moussaoui, 34, who is accused of conspiring in the terrorist attacks.

headline.main: Judge Seeks Copy of Crash Tape

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: Judge Seeks Copy of Crash Tape

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: After resisting for months, the Malaysian government has agreed to allow the F.B.I. to question a man who Malaysian and American authorities say was the host for a meeting in January 2000 of plotters for Al Qaeda. The meeting was believed to have included Khalid al-Midhar and Nawaq Alhazmi, who were among the Sept. 11 hijackers.

headline.main: F.B.I. to Question Suspect in Malaysia

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: F.B.I. to Question Suspect in Malaysia

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in the Sept. 11 attacks, has asked the judge in the case to allow him to meet with reporters. In a handwritten motion, one of several made public today, Mr. Moussaoui, who is accused of being the 20th hijacker, added that he would expect financial compensation from any news organization given an interview, to help pay for his defense.

headline.main: Man Charged in Terror Seeks to Meet Reporters

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: Man Charged in Terror Seeks to Meet Reporters

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui is so isolated in jail that he is unable to defend himself against charges that he aided the Sept. 11 attackers, his lawyer said today. ''With his life hanging in the balance,'' it is essential that Mr. Moussaoui have a computer work station and that officials ease his conditions of confinement, the lawyer, Frank Dunham Jr., said in a motion filed in Federal District Court.

headline.main: Moussaoui Seen As Too Isolated

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: Moussaoui Seen As Too Isolated

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person arrested so far in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, has met with a court-appointed psychiatrist who is helping a federal judge determine if he is mentally competent to defend himself at trial, according to court papers made public today. The conclusions of the psychiatric report, which was filed with the Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., outside Washington, were not revealed. But the court papers do reveal that Mr. Moussaoui backed down from his refusal to meet with the psychiatrist, Raymond Patterson, a former administrator of St. Elizabeth's Hospital for the criminally insane in Washington.

headline.main: Defendant Yields on Refusal to See Psychiatrist
headline.kicker: TRACES OF TERROR: THE TERROR SUSPECT

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: Defendant Yields on Refusal to See Psychiatrist

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui, the first man to be indicted on charges involving the Sept. 11 attacks, is scheduled to be in court on Wednesday to enter a plea on charges of conspiring with Osama bin Laden and others to murder thousands of people. Mr. Moussaoui, 33, a French citizen of Moroccan descent, will be arraigned in Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., on charges set out in a Dec. 11 indictment. Judge Leonie M. Brinkema may set a date for the trial to begin.

headline.main: Plea Today in Terror Case

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: Plea Today in Terror Case

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in an American court with conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks, filed an appeal on Thursday of a recent ruling allowing prosecutors once again to seek the death penalty in the case, court records show. The filing seeks to have the ruling, made on April 22 by a three-judge federal appeals panel in Richmond, Va., reviewed by the full appeals court. It was placed under seal because of secrecy rules in the case, which involves a variety of classified information.

headline.main: Appeal by Sept. 11 Suspect

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: Appeal by Sept. 11 Suspect

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court affirmed on Monday that Zacarias Moussaoui may submit written questions to people held by the United States as enemy combatants to bolster his assertion that he was not involved in the Sept. 11 attacks. In its ruling, heavily censored for reasons attributed to national security, the court, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, said the statements could help in the defense of Mr. Moussaoui, the only person charged in an American court with conspiring in the attacks.

headline.main: Court Bolsters Terror Defendant On Questioning

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: Court Bolsters Terror Defendant On Questioning

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Families of victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks cannot view hundreds of thousands of nonpublic documents used in the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, an appeals court said, overturning a lower court's order. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, said the families were not entitled to view documents that were given to Mr. Moussaoui's lawyers to aid his defense but were not made public. Mr. Moussaoui, 38, is the only person charged in the United States in connection with the attacks.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Court Bars Families From Moussaoui Evidence

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Court Bars Families From Moussaoui Evidence

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Zacarias Moussaoui resumed his place in a federal courtroom here on Wednesday and sat quietly as lawyers questioned potential jurors after he apparently reversed course and agreed not to disrupt the proceedings. A day earlier, Judge Leonie M. Brinkema ejected Mr. Moussaoui from the courtroom after he refused to heed her warnings to defer to his court-appointed lawyers and stop making speeches about his case. She ruled that Mr. Moussaoui, the only person to face trial in the United States in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, would be able to observe the next few weeks of the proceedings only from a closed-circuit television hookup in a jail cell.

headline.main: Defendant In 9/11 Case Heeds Judge

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: Defendant In 9/11 Case Heeds Judge

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor on Monday asked a jury to sentence Zacarias Moussaoui to death, saying his willful decision to conceal his knowledge of the Sept. 11 terrorist plot when he was arrested weeks earlier made him responsible for the thousands of deaths that day. In response, a court-appointed lawyer for Mr. Moussaoui told jurors they could not order the execution of a man on no more than a supposition: that had he revealed his knowledge of Al Qaeda's interest in flying planes into public buildings, the federal authorities would have prevented the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline.main: Prosecutor Urges Death for Concealing Sept. 11 Plot

Zacarias Moussaoui.mainheadline: Prosecutor Urges Death for Concealing Sept. 11 Plot

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: Jury selection began yesterday in Federal District Court in the long-delayed trial of Osama Awadallah, a student from Jordan accused of lying to a grand jury investigating the Sept. 11 attack. A jury was chosen in May 2005, but Judge Shira A. Scheindlin sent the jurors home after the government brought a last-minute appeal seeking to have the case transferred to another judge. That appeal was rejected in January. Yesterday, the jurors were recalled and new ones added to create a pool of 35 for the final selection. The judge questioned the candidates to see if their views had been affected by news about the sentencing trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, who pleaded guilty to conspiring in the 9/11 attacks. Mr. Awadallah is not charged with any role in the attacks. JULIA PRESTON (NYT)

The court papers show that Mr. Moussaoui, acting as his own lawyer, questioned the witness, Faiz Bafana, in a videoconference last year, with federal prosecutors cross-examining Mr. Bafana.

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: The judge in the case of Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person facing trial in the United States in the Sept. 11 attacks, made it clear that she would not decide whether to dismiss the case or impose other sanctions on the Justice Department for at least next month. The judge, Leonie M. Brinkema of Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., said she would delay her decision until prosecutors and defense lawyers had offered their views on what sanctions she should impose for the government's refusal to grant Mr. Moussaoui the chance to interview a captured member of Al Qaeda. Philip Shenon (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: August Decision Seen In Moussaoui Case

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department renewed its warning that the case against Zacarias Moussaoui might have to be dismissed if the trial judge continued to insist that Mr. Moussaoui have access to captured terrorists of Al Qaeda for questioning. The department acknowledged that its refusal to comply with the order ''obligates the court now to dismiss the indictment unless the court finds that the interests of justice can be served by another action.'' The department made a similar statement earlier this year when Judge Brinkema ordered that Mr. Moussaoui be given access to another captured Qaeda member. Mr. Moussaoui, a French citizen,is charged with conspiring in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Philip Shenon (NYT)

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has ordered that the terrorist suspect Zacarias Moussaoui be given the opportunity to question two high-level operatives of Al Qaeda, including the man officials say masterminded the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001. The decision on Friday by Judge Leonie M. Brinkema of Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., promises to further complicate a government prosecution that has already become entangled by unexpected legal obstacles. Officials have been considering whether to move Mr. Moussaoui to a military tribunal rather than continuing to prosecute him in civil court, and Judge Brinkema's decision could increase the likelihood of such a move.

headline.main: New Ruling Favors Suspect In Terror Case

Zacarias Moussaoui.lead_paragraph: The German government has agreed to provide evidence against Zacarias Moussaoui, the only suspect in the Sept. 11 attacks facing trial in an American court, and France is expected to follow suit, administration officials said tonight. Before sharing information with prosecutors, each country sought assurances from American officials that they would not seek the death penalty for Mr. Moussaoui.

headline.main: Germany Agrees to Share Evidence Against 9/11 Defendant

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: American officials identified a Saudi man today as the highest ranking Al Qaeda official captured in Afghanistan and taken into American custody. Officials identified the man only as Abdul Aziz, an official with the Wafa Humanitarian Organization. They said he was now aboard the helicopter carrier Pelileu in the North Arabian Sea. The United States has alleged that Wafa, a Saudi-based Islamic charitable organization, has funneled money to Al Qaeda.

headline.main: Saudi Prisoner Called a Chief For Al Qaeda

Al Qaeda.mainheadline: Saudi Prisoner Called a Chief For Al Qaeda

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Family members of more than 900 victims of the Sept. 11 attacks filed a lawsuit against three Saudi princes, seven internalional banks operating mainly in the Middle East, eight Islamic foundations and charities and the government of Sudan for allegedly funding Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda. The suit, in federal district court in Washington, is one of several expected in coming months against foreign governments and individuals who may have aided the terrorist network. The defendants named in the lawsuit include Mr. bin Laden and several family members, as well as three members of the Saudi royal family: Turki al Faisal al Saud, Sultan bin Abdul Aziz al Saud and Mohammed al Faisal al Saud.

Al Jazeera identified the reporter as Sami al-Hajj, a Sudanese, who it said was arrested in southern Afghanistan on Dec. 15.

headline.main: U.S. Holds Reporter, Arab Station Says

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: A senior agent for Al Qaeda with links to the group's former operations chief has been arrested in Morocco, goverment officials said today. The man, Abu Zubayr, was taken into custody last week, the officials said. He is believed to have been associated with Abu Zubaydah, Al Qaeda's former operations chief, who is being held by the United States. American officials said they were uncertain whether Abu Zubayr was involved in the planning of the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States.

headline.main: Morocco Detainee Linked to Qaeda

Al Qaeda.mainheadline: Morocco Detainee Linked to Qaeda

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: The Spanish police rounded up four more men suspected of belonging to Al Qaeda cells in Spain. In a pile of homemade videos taken from one of the suspects, the police found hours of what they described as surveillance tapes filmed in 1997 at the World Trade Center and other American landmarks. The tapes were taken at the Statue of Liberty, Disneyland and other sites, and were shot from various angles and distances, with an unusual interest in structures and access. Tim Golden

headline.main: July 14-20: FRONT LINES; SPANISH ROUNDUP

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: The Dutch police today detained four suspected members of an Algerian Islamic group believed to be linked to Osama bin Laden, according to prosecutors. The police in Spain re-arrested a man they said had helped finance Al Qaeda operations. And in Britain, a court dismissed the remaining charges against Lotfi Raissi, a British-based Algerian pilot originally accused by the United States of training the Sept. 11 hijackers.

headline.main: Dutch Detain 4; bin Laden Links Cited

Al Qaeda.mainheadline: Dutch Detain 4; bin Laden Links Cited

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: The Arab television station Al Jazeera said in a statement that it never aired an October interview with Osama bin Laden because it was conducted under duress and the questions were dictated to its correspondent. The statement was the latest Al Jazeera said CNN, which aired the interview on Thursday, had obtained the tape illegally. A CNN official denied that and said Al Jazeera should explain why it had never made the tape public.
