Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, said Al Qaeda followers in the United States and abroad remained committed to participating in terror attacks in the United States. Mr. Mueller, speaking at a hearing of the House Appropriations Committee on his bureau's budget, said counterterrorism officials had thwarted some attempted terrorist plots. ''But,'' he warned, ''the mere fact that there have been successes does not in any way, shape or form mean that we are confident that there will not be another attack.'' David Johnston (NYT)

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- An American aid expert being held hostage by Al Qaeda in Pakistan was shown making an emotional appeal to President Obama to negotiate for his release in a video released on Monday in what analysts described as a jihadist counter against the wave of publicity that marked the first anniversary of the death of Osama bin Laden. The hostage, Warren Weinstein, a 70-year-old development consultant who was kidnapped in the eastern city of Lahore in August, appeared in the video released on the Internet. Wearing traditional Pakistani clothes, he appealed to Mr. Obama to bow to his captors' demands.

headline.main: Kidnapped American Makes Appeal to Obama in Qaeda Video

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: A detainee at Guantánamo Bay who has been described as a financier of the Sept. 11 attacks said at a closed hearing that top operatives of Al Qaeda informed him of the impending attacks the night before they occurred, according to a transcript released yesterday. The detainee, Mustafa Ahmed al-Hawsawi, said he was told by Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who has been identified as a top Qaeda operative, ''that next night there would be an operation.'' In the transcript of the March 21 hearing, he said he also discussed the attack with Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who was quoted earlier this month as telling a similar closed hearing that he was the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks. WILLIAM GLABERSON

headline.main: National Briefing | Terrorism: Detainee Says He Was Told Of Sept. 11 Attacks

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Doubleday will publish a collection of the translated writings of Al Qaeda leaders next year and will donate profits from the book to charities that are aiding American victims of terrorism. The book, tentatively titled ''The Al Qaeda Reader,'' will consist of writings by Ayman al-Zawahiri, Al Qaeda's second in command, plus material attributed to Osama bin Laden. The material was discovered in the Library of Congress by Raymond Ibrahim, a Library of Congress specialist in Middle Eastern studies, who will translate the text. Stuart Applebaum, a spokesman for Random House Inc., Doubleday's parent, said the company had not yet determined which charities would receive profits from the book. Doubleday considers its use of the material to be ''fair use'' and therefore will not pay royalties, although it will make payments to the translator for the right to publish his work. EDWARD WYATT

headline.main: Arts, Briefly; Al Qaeda Anthology

Al Qaeda.mainheadline: Arts, Briefly; Al Qaeda Anthology

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: WHEN Victor Diaz was setting Mets rookie records for April with 10 runs batted in and 16 runs scored, it was as if Mike Cameron had disappeared. And in a way, he had. Cameron, who had been blueprinted as the Mets' right fielder after Carlos Beltran's takeover in center, was on the disabled list for most of the first five weeks of the season with tendinitis in his left wrist.

headline.main: A Bit Off-Center, Cameron Is Thriving in Right Field

Al Qaeda.mainheadline: A Bit Off-Center, Cameron Is Thriving in Right Field

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: ABOVE all else, John McMullen was a man of his word. If he said something, if he took a position on something, he could be counted on to stick to it. He did not go back on his word. The same cannot be said of many other owners I have encountered in baseball the past 35 years. John McMullen could be difficult. He could be irascible. But he possessed a remarkable personality trait. He had the capacity to like a person and have a close relationship with him even if they disagreed philosophically or for some other reason.

headline.main: Final Toast to an Owner Who Defined Integrity

Al Qaeda.mainheadline: Final Toast to an Owner Who Defined Integrity

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: While Nomar Garciaparra dressed in the visiting clubhouse at Shea Stadium yesterday, he slid his batting helmet over his head, as if he needed to protect himself from falling light fixtures. The Cubs would probably not have looked askance if Garciaparra had worn an entire coat of armor onto the field. Last night, Garciaparra played his first major league game since April 20, when he stumbled out of the batter's box at Busch Stadium in St. Louis and crumpled to the dirt, looking as if he had been shot in the hindquarters.

headline.main: A Rare Cubs Sighting: Garciaparra on the Field

Al Qaeda.mainheadline: A Rare Cubs Sighting: Garciaparra on the Field

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department renewed its warning that the case against Zacarias Moussaoui might have to be dismissed if the trial judge continued to insist that Mr. Moussaoui have access to captured terrorists of Al Qaeda for questioning. The department acknowledged that its refusal to comply with the order ''obligates the court now to dismiss the indictment unless the court finds that the interests of justice can be served by another action.'' The department made a similar statement earlier this year when Judge Brinkema ordered that Mr. Moussaoui be given access to another captured Qaeda member. Mr. Moussaoui, a French citizen,is charged with conspiring in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Philip Shenon (NYT)

Al Qaeda.lead_paragraph: Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, suspected of being a Qaeda terrorist, was captured in Pakistan in 2004, held in secret prisons run by the C.I.A. and then moved to the naval base at Guantánamo Bay. During about five years of detention, he says, he was confined in harsh conditions, abused during interrogation and denied a lawyer. Since the spring, Mr. Ghailani has also been a defendant in federal court in Manhattan, the first Guantánamo detainee to be moved to the civilian courts.

headline.main: Terrorism Trial May Point Way For 9/11 Cases

Al Qaeda.mainheadline: Terrorism Trial May Point Way For 9/11 Cases

Anthrax Scare.lead_paragraph: In response to the recent spate of anthrax threats, anxious citizens are demanding that doctors test them for the disease. But, unlike strep throat, there is no rapid screening test for anthrax. In Florida and New York, authorities have used nasal swabs to confirm exposure to the germ. But experts say swabs are not necessarily a reliable indicator of whether someone is actually sick.

headline.main: No Swift Anthrax Test

Anthrax Scare.lead_paragraph: About 32,000 people have taken antibiotics in the past month as a precaution against possible exposure to anthrax spores, federal health officials said today. About 5,000 of them have been advised to take the drugs for 60 days. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a detailed summary of the nation's response to anthrax outbreaks in Florida, New York, New Jersey and Washington.

headline.main: Use of Anthrax Fighters

Anthrax Scare.lead_paragraph: The first pieces of irradiated mail from the anthrax-tainted Hamilton postal center were delivered Saturday, the Postal Service said. Carl Walton, a spokesman for the Postal Service, said that about 1,000 pieces of the decontaminated mail were sent out. The irradiation might have harmed or ruined products including food, medicine, film, contact lenses and electronics. About 800,000 pieces of mail have gone undelivered since the Hamilton post office closed Oct. 18 because of anthrax contamination. The complex handled at least four tainted letters.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hamilton: Treated Mail Delivered

Anthrax Scare.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hamilton: Treated Mail Delivered

Anthrax Scare.lead_paragraph: A Texas laboratory worker who contracted skin anthrax last month probably got it because he was not wearing gloves when he handled vials of spores collected from last fall's mail attacks, the government said today. The worker handled the spores a day after cutting his jaw while shaving, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported. He then apparently touched his face and developed an anthrax sore on his jaw.

headline.main: New Case of Anthrax Is Tied to Bare Hands

Anthrax Scare.mainheadline: New Case of Anthrax Is Tied to Bare Hands

Anthrax Scare.lead_paragraph: A building at the Army Reserve Command headquarters in Fort McPherson on the south side of Atlanta was evacuated yesterday after a powder on a mailed package tested positive for anthrax, Army officials said. Six people in the mailroom were decontaminated after they were exposed to the package, a spokesman said. It was taken to the Centers for Disease Control for further tests. David Firestone (NYT)

headline.main: Briefly Noted; ANTHRAX EXPOSURE?

Anthrax Scare.lead_paragraph: The cost of the anthrax cleanup at the Hart Senate Office Building has reached $23 million, $2 million shy of the ceiling approved last year by Environmental Protection Agency, officials said. The figures were released by Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the ranking Republican on the Finance Committee, who had questioned whether the agency had spent the money properly.

headline.main: ANTHRAX

Anthrax Scare.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission received thousands of documents this month that were mailed as early as October and quarantined because of anthrax contamination at a Postal Service center in Washington. Mail routed through the Brentwood postal center was irradiated by outside contractors to kill anthrax spores after two Postal Service employees died from inhalation anthrax.

headline.main: Mail Delay at the S.E.C.

Anthrax Scare.lead_paragraph: The 15-story Postal Service building at 90 Church Street, which has been closed since the adjacent World Trade Center collapsed three years ago, is to reopen on Monday, postal officials said yesterday. The building was contaminated with asbestos, mercury, mold and other substances and had to be gutted and have 800 of its windows replaced. The ornate marble lobby also had to be restored. ''We are excited to return this postal facility to the community,'' Postmaster Vinnie Malloy said.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Post Office Reopening

Anthrax Scare.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Post Office Reopening

Anthrax Scare.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- A review of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's scientific work on the investigation of the anthrax letters of 2001 concludes that the bureau overstated the strength of genetic analysis linking the mailed anthrax to a supply kept by Bruce E. Ivins, the Army microbiologist whom the investigators blamed for the attacks. The review, by a panel convened by the National Academy of Sciences, says the genetic analysis ''did not definitively demonstrate'' that the mailed anthrax spores were grown from a sample taken from Dr. Ivins's laboratory at Fort Detrick in Frederick, Md. It does add, however, that the evidence is ''consistent with and supports an association'' between Dr. Ivins's flask and the attack anthrax.

headline.main: Expert Panel Is Critical of F.B.I. Work in Investigating Anthrax Letters

Anthrax Scare.mainheadline: Expert Panel Is Critical of F.B.I. Work in Investigating Anthrax Letters

Anthrax Scare.lead_paragraph: The Postal Service should protect New Jersey postal workers in case of another anthrax attack, union leaders said. ''There's been nothing put in place to safeguard us or the public,'' said Bill Lewis, president of the Trenton area branch of the American Postal Workers Union, A.F.L.-C.I.O. Mr. Lewis spoke on Saturday during a union rally at the mail center in Hamilton, which processed four tainted letters and has been closed since the letters were traced there last October. Diane Todd, a spokeswoman for the Postal Service, has said that the postal service hopes to install equipment at the center that would be able to detect anthrax and other germs.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hamilton: Union Criticizes Post Office

Anthrax Scare.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hamilton: Union Criticizes Post Office

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: John F. Welch Jr., the retired chairman of General Electric known for his management skills and, more recently, his best seller, ''Jack: Straight From the Gut,'' is giving the United States government low marks for the way it has managed homeland security since the Sept. 11 attacks. Speaking to the American Magazine Conference last week in New York, Mr. Welch said, ''The homeland security idea is a good idea, but it isn't going to go anywhere, in my own personal opinion.''

headline.main: Private Sector; From His Gut to Bush's Ear

Homeland Security.mainheadline: Private Sector; From His Gut to Bush's Ear

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, became the latest official yesterday to visit ground zero with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in the months since the terrorist attack. The almost daily visits by lawmakers, celebrities and world leaders are part of the mayor's strategy to shock people with the severity of the devastation -- particularly those in a position to influence the flow of money to the city -- a strategy that appears to be working.

headline.main: A Visit to Ground Zero

Homeland Security.mainheadline: A Visit to Ground Zero

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: A day after the nation's governors asked Congress for an immediate $3 billion to fight terrorism, Tom Ridge, director of homeland security, promised that President Bush's budget proposal next year would include ''substantial down payments'' to the states for security. Mr. Ridge spoke as questions of how much domestic security should cost after Sept. 11 have proliferated on Capitol Hill and as states, facing recession and budget shortfalls, are grappling with how to pay for new responsibilities to help guard borders, bridges, dams and nuclear power plants.

headline.main: Ridge Promises Security Funds For States in Next U.S. Budget
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE DOMESTIC FRONT

Homeland Security.mainheadline: Ridge Promises Security Funds For States in Next U.S. Budget

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: President Bush said today that he had asked Tom Ridge, his chief adviser on homeland security, to testify before Congress on the need for a new cabinet department to coordinate domestic defense, but neither the White House nor Mr. Ridge would say whether he was in line to become secretary of the new department. Mr. Ridge, who resigned as governor of Pennsylvania in October to take the job in the White House, told reporters he would limit his Congressional testimony to advocacy of a new cabinet department and would not testify about his advice to the president.

headline.main: Bush Tells Security Adviser To Testify Before Congress

Homeland Security.mainheadline: Bush Tells Security Adviser To Testify Before Congress

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, rejected an offer today by Tom Ridge, director of the Office of Homeland Security, to give briefings rather than formal testimony to Congress on how the administration is strengthening domestic security. President Bush has said that as his adviser Mr. Ridge is not accountable to Congress and therefore not required to testify about his office or the $38 billion budget request for domestic security next year. But the White House agreed to make Mr. Ridge available in informal meetings and briefings.

headline.main: Senator Insists Ridge Testify Before Congress

Homeland Security.mainheadline: Senator Insists Ridge Testify Before Congress

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: To keep airport security running through a federal takeover on Nov. 19, the government is offering $500 bonuses to entice privately hired screeners to stay on the job until then. The Transportation Security Administration has to hire 57,500 people to screen passengers and check luggage. Blaine Harden (NYT)

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: A sniper's bullet ripped the head from a terrorist, and the rout was on. Within four minutes, a SWAT team had secured the nuclear processing plant, saved eight hostages, dispatched the intruders from Al Qaeda and dismantled a crude atomic device. The mock commando raid on the makeshift steel structure, with dummies used for terrorists and flour-based explosives, was far hokier and much less spectacular than the atomic tests that once scarred this desert stretch. But it seemed to make an impression on Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, whose endorsement could help revitalize this region as a military training ground.

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: Seeking to defuse a growing confrontation with Congress, Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, has softened his refusal to testify before senators about domestic security efforts, offering to take questions from lawmakers informally but in public. The proposal by Mr. Ridge, made in a letter hand-delivered today to Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the chairman of the Appropriations Committee, stopped just short of offering formal testimony, a Congressional official said.

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. extended its terrorist threat warning today until after the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, notifying police agencies nationwide to remain on high alert through March 11. Law enforcement officials said the extension was not based on a specific threat, but on general intelligence of the continuing possibility of terrorist attacks against the United States and because the country remained at war in Afghanistan.

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: An agreement was reached in the United States Senate yesterday to overhaul the way the federal government distributes homeland security money, with an eye toward funneling the money to areas believed to be at greatest risk of a terrorist attack, according to Senator Charles E. Schumer. The proposal for a new formula was packaged as an amendment to a larger bill making its way through the Senate that would adopt many of the security measures recommended by the 9/11 commission. The larger bill is expected to be voted on later this week. The way the federal government now apportions antiterrorism dollars has been criticized as another way for lawmakers to funnel money back to their own districts in pork-barrel fashion. But the new formula would allocate the money in a way that a growing number of lawmakers and other security experts have been demanding: on the basis of actual threat, Mr. Schumer's aides said. Raymond Hernandez (NYT)

In a seminar for commissioners and other top officials of professional and amateur sports organizations on Friday, Ridge and other officials asked for help to ensure safety at and around major sporting events. He repeated a warning that the government fears Al Qaeda might try to stage another large-scale attack in the United States, although he said he had no details on the time, place or method.

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: IF it is true that, as an old Chinese proverb says, crisis equals opportunity, then the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, have yielded a bonanza. Billions of dollars have been poured into homeland security by the cabinet department of the same name, the Pentagon, law enforcement and corporations. With so much money available, more than 500 exhibitors at a security conference here last week were out to reap their share. The most futuristic tools and weapons for tracking and catching potential terrorists were presumably not on display. But if the goods and services hawked at the conference are any measure, the urgent quest for greater security has stirred creative juices among inventors -- and marketers.

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: Steven Plate, a 51-year-old engineer, was named yesterday as director of priority programs for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. He will oversee the World Trade Center redevelopment project for the authority, which owns the site, and the construction of a permanent PATH transportation hub there. In 21 years at the authority, Mr. Plate has managed several projects, including the $1.9 billion AirTrain system at Kennedy International Airport. He was also the mayor of Glen Ridge, N.J., from 2000 to 2003. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

George E. Pataki said yesterday. James Kallstrom, a senior adviser to the governor, said the company would provide experts in counterterrorism, law enforcement, intelligence, military affairs, corporate security, emergency services, transportation, engineering and site development. Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: SCHENECTADY, N.Y. -- President Obama, sending another strong signal that he intends to make the White House more business-friendly, named a high-profile corporate executive on Friday as his chief outside economic adviser, continuing his efforts to show more focus on job creation and reclaim the political center. Here in the birthplace of General Electric, Mr. Obama introduced the new appointee, Jeffrey R. Immelt, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, who will serve as chairman of his outside panel of economic advisers. Mr. Immelt succeeds Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, who is stepping down.

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: On the first day of a sweeping government overhaul, the Department of Homeland Security opened for business today with a skeleton staff that will take control of 22 existing federal agencies over the next several months, redirecting their mission to focus on the defense of American soil from the possibility of new terrorist attacks. After being sworn in today at the White House as the first secretary of homeland security, Tom Ridge, the former governor of Pennsylvania, acknowledged that ''we have a long way to go'' in meeting the department's goal of pre-empting a new wave of terrorist strikes.

Homeland Security.lead_paragraph: Labor leaders and their supporters in New York yesterday criticized the domestic security bill passed by the House of Representatives last week, saying it would end some civil service rules for thousands of workers and reduce their rights. Workers could lose protections related to matters like vacation time, disciplinary proceedings, and how job assignments and workplace conditions are determined, the labor leaders told reporters outside 26 Federal Plaza. But Richard Diamond, a spokesman for Representative Dick Armey, the chairman on the Select Committee on Homeland Security, said such increased powers were necessary to manage the nation's new security needs. Al Baker (NYT)

Afghani Humanitarian Relief.lead_paragraph: United Nations officials said today that they were planning airlifts of food and medicine to Afghans who, because of their remote locations, could no longer be supplied by road. Relief officials said those plans were at the preliminary stage. They emphasized, however, that the bombing campaign and banditry continued to hinder relief efforts. ''If we don't get the food into those remote areas, the people will come to us -- if they are physically able,'' said Oliver Ulich of the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.

The Church Council of Seattle, joined by the Washington Association of Churches and 911 Peace Coalition, will sponsor four days of food drives and a 72-hour fast to protest the bombing's effect on the country. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

Afghani Humanitarian Relief.lead_paragraph: The first pieces of irradiated mail from the anthrax-tainted Hamilton postal center were delivered Saturday, the Postal Service said. Carl Walton, a spokesman for the Postal Service, said that about 1,000 pieces of the decontaminated mail were sent out. The irradiation might have harmed or ruined products including food, medicine, film, contact lenses and electronics. About 800,000 pieces of mail have gone undelivered since the Hamilton post office closed Oct. 18 because of anthrax contamination. The complex handled at least four tainted letters.

Afghani Humanitarian Relief.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that sales last week at stores open at least a year rose within the company's forecast as consumers bought household goods and food. Wal-Mart, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., has forecast a 4 percent to 6 percent gain in September same-store sales. The sales results were difficult to compare with the year-earlier period, when the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks led consumers to stock up on items like batteries, gas cans and bottled water, Wal-Mart said. Fabrics and crafts, intimate apparel, electronics and food had the strongest increases in sales, the retailer said. Wal-Mart's August sales were less than expected, the second consecutive month they were below forecast.

Among their complaints are the length of their detentions and inadequate medical treatment, several detainees said. Kerry Gill, Immigration and Naturalization Service spokesman in Newark, said it was hard to say how many detainees were involved. The warden, Michael T. Abode, said that rather than go hungry, some detainees had bought food at the commissary, which sells candy and instant soup. Immigration and jail officials denied there were serious problems at the jail but said they would look into the complaints. Christopher Drew (NYT)

The United Nations said a warehouse belonging to one of its affiliates was looted and robbed of 40 tons of food last Thursday. It was the second attack in a week on relief efforts operated by the World Food Program, said a United Nations spokesman, Jordan Dey.

But as business travel has started to pick up, and revenue along with it, a number of major hotel brands are once more turning to sprucing up their executive club lounges, making them more residential in feel and providing healthier food and improved technology like free Wi-Fi. ''The time is appropriate,'' said Bjorn Hanson, dean of the Preston Robert Tisch Center for Hospitality, Tourism and Sports Management at New York University. Upgrades were a priority from 2005 to 2007, but since then, many hotels have deferred investments, Mr. Hanson said. ''Frankly, some of these facilities need to be refurbished and redesigned.''

Officials with the group said that they signed a lease yesterday and that the restaurant, south of the Public Theater, would open later this year. Colors, which is to serve American food with global influences, is receiving financial support from a consortium of Italian food cooperatives. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

Afghani Humanitarian Relief.lead_paragraph: FENG SHUI seemed destined to go the way of hippie communes, ridiculed as a bourgeois lifestyle fad. Instead, like yoga and organic food, the ancient Chinese practice of positioning objects, buildings and even whole communities to maximize the flow of energy, or chi, has penetrated the culture beyond the New Age world of crystals and chimes. ''Growing up in Brooklyn, the closest I came to feng shui was the Chinese laundry,'' said Robert A. Levine, president and chief executive of the RAL Companies, a real estate development and management firm. ''I thought of feng shui as a lifestyle for certain people versus something to implement in terms of commercial development projects.''

Afghani Humanitarian Relief.lead_paragraph: Refugees from New Orleans arrived Thursday at the Houston Astrodome, finding a roof, dry cots, air-conditioning and hot food. But after accepting 11, 500 refugees, a Red Cross spokeswoman said, the Astrodome was deemed full and people were being diverted to other shelters in the area Thursday night. Those who were able to be accommodated found some conditions familiar to those who fled the Superdome: raw tensions, long lines and some backed-up toilets, portending trouble ahead as thousands more were expected to come.

Afghani Humanitarian Relief.lead_paragraph: JAMES BROWN, the Godfather of Soul, pressed huge tips into his hand for errands and urged him to read. The comedian Jackie (Moms) Mabley sent him to the store to buy chitlins or pork chops, to be shared with everyone, cooked on a hot plate. Flip Wilson sent him out for food too but locked the door to his dressing room for privacy as he washed and ironed (badly) his polyester suits between acts. These memories belong to Billy Mitchell, the resident historian and tour guide at the Apollo, the fabled Harlem institution that propelled the careers of Ella Fitzgerald, Billie Holiday, the Jackson Five and scores of others. Mr. Mitchell, 58, was a teenager when he began hanging around the Apollo's backdoor, performing odd jobs to help support his family. Since then he has held several bona fide jobs at the theater, including his current one, since 1991.

headline.main: Uptown Shrine's Upbeat Anniversary

Afghani Humanitarian Relief.lead_paragraph: People who get food stamps but whose food was lost through power failures or other events after the attacks on the World Trade Center can get replacement food stamps quickly, state officials said yesterday. But the deadline is midnight tonight to report the losses at (877) 472-8411 (for those who speak English and Spanish) and (718) 557-1015 (for those who speak other languages). As many as 10,000 households in Lower Manhattan receive food stamps. Separately, residents who do not currently qualify for food stamps may be eligible for emergency benefits and can call the same numbers. Nina Bernstein (NYT)

'Every Muslim Is Osama bin Laden' Several hundred Muslims poured out of the Jamia Mosque this afternoon and began denouncing the United States. ''We feel that the United States is the terrorist,'' said Sheik Haroum Odundo, a spiritual leader. ''Every single Muslim is being targeted by the United States. Every Muslim is Osama bin Laden.''

Islamic People.lead_paragraph: For the first time since Sept. 17, President Bush met yesterday with a group of Muslim and Arab-American leaders, some of whom had been pressing to meet him since early this year. Three participants at the meeting, at the Afghan Embassy in Washington, said the president told the group that he was concerned about growing anti-American sentiment in Arab and other Muslim countries and that he wanted to repeat the message that he sent last fall that the United States was at war with terrorists, not with Islam.

Islamic People.lead_paragraph: A philanthropic group founded by the billionaire George Soros will award grants to groups seeking to protect the rights of Arab and other immigrant groups in the wave of anti-Arab feeling since the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The Soros group, the Open Society Institute, will give $2.5 million to 29 nonprofit organizations nationwide. The largest grant, $350,000, will go to the Tides Foundation for its fund for Arab, Muslim, Sikh and South Asian organizations responding to ''erosions of civil liberties and rights.'' Unlike other Soros philanthropies that promote democracy internationally, the Open Society said its mission was to correct what it sees as deficiencies in American democracy. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

The scholar, Mufti Muhammad Iltimas, was arrested near the Afghan border in the village of Bannu, according to Qari Abdullah, a local leader of one of Pakistan's largest Islamic groups, Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam. Mufti Iltimas said he had learned of the arrest from residents of a nearby village.

Islamic People.lead_paragraph: A man who said he hated Muslims drove a truck into a Florida mosque just 30 minutes before evening prayers, the police said. No one was injured on Monday in the Islamic Center of Tallahassee at Florida State University. The driver, Charles Franklin, 41, was arrested later at a campus bar. Investigators said Mr. Franklin told the police that he tried to join the military to kill Muslims but was turned down.

The A.C.L.U. said Ms. Kaukab, 22, had been singled out because of her religious attire for a search that violated her constitutional rights to equal protection and religious freedom. Mr. Bashir, 66, the spiritual leader of the Islamic group Jemaah Islamiyah, which has been labeled a terrorist organization by the United States, has been in prison since 2002, when he was cleared of terror charges but sentenced to 18 months in jail for immigration violations. Islamic People.lead_paragraph: Reports of bias incidents against Muslims increased by about 70 percent in the United States last year, according to a study by the Council on American-Islamic Relations, an advocacy group in Washington. The study showed that Muslims had reported 1,019 incidents of harassment, violence and discriminatory treatment in 2003, up from 602 in 2002. In many cases, the report said, complainants contended that laws were applied to them unfairly or they had been singled out by local and federal law enforcement authorities because of their religion or ethnicity. Among reasons for mistreatment, the report said, was ''a lingering atmosphere'' of fear since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. John Files (NYT)

It did not admit that it broke federal antidiscrimination laws.

He killed at least two: Vasudev Patel, an Indian immigrant who was Hindu, and Waqar Hasan, a Muslim born in Pakistan. A third shooting victim, Rais Bhuiyan, 37, a former Air Force pilot from Bangladesh, survived after Mr. Stroman shot him in the face at close range. Mr. Stroman admitted to the shootings. He is scheduled to be executed on Wednesday.

Islamic People.lead_paragraph: A Yemeni cleric was arrested in Germany on charges of financing terrorism, and United States prosecutors charged that he used a Brooklyn mosque to raise millions of dollars for Osama bin Laden. The cleric, Sheik Muhammad Ali Hassan al-Mouyad, told an F.B.I. informant that he was Mr. bin Laden's spiritual adviser, and authorities said they traced suspicious bank deposits to five people associated with the Al Farooq mosque in Brooklyn. The mosque, which denied any knowledge of the plot, is the same one where Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman -- convicted in the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center -- served as imam in 1990. Eric Lichtblau

Islamic People.lead_paragraph: As Islamic protests grew against the publication of cartoons lampooning the Prophet Muhammad, a small but vocal Muslim immigrant organization responded with a drawing on its Web site of Hitler in bed with Anne Frank. ''Write this one in your diary, Anne,'' Hitler was shown as saying. The intent, said the group, the Arab European League, was ''to use our right to artistic expression,'' just as the Danish newspaper Jyllands-Posten did last September when it published 12 cartoons showing Muhammad, several of them satiric.

Muslims have complained of greater hostility and aggression against them since the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks in the United States. Jews have denounced a rising wave of anti-Semitic incidents, which have intensified in recent months with Israel's crackdown on Palestinian militants and the war in Iraq. Marlise Simons (NYT)

Islamic People.lead_paragraph: Equipment worth hundreds of thousands of dollars was vandalized over the weekend at an Anchorage printing shop owned by a Muslim, and the authorities are calling the incident a hate crime. The shop's owner, Mike Maad, who has lived in Anchorage for 20 years and is of Syrian descent, found computer equipment and printers smashed when he came to his shop on Saturday. Spray-painted on the wall was the message ''We hate Arabs.'' Some Anchorage residents have established a fund to help Mr. Maad. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

The podiatrist, Dr. Robert Goldstein, and his wife, Kristi, are accused of planning to blow up an Islamic education center in St. Petersburg. Dr. Goldstein was described in court documents as seeking to retaliate for the Sept. 11 attacks and the Arab-Israeli conflict.

Islamic People.lead_paragraph: A Paris court, citing an error in the legal paperwork, threw out a case against the Italian journalist Oriana Fallaci, who was accused of inciting racial hatred for the assertion in her book ''The Rage and the Pride'' that Muslims ''multiply like rats.'' Ms. Fallaci has been outspokenly critical of Muslim militancy since the Sept. 11 attacks. The case was brought by groups opposed to racism and human rights abuses; one sought to have the book banned and two others asked that a warning be placed in it. Last month the French novelist Michel Houellebecq was acquitted of similar charges for declaring in an interview that Islam was the ''most stupid religion.'' John Tagliabue (NYT)

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the developer Larry A. Silverstein used $702 million in insurance proceeds from the World Trade Center complex yesterday to pay off a lender and the company that operated the retail mall at the complex. In what he said was an effort to ease the rebuilding process, Mr. Silverstein paid GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation $562 million to satisfy the loan he took out when he leased the trade center in 2001. The Port Authority simultaneously paid Westfield America $140 million for its retail interest in the trade center. The deal allowed Mr. Silverstein to get back most of the $125 million in equity he and his partners put into the winning bid for the trade center leases. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: In the most tangible way yet, the site of the former World Trade Center began its slow metamorphosis into something more than a place of loss: commuters returned aboard the PATH train. Last Sunday, the ceremonial reopening of the rebuilt World Trade Center station was mostly attended by the important and the curious. But by Monday, the station was filled with the suited, workaday crowds of Lower Manhattan. A few cried as they gripped the station's latticework walls and stared at ground zero, but others just charged up the escalators to get to work. Michael Luo

Mr. Bernard worked as an industry specialist for the Internal Revenue Service and was based in Boston. N.Y.U. said the turnabout was a result of strong support from New York's Congressional delegation and Gov. George E. Pataki. N.Y.U. had submitted a list of about $10 million in expenses, which included the cost of rehousing students and removing debris from dormitories near the World Trade Center. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: The 15-story Postal Service building at 90 Church Street, which has been closed since the adjacent World Trade Center collapsed three years ago, is to reopen on Monday, postal officials said yesterday. The building was contaminated with asbestos, mercury, mold and other substances and had to be gutted and have 800 of its windows replaced. The ornate marble lobby also had to be restored. ''We are excited to return this postal facility to the community,'' Postmaster Vinnie Malloy said.

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: A Manhattan woman charged with stealing money from relief agencies after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court and is expected to be sentenced to 52 weekends in prison, in addition to having to pay fines and restitution. The woman, Beatrice Kaufman, 68, originally said she had been forced to evacuate her apartment and had lost earnings because of the destruction of the World Trade Center. But officials said Ms. Kaufman, who ran an employment agency for lawyers, was at her summer house on Long Island during the attack. Susan Saulny (NYT)

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: A 30-by-60-inch electronic sign over the Cortlandt Street subway station, which consistently broadcasts brief advertisements on the edge of the World Trade Center site, was removed yesterday, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said. Clear Channel Outdoor, which operated it, took it down at the request of the M.T.A. chairman, Peter S. Kalikow, above. ''It was felt that it was not a proper setting, so close to ground zero,'' said Tom Kelly, an authority spokesman. Among those who complained about the sign were Assemblyman Scott Stringer of Manhattan and Stan Simon, who lost a brother and nephew in the 9/11 attack. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sign Removed At Ground Zero

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sign Removed At Ground Zero

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: A group of workers has filed a class-action lawsuit against the companies hired to clean up after the World Trade Center attack. The workers claim they were exposed to toxic fumes and debris at ground zero. The lawsuit, which also names the entities that leased and managed the trade center, was filed on Friday in federal court in Manhattan and announced yesterday. The companies have not yet responded. The plaintiffs also intend to sue the City of New York, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the federal Environmental Protection Agency, David E. Worby, the lawyer for the workers, said. He was joined at a news conference by 13 people who he said had physical ailments directly related to their exposure to what he said were 9/11 toxins. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Workers Sue

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: New York State is looking into the sale of the rights to the three-word name to a nonprofit, accusing a former Port Authority official of leading the deal without proper approval.

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Christopher O. Ward, who jump-started development of the stalled World Trade Center site and memorial and oversaw a significant toll increase on the Hudson River crossings, intends to resign as executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, according to two people familiar with his plans. Mr. Ward's departure is planned for the end of October. It will create a formidable challenge for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who must now appoint a new chief for two of the most influential agencies under his purview: the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Jay H. Walder, also plans to leave next month, having announced his resignation in July.

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Just four days after 9/11, James P. Stuckey, then a vice president of Forest City Ratner Companies, met with executives of Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield at Forest City's headquarters in Brooklyn. Empire had been the fourth-largest tenant at the World Trade Center, and the shell-shocked executives were already thinking about new offices. Mr. Stuckey promised them a building in 18 months, even though, he said, ''they didn't have any floor plans, they didn't know who had sat next to who, or even where much of their staff was.''

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: In one of the haunting legacies of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, the remains of 1,123 of the victims, 41 percent of the total, have not been identified, leaving many of their relatives yearning for closure. At the same time, nearly 10 years later, 9,041 pieces of human remains -- mainly bone fragments but also tissue that has been dehydrated for preservation -- are still being sorted through by the city's medical examiner for DNA, though the last time a connection was made was in 2009. Now, a dispute over what to do with those remains is simmering between some of the victims' families and the officials planning the National September 11 Memorial and Museum underneath where the twin towers stood.

headline.main: An Unsettled Legacy for 9/11 Remains

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: An Unsettled Legacy for 9/11 Remains

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Condé Nast Publications, whose stable of magazines chronicles the American zeitgeist as meticulously as any anthropologist, has reached an agreement to lease one million square feet at 1 World Trade Center, giving ground zero a much-needed corporate anchor with a proven ability to attract other businesses. The company signaled its interest in moving to 1 World Trade Center several months ago. But that was just the beginning of a marathon courtship befitting one of the country's most influential buildings and one of its trend-setting media empires, which went far beyond the typical landlord-tenant transaction.

headline.main: A Stylish Anchor for 1 World Trade Center

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: A Stylish Anchor for 1 World Trade Center

headline.print_headline: Two New Deaths, Same Old Questions

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: The boundaries of the World Trade Center redevelopment project were expanded yesterday by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to include the 7 World Trade Center parcel immediately to the north, across Vesey Street. This could eventually permit the reopening of Greenwich Street, between Vesey and Barclay Streets, as a two-lane southbound roadway. It is now a dead end, used for drop-offs at 7 World Trade Center. South of Vesey Street, Greenwich Street is to be recreated through the main trade center site as a four-lane southbound roadway. It was closed in the 1960s to make way for the trade center superblock. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: World Trade Center Site Expands

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: World Trade Center Site Expands

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: As an architecture student at Cooper Union three decades ago, Daniel Libeskind watched the World Trade Center being built. ''It was such an inspiring and controversial and wonderful moment,'' Mr. Libeskind said last week -- second only, perhaps, to the moment his design was chosen as the plan to rebuild the trade center. Centered on a recessed memorial to the victims of the 9/11 attack, the plan includes a spiral of buildings rising to a tower standing 1,776 feet -- ''a date or a number,'' he said, ''that will never be surpassed in world history.'' Edward Wyatt

headline.main: DESIGN FOR GROUND ZERO

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: DESIGN FOR GROUND ZERO

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Silverstein Properties announced yesterday that ABN Amro, an international bank based in the Netherlands, had signed a 15-year lease for three and a half floors at Silverstein's 7 World Trade Center tower, opposite ground zero. The bank will move about 500 employees there from Midtown in late 2007 or early 2008. It is the second-largest tenant so far, after Moody's Investors Service, in the 52-story building. The terms were not disclosed. DAVID W. DUNLAP

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dutch Bank At 7 World Trade

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dutch Bank At 7 World Trade

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Searchers recovered nine bone fragments that they believe to be human from the World Trade Center haul road along West Street yesterday. Four were found at the site and five others as material was being inspected at a sifting center in Brooklyn, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the chief medical examiner. The bones ranged in size from one to four inches. Since September 2005, 990 human remains have been found around ground zero. DAVID W. DUNLAP

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Remains At Ground Zero

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Remains At Ground Zero

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Several dozen former workers at Windows on the World, the restaurant destroyed in the attack on the World Trade Center in 2001, will open a cooperative restaurant called Colors at 417 Lafayette Street, according to the Restaurant Opportunities Center of New York, a group working with the employees. Officials with the group said that they signed a lease yesterday and that the restaurant, south of the Public Theater, would open later this year. Colors, which is to serve American food with global influences, is receiving financial support from a consortium of Italian food cooperatives. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Workers Plan To Open Restaurant

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Workers Plan To Open Restaurant

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed yesterday to contribute $3 million to the Tribute Center, the temporary 9/11 memorial that is scheduled to open in the spring at 120 Liberty Street, near the World Trade Center site. The center's Introductory/Orientation Gallery will be named for the Port Authority, and Port Authority employees will lead tours of the site from there. Supporting the center ''is in line with our mission of revitalizing Lower Manhattan and redeveloping the World Trade Center site,'' said James Connors, a Port Authority executive. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Port Authority Gives To 9/11 Memorial

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Port Authority Gives To 9/11 Memorial

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: The Cortlandt Street station on the R and W lines will close for six months, starting on Aug. 20, to allow construction of a 150-foot underpass as part of the $750 million Fulton Street Transit Center. Trains in both directions will bypass the station until February. The underpass will link the new transit center with PATH trains and with a future development at the World Trade Center. New York City Transit, which announced the closing, advised riders to use four nearby stations: Rector Street and City Hall on the R and W lines, World Trade Center on the E, and the Fulton Street/Broadway-Nassau complex on the A, C, J, M, Z and the 2, 3, 4 and 5 lines. Sewell Chan (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway Station To Close

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway Station To Close

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: The state agency that owns the former Deutsche Bank building hopes to resume work dismantling it next month, and the delays after a deadly fire should not affect the rebuilding schedule at the World Trade Center site, an agency official said yesterday. Avi Schick, the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, would not estimate the completion date for dismantling the tower, which now stands at 26 stories. Before the fire, the agency had said that the building, heavily damaged by the collapse of the trade center on Sept. 11, would be removed by the end of the year. Work to dismantle the tower floor by floor -- and clean several floors of toxic debris left by the trade center's collapse -- stopped after the Aug. 18 blaze, which killed two firefighters.

headline.main: Manhattan: Bank Dismantling To Resume

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Manhattan: Bank Dismantling To Resume

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Rejecting a request to immediately halt work at the World Trade Center site, a State Supreme Court justice said yesterday that site preparation for the World Trade Center Memorial could continue until late April. ''It seems to me that there's no building going on here, so we certainly don't need a temporary restraining order,'' Justice Shirley Werner Kornreich said, responding to a request by the families of trade center victims to halt construction of a $330 million memorial and a $160 million museum because, they argued, it would damage historic remnants in violation of state statutes. Lower Manhattan Development Corporation lawyers promised that only inspection, cleaning and protection of the remnants would proceed until an April 27 hearing. GLENN COLLINS (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Allows Work At Ground Zero

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Allows Work At Ground Zero

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Officials have identified the remains of Harry Blanding Jr., a victim of the World Trade Center attack, through DNA testing, the medical examiner's office announced yesterday. Mr. Blanding, 38, of Blakeslee, Pa., was a claims analyst. Officials have identified 1,598 of the 2,749 people who died in the attack, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Victim's Remains Identified

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Victim's Remains Identified

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki reiterated his support yesterday for government financing of the underground infrastructure at ground zero, leaving the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation responsible only for meeting the $500 million budget now assigned to the memorial and museum. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to pay $100 million of the memorial's share of infrastructure costs. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Government Financing For Ground Zero

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Government Financing For Ground Zero

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Gretchen Dykstra, the president and chief executive of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, said after a board meeting yesterday that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the trade center land, should ''be delivering to us a buildable site'' for the memorial and memorial museum, meaning the authority alone should pay the cost of the underground infrastructure. At the meeting, Christine A. Ferer, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's liaison to the families of 9/11 victims and a Port Authority commissioner, joined the board. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Memorial Chief Seeks Port Authority Financing

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Memorial Chief Seeks Port Authority Financing

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Julie Menin, a director of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation and the chairwoman of Community Board 1 in Lower Manhattan, objected publicly yesterday to an announcement that the foundation would not solicit any more money until it had a clearer idea of the cost and design of the memorial and museum. Writing to Thomas S. Johnson, the chairman of the foundation's executive committee, Ms. Menin said, ''By suspending fund-raising (and more pointedly by suspending it without a board vote), more doubt and turmoil has been created.'' She called for a vote at the next board meeting. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dissent In Memorial Foundation

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dissent In Memorial Foundation

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: The producers of the film ''World Trade Center'' are donating $1.3 million, or 5 percent of its opening-weekend proceeds, to the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, the foundation said yesterday. Another $1.3 million will be divided among three other 9/11-related charities. The producers of the Paramount Pictures film, about police officers trapped in the trade center rubble, had promised a total donation of 10 percent of the box office proceeds from its opening weekend to the foundation and the other charities.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Donation To 9/11 Memorial

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Donation To 9/11 Memorial

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Science Applications International Corporation of San Diego has been chosen to develop a security plan for the World Trade Center redevelopment project, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday. James Kallstrom, a senior adviser to the governor, said the company would provide experts in counterterrorism, law enforcement, intelligence, military affairs, corporate security, emergency services, transportation, engineering and site development. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Security Plan

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Security Plan

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: An application by the developer Larry A. Silverstein for preliminary approval of $3.35 billion in Liberty Bond tax-exempt financing for office towers at the World Trade Center site has been withdrawn from consideration. Andrew M. Alper, the chairman of the city's Industrial Development Agency, which was scheduled to vote on the request today, cited ''unresolved issues'' but said he was optimistic that the application could come to a vote soon. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Vote Is Put Off On Bonds For Towers

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Vote Is Put Off On Bonds For Towers

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: ''Transparency'' is the architectural watchword of the era, almost guaranteed to appear in any reference to contemporary glass-clad towers. But real buildings usually look a lot different than the clear plastic models and crystalline renderings shown at news conferences and ribbon cuttings.

headline.main: The See-Through Skyscraper

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: The See-Through Skyscraper

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: A piece of landing gear, apparently from one of the jets that crashed into the twin towers on Sept. 11, 2001, was discovered wedged between two buildings on Wednesday.

headline.main: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero
headline.print_headline: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Larry Davis, owner of DCM Erectors Inc., is expected to be charged with evading requirements on hiring subcontractors, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline.main: World Trade Center Contractor Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry Into Misuse of Funds
headline.print_headline: Trade Center Contractor Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry Into Misuse of Funds

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: World Trade Center Contractor Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry Into Misuse of Funds

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: The story of her improbable rescue by New York City firefighters was among the most enduring to emanate from the horror of Sept. 11, 2001. It was told and retold: how a weary woman, Josephine Harris, was coaxed and carried to safety by six men from Ladder Company 6 in Chinatown who had rushed to the World Trade Center that morning. It was a feat of timing, engineering and plain luck that when the rush of wind and noise came and the north tower fell away, the firefighters and Ms. Harris were not crushed in a sea of concrete, dust and steel as they were spread along the stairwell between the fourth and first floors. Rather, the building fell around them.

headline.main: Mourning A Woman Who Shared A 9/11 Escape

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Mourning A Woman Who Shared A 9/11 Escape

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: A Times article about the 47 colossal arches forming the galleria of the World Trade Center Transportation Hub elicited requests from readers for more pictures of the arches. So, here they are. ''Since summer, daylight has bathed the galleria of the new World Trade Center, pouring through the five-and-a-half-foot intervals between its rounded steel arches and creating a modernist version of the ancient, roofless hypostyle halls of Egypt,'' David W. Dunlap wrote. The arches will eventually be covered by a steel roof. nytimes.com/nyregion

headline.main: SCULPTURAL STEEL IN TRADE CENTER ARCHES

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: SCULPTURAL STEEL IN TRADE CENTER ARCHES

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed a bill that would have prohibited admission or other fees at the World Trade Center memorial, museum or visitor center, his office said yesterday. Mr. Pataki said the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation could not rule out charging the public, given what he estimated would be the $50 million annual cost of operating a memorial and museum at ground zero. State Senator Martin J. Golden, the Brooklyn Republican who introduced the bill, had said ''there should be no barriers,'' including fees, that would prevent people from paying their respects. DANNY HAKIM (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Governor Vetoes Bill Blocking 9/11 Memorial Fee

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Governor Vetoes Bill Blocking 9/11 Memorial Fee

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: The administration of Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. is considering selling the state-owned Baltimore-Washington International Airport and the World Trade Center, a landmark 32-story building on Baltimore's Inner Harbor. Henry Fawell, a spokesman for Mr. Ehrlich, a Republican, said selling the properties could ease the state's budget difficulties. He had no estimate on asking prices for the sites. Gary Gately (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: State Considers Real Estate Sales

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: State Considers Real Estate Sales

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: A section of steel girder from the World Trade Center given to the British will be buried rather than displayed in a planned memorial garden in London, to prevent distress to victims' relatives, officials said yesterday. The Department of Culture, Media and Sport is overseeing the memorial's construction. The blackened, twisted piece of metal from the north tower was given to Britain by the mayor's office in New York for a memorial in Grosvenor Square, opposite the United States Embassy. Sixty-seven Britons were killed in the terrorist attack.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Sept. 11 Memorial In London

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Sept. 11 Memorial In London

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Relatives of those killed in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center will have an extra six months to file wrongful-death suits under a bill signed into law yesterday by Gov. George E. Pataki. The measure extends the two-year statute of limitations for filing suits, previously set to expire Sept. 11, 2003, to March 11, 2004. The bill was approved by the Legislature before it completed its regular session last month. Governor Pataki said it is only fair to give the families of the nearly 3,000 people who died in the terrorist attacks on the trade center more time to consider their legal rights.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Sept. 11 Legal Deadline Extended

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Sept. 11 Legal Deadline Extended

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Kenneth R. Holden, the New York City administrator who supervised the cleanup and removal of 1.7 million tons of steel and debris from the World Trade Center site, is resigning to take a private-sector job. He will become corporate vice president for real estate and facilities of Continuum Health Partners, which operates seven major hospitals, including Beth Israel Medical Center and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. His successor has not been named. Eric Lipton (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground-Zero Official Takes New Job

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground-Zero Official Takes New Job

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: An office building severely damaged in the attack on the World Trade Center has been sold, and its buyer is considering converting it into condominiums. The buyer, Brack Capital Real Estate Ltd., an international real estate company, paid $12.25 million to Aegon USA Realty Advisors for the 23-story office building at 90 West Street. But Brack will have to spend more than $50 million to repair the fire-scarred building, built in 1907, and restore architectural features. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Building Near Ground Zero Is Sold

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Building Near Ground Zero Is Sold

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: A Newark man who the authorities say telephoned a radio station to falsely claim he was trapped beneath the rubble at the World Trade Center has been arrested. The man, Mikal Wazeerud-Den, 23, called WNEW around 9 p.m. on Tuesday saying that he was buried alive and that his cellular phone was running low on power, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Man Charged In Trade Center Call

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Man Charged In Trade Center Call

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has reopened the exhibit of design concepts for the World Trade Center site. The exhibit, at the World Financial Center Winter Garden, has been reorganized to display the two designs under consideration: Memory Foundations by Studio Daniel Libeskind and the World Cultural Center by the Think team (Shigeru Ban, Frederic Schwartz, Ken Smith and Rafael Viñoly). The exhibit will continue until the end of this month, when a winner will be chosen and displayed through April. The exhibit is open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. daily.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Design Finalists On Display

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Design Finalists On Display

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank sued New York State yesterday, contending that the state was negligent in failing to protect the bank's headquarters building, at 130 Liberty Street, after the collapse of the World Trade Center towers. The lawsuit follows the dismissal last month of a similar complaint against New York City. Both actions were filed in United States District Court in Manhattan. A spokeswoman for the bank said the lawsuit was required by the bank's insurance policies on the building, which was severely damaged by debris from the World Trade Center. The bank wants to tear down the building and is fighting two of its insurers, which say the building can be repaired and reoccupied. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Building Owner Sues

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Building Owner Sues

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: A fresh Macoun apple in Midtown? Might as well try to buy Ferragamos on a farm. But a Greenmarket that's brightening Rockefeller Plaza on Fridays and Saturdays has apples, including crisp, tart Macouns ($1 to $1.25 a pound) that are great for snacking.

headline.main: Apples as Crisp as the Autumn Air at Rockefeller Center

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: Apples as Crisp as the Autumn Air at Rockefeller Center

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: ''You can look at the trees, and see many things that should have been done better or quicker. But if you look at the forest, it's a large and unprecedented sum of money that's basically being used in the way that it was needed and intended.'' SENATOR CHARLES E. SCHUMER, Democrat of New York, on federal disaster relief after the destruction of the World Trade Center. [B4]

headline.main: QUOTATION OF THE DAY

World Trade Center Attacks.mainheadline: QUOTATION OF THE DAY

World Trade Center Attacks.lead_paragraph: In his new role as chairman of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg backed away yesterday from his insistence that the names of the dead be displayed in random order, a position that had pitted him against many relatives of the victims and representatives of those who died in the 9/11 rescue effort. ''Where we'll come out on the names or a couple of other issues, we'll just have to see,'' Mr. Bloomberg told reporters at a news conference. Other officials have suggested displaying the victims' names around the footprint of the tower in which they died and grouping them by affiliation, like the company or emergency service unit where they worked. DIANE CARDWELL (NYT)
